HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Long-Term Treasury Prices Soar

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Prices of long-term Treasury bonds soared yesterday on expectations that Washington would report a sharp rise in unemployment this morning. If so, it would benefit investors in fixed-income securities because it would lessen the demand for loans, ease inflation pressures and possibly prompt the Federal Reserve to reduce interest rates.
Any decline in interest rates would enhance the value of bonds outstanding and other fixed-income securities. As it was, the Treasury's benchmark long bonds, the 7 7/8 percent issue due February 2021, were offered late in the session at 96 8/32, up 18/32 on the day. This caused the issue's yield to drop to 8.21 percent, from 8.27 percent the day before. 
 Gains were more modest among shorter Treasury coupon issues. The 6.75 percent notes of 1993, for example, rose 2/32, to 99 12/32, for a yield of 7.09 percent; the 7.5's of 1996 gained 7/32, at 99 5/32, to yield 7.70 percent; the long notes, the 7.75's of 2001, climbed 12/32, to 98, while the yield fell to 8.04 percent, from 8.10 percent the day before.
 
Covering Short Positions
 Some dealers said demand for the long bond came after the Chicago bond futures market closed. Although the Chicago futures represent 20-year Treasury bonds, and not the 30-year issue traded in the cash market, it is customary for those caught in unprofitable positions in Chicago to cover them in the cash market. In yesterday's case, some of those who had sold bond futures short moved to cover their positions by buying long bonds in the cash market.
The spot March Chicago bond futures closed at 96, up 17/32 on the day.
Dealers said the rebound in Treasury bond prices from Wednesday's sharp decline began during overnight trading in Tokyo and gathered force later in the New York cash and Chicago bond futures markets.
"The spark that ignited the bond market was a Government report that said initial claims for unemployment insurance in the week ended Feb. 23 were the highest in at least seven years," said Philip Braverman, senior vice president and chief economist at the DKB Securities Corporation, the domestic arm of the giant Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank of Tokyo.
Although the initial unemployment claims do not always telegraph what the jobs data for February will be, they impressed the bond buyers for two reasons, Mr. Braverman said. For one, the latest data on claims were for a holiday-shortened week, the first day of which was the Washington's Birthday holiday. The second factor was the size of the claims, 508,000, up 20,000 from the previous week.
 
More Fed Action
 Mr. Braverman said that "if this morning's report on unemployment in February is as dismal as the jump in initial insurance claims would indicate, it should jolt the Fed into taking further action to cut the cost of credit."
For its part, the Fed once again moved to add reserves to the banking system as the Federal funds rate climbed to nearly 6.5 percent, or a quarter-point above the Fed's perceived target level. The funds rate is what banks charge each other for overnight temporary loans and is thus considered the basic cost of credit.
Despite the infusion of reserves by the central bank system, the funds traded at 6.5 percent late in the day. But dealers said the funds rate had no impact on Treasury bills, which are normally most sensitive to any change in the funds rate.
The discount rate on 90-day bills dipped a basis point, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 6.08 percent; six-month bills slipped a basis point, to 6.05 percent.
But the average discount rate soared at the Treasury's monthly auction of one-year bills. The average rate climbed to 6.06 percent, from 5.85 percent a month ago. On a bond yield equivalent basis, the 6.06 percent rate translates into 6.46 percent a year.
Following are the details of the Treasury auction of one-year bills:

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Silver Recovery Continues; Grain and Soybeans Decline

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Silver rallied to a spot delivery price of just under $4 an ounce yesterday on New York's Commodity Exchange, extending a recovery driven by perceptions that the recession is easing.
On other commodity markets, pork futures surged; cattle were mixed; energy futures fell, and grain and soybeans were lower. 
 Silver futures settled 10.5 cents to 12 cents higher in New York, with the contract for delivery in March at $3.973 an ounce. The March contract traded as high as $3.99 during the session, the highest spot silver price since Jan. 22.
Silver has risen by nearly 14 percent since Feb. 22, when it dropped briefly below $3.50 an ounce for the first time in 17 years.
The rally mainly reflects the belief that the end of the gulf war will hasten a turnaround in the economy and lead to increased industrial demand for silver, analysts said.
 
Pork Bellies Higher
 Some hog and pork belly futures rose by their permitted daily limits on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange in anticipation of a seasonal upswing in the cash market tied to the beginning of spring planting in the Middle West. Hog marketings typically decline in late March as farmers concentrate on preparing their fields.
Live hog futures settled 0.20 cent to the limit of 1.50 cents higher, with April at 54.10 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1.47 cents to the limit of 2 cents higher, with March at 67.20 cents a pound; live cattle were 0.20 cent lower to 0.20 cent higher, with April at 81.40 cents a pound, and feeder cattle were 0.07 cent lower to 0.15 cent higher, with March at 90.30 cents a pound.
Oil and gasoline futures weakened on the New York Mercantile Exchange amid profit taking and nervousness ahead of Monday's meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries in Geneva.
Light sweet crude oil finished 21 cents to 39 cents lower, with April at $19.42 a barrel; heating oil was 0.14 cent to 0.53 cent lower, with April at 55.55 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 0.41 cent to 0.95 cent lower, with April at 70.35 cents a gallon; natural gas was 0.2 cent lower to 1.3 cents higher, with April at $1.363 for 1,000 cubic feet.
Grain and soybean futures slipped on the Chicago Board of Trade amid prospects for improved growing conditions in some regions, including the United States winter wheat belt.
Wheat settled 1/2 cent to 2 cents lower, with March at $2.72 3/4 a bushel; corn was 1/2 cent lower to 1/4 cent higher, with March at $2.46 1/2 a bushel; oats were 1/4 cent to 3/4 cent lower, with March at $1.19 1/2 a bushel, and soybeans were 2 1/4 cents lower to 2 cents higher, with March at $5.92 a bushel.

HEADLINE: Consumer Debt Plunged 4% in January

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 7

 BODY:
Consumer credit fell at a 4 percent annual rate in January, the Government reported today. It was the steepest plunge in four years as recession and war curbed personal spending.
The Federal Reserve said consumer installment debt dropped a seasonally adjusted $2.44 billion, the biggest percentage decline since it fell 5 percent in February 1987. 
 It followed a revised six-tenths of 1 percent slip in December for the first back-to-back decline since a three-month string of losses that began in December 1986.
The $342 million drop in December was the first decline since a two-tenths of 1 percent dip in February 1989. December debt was reported earlier to have decreased at a 2.3 percent rate, to $1.45 billion.
 
Finances Consumer Spending
 Consumer credit includes all consumer loans except mortgages and home-equity debt. It is tracked closely since it helps finance much of the spending by consumers, which represents two-thirds of the nation's economic activity.
In recent months, the Persian Gulf war has eroded consumer confidence and the recession has reduced jobs and income. As a result, consumer spending fell six-tenths of 1 percent in January, its biggest drop since a 1.3 percent decline in January 1987, the Commerce Department reported. Retail sales were down nine-tenths of 1 percent, including the second consecutive 4.4 percent monthly drop in automobile sales.
Major retailers reported yesterday that buyers continued to avoid their stores in February, making that typically slow month even slower.
But although the recession persists, some economists have reported signs of improvement in some areas of the economy since consumer confidence plunged to a 10-year low in January as the Persian Gulf war broke out.
Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, told Congress on Wednesday that after the end of the war, traffic picked up in real estate offices and auto showrooms, raising "the possibility that stronger consumer demand may be emerging."
But in January, consumers had backed off. Auto loans, which had fallen for six months until picking up at a three-tenths of 1 percent rate in November and 3.6 percent in December, dropped again -- down a sharp 8.2 percent, or a seasonally adjusted $1.95 billion.
Bank and credit union loans not secured by real estate plummeted 14.7 percent, or $2.63 billion, following a 5.8 percent gain a month earlier.
Consumers reached again for their credit cards, however, increasing revolving credit by a 7 percent rate, or $1.27 billion. Revolving credit had fallen by 8.3 percent in December.
Borrowing for mobile homes erased a 37.4 percent rate of decline in December by jumping 47.8 percent in January, or $868 million.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Debt Deal Favors Water St. Fund

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
IN the high-stakes, behind-the-scenes game that is the new world of corporate restructuring, bondholders who start out with similar holdings can wind up in very different positions.
That is what happened this week when the Journal Company, the largest of the three debt-laden newspaper companies once controlled by Ralph Ingersoll, announced a partial debt restructuring. 
 Its holdings include nine daily newspapers, among them The Trentonian in Trenton; The Daily Local News in West Chester, Pa.; The Herald News in Fall River, Mass., and The Record in Troy, N.Y. It also operates weeklies, including the Suburban Journals around St. Louis, which claim to be the largest group of weekly papers in the country. An attempt to start a St. Louis daily, The Sun, ended in failure last year.
The evident winner in the new deal is the Water Street Corporate Recovery Fund, a fund organized by Goldman, Sachs & Company. The loser for now appears to be the First Executive Corporation, the insurance company that owns large quantities of the Journal Company's 'junk bonds."
The overhaul of its debt did not get the Journal Company out of hot water, but it did avert an immediate crisis. Moreover, it shed light on the operating style of the $784 million Water Street fund, which is run by Mikael Salovaara, a hard-charging Goldman partner who told institutions that they could prosper by buying controlling positions in distressed securities and then making deals with the companies that issued them. This is the first such deal that has been disclosed in which Water Street played a leading role.
"This deal is excellent for them and it is excellent for the company," said John L. Vogelstein, the vice chairman of E. M. Warburg, Pincus & Company, which controls the Journal Company, referring to Goldman. "It is a major first step in restructuring the company's finances."
The deal that Mr. Salovaara cut sacrifices current income for the fund by accepting lower interest rates, but it puts Water Street ahead of all other bondholders in two important ways. Water Street's new bonds mature in 1996, instead of 1999 and 2000 for the other bondholders, and they are secured and rank above the other bonds. If the Journal Company does end up going broke, Water Street is likely to get a full payout, while other bondholders could suffer losses.
Last year, Mr. Ingersoll and Warburg, Pincus, which had made joint investments, agreed to split his debt-laden newspaper empire, with the investment firm taking the American operations and Mr. Ingersoll getting the British ones. The smallest of the three related American operations, Community Newspapers, filed for bankruptcy last month after bondholders balked at a bond exchange offer. The third company in the complex, NH Acquisition, publishes The Register in New Haven. It is not in financial difficulty, and in fact is said by people with access to its financial reports to have posted record operating profits of $23 million last year.
But the Journal Company did not have the money to make a $7 million interest payment that was due on March 1, although Warburg, Pincus said it would have come up with the money before the grace period expired. Instead, the deal with Water Street enabled it to have to pay only about $3 million to other bondholders. That payment is to be made today.
The Journal Company had announced that it was in negotiations with two large bondholders. The second was not identified, but H. F. Pearson & Company, which monitors filings by bondholders, reported that First Executive held a large stake. First Executive officials did not return telephone calls, but some people familiar with the negotiations said it had held out for a better deal, involving stock in the Journal Company.
One reason that Water Street might have been more willing to accept the deal is that it bought its bonds late last year and early this year, after they had fallen sharply in price. If it is able to assure the eventual recovery of full face value, even with a reduced interest rate it will have an excellent investment. First Executive probably paid much more for its stake.
Other bondholders, including some mutual funds, were not offered a similar deal. Neither Mr. Vogelstein of Warburg, Pincus nor Robert M. Jelinic, the Journal Company's president, would comment on whether a future exchange offer would be made to them. But it appears that Journal needs more help, and a future restructuring is likely.
Late last year, the Journal Company told bondholders that it did not think its operating cash flow for this year would be enough to cover its expenses. Unless more is done soon, it is expected that Warburg, Pincus will have to come up with cash to make a $9 million interest payment due to bondholders on May 1.
Mr. Jelinic attributed the Journal Company's problems to the poor economy, the heavy debt load and the losses from The St. Louis Sun, which he said were continuing because the company was stuck with a lease on expensive office space. For the first nine months of last year, the company reported an operating loss of $16.9 million, on revenues of $131.1 million. That included $12.9 million in costs involved in shutting The Sun.

HEADLINE: Control Board Says Dinkins Plan 'Actually Disguises' Budget Gap

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
The State Financial Control Board issued new warnings yesterday about New York City's handling of its long-term fiscal problems as Mayor David N. Dinkins struggled to rally support in an unusually pointed appeal to black New Yorkers.
The control board, set up to monitor the city's finances during the fiscal crisis of the mid-1970's, said Mr. Dinkins would undoubtedly balance the budget for the coming fiscal year. But it said the Dinkins administration's plan for doing so "does not clearly portray the city's problems" and, despite large tax increases and service cuts, would certainly produce billion-dollar budget gaps in future years. 
 "In fact," the report said, the Mayor's preliminary $29 billion spending plan "actually disguises the persistence of imbalance," in part because of its reliance on a number of money-saving moves taken in this and recent years -- from bond refinancings to wage deferrals -- that will cost more in the future.
 
Special Troubles
 The report came a day after municipal union leaders harshly attacked the Mayor over suggestions that they agree to defer some wages and over disarray among his top staff members. It was one more sign of the special troubles Mr. Dinkins faces in striking a balance between his critics in the financial community and skeptics among his supporters in liberal and labor circles.
"Let me tell you something, there are a lot of folks who are not pleased that I am Mayor," an apparently frustrated Mr. Dinkins told listeners in an appearance on the black-oriented radio station WLIB-AM yesterday morning. Listeners questioned his handling of everything from labor relations to the black-led boycott of a Korean-American grocery in Brooklyn.
"So," the Mayor said, "I don't expect you all to agree with me because you're African-American and I'm African-American. That's nonsense. I can be wrong and you can be wrong. But let me tell you something: There are a lot of folks who don't want me to be right no how under any circumstances."
"And I think you need to think it through and decide there will be quarrels you will have with me from time to time, just like you have quarrels within your own family."
 
Concerns Shared
 Later, at a news conference at City Hall, Mr. Dinkins said he shared the Financial Control Board's concerns about assuring that the city's budget stayed balanced over the long term, as required by law, and that he was committed to taking whatever actions were necessary to make sure it would.
Senior mayoral aides found some vindication in the control board's prediction that the budget for the fiscal year that starts July 1 would be balanced despite a projected total gap of more than $2 billion. If the city ran a deficit of $100 million or more, the board, headed by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, could reassert binding powers over the city's fiscal affairs.
"Clearly, they're going to have to do some other actions, but I'm not worried about '91 and '92," said the board's executive director, Allen J. Proctor, who prepared the report. He said the city could probably keep its budget balanced for the coming year solely by letting thousands of positions fall vacant through attrition.
But he said this would have more damaging effects on services than a selective mix of layoffs and attrition since jobs did not always fall vacant in the places the city wanted to cut. Mr. Dinkins said later, "We can't do it all by attrition," though the precise mix is not yet clear.
 
Questions Raised
 The control board's report raised questions about the administration's plans for getting beyond the next 16 months. "In a time when fiscal stress is so great, we are particularly concerned that this modification lacks a clear and consistent articulation of mayoral tax and spending policies," it said.
That is so, the report said, because the administration is seeking real-estate tax increases of $770 million to meet one of its planned revenue targets, instead of the $300 million explicitly outlined in the preliminary budget proposed Jan. 16.
The report said the city's budget would be adequate only if it restructured the types and levels of services the city provided. While the city has proposed spending cuts that would produce growth slower than the inflation rate in most broad areas, the report said, spending in other areas continues to rise at a rate bound to produce future deficits, even assuming the city's most optimistic assumptions about the economy and state aid are borne out.
Those three areas are spending for debt service on the city's bonds for long-term project, for social services and for fringe benefits for city workers.
 
Administrative Costs
 The city has already cut back its capital plan to save money on debt service, and Mr. Dinkins said yesterday that further reductions would be needed and that he would look for more ways to cut administrative costs for social services. He also said the city expected to identify up to $750 million in unspecified additional measures to counter the effects of proposed state budget cuts.
Mr. Proctor of the control board said he was not accusing the administration of "malfeasance" in understating the long-term depth of the city's problem. "It's just the nature of the problem is such that how you cut it has become as important or more important than if you can cut it," he said.
In the last two fiscal years, Mr. Proctor said, the city has taken more than $1 billion in actions that either accelerated revenues or pushed expenses off to the future, "one shots" that made its long-term problems persist.
 
'How Much for How Long'
 Mr. Dinkins acknowledged that should the city defer payments of some wages for more workers to balance the budget now, it would create costs in the future. "Deferrals per se are not bad," he said. "It depends on how much for how long." And he said the city would continue to explore that option despite resistance from unions and worries by fiscal monitors.
Earlier, on the radio broadcast, after one questioner in the studio at the Apollo Theater in Harlem asked him what he had done for blacks after doing "something for the Jews" by going to Israel, Mr. Dinkins pointed to his efforts to increase the number of city contracts awarded to minority companies and to give city bond underwriting business to minority firms.
"First of all, I do feel that I'm Mayor of all the people," he said. "And the things I say here I say in the synagogue, or in St. Patrick's Cathedral. I'm the same person everywhere."

HEADLINE: House Approves $200 Million To Speed Benefits to Jobless

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 7

 BODY:
The House of Representatives today approved a $200 million grant to the states to help them speed the processing of unemployment benefit applications.
The funds, intended to reduce growing lines at state unemployment offices and delays in the mailing of benefit checks, are twice as much as the Bush Administration had requested for the purpose. They are part of a $4.1 billion supplemental budget appropriation that was approved by the House today on a vote of 365 to 43. 
 The Senate is expected to agree with the House and vote $200 million in administrative funds for the nation's unemployment system before Congress adjourns for its Easter recess on March 25.
While benefits paid to the unemployed come from state funds, the administrative costs of the unemployment system, including staff salaries, are a Federal responsibility. The Federal Government initially allotted $1.98 billion to cover that responsibility in the budget for the current fiscal year.
But with the unemployment rate climbing in recent months, the amount proved insufficient. State unemployment offices have been overwhelmed by a lack of adequate staff, and as a result applicants at some offices have waited four or five hours before being interviewed and up to six weeks before receiving their first benefit checks. The money voted by the House today would ease their problem by paying for additional staff members and other administrative improvements.
The House action came on a day when the Labor Department reported that 508,000 new applications for unemployment benefits were filed in the week ended Feb. 23, the largest number of new claims in eight years. And the total number of Americans receiving such benefits in that week also hit an eight-year high, at 3.254 million, the department said.
Because of the budget law enacted last year, any new Federal spending must be offset by an equal amount in reduction of other spending or in increased taxes, unless the President declares that the new spending is necessary to meet a national emergency. So far, President Bush has declined to declare an emergency, but Congress has not yet identified where the money for the new spending will come from.

HEADLINE: Poll Finds Postwar Glow Dimmed by the Economy

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER

 BODY:
The war in the Persian Gulf has given a striking boost to the nation's confidence and morale, but Americans are now turning their attention to the economy and other domestic concerns about which they are far less ebullient, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.
The poll found that President Bush was still on an extraordinary high with the American public, with an overall approval rating of 88 percent. It showed Americans setting a post-Vietnam record for confidence in the military and voicing a new conviction that their country was not a declining world power. 
 Even as they began to fret about the economy, more than half seemed willing to concede that Mr. Bush had other things on his mind in recent months.
But there are signs of vulnerability, too, or at least new challenges for the President, as the troops begin returning home from the gulf and domestic issues move up on the public's agenda.
 
Economy Is No. 1 Concern
 The economy is now mentioned more than anything as the No. 1 problem facing the country: 36 percent cited it this week, compared with 19 percent who gave that answer in October, when the economy was tied, roughly speaking, with the deficit and the Middle East as the top problems.
And Mr. Bush's grades on the economy are in stark contrast to his grades on foreign policy, according to the nationwide telephone poll of 1,252 adults. Forty-two percent approve of the way he is handling the economy, while 83 percent approve of his conduct of foreign policy.
This helps explain why the Democrats are so eager to turn the political debate back to domestic issues. Some strategists consider this their only hope of mounting a competitive challenge to Mr. Bush in the 1992 election. But the poll showed that the Democrats hardly had a clear shot on these issues: 42 percent of respondents said the Republican Party was "better able to insure a strong economy," compared with 27 percent who gave the edge to the Democratic Party.
In addition, the public seems to blame Ronald Reagan more than Mr. Bush for the current recession: 48 percent say they put a lot of the blame on the policies of the Reagan Administration, compared with 15 percent who put the blame primarily on the Bush Administration.
The survey, which has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points, was conducted in telephone interviews Monday through Wednesday. No interviews were conducted after the President's speech to a joint session of Congress on Wednesday night, when he hailed the returning troops, pledged to get the economy rolling again and called for action on pressing domestic issues.
 
A Grace Period
 Because of the war, Mr. Bush has been given something of a grace period on the economy: 55 percent said the President paid as much attention as he could to the economy during the war. But now, 61 percent say Mr. Bush should be paying more attention to the economy than he is.
"Now it's time to concentrate on the home front, to help the American people and build the economy back to where it should be," Stephen Miller, 45, an assistant business manager in Clearwater, Fla., said in an interview after the poll was completed.
Sixty-three percent of the respondents said they knew someone well who is out of work and actively looking for a job. This is statistically equivalent to the 65 percent level registered in a January 1982 Times/CBS News Poll during the last major recession, which occurred in the first Reagan Administration.
For all of that, the war in the gulf left a remarkable afterglow in public attitudes. Confidence in the military stands at the highest level measured for any institution since the Gallup Poll began such measurements in 1973. In the Times/CBS Poll, 88 percent said they had "a great deal" or "quite a lot" of confidence in the military. The low point in confidence in the military since 1973 was registered in a 1981 Gallup Poll, when the level was 50 percent.
Trust in Government seems to be on the rebound: 47 percent said they trust the Government in Washington to do the right thing "just about always" or "most of the time," compared with 25 percent who held that view last October in the middle of the struggle over the budget between the White House and the Congress,
 
'Right Direction'
 And in a closely watched measure of the public mood, 51 percent now say the country is going in the "right direction," compared with 42 percent who felt the country was "off on the wrong track." This is a significant change from the polls last fall, when the pessimists outnumbered the optimists by a ratio of 2 or 3 to 1.
The gulf war has also transformed Americans' sense of their place in the world: 73 percent said they rejected the notion that the United States was in decline as a world power. Last June, 44 percent rejected it.
Still, there are underlying concerns that were much less affected by the post-war optimism. When asked to look ahead to the next century, 39 percent said they saw the United States as likely to be the No. 1 economic power in the world, while 43 percent said they saw Japan in that role.
Expectations about the long term remain tempered: 36 percent say life for the next generation of Americans will be better than life today, while 26 percent say it will be worse and 35 percent say it will be about the same.
 
War's Effect on Image
 While Mr. Bush emerged with a glowing image from the war, Vice President Quayle was not as fortunate: 19 percent gave him a favorable rating and 27 percent gave him an unfavorable rating, close to the previous level, recorded in January.
The poll gave some inkling of post-war politics. A majority of Democrats voted against the resolution in Congress to authorize the use of force in the gulf; and Republicans seem eager to make it an issue. But the survey found that in the view of 73 percent, both parties supported the war equally once it began.
Still, the poll suggested that the issue has potential for the Republicans: 52 percent said that if their congressional representatives voted against the resolution, it would make a difference in how the respondents would vote in that lawmaker's re-election. Moreover, by 4 to 1, these respondents said a vote against the President's proposal would make them less likely to vote for their lawmaker.
The effect of the gulf debate on party image was apparent in two other questions. Asked which party was more likely to keep the country out of war, 45 percent said the Democrats, while 23 percent said the Republicans.
But Republicans had an enormous edge when people were asked which party was more likely to "make sure U.S. military defenses are strong." Sixty-one percent said the Republicans, 14 percent said the Democrats.
Mr. Bush's overall popularity has soared during the gulf war, but there has been no major consistent change in his ratings on several domestic policy issues, including drugs, the environment and education. Fewer than four in ten say his Administration has made progress in dealing with those issues.
Still, he continues to match President Harry S. Truman's historic high for Presidential popularity, which came in June 1945 after the surrender of Germany and Mr. Truman's ascension to the White House.
But there is also an ominous precedent here for Mr. Bush: By 1951, Mr. Truman's approval rating had sunk to 23 percent, one of the lowest ever recorded for a President by the Gallup Poll.
 
How the Poll Was Taken
The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Monday to Wednesday with 1,252 adults throughout the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii.
No interviews were conducted after the President's televised speech to Congress on Wednesday night.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was selected by a computer from a complete list of exchanges in the country. The exchanges were chosen so as to insure that each region of the country was represented in proportion to its population. For each exchange, the telephone numbers were formed by random digits, thus permitting access to listed and unlisted numbers. The numbers were then screened to limit calls to residences.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines into the residence and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to region, race, sex, age and education.
In theory, in 19 of 20 cases the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all American adults.
The potential sampling error for smaller subgroups is larger. For example, for either Democrats or Republicans it is plus or minus five percentage points.

HEADLINE: Catholic Schools Worry As Closings Draw Near

BYLINE: By ARI L. GOLDMAN

 BODY:
These are fretful times for New York's Roman Catholic schools. In the next few days, the Archdiocese of New York is expected to announce that, because of mounting deficits, a handful of the schools, all in poor neighborhoods, will have to shut their doors.
The threat of closing has been hanging over the schools for several months, but as the time for a decision draws near, pastors, principals and parents say that they are on edge. "Rumors are flying like crazy," said Sister Mary Ellen Fuhrman, principal of St. Pius V School in the South Bronx. 
 One rumor circulating in the Bronx is that five schools will close; another, heard in Manhattan, says 10. The secretary at one Bronx church said that she jumps every time the phone rings, afraid that it will bring bad news.
"I'm praying to St. Jude that it's not us," said Suzanne O'Reily, the principal of the Transfiguration School in Chinatown. "You know St. Jude, he's the saint of the impossible."
Apologies for the closings have already been made. In a lengthy column last month in Catholic New York, the weekly newspaper of the archdiocese, John Cardinal O'Connor wrote that he has tried to "move heaven and earth" to keep the doors of each and every school open but that fiscal realities have made that impossible. "We will have to close some schools before September 1991 -- this year." He did not mention how many but said he would keep it to "the bare-bone minimum."
Bishops in other cities around the country have been faced with similar decisions. Chicago, Detroit and Washington have closed schools in recent years, and the Diocese of Bridgeport, Conn., announced a few days ago that it would have to shut four schools. All cite financial problems and declining populations in poorer urban areas.
Cardinal O'Connor, who is the head of the Archdiocese of New York, said that his decision would be made only after study, consultation and prayer.
A spokesman for the archdiocese said that meetings were held yesterday with some of the schools under consideration for closing at the Cardinal's office on First Avenue. In his newspaper column, the Cardinal had written that no school would close without his personal review. He added: "So whoever is looking for someone to blame can blame me."
The archdiocese and school officials declined to say yesterday which or how many schools had been called in. An announcement on the closings is expected within the next few days.
Talk of closings began to circulate in December when the archdiocese announced that it would have to slash by 50 percent the $20 million in subsidies it provides to 140 inner-city elementary and high schools. These schools represent 45 percent of the system's 312 schools; the balance are self-sustaining.
The diocese is made up of Manhattan, the Bronx, Staten Island, Westchester and five other counties north of New York City. It runs the largest private school system in the region with 96,000 pupils. The 140 schools facing cuts range from Holy Cross at 332 West 43d Street, just off of Times Square, to St. Peter's in Liberty and Sacred Heart in Newburgh.
The archdiocese immediately organized the schools in geographical clusters and asked that they work together to draw up plans for economizing and possible consolidation. In January, the Cardinal announced the start of an effort to raise $100 million over three years to help save the inner-city schools.
As part of the campaign, the archdiocese tried to drive home the point that the Catholic schools serve a broad population that includes Catholics and non-Catholics and many minority groups. It also touted the schools' achievements, including statistics that show that 85 percent of its high school graduates go on to college and that fewer than 1 percent drop out.
Some school administrators and pastors have told of seesaw emotions in recent weeks. When two weeks ago a rumor swept Mount Carmel-Holy Rosary Consolidated School in East Harlem that it would close, parents organized an evening prayer vigil outside of the Cardinal's residence on Madison Avenue and 49th Street.
 
Cardinal Meets Parents
 As 40 parents stood out in the cold, the Cardinal's car pulled up. Parents who were there said that the Cardinal spoke with them for several minutes and assured them that he would do everything in his power to keep the school open. "I think it helped a lot in making them more secure in the fact that their children will continue to receive a good Catholic education," said Desiree Edwards, the principal. "It was good to hear."
One of the reasons for the concern among parents was that the school appeared to fit at least one of the criteria spelled out in the Cardinal's column. "I can no longer keep two schools open which are only a short distance from each other if neither has enough students or one has a building falling down," he wrote.
Mount Carmel-Holy Rosary, itself the result of a merger several years ago, is only four blocks from another Catholic school, St. Paul's at 118th and Lexington Avenue. "We didn't want to see Mount Carmel-Holy Rosary-St. Paul," said Mrs. Edwards. "That would be too much."
In his column, the Cardinal also sought to put to rest what he called "the myth" of a wealthy archdiocese that is playing Scrooge with the schools. "Why can people see so easily that the Federal Government is running an enormous deficit, as is the State of New York and the City of New York, but insist that the Church has untold wealth? One reason is that they see a lot of buildings owned by the Church, so they ask why we don't sell them.
"Did you ever try to sell a school that needs capital repairs to the tune of $800,000? How about a church with the walls caving in? More importantly, what do you do if you sell them? Where do you hold school -- on a vacant lot?"

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR: Israel;
Mideast Pact: Israelis' View

BYLINE: By JOEL BRINKLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, March 7

 BODY:
On four crucial points, almost everyone in the Israeli political establishment seems to agree:
 Never has there been a more opportune time for Israel to make peace with its Arab neighbors. 
 If progress is to be made, the nation must act fast.
When Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d comes calling next week, the Government will have no new peace proposals to offer, and few if any original ideas.
So if progress is to made at this critical moment, it will have to be the result of someone else's initiative, Arab or American.
 
Arab-Israeli Talks
 As Justice Minister Dan Meridor put it, seeming to express the view of almost everyone in Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's right-wing Government: "America can tell the Arab states to come and talk with Israel. If they do this, the whole psychological area will change."
President Bush told Congress on Wednesday night that the United States was committed to working toward a solution to the Arab-Israeli conflict. But in a warning to both sides, he also said, "By now, it should be plain to all parties that peacemaking in the Middle East requires compromise."
Mr. Bush also repeated that any agreements should be based on Security Council Resolution 242 of November 1967, which in effect calls on Israel to return most if not all of the lands occupied in the 1967 war in exchange for having its borders recognized by Arab nations.
The political map of the region has changed little since 1979, when the Israeli Government of Prime Minister Menachem Begin signed a peace treaty with President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt that was brokered by President Jimmy Carter. In return for peace, Israel returned all of the Sinai, which was seized from Egypt in 1967. Israel still controls the Golan Heights, taken from Syria in that war, and the West Bank of the Jordan, including the eastern part of Jerusalem, taken from Jordan. The current Government of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir has taken a position opposing any further "peace for land" compromises with its Arab neighbors.
 
Problem of Coalition Politics
 Although Israeli officials agreed that the time was ripe for movement, they said they had no compromises to offer Syria or Jordan or the Palestinians, who clamor for their own homeland on the West Bank.
"They ask, what are we willing to give?" said Yossi Ben-Aharon, the Prime Minister's chief of staff. "We ask, what are the Syrians willing to give?"
Because of the intricacies of coalition politics, the Israelis have found it very hard to come up with peace initiatives. To stay in power, the Likud has made alliances with parties that are even less interested in making any concessions.
"It's the electoral system that creates these impossible coalitions," Shimon Peres, leader of the Labor Party, said when asked why Israel cannot seem to carry out any plans for peace.
 
Waning Support for Vote Plan
 Because Israel's system of proportional representation has not given a party a secure governing majority for years, "we must all the time be in the business of making coalitions," Mr. Peres said.
Mr. Shamir says his Government stands by its May 1989 initiative, which had as its central tenet elections in the occupied territories for Palestinians. That idea got nowhere at the time because the Israelis wanted to bar the Palestine Liberation Organization from taking part. And now that the P.L.O. is weakened politically because of its support for Iraq, senior Israeli officials indicate that the Government is not really committed to the idea of elections any longer -- partly because several far-right-wing ministers who together have the power to bring the Government down have made it clear they oppose it.
"The plan was adopted by the national unity Government in which the Labor Party was a 50 percent partner," said Science Minister Yuval Neeman of the far-right-wing Tehiya party. "I have no doubt that the Likud was obliged to compromise with Labor. These circumstances do not exist anymore."
He and several others, including Housing Minister Ariel Sharon, who was instrumental in scuttling the elections plan a year ago, have formed a right-wing front within the Government that opposes any use of even the 1989 plan.
 
Peres to Offer a Plan
 On the left, Mr. Peres, whose Labor Party is now out of the Government, has drafted a comprehensive proposal calling for a joint Jordanian-Palestinian delegation to work out a settlement in the West Bank and Gaza.
The plan also calls for a demilitarized West Bank and for an international conference to establish an economic cooperation agreement for the entire Middle East. Mr. Peres said he hoped to meet with Mr. Baker to discuss the plan. At the same time, at least three Labor factions are trying to sink his plan or promote programs of their own.
Politics aside, officials of every political persuasion agree that now is the moment to act. With Iraq's military destroyed, the army's assessment is that the threat of serious attack from the east has been virtually eliminated.
The Palestinians' position has been considerably weakened as a result of their support for President Saddam Hussein. And the Scud missile attacks on Israel, coupled with the Government's decision not to respond, have raised Israel's image in the West to levels unknown in recent years.
"We can't waste time," Mr. Peres said. "We have maybe a year, probably less. Then there will be elections in the United States, and here."
"I totally agree," said Amnon Rubenstein, leader of the center-left Shinui party. But many people agreed with Mr. Rubenstein when he also said: "I'm not overly optimistic about this. I know a lot of people say there has never been a better moment. But things don't work that way."
The reason, he and others said, is fear.
Even as the war has created a favorable political moment for Israel, the missile attacks have also left its people dazed and afraid.
Mr. Rubenstein, a leader of the leftist peace camp, had to move out of his home in Tel Aviv for several days last month because it had no bomb shelter. Two missiles fell in his neighborhood. And as he put it this week: "Look, even the people here who truly want peace just don't trust the Arabs. People here just don't see any reliable interlocutors out there."

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR: War Budget;
House, Voting $15 Billion for War, Warns Allies to Pay Their Part

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 7

 BODY:
The House of Representatives voted tonight to appropriate $15 billion to pay for the Persian Gulf war after warning other countries to make good on their pledges of aid and promising that Congress "may consider appropriate action" if those commitments were not fulfilled.
The statement of Congressional intent was added to a $4.3 billion supplemental appropriation bill intended to pay some of the domestic costs of the gulf war, provide aid to Israel, and pay for a variety of programs from Food Stamps to nuclear-waste cleanup to veterans pensions. 
 The $15 billion measure, adopted by a 380-to-19 vote, also spelled out procedures for using those contributions from other countries first and the United States dollars last.
The warning to other nations was adopted on a voice vote, despite a cautioning by Representative Jamie L. Whitten, Democrat of Mississippi and chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, that "we'll get more money if we don't threaten them."
 
Complaints on Pledges
 The resolution was proposed by Representative Jim Chapman, Democrat of Texas, who complained about "allied pledges that the checks are in the mail." Other countries have pledged $54.5 billion in contributions to help pay for the war, but only $16.9 billion of it has been paid so far. Neither his proposal nor the debate offered any suggestions about what Congress might do if other countries did not meet the demand to achieve "substantial compliance or an agreed upon payment schedule no later than April 15."
After passage by a vote of 365 to 43, the supplemental appropriation bill went to the Senate, where complaints about slow payments from allies have also been voiced angrily and frequently.
On the aid for Israel, there were about two hours of debate before the 397-to-24 vote for $650 million for that country came. Most of the speakers supported the aid and wanted to get on record with their arguments that Israel, a steadfast ally of the United States, had suffered losses of at least that much because of the war -- from damage by Scud missiles to a continual air-force alert to the distribution of gas masks.
 
On Israelis' Defense
 The opponents generally insisted that they were supporters of Israel. But they said the $3 billion Israel now gets annually was enough. Representative Tim Valentine, Democrat of North Carolina, who offered the amendment, said more aid for Israel was inappropriate "when we are struggling under the weight of a recession."
But Representative Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of Brooklyn, insisted, "The Israelis simply want the wherewithal to defend themselves as the rest of the world turns against them."
And Representative David R. Obey, the Wisconsin Democrat who heads the appropriations subcommittee on foreign operations, said he supported the Administration in its request for aid. He said the Administration needed support as it sought peace in the Mideast. He did complain that the original Israeli request for $1 billion was "outlandish."
 
An 'Emergency' Provision
 The aid to Israel was adopted under a provision of last year's budget act, under which "emergency" needs were exempt from the spending limits set at that time. Representative Robert H. Michel of Illinois, the House Republican leader, voted for the aid to Israel, but warned against using the concept too loosely. "Let's not let the word 'emergency' fall victim to semantic inflation," he said.
The $650 million for Israel was included in a grab-bag $4.3 billion appropriations bill that also included $151 million to offset various domestic costs arising out of the war, especially security expenses for the F.B.I., the Secret Service, the Capitol Police and the District of Columbia police force. There were also war-related appropriations of $200 million for maintenance of military depots and $270 million for health-care costs for the military and their dependents.
The other big items in the bill were $1.5 billion for food stamps, $603 million for nuclear-waste cleanup, $303 million for veterans pensions, $232 million for supplemental security income payments by the Social Security Administration, $200 million to help states pay the costs of administering the unemployment compensation program, and $100 million for an increased Federal payment to the District of Columbia.
The bill also directed the Department of Defense to go ahead with a $988 million program of modernizing 12 Grumman F-14A aircraft, a plan the Pentagon seeks to cancel. It also told the department to spend previously appropriated funds on the vertical takeoff Osprey aircraft, another project the Pentagon resists.
The House did move to cut spending on one matter. At the urging of Representative Jim Slattery, Democrat of Kansas, it voted 71 to 11 to repeal a $500,000 appropriation to develop a tourist center around the restored birthplace of Lawrence Welk in Strasburg, N.D. "No issue caused us more grief last year," said Representative Dan Glickman, also a Kansas Democrat.
Despite Wednesday night's appeal by Persident Bush for rapid Congressional action on his domestic agenda, the House rejected, by a 246 to 177 vote, an effort to start spending money quickly on various new housing programs he pushed last year, including one that would enable public housing tenants to buy the housing they now rent.
Representative Newt Gingrich, the Georgian who serves as Republican whip, urged passage of a plan to shift $779 million in funds already appropriated for other housing programs to those plans.
"How can you turn the President down," he said.
But Representative Bill Green, Republican of Manhattan, said local communities were not ready to implement the new legislation and the proposal would "start the program off on the wrong foot by trying to force feed them."

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR: Veterans;
Outpouring of Scholarships and Jobs Await Returning Heroes After the Ticker Tape

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON

 BODY:
In a homecoming fit for conquering heroes, a grateful American public will bestow more than ticker tape on troops returning from the Persian Gulf. There are offers of college scholarships, carpenter jobs that pay $22 an hour, free weekends in wine country, even promises to baby-sit the children.
In what one Congressman described as a "maddening drive to the floor of the House," politicians in Washington and around the country are racing to outdo one another with bills that would benefit the troops. 
 And job recruiters say they will be eager to court those men and women whom President Bush described as "first-class talent."
"If we learn that an applicant has seen duty in the Persian Gulf," said Arnold Silberman, vice president of the Rust-Oleum Corporation, "that's something we're going to consider very, very highly."
 
Gratitude and Guilt
 One of the career choices the veterans might consider is public office. Representative Newt Gingrich, Republican of Georgia, is urging his party to nominate gulf war veterans to run against Democrats.
The extraordinary show of support is "almost out of proportion," said Charles Moskos, a Northwestern University sociologist who studies the military. The outpouring, he said, reveals a great sense of appreciation among Americans, but perhaps also some guilt.
"In some ways, I see this as a kind of moral payback for the short shrift we gave to the Vietnam veterans," said Mr. Moskos, who noted that 500 times as many troops died in Vietnam as in the Persian Gulf fighting. "I think there's also a measure of collective guilt among the American elite who knew that it wasn't their sons and daughters fighting over there."
The return of tens of thousands of troops from the Persian Gulf is not likely to have a wrenching effect on the economy, as did the two million soldiers mustered out of service in the year after the ending of World War II.
But ordinary Americans, too, have been lining up to do whatever they can to demonstrate support for the troops.
A plumbing contractor in Pleasanton, Calif., Frank Capilla, has already rounded up pledges of 30 jobs from businesses in his area. A suburban Minneapolis insurance salesman, Kenneth Smith, has secured a host of pledges of blue-collar and white-collar jobs for troops returning to Minnesota.
 
A Perfect Gift
 "What better gift can you give a serviceman than a job?" Mr. Capilla asked.
In Chicago, a radio talk show host challenged his listeners to "put up" something more tangible for the troops than yellow ribbons. The calls rushed in. Dozens of people called with offers to give up their tickets for a Cubs game, theater, a night at the symphony. One woman said she would donate her services as a baby sitter. Another promised to watch the pets.
"They actually came through," said the host, Stacy Taylor. "They called the station with pledges, and they left their names and telephone numbers."
In Congress, a dizzying array of proposals to help veterans are being considered. One measure would waive the usual 10 percent penalty for withdrawals from individual retirement accounts for the gulf troops. Another would raise the tax exemption on commissioned officers' combat pay to $2,000 from $500.
The rush for veterans-related legislation is strikingly different from what happened in the last Congress, when political maneuvering led to the blocking of a bill to provide cost-of-living increases to disabled veterans.
It is difficult to know, of course, how long the support will last. A year from now, when the euphoria over military victory has abated, will the troops be forgotten? If the troops do get any breaks in the job market, will appreciation turn to resentment among workers hurt by the recession?
"Next week, they're seen as conquering heroes," said Mr. Moskos. "But two years from now, when some of the troops get laid off, as we expect to happen, will the public simply view them as marginal?"
A note of skepticism was also sounded by Representative Leon E. Panetta, a California Democrat, who cautioned against raising "false hopes" among the veterans. "This maddening drive to the floor of the House is not a good way to do business," he said. "How are we going to pay for some of these things?"
Since many troops will continue to serve in the armed forces, the private sector will not be inundated with returning veterans. The thousands of troops, whose terms were extended during the war, will soon be discharged.
For the first time since World War II, the troops will return together in units, making it easier for communities to hold rallies and confer honors.
Ticker tape parades are scheduled in many cities, from New York to Jacksonville, N.C., where confetti will be dropped from ladders, since there are no tall buildings in the city.
When the time comes to enter the labor market, the troops will be coveted by many companies, according to recruitment specialists.
"Action in the Persian Gulf is going to look very good on a resume," said Kent Milius, the owner of Management Recruiters of Colorado. "They have demonstrated that they can take the pressure, and employers like that."
A few days ago, Mr. Milius was discussing the attributes of a job candidate with a prospective employer.
"When I mentioned that the man was a former Green Beret, my client really sat up and took notice," Mr. Milius said. "Six months ago, I don't think it would have worked that way."
The president of the American Federation of Teachers, Albert Shanker, has issued an appeal for veterans to consider teaching, a field expected to experience many vacancies in the next few years.
"We have a shortage of minority teachers in particular," he said, "and the people who served would make very good role models in the classroom."
 
Gain for Minority Workers
 Leaders of civil rights groups said they hoped the valor demonstrated by so many black and Hispanic soldiers, along with the leadership of Gen. Colin L. Powell, would convince corporations that minority workers could contribute mightily.
"The armed forces have proven that affirmative action and equal opportunity can work," said Benjamin Hooks, director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. "If it can work in the biggest enterprise we have, it is foolish to think that it can't work in corporate and civilian life."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
With Victory, New Challenges

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
IN his address to Congress this week on the end of the Persian Gulf war, President Bush linked economic development to the peace process. With Iraq's aggression repulsed, the new challenge, he said, "is to reach higher -- to foster economic freedom and prosperity for all people of the region." Indeed, he went so far as to suggest that a solution in the Middle East would help bring about a new world order "in which freedom and respect for human rights find a home among all nations." The war, he said, had provided a first test of such a new world, and we had passed the test.
Immediately, however, comes the second test: resolving the clashing interests and ancient enmities that have survived the war. The Administration has begun a large-scale effort to think through the security and economic arrangements for an enduring peace in the Middle East. 
 In a briefing held shortly before the President addressed Congress Wednesday night, a senior Administration official said that in the last few weeks key departments of the Government, with the State Department foremost, had been producing papers on postwar arrangements in the Middle East. These were being integrated, he said, "to lay the foundation for an effort which Secretary Baker will clearly lead on the President's behalf."
He did not deny that the Administration has some "pretty explicit ideas" of its own, but Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, now on his trip to visit Arab and Israeli leaders, would first be taking the measure of "how the landscape has changed in the Middle East between the beginning of the war, or the prewar period and now." This would enable him to determine "degrees of congruence" between their ideas and ours, the official said. In fact, it seems evident that much has changed in the Arab world because of the war. Most important is the new perception of American power, with the American image changing from a declining to an ascending force in the world. The swiftness with which United States and coalition forces prevailed was overwhelmingly a consequence of American technology and of the skill and spirit of the men and women operating that technology. This was as true in the lightning war on the ground as in the air.
But what is true on the battlefield holds as well for the civilian economy. And the lesson for Iraq, and for third world and Communist nations, is that national power stems not from the weight of arms or material resources or numbers of people but from the quality of human resources.
A report just released by the United Nations Development Program, based on a conference held in Antalya, Turkey, three weeks after Iraq invaded Kuwait, declares, "Politics and economics must embrace all the concerns of humanity for sustainable strategies for ecological and human welfare, bearing in mind that human beings are more important than material resources." The report now appears prescient. And the victory in the gulf gives the Middle Eastern countries the opportunity, if they are to move ahead, to act on that principle of putting human skills -- and human values -- first and to act in their urgent common interest.
The war has left in its wake what has been described as the worst ecological threat in history, with millions of barrels of oil dumped by Iraq into the gulf and the burning of Kuwaiti oil wells by retreating Iraqis. Working together, and with Western help, the Arabs need to overcome that threat to their health and economies.
An even greater environmental threat lies ahead: the extreme shortage of water in the Middle East. As Joyce R. Starr writes in the new issue of Foreign Policy: "Water will become a more precious commodity than oil. The next war in the Middle East will be fought over water."
Environmental protection and economic development in the Middle East must be linked to the peace process. Even before Secretary Baker arrived for his discussions, the foreign ministers of Egypt, Syria and six other Arab nations proposed creation of a peace-keeping force, to replace United States and Western forces.
This proposal may provide Mr. Baker with a handle to work out joint security arrangements, and, with American involvement by continued air and naval presence, link them to Israel's security. In the new spirit of the stunning victory in the gulf, things that looked impossible only weeks ago now seem possible.
That extends to the new confidence in the White House and Congress that economic and social problems here at home can be solved if the nation tackles them with the same "can do" spirit that brought such remarkable results in the war. In his victory speech, Mr. Bush lost no time in declaring his determination to end the recession and address social problems at home. But the follow-through will be even more difficult to execute than his brilliant success in the gulf.

HEADLINE: New World Bank Chief Seen Focusing on Debt

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 7

 BODY:
Lewis T. Preston, retired chairman of J. P. Morgan & Company and President Bush's choice to head the World Bank, is likely to refocus attention on reducing the crushing debt burden of third world countries as a key to lifting global living standards.
A commercial banker's perspective sets him apart from his predecessor, Barber B. Conable Jr., a former Congressman from upstate New York. Mr. Conable not only enhanced the bank's image in Congress but also obtained a huge infusion of capital to further lending and technical assistance programs in more than 100 countries. 
 President Bush formally submitted Mr. Preston's name to the bank's executive board today, and little opposition is expected.
Although the bank -- which chiefly makes loans to build highways, dams, irrigation works and other long-term economic improvement projects -- has 155 member governments, the United States, as the largest donor, traditionally names the chief executive. Its sister organization, the International Monetary Fund, which helps countries pay short-term bills, is traditionally headed by a European. The current managing director is Michel Camdessus, a former French central banker.
Mr. Preston declined to be interviewed. His spokesman, John M. Morris, did issue a statement that Mr. Preston was excited by the nomination "at a time when the challenges before the World Bank have never been greater."
The bank's current importance is underscored by the fiscal constraints that Mr. Preston said were now affecting the traditional aid flows from the United States, Western Europe and Japan.
The bank's loans are expected to total well over $20 billion this year.
Mr. Preston "comes to the bank with a broad background in public policy," said C. Fred Bergsten, a former senior Treasury official who is director of the Institute for International Economics, a Washington-based policy organization. "The job he did at Morgan also gives him great respect in the private sector."
Under his presidency, Morgan devised a debt reduction plan for Mexico that spurred a more sweeping plan adopted by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady.
Mr. Preston's sensitivity to the problem may have been heightened by his position as head of Morgan's international banking department from 1968 to 1976 when Morgan itself was making many of the third world loans that countries like Mexico then found they could not repay. It was Mexico's inability to pay creditors that started the debt crisis in the summer of 1982.
As chairman of the nation's fourth-largest banking company during the last decade -- a period in which many investment banking and securities firms foundered -- the 64-year-old banker and World War II marine corporal took the bank into new revenue areas without sacrificing its reputation as a blue-chip banking firm.

HEADLINE: Chrysler Dividend Is Halved

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 7

 BODY:
The board of the Chrysler Corporation cut the auto maker's regular quarterly dividend in half today, to 15 cents a share from 30 cents.
The action, taken at the board's regular monthly meeting in New York, was widely expected by financial analysts. It will save Chrysler roughly $33 million quarterly. 
 "Reducing the dividend was the prudent and sensible thing to do in light of the dismal market conditions of the past few months," said Robert S. Miller Jr., Chrysler's vice chairman. "We still have a long-term confidence in the business, however, so it would have been inappropriate to eliminate the dividend."
 
Aggressive Cost-Cutting
 Chrysler and other auto makers in the United States have been cutting costs aggressively in the face of 18 months of sluggish sales. Earlier this year, the General Motors Corporation cut its quarterly dividend in half, and analysts expect the Ford Motor Company to cut its dividend when its directors meet on April 11.
Mr. Miller said an economic rebound might permit Chrysler to restore the dividend to 30 cents. The Big Three auto makers say orders from dealers have picked up since the end of the Persian Gulf war. But that optimism has not been reflected yet in retail sales, which were weak in the last 10 days of February.
The meeting yesterday provided an interesting footnote as Clarence M. Ditlow, head of the Center for Auto Safety, was allowed to make a pitch to the board to improve vehicle safety. [Page D3.]
The money Chrysler will save by halving its dividend is not much, but it should send a positive signal to bankers that the company is doing everything it can to save money.
 
Bigger Credit Risk
 Chrysler's shaky financial condition has made it a bigger risk to lenders. It is currently trying to reach an accord with 38 banks on a new $1.7 billion line of credit. The banks, led by the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, are considering the new, more modest credit line to replace a $2.6 billion loan agreement.
Neither the auto maker nor its finance subsidiary can borrow in the public credit markets because their securities are rated at "junk bond" levels. But Chrysler is trying to sell a stake in the finance subsidiary to a stronger company, which could result in higher ratings on the finance subsidiary's debt and allow the unit to sell bonds and commercial paper.
Chrysler shares rose 62.5 cents each on the New York Stock today to close at $14.50.

THE ECONOMY
Long-distance telephone companies are offering businesses more modern, precise methods of calculating service charges. But residential customers remain on the old system of rounding off each call to the next full minute, and pay an extra $2 billion a year in the process. [Page A1.]
Congress moved much closer to approving $30 billion more for the savings and loan bailout. Hundreds of failing savings and loans will have to be attended to. [D1.] 
 Most retailers report slow sales for February, with consumers apparently not showing much interest in spring clothing. [D1.]
The House of Representatives approved a $200 million grant to the states to help them speed the processing of applications for unemployment benefits. [A20.]
Consumer credit fell at a 4 percent annual rate in January, the Government reported. [D1.]
Three Congressmen say the Food and Drug Administration failed to take early action against abuses by some generic drug companies. [D3.]
The military won't try to use depictions of combat to attract recruits. Marketing and advertising officials say the reality of warfare could scare away potential enlistees. [D1.]
 
COMPANIES
NCR's chairman appeared to acknowledge that a takeover by A.T.&T. was all but inevitable. After a meeting with the company, analysts said Charles Exley accepted the idea that the deal would be completed. [D1.]
Chrysler cut its dividend in half, to 15 cents a share from 30 cents. The move, which was expected, will save the No. 3 auto maker $33 million a quarter. [D1.]
Security Pacific will sell $175 million in preferred stock to strengthen its capital base. [D3.]
Time Warner says 10,000 cable television subscribers in Queens will be able to receive 150 channels by the end of the year. [D5.]
A Federal judge blocked Exxon's $1.2 billion settlement with the Government of civil lawsuits over damage done by the Exxon Valdez two years ago in North America's largest oil spill. Fifteen Alaskan Indian tribes had sought the temporary order. [A12.]
Apple Computer's stock jumped and Microsoft's sagged after a court decision favorable to Apple. [D3.]
 
MARKETS
Blue chip stocks weakened in cautious trading, with many investors waiting to see the unemployment report due today. The Dow fell 9.90 to 2,963.37. [D6.]
Prices of long-term Treasury bonds soared on the expectation that a sharp rise in unemployment would lessen the demand for loans. [D14.]
Silver prices rallied to just under $4 an ounce on the New York Commodity Exchange. [D15.]
The dollar gained against most major currencies in choppy trading. Gold prices rose $1 an ounce. [D15.]

HEADLINE: Chief Seeks Charges in Police Beating

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, March 7

 BODY:
The Chief of Police of Los Angeles said today that he would seek felony criminal charges against three officers seen beating a prone suspect, apparently not resisting arrest, in an amateur videotape that has stirred national revulsion.
Calling the incident an aberration in a "well-disciplined department," Police Chief Daryl F. Gates said all 15 officers present at the beating late Sunday night would also face departmental charges. 
 He singled out the supervising sergeant at the scene who stood by while the officers rained from 53 to 56 nightstick blows on the subdued suspect and kicked him at least seven times, what Chief Gates conceded at a news conference was "excessive force" in a making an arrest.
Chief Gates said he did not seek criminal charges against the sergeant because he had not participated in the beating, apart from applying a shock from a stun gun, which he said was an accepted departmental procedure.
 
Defending the Department
 In his announcement, Chief Gates stoutly defended his department against charges that his officers regularly brutalized blacks and other minority members and defiantly rejected suggestions that he should resign.
"We do not and have never allowed our officers to use excessive force," he said, adding that two officers had been killed in the last four months and five shot. "Suddenly the tables are turned by one incident, and, unfortunately, we are painting 8,300 additional officers with this broad brush."
Today's action seemed unlikely to quiet the crescendo of calls for Chief Gates's resignation from political leaders who have charged he has failed to correct a pattern of police abuse.
"I have absolutely no thoughts of resigning," Chief Gates said.
His critics have included Mayor Tom Bradley, who met with his Police Commission, a five-member body that oversees the department but which has no authority to dismiss Chief Gates.
At news conference at City Hall this evening, Mayor Bradley, a former police officer, demanded a "speedy bringing to justice of the guilty," adding "This city will not tolerate that kind of conduct by its police officers."
He said the Police Commission would take a "comprehensive look" at the department's training and supervisory practices and at whether there were any patterns of racial discrimination in their behavior. He praised Mr. Gates for his action today, declining to renew his past criticism of the Chief.
 
Possible Assault Charges
 Chief Gates said that he would ask the District Attorney of Los Angeles County to bring criminal charges, probably including assault with a deadly weapon, against the three officers who could be identified in the videotape as administering the blows to Rodney Glen King, the 25-year-old suspect, after a chase on the Foothill Freeway in the northern part of the city.
Chief Gates said the names of the three officers would not be released until the District Attorney had filed charges.
Chief Gates was particularly critical of the sergeant because an explicit duty after a violent arrest is to prevent excited officers from inflicting unnecessary injury. He added that all other officers who did not intercede would be charged internally with neglect of duty.
A spokesman for District Attorney Ira Reiner said today that prosecutors were investigating the incident and that charges could be brought against more officers than just the three cited by Chief Gates.
The chief maintained race was not a factor in the beating. "We can turn up absolutely nothing except that the officers were white and the suspect black," he said.
With that much, at least, Mr. King apparently agreed. "We are not seeking to make a racial issue out of this," said one of his lawyers, Robert Rentzer. "This is simply a violation of one human being's human rights. It is a matter of human dignity, not a matter of racial dignity at this time."
He said Mr. King, an unemployed construction worker from Altadena who is on parole from a robbery conviction, was preparing to file a civil rights suit against the Police Department and had signed a criminal complaint against the men who beat him, at the request of the Police Department.
Mr. Rentzer said Mr. King would undergo tests to determine the extent of his injuries, including examinations of his eyes, a fractured ankle, possible internal injuries, a possible broken nose, dizziness and memory loss. He added that Mr. King's wife, Carol, would file a separate civil suit.
In defense of his officers, Chief Gates asserted that it was Mr. King who "created" the incident by speeding and evading arrest, adding that they suspected he was under the influence of alcohol or PCP, an illicit drug. The police report stated that Mr. King was driving at 115 miles an hour. Mr. Rentzer said tests were being conducted on the Hyundai sedan to determine whether it could have reached such a speed.
Chief Gates said he believed that Mr. King behaved in a threatening way at the beginning of the tape but that once he was on the ground and restrained further blows were "inappropriate."
Leaders of minority groups said the incident would have gone unnoticed had it not been videotaped by a man outside whose apartment the beating took place. The photographer, George Holliday, who lives in the San Fernando Valley, turned the tape over to a local independent television station, KTLA-TV, in Los Angeles, which gave it to the Cable News Network.
Chief Gates praised Mr. Holliday today as a citizen who "decided to get involved" and publicly assured him that his wife's fears of retribution by police officers were unfounded. He also thanked KTLA and Mayor Bradley.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Police Chief Daryl F. Gates of Los Angeles said he would seek felony charges against three officers videotaped beating a suspect. He told reporters that "excessive force" was used in making the arrest. (Roger Sandler for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: An Infant Boy Is Found Dead Of Starvation

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr.

 BODY:
An emaciated 7-month-old boy was found dead in a Bronx apartment yesterday morning, and the Medical Examiner's office said the child had died of starvation and dehydration.
The infant's mother, June Scott, 28, and his father, Jose Valez, 26, were arrested last night and charged with manslaughter and abandonment of the child. 
 Ms. Scott told investigators earlier yesterday that she had left her son, Daniel Scott, in the care of his father on the evening of March 1, Lieut. Donald Stephenson of the 44th Precinct detective squad said.
She was gone for six days, the lieutenant said. When she returned at 8 A.M. yesterday, he said, she found the child dead, lying next to his crib in the living room of her apartment on the second floor of 1106 Morris Avenue near East 166th Street in the Melrose section. There were small bruises on the child's forehead. Investigators said it appeared the starving baby had climbed out of the crib and fallen to the floor.
The police estimated the baby had been dead for at least 12 hours, and perhaps 16. He was dressed in a pair of filthy diapers. No food or baby formula was found in the apartment.
 
'Homicide by Neglect'
 Ellen Borakove, a spokeswoman for the Medical Examiner's office, said a coroner determined yesterday afternoon that the death was "homicide by neglect." The autopsy report said the baby had died from severe starvation and dehydration.
It was the second time in three weeks that the death of a baby in New York City was attributed to neglect. On Feb. 16, a month-old boy, Angel Lee, died en route to Harlem Hospital after falling unconscious in his parents' apartment at 227 West 145th Street in Harlem. A medical examiner later determined he had died of severe malnutrition and neglect. No charges have been filed against the parents, who have not been identified, but an investigation is continuing.
Miss Scott, who is unemployed, told the police that the baby's father was a homeless man who spent most of his time loitering on the streets near her apartment, Lieutenant Stephenson said.
Miss Scott told the police she had spent the six days she was gone on an extended crack binge, prostituting herself for drug money, the detective said.
"We're basically taking her word for the fact she wasn't there and she left the baby with the father," Lieutenant Stephenson said. "This is a horror story."
