HEADLINE: Review/Art;
Sculpture Borne by the Earth and Lighted by the Sky

BYLINE: By MICHAEL BRENSON

 BODY:
Summer is no longer the only eventful season for outdoor sculpture. As sculpture -- so often costly to make and show -- seems more and more of an outcast in galleries during this economic crunch, it may be finding more of a home in New York City's parks and streets. Sculpture, and public art in general, now almost seems part of the fabric of New York rather than just a guest waiting, or sometimes demanding, to be invited in for a few months each year.
Not all the sculpture on view is worthy of attention; it never is. And some of the news from the outdoor-sculpture front is not good. Vandalism is so widespread that sculptors installing work outdoors have to consider it more than a remote possibility. But this is winter -- not summer, when sculpture is almost in the air -- and the thoughtful commitment to public art, throughout this city, is indicative of a healthy situation. 
 This winter offers three main events. One is taking place at the Hunts Point Food Distribution Center in the Bronx, which last year inaugurated a sculpture program unlike any other in the history of New York City. Another is at Socrates Sculpture Park in Long Island City, Queens, which is now the most influential and important outdoor sculpture site in New York. For sculptors and their supporters, these out-of-the-way parks are fields of dreams.
The third main event is taking place on bus shelters and billboards throughout the five boroughs. The promoter is the Public Art Fund, which commissioned works from Gran Fury, the Guerrilla Girls and Barbara Kruger. Their posters are nasty, alarming and absurd enough (those of Ms. Kruger feature photographs of hard-hat or yuppie men pleading for help after learning they are pregnant) to make some people think a bit differently about abortion, AIDS and censorship. Done well, this kind of art counters and questions the subliminal messages spread in subways and bus stops and other places where advertisements tend to be passively absorbed.
The Food Center Sculpture Park at Hunts Point is not yet a sculpture park but rather is an assortment of works installed in one of the largest food-market complexes in the world. The park's second annual exhibition is hardly even an exhibition, since there is no theme and little coherence to the selection and installation.
The roughly 20 works, most of them outdoors, include a number of John Ahearn's and Rigoberto Torres's portrait busts (from the mid-1980's) cast from ordinary people in the South Bronx, and Jonathan Silver's classically inspired "Small Venus" from 1979, an earthy yet fragmented nude that underlines the precariousness that can be felt throughout this site. The exhibition also includes a procession of abstract sculptures in wood and steel marching aimlessly across the pebbly front yard of the headquarters of National Foods.
More important than the limited success of this show is the very existence of sculpture in this raw, stripped-down neighborhood and the potential of this program to define many of the possibilities of sculpture in the 90's. It is startling to encounter sculptures behind barbed wire, or in a field alongside a Sanitation Department transfer station where garbage is loaded onto barges, or near Food Center Drive, a main thoroughfare on which an abandoned car that seems less stripped than raped can sit for weeks before authorities remove it.
If the future of the Hunts Point Sculpture Park is still up in the air, the next few years of the Socrates Sculpture Park look reasonably secure. The park has signed a temporary occupancy permit with the city through October 1992, and its officials hope to sign two more one-year permits afterward. The current exhibition, "No Man's Land," appears, like this park's previous exhibitions, to be something of a free-for-all, but it is in fact quite clear about the directions the park intends to follow.
There is nothing quite like this park. In its largely untamed site by the East River, visitors know right away this is not first of all their world. The park seems to belong to the sculptures, which over the years develop lives of their own. Only a sculptor -- Mark di Suvero, whose towering black steel beams preside over the park -- could have conceived a place in which sculpture can be so free.
Now for the bad news. The same climate of vulnerability and hostility that is creating more of a need for public art is also making it harder for it to survive. In the last year, one sculpture in the first annual Hunts Points exhibition was stolen; two sculptures in the current show at Socrates Sculpture Park were destroyed; an outdoor sculpture in TriBeCa was banged up, and a recent installation in a SoHo park had chained-in parts removed.
In light of this vandalism, public art in New York must be selected and installed with the kind of care that inspires respect. Some trivial works, like Keith Haring's sprightly red figures in Dante Park, in front of Lincoln Center, are probably harmless. Some, like Linda Cunningham's "Structural Transformations: An Environmental Memorial," a two-part installation that is totally out of place on the pavement of TriBeCa, are unfortunate. This installation combines natural and industrial materials like fossilized rock and steel and includes references to the fragility and survival of nature, but there is nothing redeeming about its materials or content. Such a work cannot make it easier for other outdoor sculptures to be protected and shown.
 
Food Center Sculpture Park at Hunts Point
Hunts Point Food Distribution Center
 The Bronx
 Through 1991
Although this exhibition includes several successful works, the Food Center Sculpture Park is still clearly searching for a firm foundation. The financing was very limited, only $15,000. One of the two site-specific projects, a sculpture by Martha Burgess, has yet to be installed. One other work, a mural by Richard Haas, is not yet in place. Some works accompanying the exhibition -- T-shirts and signs by Barbara Kruger and signs by Anton von Dalen -- are still being produced.
The sculptures with the most personality, by far, were made by Ming Fay for a small space by a staircase inside the wholesale produce market that looks a bit like a vast army barracks. In "Orange Queen," "Black Plum" and "Big Bosc," giant pieces of fruit seem to have been squeezed into packing crates so that each looks like an orangutan in a cage. In each work, the fruit seems imprisoned, eager to escape its commercial fate and gain the kind of freedom Mr. Fay confers on his fruit in his current SoHo installation at Exit Art (through March 23). The Chinese characters written on the crates suggest the exotic nature of the familiar freight. Stenciled letters on the crates spell out "handle with care" and "made in USA" and acknowledge the sponsors of the exhibition.
Other sculptures with some zip include Hank de Ricco's "Rounder" and "High Noon," both of which relate to activities in the market. Each of these wood sculptures looks like an armature: for a giant basket or refuse container ("Rounder"), or for a giant, crystalline toy or storage bin that can be stretched this way or that ("High Noon").
The exhibition provides an instructive example of how a site can affect art. In last year's show, the two wood sculptures by Peter Dudek were ineffective alongside company headquarters buildings. Now in an open field by the marine transfer station, the sculptures' taut grids and Mondrianlike colors bring to their bleak site a concentrated dose of energy and light.
The selection process for the exhibition was similar to last year's. The participating organizations either commissioned works or chose works from proposals made by a committee representing several commercial and arts organizations. The administrator of the show was Lyn Freeman, formerly of the Public Art Fund. Prominent figures in the sculpture park continue to be Sigmund R. Balka, the general counsel for Krasdale Foods; Coy LaSister, the director of markets for the City Department of Ports and Trade, and Betti-Sue Hertz of the Bronx Council on the Arts. For information on the show, call (212) 931-9500.
 
No Man's Land
Socrates Sculpture Park
 Broadway and Vernon Boulevard
 Long Island City, Queens
 Through March
"No Man's Land" provides a good idea of what the Socrates Sculpture Park is trying to do and where it is going. The exhibition gives gallery sculptors like Robin Hill a chance to show outdoors. It brings to New York sculptors like Vicki Scuri and Keith Oliver, who laid long shreds of tires in black paths that slither from the waterfront into the heart of the park. It encourages experimental work, with light (Ed Andrews) and water (Ray Kelly). Two large blue columns by the Mexican sculptor Sebastian demonstrate the park's interest in artists from outside the United States.
Several of the works are big. Mr. Andrews's 50-foot-tall column is made up of around 10 layers -- each resembling a stainless-steel grass skirt -- with a small wind sensor on top. The speed with which the sensor spins determines the amount of light produced by the neon camouflaged within the metal.
Jesse Moore is a talented young sculptor who is beginning to feel her oats. Her "Calling to Evangeline" brings to mind the big wood wheel by Martin Puryear and the wooden spokes in sculptures by Elizabeth Egbert. Her two wheels are enormous, and they support a long horn that can be looked through, as if it were a telescope, or spoken into, as if it were a megaphone trying to persuade the rest of the park and even Manhattan itself, across the river, to listen.
All the shows in this park are distinguished by a feeling for materials. Pat Dougherty is one of a number of contemporary sculptors looking to weave together industry and nature. His work includes a metal frame the size of a small house, which seems to have been settled by giant birds. Clusters of saplings are wound around two parts of the house. A third cluster sits on a lawn in the middle of the house like a child's castle or like the nest of a gigantic avian creature that will shortly return.
 
Mel Edwards
 Doris Freedman Plaza
 60th Street and Fifth Avenue
 Through May
"Tomorrow's Wind" is evidence of the large-scale, public-art side of Mel Edwards, who is best known for his small "Lynch Fragments" (a sculpture representing the third, polychrome side of his work is on view at the Whitney Museum of American Art at Philip Morris). In June, "Tomorrow's Wind" is to be installed in the site for which it was made, Thomas Jefferson Park in East Harlem.
This 13 1/2-foot-tall, welded stainless-steel sculpture features a disk that tilts backward, reflecting light to the point where the heavy metal can seem like a silver sun. A second form, almost guarding the disk, is upright and blade-shaped. The third form looks like a piece of a house with a door cut out of it. With their hints of building blocks, tools, homes and stars, the forms are loaded with symbolic meaning.
The work is fully three-dimensional and loses its sculptural conviction only from the back, when it stops responding to its environment and turns inward. One problem people may have with the work is that its debt to the tradition of stainless-steel sculpture is so obvious. In his public art, Mr. Edwards is clearly less interested in originality than he is in making an intense and full human statement.
 
Gran Fury, Guerrilla Girls, Barbara Kruger
Bus shelters and billboards
New York City
On the 100 color posters by Gran Fury on bus shelters throughout the city, the English text (half the posters are in Spanish) includes the words: "Women don't get AIDS, they just die from it." In smaller letters, the posters call attention to the problem faced by women who test positive for the AIDS virus but whose infections don't fit the Centers for Disease Control's definition of AIDS, which Gran Fury says prevents these women from getting health care. In a kind of blue mist behind the letters are images of bathing beauties in a Miss America pageant. The reality of the words overpowers dreamy images of idealized women who seem little more than mouths and legs.
The posters by Barbara Kruger appear on 100 bus shelters around the city. One of her three images presents a young black man, another a middle-aged construction worker, another a yuppie father with his child. All have the word "help" plastered in red letters across their chests. On their bellies we read about their confusion now that they have found out they are pregnant and cannot follow the personal and professional lives they planned. The tone of these posters is deadpan. The effect is comic and pointed.
The Guerrilla Girls' poster, on 10 billboards throughout the city except Staten Island, is an attempt to link government control of women and censorship of art. "First they want to take away a woman's right to choose," read the red and black letters on a yellow ground. "Now they're censoring art." To the right of the words is an image of the "Mona Lisa" with a green fig leaf over her mouth. The poster has the Guerrilla Girls' graphic gift and ability to make a general point. It also has their weakness for blanket, us-versus-them statements that inflame passions and make it harder to think about actual, concrete situations.
(The Guerrilla Girls' posters remain up through March; the others remain up through April.)

HEADLINE: CHRONICLE

BYLINE: By SUSAN HELLER ANDERSON

 BODY:
PRESIDENT BUSH presented MARGARET THATCHER with the Presidential Medal of Freedom yesterday in the East Room of the White House. He recalled some advice the former British Prime Minister gave him during a telephone conversation early in the Persian Gulf crisis: "Remember, George: this is no time to go wobbly."
Mrs. Thatcher smiled as the President repeated her words and shifted in her chair as Mr. Bush said he kept her counsel in mind through the months leading up to the liberation of Kuwait.

HEADLINE: Everywhere Flowers And a Topiary World

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON

 BODY:
The New York Flower Show has enough good-smelling greenery to shame a black-thumb gardener whose horticultural aspirations always seem to wither in the original pot on the way home from the neighborhood 5-and-10-cent store. With two acres of blossoms and blooms and trompe l'oeil gardens running the length of a huge pier on the Hudson River, the flower show is the kind of inspiration a luckless amateur needs to pick up a trowel and try again.
After all, every blade of grass at the flower show came in through the door. The weeping pine trees were hauled in from Oregon, the sod from Maryland, the bridal wreaths from Rikers Island. The conversation piece at the Garden Club of America exhibit is the conversation piece azalea. Josyane Colwell, who helped coordinate the display, said she put 3,000 miles on her car finding it, tracking down the right stone for the wall and locating the perfect mulch. 
 After planting and trimming and sculpturing, the exhibitors have hosed the mud off the floor and stowed away the hand trucks on which they wheeled in all the shrubs and flowers. The logistics were so complicated that one nursery in Rockland County in New York tried to deliver what it needed on a barge.
People attending the show, at Pier 92, can come by land.
 
Where the Bears Are
 The sponsor is the New York Horticultural Society, which is raising money for its community-service projects like Greenworks, which keeps a greenhouse on Rikers Island well stocked and well tended by inmates.
Each day will bring a celebration of a different theme. Japan Day, City Gardener Day and Daffodil Day are all on the schedule, with three lectures each day.
And each day will give visitors a peek at unseen props of the city. The Parks Department raided its warehouses and came up with items that no longer grace parks and monuments: an urn designed by McKim, Mead & White, a forest of elegant old-fashioned lampposts and a family of cast-iron bears that had been in a storage room under the Triborough Bridge. Not to worry. They are not as massive or menacing as their grizzly cousins in Alaska.
To someone befuddled by mere begonias, the fantasy world created by the 50 nurseries, florists, plant societies and garden clubs is nothing less than mind boggling.
"People seem to think that you freeze-dry the materials and haul them out of the closet once a year and fluff off the tulips," said Michael Riley of the Horticulture Society.
If only it were that simple. Spring begins in less than two weeks, but in the make-believe world of flower shows, it has to come early. So gardeners simulate spring in hothouses -- they call it forcing the blooms and blossoms -- to produce all those brilliant azaleas, rhododendrons, tulips and daffodils. Never mind global warming and ozone depletion. This is the greenhouse effect.
 
Dorothy's Green Slippers
 Flower shows cut across the social and economic strata of society, offering something for everyone, no matter how elaborate the displays, Mr. Riley said. Someone with a box and a sunny window can come away with planting tips. And someone with a big house and a big budget may borrow ideas from the elegant-looking town house gardens done by interior designers.
One is Cumulus IX, which is Cloud 9 to those who can never remember the names of the fuzzy white shapes in the sky or Roman numerals. It looks like a playful rendering of a Manhattan town house. The equally playful garden comes with mosaic stars and topiary shoes, a green greenhouse.
 
Where and When
 The New York Flower Show is to run through March 17 at Pier 92, 51st Street and the Hudson River in Manhattan. Weekend hours are 10 A.M to 8 P.M. today and 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. tomorrow and Sunday. Tickets are $8 today and $10 tomorrow and Sunday. Information: (212) 757-0915. The Long Island Rail Road is offering a free shuttle bus to the show from Penn Station and reduced admission to the show with a round-trip ticket. Information: (718) 217-5477 or (516) 822-5477.

HEADLINE: Gallery Etiquette: A Duel of Dealers and Browsers

BYLINE: By GRACE GLUECK

 BODY:
WHEN the art dealer Holly Solomon had her gallery on the ground floor of a SoHo building, the scene got so vivid on Saturday afternoons that she put up a sign banning skateboards and fast foods. Then a kiddie stroller collided disastrously with a sculpture, and she added "No Strollers" to the list. Under it, the next day, she found a sardonic scrawl: "No People."
Things are more decorous now that the gallery is tucked away on the fifth floor of an imposing building on Fifth Avenue near 57th Street. But the faceoff between people and art can still be wearing. "I don't like it when they show disrespect for the work," she said, giving voice to a certain tension that exists between dealers and their visitors, a kind of love-hate relationship that can sometimes make the weekend gallerygoing experience in Manhattan a tribulation for both sides. 
 Dealers complain that visitors ask for prices or tips about neighborhood restaurants before they look at the art. They say they let their pets sniff, lick or chew the work, indulge in social chit-chat while they're looking, and request "something pastelly" for their living rooms.
Gallerygoers say that dealers deliberately foster a rarefied atmosphere -- what one calls the "Studio 54 mystique" -- aimed at making visitors feel it's a privilege to enter their precincts; that they assess prospective buyers by the way they are dressed, and that they make them feel, well, insecure about the art they are showing.
"I always check myself over before I visit the Mary Boone Gallery," said Marcia King, a well-groomed painter who actually seems to enjoy looking at other artists' work. "They scrutinize you like they have the profile of who's going to bomb an airplane." Other weekend gallerygoers complain about what they insist is a dress code not only at this particular SoHo emporium, but at many others, uptown and down, in which they say they are not-so-subtly given the onceover by staff members.
"A lot of front-desk people size you up to see if you're stylish enough," said Patti Kolodny of Princeton, N.J. "It's like saying, 'We're very busy; is it worth spending 20 minutes with you, are you going to buy?" With her husband, Frank, she has been collecting contemporary art for 20 years and remembers the good old days when dealers said hello before you bought. "But they're in a retail business, and in this time of recession they're going to have to learn to give real service again," she added.
Mary Boone, whose SoHo establishment does not have a reputation for coziness, is unmoved by such criticism. "If people feel intimidated or uncomfortable, it's because of their own preconceptions," she said. "They buy into cliches about galleries. And I don't subscribe to the idea that people have to be educated in art to look at it. I invite all kinds of communication, except hostility. I don't like people who say, aggressively but in an uninformed way, 'You mean this is art?' "
Dealers also dismiss the idea that they are influenced by what their visitors are wearing. "Believe me, I've found that the more they put on their backs, the less they put into art," said Marilyn Pearl, proprietor of a SoHo gallery bearing her name.
Irving Blum of the Blum Helman Gallery on West 57th Street said he didn't give two hoots about his visitors' get-up. "Once at the Ferus in the 70's," said Mr. Blum, recalling a Los Angeles gallery in which he was a partner, "a flower-generation guy came in wearing a white robe and thongs. He was very interested in a couple of small paintings, and said he'd have to go get the money to buy them. He was back in an hour carrying a bag stuffed with $100 bills. It turned out that his mother was a Brazilian coffee heiress." Since then, Mr. Blum said, he has not paid too much attention to what people are wearing.
 
The Favored Few
 More plaintive than the protests over clothes checks are those about dealers distancing themselves from all but favored clients. At galleries handling the works of sought-after artists -- Jasper Johns, Anselm Kiefer, Eric Fischl and the like -- visitors off the street (called "boardwalk traffic" in the trade) stand little or no chance of buying one, no matter how heavy their wallets. Such works are not sold over the counter; dealers reserve them for museums and other committed, deep-pocket clients who are often themselves on a highly competitive waiting list.
But some dealers don't bother at all, say gallerygoers, with potential buyers of less expensive works. They callously leave them to the tender mercies of the front desk, not going out of their way to greet them or encourage their interest. A lawyer with a mild feeling for art reports that last year he visited a certain SoHo gallery, looked at the paintings on view, then asked the desk clerk for information about the artist and the works. "They're all sold," was the response. Squelched, the lawyer left, his interest in art even milder than before.
But the blame was partly his, in the view of some seasoned buyers. "You don't act meek when you visit a gallery," said Gerald Elliott of Chicago, known for his collection of contemporary art. "If you do that, you never get by the front desk, and that's where the intimidation comes from, the kids sitting at the front desk who have a great degree of self-importance. You have to come into a gallery and assert yourself. If you can crack the front desk and get to the dealer, he or she will probably be genuinely nice. After all, we're through with the 1980's, when business was so good that they could afford to be haughty."
Still, dealers are often at a loss as to how to play host, Holly Solomon suggested. "It's hard for a dealer to decide how friendly to be," she said. "Half the time I figure if people want to say hello, they will. But sometimes they want to be anonymous. I tend to be shy myself, but sometimes I stop to talk, try to be hospitable and courteous and answer questions and maybe sell a painting. But at the same time I want to give people a little air and privacy. It's very tricky."
 
How to Be Sophisticated
 Anyway, how do you crack the staff at the front desk, which may itself be suffering from visitor burn-out? You could snow them with art lingo by boning up on, say, the current issue of Artforum. Use words like "contextualization," and bandy such phrases as "the perfect paradigm for the slippery dialectic between illusion and literality" or, "expressive rhetoric and the knowing stance of style revisited." But this can backfire, like trying your few shards of Hungarian in Budapest. What happens when you're answered in the same language and you've exhausted your repertory?
No, it may be better to do a little homework, as Irving Blum suggests. "It's important to be somewhat knowledgeable," he says. "Otherwise there just isn't enough time for the dealer to come out and focus. Or you can confess your naivete in advance of coming to the gallery. If someone calls me and says I don't know a lot but can I come in when it's convenient for you and get a brief immersion, I wouldn't resist. If you want special attention, you have to do a little homework, then call the dealer and engage him."
Lisa Spellman, proprietor of the 303 Gallery, which deals in some of the more challenging species of contemporary art, feels her SoHo gallery is providing a service in mounting shows. "But we have a small staff," she said, "and I lose my patience when people come in and want an art history seminar, say on the development of figuration through the late 20th century. I tell them to get a library card."
The need for homework is not accepted by some seasoned gallerygoers, however. "I don't think a person has the obligation to study up on an artist," said Norman Dubrow, a collector of contemporary drawings. "There are so many galleries. Dealers have to approach things with a little modesty and respect people's intelligence. They have to understand that everything they're showing isn't a masterpiece; in fact, a lot of it isn't very good."
Buyers who want to display real savvy, Mr. Dubrow advises, should ask for a discount when they are ready to close a sale. "It's so common in the trade," he added. "If they don't want to give it to you, they won't."
 
Buyers' Revenge
 Dealers are more likely to do that these days than they were a year or two ago. There are signs in the current recession that after a 10-year sellers' market, buyers are beginning to exact revenge for having been put on hold. "Now that they sense a weakened moment, they're zeroing in for the kill," said Lisa Spellman. "They're creating an antagonistic atmosphere by canceling or reneging on sales and bargaining for absurd prices. And whereas they bought or are trying to buy at low prices, they're now bringing back works for dealers to sell at highly inflated ones."
But such handwringing does not move Alan Hergott, an entertainment lawyer from Los Angeles, who feels he has had his share of put-downs by New York dealers. "A lot of collectors have been treated badly," he said. "There's been a pecking order, and people have been put on various planes. But the worm is turning, and collectors will have their day."
One of the few dealers that gallerygoers seem to have no quarrel with is the Sonnabend Gallery in SoHo, which gets high marks for hospitality and helpfulness even from dedicated kvetchers. What is Sonnabend's secret? "We really think pretty much about interesting people in what we are interested in," said Antonio Homem, the gallery's co-director. "What we're trying to convey is our enthusiasm for and belief in artists. If there are going to be sales, they'll follow from there."
But even he is a little ambivalent. "I sometimes think if we played a bit harder to get," he said, "people would like it a lot more."

HEADLINE: Level With Labor -- and New York City

 BODY:
Municipal labor leaders are furious, and who can blame them? A misleading memo from New York City's Budget Director, Philip Michael, told a bond rating agency that negotiations were under way to defer part of the wage increases they had just won.
The episode -- an all-too-familiar display of City Hall ineptitude and internal feuding -- is yet more troubling evidence that Mayor David Dinkins still hasn't faced up to the urgency of the city's fiscal crisis, or the need to enlist labor and business in cooperative efforts to solve it. Having agreed to wage settlements the city cannot afford, Mr. Dinkins has yet to muster the courage to fully level with his old political allies in labor about the sacrifices now required for the city's survival, sacrifices he is apparently already counting on. 
 The need for stronger action by City Hall to avert fiscal disaster is underscored by a new report from the State Financial Control Board. It charges that the Mayor's latest financial plan "disguises the persistence of imbalance" and will lead to billion-dollar budget deficits in future years.
Mr. Dinkins says the problem with the memo to Moody's Investors Service was that it suggested negotiations were already under way to defer wages, when the city had only informally broached the subject in general terms with union leaders. That sounds like fudging. The memo was sent last month in an unsuccessful effort to forestall a drop in the city's bond rating. Essentially, City Hall was trying to tell a rating agency what it thought it wanted to hear, just as it was telling the unions what they wanted to hear when it approved higher wages. That's not a fiscal policy; that's incoherence.
The new report from the Financial Control Board makes clear the city's need to find several hundred million dollars in wage and benefit savings, productivity gains and other items. Why, a month after Mr. Michael's memo, have there still been no concrete talks about deferring wages?
New York's municipal labor leaders, and the employees they represent, were crucial partners in helping the city through the 1975 fiscal crisis. When tempers cool, there is reason to hope they will again rally to save the city. But that can't happen unless the Mayor unambiguously owns up to the reality of the situation, and develops a sound fiscal plan.

HEADLINE: Fine, 100 Days. But for What?

 BODY:
The challenge President Bush put to Congress Wednesday could hardly have been plainer. We have won the war in the gulf, he said. Now we must apply the same urgency and self-discipline "here at home." Then, invoking F.D.R., he sharpened the challenge: "If our forces could win the ground war in 100 hours, then surely the Congress can pass this legislation in 100 days."
What legislation? Mr. Bush's roar brought forth two mice: a crime bill that would do little to fight crime. And a proposal to repair old roads and build new ones. Hardly a vision to send the Congressional troops charging out of the trenches. 
 Nobody could reasonably have denied George Bush his night in the sun, his right to savor the accolades for orchestrating the Persian Gulf war. And what a night it was: a pep rally and the State of the Union rolled into one, with flag-wearing Republicans and even dyspeptic Democrats on their feet, applauding again and again.
Mr. Bush resisted the temptation to criticize those in Congress who had opposed the war. He struck exactly the right notes about converting the "horrors of war" into a new "momentum for peace," especially peace between Israelis and Arabs. He was also right to summon Congress to convert triumph abroad into renewal at home. Yet it quickly became clear that Mr. Bush has either no coherent idea of how to do that or no compelling desire to do so.
The subjects of Mr. Bush's domestic proposals are worthy enough, although he might have chosen other examples to adumbrate his vision. The crime bill is in part a sop to death penalty advocates, and does nothing about the availability of the weapons that create so much urban carnage. The transportation plan would promote new highways but shortchange mass transit. Given the nation's energy and environmental concerns, Mr. Bush seems to have his priorities backward.
Yet even if these were sterling proposals, what kind of agenda do they make? True, there's not a lot of money lying around for big domestic initiatives. But that's all the more reason to ask for a sharper sense of priorities from the White House. The big problems are not hard to identify: a medical care system hopelessly out of control, states and cities staggering under impossible burdens, an educational system that leaves the nation increasingly vulnerable to international competition.
The public sees the discontinuity between Mr. Bush's strength abroad and his diffidence at home. He gets extraordinarily high marks for his handling of foreign policy -- 83 percent approval, according to today's New York Times/CBS Poll. Yet he fails to persuade even a bare majority that he's really interested in doing something about the economy or drugs or education.
There was a point in the speech when Mr. Bush, honoring the soldiers, came close to acknowledging the discrepancy. "We hear so often about our young people in turmoil, how our children fall short, how our schools fail us, how American products and American workers are second class. Well don't you believe it. The America we saw in Desert Storm was first-class talent."
It was indeed first class. And why? One reason, of course, was the dedication and spirit of the American forces. But another, surely, was that Mr. Bush gave them conviction, clarity of purpose and a gambler's courage. That is the job of a leader. At home, too.

HEADLINE: Hard Passage in India

 BODY:
India's politicians emerge with little glory from the quarrels that have brought down Prime Minister Chandra Shekhar's minority Government. If they now maneuver to avoid elections, Mr. Shekhar's opponents can only deepen a crisis that has shaken the world's most populous democracy.
Giving the people a chance to judge their rulers has for the first time become prevailing practice elsewhere in the Indian subcontinent. Pakistan and Bangladesh have each recently transferred power through democratic elections, and tiny Nepal is about to follow suit by conducting the first contested elections in three decades. 
 When India last voted in 1989, an ambivalent electorate turned against Rajiv Gandhi's Congress Party but failed to give a majority to any of its rivals. Successive Prime Ministers -- V. P. Singh and then Mr. Shekhar -- formed wobbly coalitions or minority regimes, each weakened by corrupting intrigues and venal party-switching. The result was disarray as India was shaken by separatist risings, communal clashes between Hindus and Muslims, and an economic crisis heightened by the Persian Gulf conflict.
Initially supported by Mr. Gandhi, Mr. Shekhar has turned bitterly against his former ally. Their breach ostensibly is owed to a petty scandal -- the posting by a local government of police snoopers outside Mr. Gandhi's home. More substantive was an earlier quarrel over the Government's agreement to refuel American military aircraft headed for the gulf. Mr. Shekhar insisted they were carrying non-lethal cargo, but Mr. Gandhi and Mr. Singh said this still collided with India's nonalignment.
What matters most from an American vantage is the promise of an election that can yield a stable government. Having led the way to self-government in South Asia, it would be curious indeed for India to evade the normal remedy for failure: a vote.

HEADLINE: ON MY MIND;
Break the Boycott

BYLINE: By A. M. Rosenthal

 BODY:
The high-level emergency meeting of the Arab nations was held in private, in Damascus. It was called to deal with just one subject: the economic strangulation of Israel.
Representatives of Iraq and Kuwait were at the table, eagerly taking part. That was in July of 1990. 
 A couple of weeks later, the Iraqis gave the Kuwaitis something else to think about. Saddam Hussein taught them that their real enemy was not the distant Jewish nation but the Muslim neighbor next-door.
Now the very viciousness of the destruction of Kuwait gives its people and its Government the chance to bring peace an important step closer -- by turning away from that meeting in Damascus and what it means.
A little history. In 1948 the Arab nations imposed a boycott and embargo against Israel. Any company in the world that trades with Israel or makes any investment in the country is forbidden to do any business with any Arab state -- no oil deals, no investments, no exports or imports, no construction contracts, nothing.
The embargo has been a shackle on the Israeli economy. For foreign investors it meant lost opportunities. But for the Arab governments it is a fine way of controlling businesses around the world, including huge multinational corporations. And not incidentally, it gives the Arab states extra clout with trade-hungry governments -- Germany and Japan among many others.
The Damascus meeting was held at the request of the Palestine Liberation Organization to expand the boycott to any company that helps Soviet Jews settle in Israel. That would mean transportation, housing construction, insurance, hotel space, anything.
A half-year later, Kuwait is burning. It will cost at least $50 billion to reconstruct the country -- money Kuwait will draw from its enormous foreign holdings.
Will Kuwait continue the boycott and prevent companies doing business with Israel from getting reconstruction contracts?
Under U.S. law, American companies cannot tell the Arabs whether they do business with Israel. Now and then the Arabs decide that a particular American company is too important to them to blacklist even if it does business with Israel -- like weapons manufacturers or communications giants.
But most companies don't take chances. In the United States and the rest of the world an astounding number of companies have decided they are not interested in profitable business -- Israeli business. The Japanese have shown a particular aversion and Japan Air Lines can't seem to find Israel on the map.
The embargo became more powerful with the growth of multinational companies. Some of these huge multinationals specialize in the massive kind of construction Kuwait will need. They parcel out work to hundreds of smaller companies. Those known to do business with Israel don't get subcontracts.
 It will not be enough for the Kuwaitis to remain silent or allow a few companies that do have some business with Israel to take part in the rebuilding. Without a clear statement, business will assume the boycott continues, just as if the Persian Gulf war never happened.
American companies that do business with Israel stand to lose billions in Kuwaiti contracts. For their employees, that will be more emotional a matter than the Kuwaiti kisses planted on American soldiers.
Contracts are not nearly as important as the Kuwaiti opportunity to take one step toward Mideast conciliation. A couple of days ago I asked the Kuwaiti Embassy in Washington what Kuwait intended to do, and await a reply.
 I am not brimming over with optimism. The Kuwaiti Government has shown a taste for particular nastiness about Israel. But then I think -- Saddam Hussein and the P.L.O. opened a lot of Kuwaiti minds. Maybe they also opened some Kuwaiti hearts to the truth about friends and enemies.
 President Bush talked to Congress about the Arab-Israeli conflict, and the Palestinians. Immediately his words were interpreted as a threat to Israel. But it is better to wait, think and talk before pronouncing.
In any case, Mr. Bush knows no settlement can be imposed. Even Stormin' Norman can't help here. And he knows that nothing at all will move until the Arab states take a step that will cost them not a soldier, not a drop of oil, not an inch of land: ending the state of war with Israel.
Right now, the U.S., liberator of the Kuwaitis, has both the right and duty to ask them to do their part by turning the boycott, an act and weapon of war, into scrap.

HEADLINE: Guidepost;
Money in the Bank

 BODY:

How safe is your money when a bank or savings and loan institution fails? Federal regulators have a three-option plan: the institution can be sold, closed or its deposits transferred to another institution. Here is a guide to how depositors fare in each instance.
 
Closure: All accounts are closed; all insured depositors' money and any earned interest will be returned. 
 Sale: All accounts are automatically reopened with the new owner, often including uninsured balances over $100,000. The new bank or thrift has the option of lowering pre-existing C.D. rates, at which point the money can be withdrawn without penalty.
 
Transfer: Same conditions as sale, except that only insured amounts on deposit are usually transferred. Amounts above the insured amount of $100,000 could be at risk.
 
Source: Bank Rate Monitor, N. Palm Beach, Fla.

HEADLINE: Romanian Money Rules

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: BUCHAREST, Romania, March 8

 BODY:
Officials announced today that most restrictions on foreign exchange in Romania would be abolished in an effort to heal the economy and curb the black market.
The move is part of a package recommended by the International Monetary Fund, which will give Romania roughly $1 billion in aid on the condition that it swiftly puts a free market in place. 
 The national bank director, Mugur Isarescu, said the first installment of the grant was a $300 million loan from the Bank of International Settlements, which includes the national banks of the leading industrialized nations. The United States Federal Reserve provided $40 million of the loan, he said.
Mr. Isarescu said that beginning in April, some organizations and individuals would be permitted to trade in foreign currency through several authorized banks.
The national bank began experimental hard-currency trading in February, but it was limited to approved import-export companies.
The Government also plans to remove price controls on food in April, leaving energy as the only important area that will still be subsidized.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Strong Advance by Dollar Surprises Many Traders

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar staged a surprisingly strong advance yesterday despite declining interest rates and further negative data on the United States economy.
Traders said there was a strong demand for dollars on markets around the world, and many were puzzled by the keen interest in the currency. 
 The Labor Department's report on unemployment in February showed the jobless rate higher than expected, climbing to 6.5 percent from 6.2 percent in January.
Payrolls fell by 184,000 in February, the seventh straight month that more industries cut jobs than added them. Some traders were braced for a decline of 200,000 jobs, which may have accounted for the report's lack of effect on the dollar.
"Some are saying the bad news was priced in," said Jim McGroarty, a senior vice president at Greenwich Capital Markets in Greenwich, Conn.
Later, analysts said, the Federal Reserve acted to push interest rates lower, another factor that is typically negative for the dollar, because lower American interest rates make investments in dollar-denominated securities less attractive. The central bank's move to add reserves to the banking system was widely interpreted as a signal that it had embarked on another round of easing credit.
Some traders speculated that much of the demand for the dollar was coming from the Middle East, since market fundamentals would call for a lower dollar.
Gilbert Cisneros, a trader at the Bank of Boston's office in New York, said there were reports that dollar-buying was coming from Kuwait, which, he said, "needs to buy a lot of dollars to pay for reconstruction."
In Tokyo, the dollar rose 0.67 yen, to a closing 136.30 yen. Later in London, it was quoted lower at 136.20 yen. In New York the dollar settled at 136.82 yen, up from 135.65 yen on Thursday.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.8720, from $1.8865 late Thursday. In New York, it cost $1.8645 to buy a pound, cheaper than the $1.8885 on Thursday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Thursday's rates, included: 1.5700 German marks, up from 1.5460; 1.3692 Swiss francs, up from 1.3480; 5.3515 French francs, up from 5.2645; 1,174.00 Italian lire, up from 1,154.50, and 1.1614 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1594.
Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Thursday's rates, included: 1.5625 German marks, up from 1.5465; 1.3640 Swiss francs, up from 1.3495; 5.3210 French francs, up from 5.2675; 1.7610 Dutch guilders, up from 1.7430; 1,167.50 Italian lire, up from 1,155.25, and 1.1618 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1595.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Silver Soars and Gold Is Up; Near-Term Oil Prices Dip

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Silver futures prices soared yesterday, marking a partial recovery from 17-year lows, as hopes for an economic turnaround continued.
Silver futures settled up 19.2 cents to 21.2 cents on the Commodity Exchange in New York, with the contract for delivery in March at $4.162 an ounce, the highest daily settlement of spot silver since Jan. 16. The March contract traded as high as $4.195 during the session. 
 Gold prices also advanced. Gold for current delivery rose $2.80 an ounce to settle at $369.70 on the Commodity Exchange. The April contract was at $371.20 a troy ounce. The Republic National Bank's late bid for gold was $369.50, up $2.90.
 
 Platinum Finishes Higher
 Platinum was $10.80 to $10.90 higher on the New York Mercantile Exchange, with the April contract at $411.40 an ounce.
Near-term crude oil futures fell slightly on the New York Mercantile Exchange in quiet dealings before next week's OPEC meeting.
Traders sold positions near the end of the day, partly to hedge against changes in the market when the members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries meet on Monday in Geneva to discuss crude production.
Light sweet crude oil ended 14 cents lower to 6 cents higher, with April at $19.31 a barrel. Heating oil was 0.16 cent to 0.49 cent lower, with April at 55.39 cents a gallon. Unleaded gasoline was 0.64 cent lower to 0.55 cent higher, with April at 69.98 cents a gallon. Natural gas was 1 cent lower to 0.7 cent higher, with April at $1.359 per 1,000 cubic feet.
 
Rose on Recovery Hopes
 Silver and platinum prices have risen sharply since late February on a belief that the end of the Persian Gulf war will speed an economic recovery in the United States and raise industrial demand for those metals. Unemployment figures for February showed continuing economic weakness, however, and prompted the Federal Reserve to lower an important interest rate.
Don Tierney, metals analyst with Fortune Commodities Inc., said lower interest rates to stimulate industrial production had helped silver and platinum.

LENGTH: 648 words

HEADLINE: Bond Prices Swing Wildly and End Lower

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
The Treasury securities market was buffeted by wild price swings yesterday, with dealers citing confusion about the apparent easing of credit by the Federal Reserve. The Fed did lower a key interest rate, but confusion remained.
Those who believed the Fed had indeed eased credit cited the systemwide infusion of reserves into the banking system at a time when most banks appeared well stocked with money. They also noted that the central bank moved to add reserves at 11:27 A.M., a few minutes earlier than it normally intervened in the credit market. For many Fed watchers such subtle moves are taken as bold statements. 
 "Of course the Fed eased interest rates, because any time the central system injects a large amount of reserves, interest rates will come under pressure," said William V. Sullivan Jr., senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds, and a leading credit market expert. "But there are still people in the Street who have their doubts. The doubters weren't the only ones who contributed to the disarray we witnessed today."
 
 Fair Buying Overnight
 As Mr. Sullivan reconstructed the volatile session, he noted that Treasury bonds had enjoyed fair buying support overnight in Tokyo and Europe and were expected to extend their gains when the New York market opened, on the strength of expectations that a Government's report on employment would show the jobless rate rising. That in turn would allay inflation fears.
When the Government reported at 8:30 that unemployment in February soared three-tenths of a percentage point, to 6.5 percent, a four-year high, bond prices rose sharply, with the Treasury's benchmark long bond quickly soaring to what was to be its high during the day, 96 20/32.
In late trading, however, the bellwether long bonds, the 7 7/8 percent issue maturing in February 2021, were being offered at 95 9/32, down 31/32 on the day, after hitting a low of 95 6/32. At 95 9/32, the long bond's yield climbed to 8.30 percent, from 8.21 percent the day before and 8.27 percent one week ago.
 
Roiled by Debate
 "Between the high and low," Mr. Sullivan continued, "the market was roiled not only by the debate over whether the Fed had eased or whether it had made a statement to that effect, but also by reports that Middle East interests were unloading some of the huge amount of Treasury bonds they bought when Iraq invaded Kuwait. Finally, there was the latest University of Michigan survey indicating a revival of consumer confidence."
What was not in question was that the Federal Reserve added a large amount of funds to the banking system through weekend repurchase agreements. These "repo" operations involve the Fed's purchase of Treasury securities, mostly bills and short-term notes, from dealers and some other financial entities, with the clear understanding that the sellers will buy back them back at the stated time.
The purpose of the exercise is to cause a large amount of funds to be deposited at once into banks by the "sellers." When the Fed wants to drain reserves from the banking system, it effects reverse repos, also referred to as matched sales, under the same terms, which in both cases make it financially worthwhile for the dealers and other participants.
 
Aimed at Funds Rate

In either case, Fed repo operations are really aimed at moving what is referred to as the Federal funds rate up or down. The funds rate is what banks charge one another for temporary loans and is thus considered the basic cost of credit. In theory, all other interest rates are based on the funds rate. The funds rate is also the only interest rate the Fed has direct control over.
When the Fed intervened, funds were trading at 6 1/8 percent, below the 6 1/4 percent level that has recently been perceived as the rate favored by the Fed. This also contributed to the belief the Fed was easing credit.

HEADLINE: Needed for Tough Times: A $75 Tie

BYLINE: By ISADORE BARMASH

 BODY:
For 77 years, American men of means have bought suits bearing the label of Oxxford Clothes, probably the nation's highest-priced domestic suits, at $1,100 to $2,500 each.
Now Oxxford, feeling the recession's pinch and hedged in by a self-limiting market, is looking to pick up some extra revenue by expanding its offerings to shirts, ties and cologne. 
 But will customers impressed by the Oxxford name and quality be willing to pay $100 for a shirt and $60 to $75 for a tie?
Jack R. McDonald, president of the Chicago-based Oxxford, thinks so. For the first time in its long history, his company is planning to add other items to go with its suits in stores like Bergdorf Goodman, Tripler's, Saks Fifth Avenue and Barneys New York.
The new products are not being sold yet. In fact, Mr. McDonald is still looking for shirt, neckwear and other companies whose standards are high and that are willing to be acquired.
The Oxxford strategy to diversify into new products that would bear its brand name has been tried by others. But most brand transfers are accomplished through licensing and most fail, because the brand extension is too far afield from the original brand.
Hallmark Cards and Benson & Hedges tried to extend their brand names into luxury ball point pens, but the tests were not especially successful. Cartier jewelry granted a license to a company producing Cartier cigarettes, but that effort never took off.
In Oxxford's case, Mr. McDonald said he felt confident of his plan because the additions would be closely related to the original product, would attract the same customers and would be made by acquired companies, giving the parent the opportunity for direct quality control.
Despite what he called chaotic business conditions, Mr. McDonald said Oxxford's sales were ahead about 4 percent this year over the same time in 1990. He conceded, though, that the increase included a price rise to cover an October labor-rate increase and higher wool prices. That means his sales are essentially down.
Asked if slow business was a reason for the plan to diversify, Mr. McDonald acknowledged that it was but said it was not the main one.
 
 Pressure From Retailers
 "The real pressure comes from retailers who have been asking us to make other products," he said.
"We think that the combination of new products can add $10 million to $15 million to our present annual sales of $25 million," he said in a recent interview while visiting New York. "This should be accomplished within the year. The major problem is finding products with the appropriate quality that we put into our suits."
Some retailers confirmed their interest in new Oxxford lines.
"Aside from the competitive shirts and ties we 'marry' with Oxxford suits, I think our customers would welcome haberdashery with the Oxxford label," said John Fresco, vice president and merchandise manager for men's wear at Saks. "Some of our customers and our salespeople have been asking if this would be available."
Fred Pressman, president of Barneys, said: "If Oxxford would show us their own shirts and ties, I'd be interested in buying them. Their products represent the finest quality, and I'm sure that the new ones would be similar."
 
 High Degree of Handwork
 Oxxford's reputation for a quality that matches its high prices comes largely from the high degree of handwork and the expensive, imported fabrics it uses.
Oxxford garments are produced only when an order for them is received from the retailer. The suits are 90 percent handmade, with only the seams constructed by machine to reinforce them. Each garment is divided into sections, so that specialists among the 385 workers in the Chicago factory can develop strong skills in making each part of the suit.
Most clothing makers sell to several thousand retailers, but Oxxford restricts its distribution to 102 retailers who operate 165 stores because, Mr. McDonald said, department stores and others are not equipped adequately to sell and support the Oxxford line.
 
 No Sales Staff
 Also unusual is that Oxxford has no sales staff. It does all of its selling from its headquarters on Van Buren Street in Chicago. Store buyers visit that showroom twice a year to place orders, for spring and summer and for fall and winter.
Oxxford was founded in 1914 by Louis and Jack Weinberg, who decided on the distinctive spelling of Oxxford so as to differentiate it from the Oxford Manufacturing Company, a Southern clothing maker, and oxford cloth, a soft but durable fabric. One of its first big retail customers was Neiman Marcus, the Dallas-based specialty-store chain, where in 1960 Mr. McDonald, who is from Chicago, became vice president.
In the mid-1960's when the Weinberg brothers began thinking of retirement, Mr. McDonald became concerned about what might happen to Oxxford's quality under new owners and suggested to Stanley Marcus, then chairman of Neiman Marcus, that he consider buying the company. Instead, the company was purchased by Byer-Rolnick, the hat and apparel maker in Dallas, which promptly decided on a new president -- Mr. McDonald.
Oxxford Clothes is now owned by Thomas H. Lee, the Boston financier who is also a large shareholder in other companies; the Harvard University Endowment Fund; Mr. McDonald, and four others.

HEADLINE: Economic Lift Is Predicted

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: PARIS, March 8

 BODY:
The end of the Persian Gulf war should lift the world's leading industrial economies out of a slowdown, a senior German monetary official said today.
Lower oil prices and increasing private sector confidence will contribute to stronger second-quarter growth, said Hans Tietmeyer, a member of the board of the Bundesbank, German' central bank.
Mr. Tietmeyer and top monetary officials of the 24-nation Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development met here Thursday and today to discuss the postwar economy.
"We're seeing more arguments in favor of a new upturn than of a global recession," Mr. Tietmeyer said, adding that prospects are better for 1992 than for 1991.
Officials at the meeting stressed the need for the United States and other countries, including Germany, to cut their budget deficits.

HEADLINE: Latest Victim of Airline Slump

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, March 8

 BODY:
The hard times in the airline industry claimed another victim today when Air Europe, a large British carrier, and its parent, the International Leisure Group Ltd., sought bankruptcy protection from creditors and grounded the airline's fleet, stranding 25,000 people.
And in another sign that airlines expect no quick recovery from the severe downturn gripping the industry, British Airways, Britain's largest airline, said it was withdrawing from five unprofitable routes. It is ending service between Gatwick Airport near London and Stockholm; Barcelona; Karachi, Pakistan; Banjul, Gambia, and Freetown, Sierra Leone. 
 British Airways had previously announced that it would withdraw from other routes, make big cuts in its work force and delay the delivery of ordered planes. "Since then, the situation has not improved and we have had to look closely at further uneconomic parts of the route network," Liam Strong, director of marketing and operations at British Airways, said today.
 
 'A Bad Omen'

Although dwarfed by British Airways, Air Europe expanded quickly and became Britain's second-largest scheduled international carrier. It has a fleet of 37 planes, 2,000 employees and offered scheduled service to 19 destinations in Europe, mostly from Gatwick Airport but also from Manchester. It also offered charter service in Europe and to Orlando, Fla.; North Africa, and East Asia.
Analysts said Air Europe was in the vanguard of the new airlines trying to exploit the opportunities created by the continuing deregulation of the European airline industry. The market is dominated by a handful of large carriers, most of which are at least partly owned by governments.
"The financial collapse of Air Europe is a bad omen because what it in effect says is the cost of entering the market is prohibitive," said Richard Whitaker, editor of Airline Business, a trade magazine. "Air Europe offered real competition because it flew head to head with major carriers on major routes like Paris and Brussels and offered cheaper fares."
Peter Bergius, an analyst at Kleinwort Benson Securities Ltd., commented, "There will be other small airlines that go under or are forced to link with others." A small German carrier, German Wings, went out of business last year and a small British carrier, Dan-Air, is struggling.
Air Europe was founded in the late 1970's by Harry Goodman, a British entrepreneur who first focused on providing packaged holidays for Britons and then expanded into scheduled service. He hoped that by building a fleet of fuel-efficient planes, Air Europe would be able to capture business from the high-cost European giant airlines that dominate the market.
He seemed to be well on his way to succeeding. In the year that ended Oct. 31, Air Europe carried 3.7 million scheduled and chartered passengers.
Mr. Whitaker of Airline Business said Air Europe's scheduled service was similar in quality to that of the big airlines while the fares were about 15 percent less for business-class seats and about 10 percent less in the economy class.
The packaged holiday companies owned by International Leisure, which include Intasun, Select, Global and Lancaster, are collectively No. 2 in the business in Britain. But the company was pushed into a crisis by the combination of large debt, a sharp decline in the packaged holiday market that began in 1989, and the rise in fuel costs and the plunge in travelers because of the Persian Gulf conflict and the recession in Britain.
 
'Ran Out of Cash'

"It turned out to be too much, and they ran out of cash," said Timothy Hayward, head of corporate recovery at KPMG Peat Marwick McLintock, the accounting firm. Mr. Hayward, one of the court-appointed administrators for International Leisure, was pessimistic that the group would survive. He said it was more likely that its parts would be sold and said several airlines, which he declined to identify, had expressed interest.
Citibank disclosed today that a syndicate of 14 banks that it led had asked the court to appoint an administrative receiver to take control of 12 leased aircraft to cover the group's exposure to International Leisure. Others said the exposure was $315 million, which a banker confirmed.
Citibank said in a statement that the banks took action only after "we were advised by International Leisure Group that they had not been successful in raising the additional finance required for continuation of its operations."
Mr. Hayward also said the action by the banks "was not the cause of the company's collapse."
International Leisure is privately owned and does not regularly release financial figures. It said in its court filing that it had lost 50 million ($98.3 million) from November through January. Mr. Hayward said the group had total liabilities of 480 million, of which 200 million was related to leased planes. Its liabilities exceed its assets by 15.4 million, he said.
 
A Long Struggle
 The company was known to have been struggling for a long time and had acknowledged that it was talking with Lloyds Bank and several large shareholders about financial relief. It recently withdrew its applications to offer service to New York, Los Angeles, the Caribbean, Toronto and Vancouver, British Columbia.
Mr. Goodman seemed to get a reprieve in January, when Lloyds agreed to a plan that would have converted an overdraft of 50 million into equity. While the conversion has not yet been put into effect, Brian Butler, a Lloyds spokesman, said today's decision to seek bankruptcy protection was not the result of a change of mind by Lloyds.
"We certainly haven't withdrawn our support in any way at all," Mr. Butler said. "We're disappointed that the company has had to cease operations. We tried to find a way forward and will continue to do so."

GRAPHIC: Photo: At Gatwick Airport outside London yesterday, an employee of Air Europe gave one passenger the bad news that the airline had grounded its fleet, stranding him and thousands of others. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Dinkins Plans a New Group To Address Fiscal Troubles

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins plans to call together bankers, realtors, labor and other civic leaders in a group modeled after the bailout effort that pulled New York through the fiscal crisis of the 1970's, the First Deputy Mayor announced last night.
The First Deputy, Norman Steisel, said the Mayor decided to call a broad group together amid concerns that the city's fiscal problems were worsening and could require budget cuts that dwarf those of the mid-1970's. 
 "It is definitely time to rekindle the sense of purpose and spirit of '76," Mr. Steisel said.
 
Looking Ahead to 1993
 The announcement followed increasing pressure from both the business community and labor for the Mayor to take a stronger leadership stand on the city's fiscal affairs. Mr. Dinkins has been so much on the defensive recently that yesterday, on a live radio call-in show on WKRS-FM, he felt compelled to say for the first time that he intended to run for re-election in 1993, putting on notice any who would write his political obituary amid his current troubles.
"If I'm going to be Mayor and take all this heat during this time," he said, "I certainly intend to be around when things are better."
It was not clear whether the new fiscal coalition would be a public relations effort or play a central role in the budget process. During the mid-1970's, the group became a quasi-official body that helped shape the city's financial plans.
He said the Mayor would reveal more about the group in the next few days.
Last week, a group of the Mayor's advisers in the business community warned him that he was not dealing forcefully with gathering fiscal problems and urged him to form a coalition of important New Yorkers.
The business officials presented their warnings to the Mayor at a private meeting at Gracie Mansion. The meeting was described both by members of the Mayor's own top staff and the business leaders who spread word of it as an opportunity to try to get the Mayor's attention focused on a problem they worry he is not dealing with aggressively enough.
"In the 1970's we reached a point where we realized that problems went beyond politics and something dramatic had to happen," said Howard Rubenstein, a public relations executive who attended the meeting and served as an adviser to former Mayor Abraham D. Beame in the 1970's. "I think we are at that point now. The Mayor still has a reservoir of good will that can work for him. He has to come up with a courageous plan where everybody will bleed a little."
Municipal union leaders who were not at the meeting said they shared many of the sentiments of the business officials and have been meeting regularly with them for months.
Pressure for a forum to tackle the city's fiscal problems has been rising as the city's fiscal problems worsened.
At no time has this heightened concern been better illustrated, union leaders said, than when the administration appeared to fumble a plan this week to get city workers to defer portions of a wage increase to balance the budget, an approach last used in the 1970's. Union leaders who helped get the Mayor elected denounced him in personal terms Wednesday after learning from reporters about the deferral plan in a confidential memorandum prepared for a bond rating agency.
While the cries of backstabbing and betrayal may reflect a fair measure of union politics and posturing, they also conveyed a continuing complaint from labor leaders: that the administration had not brought the unions into a process that will prepare them for painful sacrifices in the future.
 
'It Will Never Make a Quilt'
 "What is missing is the spirit, the dynamics, the cohesiveness and the structures of the 1970's," said Jack Bigel, who was a major labor adviser in the 1970's and plays the same role today. "My heavens, their current approach is a kind of crazy patchwork. They are laying off. They are hiring. It will never make a quilt. I don't think we ever had any real in-depth discussions with them."
City Hall officials bristled at any suggestion that they have not been willing to take tough budget moves, even as they warned that New Yorkers will likely face far deeper budget cuts than they have seen to date. They said they welcomed an opportunity to strengthen ties with both business and labor.
"We have an economic crisis here that is creating a budgetary crisis and its impact is going to be much worse, proportionately greater, than we saw in the 70's," Mr. Steisel said.
While the administration has not calmed the concerns of municipal unions worried about layoffs and cutbacks, business leaders and fiscal analysts say he has failed to mollify them as well. They have watched, they say, the administration take a series of lurching steps; raising salaries of city workers, slashing services, announcing and then averting layoffs, negotiating wage deferrals to take away some of the wage increases already granted.
At the Gracie Mansion meeting, members of the Mayor's council of economic advisers warned that without strong leadership, the city could lose thousands of businesses and jobs. Companies, they said, were increasingly concerned about the prospect of rising taxes and declining services with no clear solutions in sight.
Raymond D. Horton, director of research for the Citizen's Budget Commission, a research group supported by the business community, said he has begun to see alarming similarities, between Mr. Beame's struggle through the early stages of the last fiscal crisis and how Mr. Dinkins is responding now: continued unfounded optimism, a series of halting steps that are rescinded and reactivated, the heads of municipal unions not convinced there is a problem and engaging in bargaining strategies and successes that make the problem worse.
"I don't think the Mayor has ever said there is a crisis and I think this is a very salient point," Mr. Horton said.
City officials say the administration has repeatedly met with union leader to discuss layoffs, and had set up a joint labor-business group that has been meeting regularly to study productivity improvements.
"If there is yet another forum that jells the whole thing, we are willing and able," said Philip R. Michael, the city's Budget Director. "We may have reached a critical mass and it is time to roll up the sleeves put aside parochial interests and hammer out a solution."
So far the administration's published financial plans call for more than $1 billion in tax increases and a reduction of more than 6,000 jobs from the current payroll level. But city officials have become increasingly gloomy, warning of far deeper job cuts when Mayor Dinkins issues his budget next month.
The crisis in the 1970's was clearly worse in some ways -- the city was unable to sell its bonds, and was found to have been hiding billions of dollars in deficits, by selling bonds and notes to cover operating expenses.
But many business and labor leaders said that the threat of imminent default on city bonds was a powerful force that brought groups together.
Yesterday at a council budget hearing, Herbert E. Berman, chairman of the City Council Finance Committee, questioned Mr. Dinkins's approach to the city's deficit.
"I believe that there is a tendency to not want to deal with this and I believe it's the wrong way to go," Mr. Berman of Brooklyn, said yesterday.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
 The nation's employment picture de teriorated significantly last month, with pay rolls shrinking and the jobless rate rising to its highest point in nearly four years. Hoping to give the economy a boost, the Federal Re serve responded to the news of worsening re cession by lowering a key interest rate an other notch. [Page 1.] Thousands of state and municipal workers have been dismissed or are threatened with layoffs across the country, particularly in the Northeast, as states try to eliminate budget deficits. [8.]
In what appears to be a serious setback for TV networks, a majority of the F.C.C. now favors continuing to limit the networks' ability to sell reruns. The issue has been the subject of an intense lobbying war between the networks and Hollywood studios. [1.] 
 An F.D.A. study group is mulling the future of over-the-counter capsules in the wake of a new rash of drug tampering. [28.]
 
 Companies
Pan Am's operations could be shut down as early as next week if U.S. and British negotiators fail to reach an agreement that would allow Pan Am to transfer its London routes to United. [29.]
Hard times in the airline industry claimed another victim. Air Europe sought bankruptcy protection and grounded its fleet. [29.]
American Airlines has delayed delivery of a second MD-11 from McDonnell Douglas while the manufacturer seeks to solve problems with the plane's cockpit computer. [32.]
Great Western Financial agreed to acquire 28 branches of Lincoln Savings from the Federal Government for $12.1 million. [29.]
NCR's chairman said that his position had not changed and that he still considered A.T.& T.'s $90-a-share offer inadequate. [29.]
For 77 years, Oxxford Clothes has made what are probably the nation's highest-priced domestic suits. Oxxford is now looking to expand its offerings to shirts, ties and cologne. [29.]
Robert Maxwell made public how much he must save if he takes over The Daily News -- a figure that works out to more than $70 million a year. Unions acknowledged that such an amount would mean deep cuts, but welcomed a target for negotiations. [27.]
An appeals court dismissed an urgent request by the Justice Department to prevent public disclosure of the secret $1.2 billion agreement to settle claims from the Exxon Valdez oil spill. [9.]
Leslie H. Wexner of The Limited has given $250 million to support a broad range of organizations and programs. [10.]
 
 Markets
The Treasury securities market was buffeted by price swings, with dealers citing confusion about the Fed's easing of credit. [33.]
Stocks dropped sharply in the final two hours of trading to end in minus territory. The Dow industrial average ended at 2,955.20, off 8.17. For the week the Dow advanced 45.30, or 1.6 percent. [33.]
The dollar staged a surprisingly strong advance despite declining interest rates and further negative data on the economy. [39.]
Prices of silver futures soared, marking a partial recovery from 17-year lows. [39.]

Amgen has won a stunning victory in its feud with Genetics Institute. But an appeals court did not address an interesting issue in the case: Should a patent based on isolating a natural protein cover its manufacture through genetic engineering? Patents. [30.]
Many people have trouble handling personal finances. A Citibank seminar offered tips. Your Money. [30.]

HEADLINE: News Summary

After the War 4-6
The United States warned Iraq not to use chemical weapons to put down rebellions after intelligence agencies intercepted orders from Baghdad authorizing chemical bombardments in two cities, officials said. Page 1
