HEADLINE: Many Public Employees Out of Jobs As Governments Try to Stem Deficits

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NORWOOD, Mass.

 BODY:
At this time of the year, Rita Caulfield could usually be found on weekday mornings poring over tax filings in the Boston assessor's office, where she worked as an analyst. Instead, on a snowy New England morning Mrs. Caulfield was in line at the Massachusetts Employment and Training office in this Boston suburb, waiting to receive her unemployment check.
"This is a pretty sad ending for somebody who's been working all her life," said Mrs. Caulfield, 71 years old, who was laid off three days after Christmas. "I know we're entitled to the money, but I feel like I'm accepting some form of charity." 
 Mrs. Caulfield is not alone in her dismissal these days.
 
Many Are in Similar Straits
 Around the country, and particularly in the Northeast, thousands of state and municipal workers have been dismissed or are threatened with layoffs as states desperately try to eliminate yawning budget deficits.
Mrs. Caulfield considers her situation particularly galling because 15 years ago she gave up a struggling real estate and insurance business for what she thought would be the security of government employment. Now she finds herself out of work and, because of her age, she believes she has little hope of finding another job.
In addition, Mrs. Caulfield lost her government job before she had accumulated enough years to build up an adequate retirement pension. She has sued the state of Massachusetts over the dismissal, charging age discrimination.
The precise number of government workers who will be let go is not yet known because belt-tightening plans drawn up by a number of governors have yet to be approved by state legislatures. But officials at the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees estimate that at least 50,000 state and local jobs could be lost nationwide through layoffs and early retirements.
In New York, where 1,000 workers have already been laid off in the last few months, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo has talked of a further 10 percent reduction in the state's work force of about 180,000 employee in the next fiscal year.
Pennsylvania recently removed about 1,500 workers from its payroll. And in Massachusetts, Gov. William F. Weld's budget for the fiscal year 1992 calls for the elimination of nearly 7,600 state jobs.
"Working for the state," Mr. Weld noted, "is not a constitutional right."
In addition to layoffs, several states are requiring employees to take unpaid furloughs. In Rhode Island, for example, about 19,000 state workers were ordered to stay home on Friday, shutting down many state offices. The forced holiday was the first of 10 days of furloughs, part of Gov. Bruce G. Sundlun's attempt to close a $222 million deficit, equal to about 15 percent of the state's budget.
 
When Cutbacks Hit Home
 For those government workers nationwide who have received pink slips or who are facing layoffs in an economic downturn, the retrenchment by state and local governments has caused shock, disillusionment and fear.
"I'm a casualty of the state budget," said LuAnn Hebner, 32, who was laid off in January as a $31,000-a-year rehabilitation assistant at an outpatient mental health center in Dunkirk, N.Y.
Ms. Hebner is angry at Governor Cuomo, and she is saddened that she and her husband, a clerk at the State University of New York at Buffalo, allowed themselves to be lulled into such a sense of security in their state jobs that they were not more frugal with her earnings.
Sipping coffee in her living room in Forestville, N.Y., she talked wistfully of buying season tickets to Buffalo Bills games and of spending money in other ways.
"Ever since we've been married, we've always lived to the maximum of our incomes," she said. "I knew it was wrong, but that's what we've done. This is the day I've always dreaded."
 
The Job to Retire From
 Last fall, Doug Wilkowski, 26, quit his job as manager of a supermarket in Blasdell, outside Buffalo, to become a corrections officer in the state prison system. Mr. Wilkowski said he believed the job offered long-term security and better benefits. "It was the job I figured I'd work all my life and retire with good benefits and a good pension," Mr. Wilkowski said.
In November, after completing a monthlong training session at the department's Albany Training Academy, he and 152 other cadets were stunned when Thomas A. Coughlin 3d, the Corrections Commissioner, told them at graduation ceremonies that they would be laid off by the end of the year.
Since then Mr. Wilkowski has postponed his plans to marry and stopped looking for a house to buy with his fiancee. Instead, he has fruitlessly searched for another job, and he has vainly beseeched his former employer at the supermarket to reinstate him. He now spends most of his days watching television at his parents' house.
"I'd give anything to get my old job back so I could get on with my life," he said.
Those who have lost their jobs say that the public will suffer from lost or diminished government services and that bright and dedicated people will think twice about careers in the public sector.
 
'Goals of the Institute'
 Last year one such worker, Charles Morreal, a chemist at the Roswell Park Cancer Research Institute in Buffalo, a hospital run by New York State, developed an anticancer compound that was 80 percent effective in curing breast cancer in laboratory rats. Three weeks ago, a member of the staff at the National Institutes of Health told him that another compound he had developed showed some promise in the treatment of AIDS.
Days later he was notified by his superiors that his work "did not coincide with the goals of the institute" and that he was among the 29 staff members whose positions were being eliminated.
"To be told that is difficult to take," Mr. Morreal said. "It's like they're saying, 'Your research is useless. Get out.' "
Mr. Morreal, 59, who had worked at Roswell Park for 26 years, decided to retire, and he says he is not worried about his financial future. But he says that he is not sure whether anyone will follow up on his research and that he is concerned about the effects the layoffs will have on the recruitment of staff at Roswell Park.
The director at Roswell Park, Dr. Thomas Tomasi, was sympathetic. "We hated to lay anybody off, from the scientist to the animal tender to the general service people," he said. "They all have families and obligations. But we felt the elimination of these positions would be the least destructive of our program."
 
Work to Be Proud of
 In her 17 years as director of the Middlesex County Court Clinic in Cambridge, Mass., Barbara Hauser has built it from a one-person operation into a respected mental health center. The staff at the clinic, which provides counseling for couples in divorce proceedings or who are engaged in child custody fights, has published papers in scientific journals, and the clinic has been cited for its work by experts in divorce.
A month ago, Ms. Hauser and her six-member staff received layoff notices. To stave off the dismissals, the staff, along with other unionized employees of the state's court system, agreed to take a day off from work a month without pay until July 1.
Ms. Hauser said she is concerned about the 200 families who are receiving counseling at the clinic. Some, she said, cannot afford private counseling.
"If government doesn't respond to citizens in a way that citizens need it to respond, then government is failing," Ms. Hauser said.

HEADLINE: Dinkins Backs School Geared to Minorities

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday endorsed the idea of an experimental public high school that would stress the education of young black and Hispanic men, taking sides on an issue that has divided his own longtime liberal and civil-rights coalition.
Mr. Dinkins made his comments in an interview on a live radio call-in show on WKRS-FM, a station aimed primarily at black listeners. 
 His support for the proposed experimental school, known as the Ujamaa Institute, came at the end of a week in which he suffered new attacks from his old allies in organized labor over his fiscal policies and turmoil among his top staff, and new warnings from fiscal monitors about his handling of the city's budget problems. The Mayor also used the same radio interview to affirm his intention to run for re-election.
Mr. Dinkins seemed to be taking some pains to embrace his political base in the face of criticism from right and left, and to remind New Yorkers of the strength of the electoral coalition that made him the city's first black mayor, although by the closest margin in a mayoral race since 1905.
In endorsing the concept of the special high school, Mr. Dinkins sided with some important political forces, including Assemblyman Roger L. Green of Brooklyn, who have supported it.
But he diverged from some others usually allied with him, including the New York Civil Liberties Union and Dr. Kenneth B. Clark, the psychologist whose research buttressed the United States Supreme Court's decision outlawing school segregation in 1954.
When the idea of an all-male high school for young black and Hispanic students was first broached some time ago, Mr. Dinkins said he could not support any proposal that was exclusionary. But the Board of Education has since broadened the concept to a school that would be open to both sexes and all races, while placing special emphasis on the problems of black and Hispanic men.
"The school is now going to have a multicultural curriculum with a focus prominently on the African-American contributions to the arts, the sciences and so forth, and it will foster pride in African-American history," Mr. Dinkins said on the radio. "I anticipate that as currently proposed and structured it will be very valuable."
 
Plan Moving Forward
 Repeating a theme he has often expressed, Mr. Dinkins said: "You know, when I was a boy, and somebody said Africa, that immediately conjured up in your mind Tarzan swinging through the trees. We did not know of the magnificent heritage that we had and the civilization that existed long ago. That pride in ourselves is so important."
In the radio interview, Mr. Dinkins also talked of his determination to run for mayor again.
"In the normal course you would hear from an incumbent, "Well, it's too early now and we're going to think about it and we'll see what the future holds,' " Mr. Dinkins said, but he said that he had already made up his mind.
"If I'm going to be Mayor and take all this heat during this time," he said, "I certainly intend to be around when times are better."
Later, elaborating on his resolve to run again, Mr. Dinkins told reporters at City Hall: "To my friends, to those who had faith in me and elected me, stood by me through difficult times, to them I have always said our dreams are but deferred, not denied. And to those who are sharpening their pencils and determining they may seek this office, obviously anyone has the right to run that wishes, but I don't intend to just leave."
Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez said yesterday that he had never discussed the high school proposal with the Mayor. He said the Board of Education was working with Dr. Edison O. Jackson, president of Medgar Evers College of the City University of New York, to develop a detailed proposal that was academically sound.
"We're moving full speed ahead," he said.
But the proposal for the school, to be known as the Ujamaa Institute after the Swahili word for family, has met much opposition. Opponents contend it could further isolate black youths, who already drop out of school, die violent deaths and are jailed in greatly disproportionate numbers.
Dr. Clark said in a telephone interview last night: "Ujamaa would be looked upon as something inferior, quite inferior, stigmatized, and as a sort of correctional institution prep school. I'm opposed to it."
Norman Siegel, executive director of the New York Civil Liberties Union, said: "We oppose the use of a curriculum that is Eurocentric, and have for years. By what logic would a curriculum that is Africa-centered be more acceptable?"
Supporters, however, say the school is an experimental attempt to deal with a daunting problem and could promote self-esteem and community service and encourage discipline.
An editorial in the current issue of The City Sun, a black weekly newspaper in Brooklyn, said: "What is not being said -- and so we'll say it -- is that these off-the wall reactions to the plan and its proponents are rooted in the belief that people of color must seek permission from the white-dominated system before they even think about exercising their prerogatives to control their destinies."

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR;
Iraqis Facing Food Shortages

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 8

 BODY:
Despite anticipated bumper crops, Iraqis are expected to face food shortages this year because of the Persian Gulf war, a Congressional report says.
Because of the war and the economic embargo against Iraq, food stocks are currently at a record low, according to the Congressional Research Service, the research arm of Congress. Without outside assistance, the report said, food shortages will occur across Iraq despite the fact that farmers nearly doubled wheat production last fall, and a record grain harvest is expected. 
 "Once the embargo was announced, Saddam Hussein essentially told every farmer to put every acre in wheat," said Susan B. Epstein, a food and agriculture specialist with the research service, who wrote the report. Nearly twice as many acres were planted over the year before, Ms. Epstein said.
The Congressional report further said the war has created manpower shortages for harvesting the crop and fuel shortages that will make it difficult to power mills and processing machinery. Bombed-out roads and bridges will make food delivery nearly impossible to some areas, the report said.

HEADLINE: Going Beyond Social Security

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE

 BODY:
This is about the time of year when millions of people are receiving annual statements of the value of their personal retirement accounts and company pensions.
Pay attention to these statements, experts say. No matter what your age, it is always appropriate to think about your retirement needs and to figure out how much money you will have after your working days. If you discover that more is needed, now is the time to try to increase your savings to achieve your objectives. 
 Of course, Social Security benefits will supplement any private pension and savings plans. (For an estimate of the Government benefits you will be entitled to at ages 62, 65 and 70, complete Form SSA-7004, available from the Social Security Administration, Department 74, Pueblo, Colo. 81009, or call (800) 234-5772.)
"Social Security typically replaces only about 30 percent of preretirement income," said Alan W. Herman, senior vice president of Retirement System Group, an employee benefits consulting company. "But replacing 70 percent to 80 percent is the recommended goal. The question all working people eventually face is, where does the other 40 percent to 50 percent come from?"
For many of those who work for businesses with company-sponsored retirement plans -- about half of the American work force -- much of the money to replace 40 percent to 50 percent of preretirement income will come from a company benefits plan. These include defined benefit plans and defined contribution plans. Some companies have both.
Defined benefit plans promise a certain monthly pension based on a participant's salary and length of service, with the payments coming from contributions made by the employer plus voluntary contributions by the employee. Defined contribution plans let workers contribute part of their before-tax salaries (401(k) plans) or of their after-tax salaries (thrift plans).
The 401(k) plans, or salary reduction plans, are particularly attractive retirement savings devices at companies that have them. These plans let workers deduct from their paychecks, before income taxes, as much as $8,475, with the money going into a special account. As with other types of tax-deferred plans, the earnings on this account also grow tax free; taxes are paid as money is withdrawn after retirement.
At some companies, employers match all or part of their employees' contributions to a 401(k) plan. "Put in as much as your employer matches," advised Marvin Greene, a vice president of Towers Perrin, an employee benefits consulting firm.
 
Most Will Need to Save More
 There is general agreement among professionals in the field that company pensions and savings plans alone will not be enough to allow most workers to achieve their retirement income goals. "In many cases people have a little from a job here, a little from a job there and nothing substantial," said Avery E. Neumark, a partner of Weber Lipshie & Company, a certified public accounting firm. "And many companies are establishing early retirement dates and terminating people."
That leaves personal savings to take up the slack. Retirement specialists advise workers to save as much as possible in tax-deferred plans. These include individual retirement accounts for workers without company pension plans or with income under certain limits, or Keogh plans for those who are self-employed, including freelancers. But people who contribute up to the maximum allowed under such plans may still have to save or invest more on their own if they are to achieve that all-important nest egg for retirement.
 
'Save Now or. . . .'
 "People are not going to get enough out of their different company programs," said Herbert M. Paul, a New York tax lawyer. "So either they're going to save now or they're not going to have the life style at retirement that they want. The more time you have to accumulate, the less you have to put away each year."
Some economists and academics believe that in the next decade personal savings in this country will rise above the present average of about 5 percent of income, as more consumers recognize the importance of saving for retirement.
"As longevity increases, people will be more inclined to save in the conventional sense," said S. Jay Levy, chairman of the Jerome Levy Economics Institute of Bard College.
The key point emphasized by planners, though, is for people to begin saving for retirement as soon as possible, despite the fact that there is no longer a mandatory retirement age for most people. "The earlier you can start, the earlier the powers of compound interest are in your favor," said Mr. Herman of Retirement Systems Group.

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
How Roosevelt's Successors Compare

BYLINE: By HERBERT MITGANG

 BODY:
The Riddle of Power
Presidential Leadership From Truman to Bush
By Robert Shogan
352 pages. Dutton. $21.95.
Since Franklin D. Roosevelt, whom most historians rank among the handful of greats in the history of the Republic, the United States has had nine Presidents: Truman, Eisenhower, Kennedy, Johnson, Nixon, Ford, Carter, Reagan and Bush. Have any of them approached Roosevelt in stature and public affection or attained similar success in both foreign and domestic affairs? 
 The sad conclusion of Robert Shogan in "The Riddle of Power" is: No.
The author, a veteran political correspondent in Washington for The Los Angeles Times, writes: "Our recent Presidents, of both parties, have led us down a road pitted with broken promises and misguided endeavors. Their combined performances have forced us to wonder what it takes to achieve success in the White House and how we should go about choosing a chief executive to lead the nation through the twilight years of this century and prepare it for the next millennium."
Mr. Shogan withholds judgment on George Bush's Presidency -- he finds it too soon to call -- even though politicians and pollsters immediately linked the successful war in the Persian Gulf to Mr. Bush's chance for re-election in 1992. He does, however, comment on the last Presidential election:
"As the election of George Bush in 1988 demonstrated only too well, Presidential campaigns have become a vicious, empty competition, dominated by mudslinging, evasion and deceit. The substantive value of that election can be judged by what is best remembered now: from the Republican side, Bush's mindless and ultimately hollow injunction to read his lips, and from the Democratic side, Lloyd Bentsen's disparaging suggestion to J. Danforth Quayle that he was not John Kennedy."
Mr. Shogan writes that regardless of the outcome of the war in the Middle East (his book went to press before Desert Shield turned into Desert Storm), the success or failure of the 41st President will still depend on how he responds to two major challenges. At home, he will need to reinvigorate the country's economy; abroad, he will have to define a new role for the country in a changing world. "In both instances," the author says, "if Bush is to rally public support he must establish a strong identity for himself and a clear direction for his Presidency, so that he can govern by actions, not reactions."
The author makes it easy for the reader to follow his standards of success or failure for each of the Presidencies by setting up three criteria: ideology, values and character. None of the Presidents since Roosevelt get top grades on all three tests. Americans who retain a memory of several or all of them, probably base their views on which lever they pulled in the voting booth. The author passes around praise where due, but also notes that some of the nine did nothing significant domestically, that others did too much militarily, and that at least one (Richard Nixon, because of Watergate) came close to impeachment and another (Ronald Reagan, because of Iran-Contra) became vulnerable to it.
"The Riddle of Power" is filled with Presidential anecdotes, many involving exchanges with the author himself during his three decades of political coverage.
Once during the Nixon Presidency, as former President Truman sat around with a group of correspondents, he was asked to evaluate Richard Nixon. Truman demurred, saying, "There is a lady present." Mr. Shogan asked him if he could "clean up" his answer. Truman replied: "No. Every time anything is said about him now it just means another headline for him. It gives him a chance to get out on the front page."
During the Nixon-Kennedy race in 1960, Mr. Shogan was working for The Miami News. Many voters found the idea of Kennedy as President difficult to accept because his credentials were slim and because his age, 43, made him seem "callow and opportunistic," the author says. When it finally became clear that Kennedy "had indeed eked out a narrow victory," he writes, the news editor at the paper "suggested a headline that would have summed up the widespread doubts about his candidacy and Presidency: 'It's a Boy!' "
One of the merits of this book is that it turns our minds to a chunk of time in this century, 1945-1990, when the postwar dream and the cold war terror collided and fused. As one goes down the list of Presidents who succeeded Roosevelt, it's interesting to note that almost every one of the nine was entangled in small or large military conflicts -- some inherited, some of their own making. These include Korea, Lebanon, Cuba, Vietnam, Grenada, Panama and the Persian Gulf, not to mention covert and proxy wars like Iran-Contra during the Reagan Administration.
In a preface to a revised edition of his classic study of the modern Presidency, "Presidential Power," Richard E. Neustadt wrote that Presidential weakness was the underlying theme of his book. One of the points Mr. Shogan makes is that the Presidency has become so complex a job that even if a President isn't weak when he enters the White House, he discovers that he cannot simply give orders to a chief of staff or try to do the job himself and expect that results will follow. Growth has made it harder to control the Federal bureaucracy and a President must still answer to Congress.
As a respected newspaperman, Mr. Shogan tries not to abandon his objectivity, but he admits that he allows his opinions to come out in this book. On the evidence presented here and elsewhere, most of these Presidents were far too ordinary to perform brilliantly in an extraordinary job. On balance, "The Riddle of Power" is a lively and straightforward primer on leadership, but it still leaves open the question why potentially great Presidents cannot be discovered, nominated and elected. That's still a riddle.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Robert Shogan (Al Stephenson/Dutton)

HEADLINE: Give Them More Than Parades

 BODY:
As the first troops return from Operation Desert Storm, jubilant Americans are offering them jobs and weekend jaunts, baseball tickets and free baby-sitting. President Bush has granted returning Government employees five days off. The generosity is richly deserved. But in the long run these and all other members of the armed forces will deserve more.
Desert Storm showcased human skill and dedication and the most dazzling weapons that money can buy. Yet it also revealed distressing official neglect for the personal concerns of military men and women. Outdated laws provide inadequate benefits for active members of the forces, as well as reservists and the National Guard. 
 Unemployment insurance offers a good example. A civilian who is laid off can collect benefits for 26 weeks. Discharged military personnel get only 13 weeks, and wait longer to get it. That's no problem for most of those who had jobs when they were called up; their slots are protected by law. But it's no help for those who were unemployed, or for those whose jobs were eliminated because of shrinking business while they were away. With unemployment rising nationwide, the military-civilian inequity is grossly unfair.
Senate Republicans propose putting the entire military on a par with civilians, but this runs up against the Administration's declaration that costs not directly related to Desert Storm must be offset by cuts elsewhere. Congress and the Administration agreed to this distinction in their overall budget agreement, but the line between war costs and non-war costs is already getting fuzzy.
The "emergency" appropriations that the House approved the other day include $438 million to buy 500 new Patriot missiles and upgrade others. That's far more than were fired at Iraqi Scuds in the war, but the $438 million is nonetheless offered as a war expense, not subject to budgetary limits.
If buying extra missiles is O.K., then why is it not equally O.K. to provide fair compensation for jobless veterans? The hard truth is that missiles have stronger lobbyists than unemployed soldiers.
Another example of inadequate benefits spotlighted by the war is the tax exemption for combat pay. Officers get a smaller exemption than enlisted personnel. The Administration says that's just too bad; fixing this inequity can't be called a war cost. Still another example is interest on mortgages and loans, reduced to 6 percent for those called to active duty. The same terms should be extended to student loans, which didn't exist when the law was written.
There are many more examples that need attention. For now, let the nation cheer its heroes. For the future, they need more than parades.

HEADLINE: Read Mario Bush's Lips

BYLINE: By Franz S. Leichter; Franz S. Leichter, Democrat, is State Senator from Upper Manhattan.

 BODY:
Mario Cuomo and George Bush have something in common: They don't like to tax the rich. To listen to the Governor, you might think the opposite. In a National Press Club speech last December, he blasted the Government for 10 years of a Robin-Hood-in-reverse economic strategy, "which operated from the naive assumption that you could ignore the middle class . . . giving the already wealthy more wealth through huge income tax cuts."
The Governor was right. However, New York has pursued its own Robin-Hood-in-reverse policy, cutting top income tax rates more than 50 percent in the last decade. The biggest beneficiaries have been the affluent. 
 The wealthiest 1 percent of the nation's population saw its share of total income increase by 86 percent during the 1980's. In New York, the income of the richest 1 percent of taxpayers increased by 137 percent.
While its share of income was increasing in the last decade, the nation's top 1 percent paid 15 percent less in income taxes. In New York, the wealthiest 1 percent paid 33 percent less in state income taxes.
While the rich became richer and paid less of their income in taxes, New York's middle class and poor became poorer in the 1980's, and the middle class paid a larger percent in income taxes, exceeding the national trend.
As a result of income tax cuts in New York, $7 billion in revenue has been lost. Owing to the reduction and a worsening economy, the state faces a $6 billion deficit. Mr. Cuomo would partly plug that hole with a regressive $500 million rise in gas taxes.
To offset U.S. and state spending cuts, local governments have had to further burden the middle class with taxes. Between 1986 and 1988, 82 percent of New York's cities and villages raised property taxes by an average of 19 percent. Since 1979, 19 counties and eight cities have begun charging sales taxes. Across the state, excise taxes on alcohol and tobacco, which hit the poor and middle class hardest, have been the preferred method of plugging deficit holes.
 On Oct. 25, 1989, The Buffalo News reported that Mr. Cuomo, criticizing Washington's proposed gasoline tax, said: "I don't believe you should raise revenues on a taxicab driver or a struggling schoolteacher. You should tax the wealthiest people . . . Tax only the top, the people over $200,000."
Last November, a surcharge of 3 percent, to be applied to taxable income over $200,000, was proposed in the State Senate. Since then similar proposals have been made. Mr. Cuomo has rejected them all and promised to veto them. He says that increasing income taxes will send the rich across state borders and destroy New York's economic competitiveness. This argument is anecdotal. He has produced no document or study to show this is the case. Numerous studies show the opposite to be true. For most corporations, the prime factors in deciding where to do business are quality of life and workforce skills, with tax policy playing a minor role.
George Bush found he could not live up to his "read my lips" pledge. With huge deficits, it was unrealistic and did not serve the nation. Mario Cuomo ought to learn from that experience and withdraw his own pledge not to raise taxes.

HEADLINE: Nigerians Speak Warmly of the Peace Corps;
Reunion in August

 BODY:
To the Editor:
President Bush, in his State of the Union Message, challenged each American "to get one addict off drugs. To convince one troubled teen-ager not to give up on life; to comfort one AIDS patient; to help one hungry child," and to "Join the community of conscience." For 30 years thousands of returned Peace Corps volunteers, after having served two or more years in developing countries, have come home and done just that.
There are now more than 120,000 former volunteers, a small peace army providing leadership in domestic volunteer activities ranging from organizing community food drives to refurbishing homes for the elderly to outreach for victims of acquired immune deficiency syndrome. 
 Next Aug. 1 to 4 on the Mall in Washington, 7,000 to 10,000 former volunteers will gather for a conference and celebration marking three decades of Peace Corps service. And once again, the returned Peace Corps volunteer community will represent the best in domestic volunteerism. In partnership with the District of Columbia, all conference participants will serve one of the city's voluntary organizations for one day, called Volunteer Day.
Throughout Washington, returned volunteers will be working on worthwhile activities bringing national attention to the need for increased volunteerism in helping solve many national problems -- housing, health, illiteracy, environmental degradation. This day will serve as a model for similar events throughout the country. It is our hope that future conventions of any large group in the District of Columbia will be encouraged to perform volunteer service in their areas of expertise.
The National Council of Returned Peace Corps Volunteers has an affiliated membership of 15,000 returned volunteers and a data base of 25,000 other nonmembers. Unfortunately, addresses of many more thousands of returned volunteers are unknown. Yet the conference is open to all current and returned volunteers and staff. Former volunteers wishing information on the conference or local organizations of returned volunteers or organizations of former volunteers from particular countries, can call the council's headquarters in Washington, (202) 462-5938.
Returned volunteers have risen to the highest levels of corporate and nonprofit industry, as well as local, state and Federal Government and Congress over the last 30 years. As a group, former volunteers represent all shades of American political, economic and social life, defying categorization. Yet the one issue the returned Peace Corps volunteers are rallying round wholeheartedly is President Bush's call for more voluntary service.
 
ROBERT KERR
Chairman, Anniversary Conference, National Council of Returned Peace Corps Volunteers
Washington, Feb. 21, 1991

HEADLINE: Unemployment Is at 4-Year High With Jump to 6.5% Last Month

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 8

 BODY:
The nation's employment picture deteriorated significantly last month, with payrolls shrinking and the jobless rate rising to its highest point in nearly four years.
Hoping to give the economy a boost, the Federal Reserve responded to today's latest news of worsening recession by lowering an important interest rate another notch. It was the second time in two months that the central bank cut rates right after unfavorable employment statistics were released. 
 In the best gauge yet of economic activity in February, the Labor Department announced that the unemployment rate reached 6.5 percent, up from 6.2 percent in January and that the number of non-farm jobs fell by 184,000. The jobless rate was at least a tenth of a point higher than most economists had expected, and the drop in payrolls was almost twice what had generally been forecast.
The economy may nonetheless pull out of the recession by late spring or early summer as the Bush Administration, the Federal Reserve and most private forecasters predict. But the employment report shows that the economic decline that began last summer had not begun to level off last month.
"It's certainly not good news," Janet L. Norwood, the Commissioner of Labor Statistics, told the Congressional Joint Economic Committee today.
 
450,000 Jobs Lost
 She said that the increase of three-tenths of one percentage point in the unemployment rate was the largest one-month rise since 1986, that the rate had not been so high since March 1987, and that 450,000 individuals had been put out of work in February. But she urged the lawmakers to take a broad focus, and not simply look at one month's figures.
"The important point," Dr. Norwood said, "is that a year ago, the unemployment rate was 5.3 percent, and it's now 6.5 percent. That's a lot of unemployment."
Moreover, she said, the number of people who want to work full time but are working only part time has reached 6.1 million, the highest level since 1983.
The Bush Administration tried to put today's statistics in the best possible light.
For example, Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher noted in an interview that the net loss of 184,000 non-farm positions was substantially less serious than a stunning drop of more than 232,000 jobs in January. "This is nothing to crow about," Mr. Mosbacher said of the February number, "but it's another indication that we're right at the bottom. I'm not going to say it's going to turn around in March or April, but by summer I think we're going to be on the way back up."
The Commerce Secretary said he
 saw "a very good chance that the President's tremendous popularity will translate into a boost in consumer confidence."
But private economists who were interviewed were less upbeat. "The data are just dreadfully weak," said Robert H. Chandross, chief economist in the New York office of Lloyds Bank. He said the numbers clearly showed that "the end of the war by itself is not going to be sufficient to turn this recession around."
The Federal Reserve apparently reached that conclusion, too. In testimony on Wednesday before the House Ways and Means Committee, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve's chairman, said the central bank would not lower interest rates further without clearer data on economic trends.
But shortly after the employment statistics were released today, the Federal Reserve bought large quantities of Government securities to indicate to the financial markets that it wanted to lower its target for the crucial Federal funds rate, apparently to 6 percent, from the current 6 1/4 percent. The funds rate is what commercial banks charge each other for overnight loans and is often a determining factor in the interest rates that banks charge customers.
By cutting interest rates, the Federal Reserve hopes to make borrowing more attractive, and thus generate economic growth through increased spending by companies and individuals.
The Federal funds rate has now been driven down by two full percentage points since the central bank began cutting interest rates in earnest in October, but Mr. Greenspan conceded this week that so far the lower rates had not encouraged banks to make more loans.
On Feb. 1, after the data for January were announced, the central bank reduced the Federal funds rate by half a percentage point and also cut the discount rate to 6 percent, from 6 1/2 percent. The discount rate is what the central bank charges for direct loans to banks.
The view among Wall Street economists today was that the Federal Reserve would probably lower the discount rate again early next week. The central bank loses some measure of control over the economy when the Federal funds rate is higher than the discount rate.
The jobs picture was bleak across the board last month, but cutbacks were especially large in the automobile industry, fabricated metal products, industrial machinery and construction. Construction jobs have fallen by about 425,000 since May, and the drop in February was worse than it appeared because weather across the country was generally good for building last month.
Over all, manufacturing employment fell by 125,000 in February, continuing a trend that began two years ago. But the service sector of the economy has also been flagging recently. Jobs in retail trade fell by 70,000 last month, after seasonal adjustment, and 35,000 positions were lost in transportation, largely a reflection of the poor state of the airline industry. Altogether, 350,000 jobs have been lost in retail and wholesale trade since last summer.
The average workweek declined by 12 minutes last month, and overtime in manufacturing declined by 6 minutes.
The unemployment rate in New York and New Jersey declined slightly, but the declines were not suprising in light of the steep increases in the rates in both states in January. In New York, the rate fell to 6.2 percent in February, from 6.5 percent, and the New Jersey rate dropped to 6.3 percent, from 6.4 percent.
Among the large states, the situation was most severe in Michigan, where the rate was 9.8 percent, up from 7.2 percent in January, mainly because of layoffs in the auto industry, and in Massachusetts, where the rate rose to 9.3 percent from 8.6 percent. The large states with the healthiest job markets were Illinois, North Carolina and Texas, where the rates were between 5 percent and 6 percent.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 19, 1991, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, a front- page article on March 9 about the nation's unemployment rate misstated the effect of two interest rates on the Federal Reserve's control over the economy. The Federal Reserve loses some control when the discount rate is not below the Federal funds rate.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Waterworks Concern Sets Shift in Top Post

BYLINE: By DANIEL F. CUFF

 BODY:
Although a waterworks holds a spot on the Monopoly game board, water utilities owned by shareholders are not large American enterprises like electrical utilities. The largest, the American Water Works Company, has named a president-elect, George W. Johnstone, to take over its operations next year.
Mr. Johnstone, who is 52, is an engineer who has been with the nationwide company for 25 years. He will succeed James W. LaFrankie, the company's top officer, who plans to retire next year at age 65. In another change, Loren D. Mellendorf, 66, executive vice president and president of the company's American Water Works Service Company, plans to retire on July 1 and will not stand for re-election to the board. Mr. Johnstone, who is currently vice president, has been nominated to succeed him on the board. 
 American Water Works, based in Voorhees, N.J., owns water utilities in 20 states and provides water to 580 communities. Its stock is traded on the New York Stock Exchange.
Britain has recently seen the privatization of several regional water companies, but water for United States communities is usually provided by municipal or private companies.
There are some 15 publicly held water utilities, with American Water Works far and away the largest, annually pumping $600 million in revenues from its various operations. The water utilities do not generally provide so high a dividend as electric utilities, but utility analysts say the companies' share prices are often more stable.
Mr. Johnstone said the company was constantly on the prowl for opportunities to buy new systems, but purchases have been relatively rare. American Water Works last bought a company in 1986, in New Mexico.
"With the need for investment to modernize systems, though, we may see that systems may turn to professionally owned and run utilities," Mr. Johnstone said.
The company was formed in 1947 in New Jersey by an entrepreneur, John H. Ware 2d, who put the water systems together. His granddaughter, Marilyn W. Lewis, is the current chairman.
Mr. Johnstone is a graduate of Penn State University and joined the waterworks in 1966. He became a vice president in 1980 and a senior vice president in 1983.
Providing such an essential service brings with it particular responsibilities, he noted. "The economic well-being of the entire area we serve is impacted by how well we do our particular job," he said.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 3; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1742 words

HEADLINE: Madonna and the New Economic Order

BYLINE: By Robert J. Samuelson; Robert J. Samuelson, who writes a column for Newsweek, has been covering economic issues from Washington for two decades.

 BODY:

THE WORK OF NATIONS
Preparing Ourselves for 21st-Century Capitalism.
By Robert B. Reich.
331 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $24. 
 Just about everyone agrees that the United States' growing involvement with the world economy is one of the great changes of our time. If you believe Robert B. Reich, we haven't seen anything yet. In his new book, "The Work of Nations," he predicts the end of "national economies, at least as we have come to understand that concept." Mr. Reich argues that in a world without economic borders all people will rise or fall to their market values; the skilled and talented will prosper, while the uneducated and unskilled will not. In his view, then, the "work" of a nation is to improve the skills of its people so that they will flourish in this new world order.
It is a plausible and seductive story that seems to explain the mysteries of daily economic headlines: persistent trade deficits, rising levels of foreign investment, and fluctuating exchange rates and oil prices. Surely no one can quarrel with Mr. Reich's basic prescription. The better educated we are, the better off we will be as a nation. And he contends convincingly -- in my judgment, at least -- that foreign investment in the United States can ultimately benefit Americans by improving technology, spreading new management techniques and training American workers. The problem with his ambitious book lies not so much in details as in his basic theme. Like many others, Mr. Reich, who teaches at Harvard University's John F. Kennedy School of Government, vastly exaggerates the impact of the global economy on the United States.
His mistake is an understandable one. Since World War II, declining communication and transportation costs have enormously expanded global flows of products, services and technology. Arguably, our consciousness of this change has increased even more, in part because we have lost much of our self-confidence. Until the mid-1970's we assumed that American companies would perpetually dominate world markets and that our economy would always lead the globe in living standards and technology. Now the economic success of others has rattled us. The Japanese, who already make many of our cars and electronic chips, seem to be buying up Hollywood. The Germans have emerged as Europe's superpower. Some Americans fear that we are becoming a massive economic colony, dominated by foreign imports, foreign investment and foreign political influence.
Mr. Reich correctly rejects this economic paranoia. But in the process he embraces the conventional view about the huge influence of the world economy on the United States. In fact the conventional view is distorted. Most nations retain their economic identities: they represent separate systems of production and distribution shaped by national values, tastes, institutions, laws and politics. This is especially true of the United States, the world's largest market.
We delude ourselves if we think our major economic problems somehow originate abroad. Our basic economic problem is not some massive global shift but low productivity growth. It was terrible in the 1970's and, although it revived somewhat in the 1980's, is still lower than it was during the early postwar decades. Yet this development has little to do with the economy's increasingly international nature. We simply are not increasing output per worker fast enough to satisfy popular desires for higher living standards and more Government services (everything from health care to road renovation to police). American productivity mostly reflects American labor, management and Government. It has not suffered from foreign competition. Quite the opposite: foreign competition has become more intense precisely because American productivity has lagged.
In other areas, what happens to the American economy is also mostly a matter of what is happening within the United States. The economy's spending is mainly generated domestically. Recessions result primarily from spending shifts by American consumers and businesses. Inflation is determined for the most part by the Federal Reserve -- how tightly or loosely it controls money and credit -- and not by outside influences such as oil prices. Even though the economy's international connections have grown substantially, their influence remains fairly modest.
Against that background, it is hard to accept Mr. Reich's argument that the expansion of the global economy explains the widening gap between America's rich and poor. In his schema, the American labor force has split into three main groups: the "symbolic analysts," the "routine producers" and the "in-person servers."
Within this division, the symbolic analysts are the elite, and Mr. Reich says they alone have benefited from the global economy. These people manipulate "symbols -- data, words, oral and visual representations." Among others, this group includes entertainers, top corporate executives, engineers, consultants, lawyers and investment bankers. Because they "add value" to the global economy, their services are demanded by companies everywhere. Therefore their salaries and living standards rise.
By contrast, other Americans do not fare so well. The wages of routine producers -- essentially factory workers, their supervisors and midlevel managers -- are hurt by direct competition with low-paid workers abroad. Some good American production jobs will remain, Mr. Reich argues, but they will be scarce because they will exist in highly automated factories. As for the in-person servers -- among them store clerks, auto mechanics, secretaries, real estate agents, nurses and taxi drivers -- they also suffer. Although sheltered from global competition, they face increased domestic competition for their jobs from displaced routine producers -- and, in addition, some of their jobs are being automated.
There is obviously something to this -- but not as much as Mr. Reich contends. The global economy has clearly helped some Americans and hurt others. The more places Madonna can sell her music, the wealthier she will be. For genuinely global American companies, success abroad enriches their executives and shareholders. By the same token, global competition has weakened the bargaining power of some American unions. Wages have been affected, and some industries have lost jobs. But these are only modest influences on the well-being of most Americans, rich or poor.
Consider first the symbolic analysts. I'm one of them. My job as a columnist depends mostly on Newsweek's domestic advertising, because revenues from the magazine's overseas editions are small. If (heaven forbid) I'm ever fired, I'll be pounding the doors of other American publications; Le Monde wouldn't bid for my services. The same is true of most symbolic analysts: their jobs depend on the domestic economy. Wall Street investment bankers are now being laid off, and so are lawyers and accountants at major firms. Their troubles stem from the American recession and the aftermath of excesses in real estate and the stock market.
Likewise, it is the overall level of American productivity that mainly determines the wages of routine producers and in-person servers. As a nation, what we consume is essentially what we produce. Even at its peak in 1987, the trade deficit (which raised our consumption) equaled only 3.5 percent of gross national product. When higher productivity increases output, the rise in spending power spreads throughout the economy. This is why a barber in New York earns more than a barber in Beijing, even though they both may do the same thing. This is also why unskilled workers from less developed countries emigrate to the United States.
International competition may have contributed to the widening gap between rich and poor. But if so, it is one of many causes, most of which are unrelated to the world economy: changing skill levels and job requirements; more competition between men and women for jobs; more immigration; more cost-consciousness by companies; and the generational "congestion" of the baby boom (so many people of the same age competing for jobs that their wages suffer). Together these factors may have increased the pay of highly skilled workers and intensified competition for low-skill jobs.
Mr. Reich does not have much new to say about how to improve productivity. He scorns industrial policy -- the notion that the economy can benefit from government aid to key industries. This idea, he says, has been outmoded by the advent of global companies. The activities of big American firms are spread around the world. Thus, helping American companies doesn't necessarily help American workers. This is a reversal for Mr. Reich, who once advocated industrial policy. His current condemnation may be too sweeping, because aid to some industries may be justified on national security grounds. He acknowledges that problem only in passing.
Nor does he say much that is helpful about American education. Spend more, he proposes, as if low spending were the major problem. It isn't. Between 1970 and 1988, real spending per student in public schools rose more than 50 percent. There may be places where additional spending would help, but no amount of money will help students who do not study. About 60 percent of high school students do no homework or less than an hour's worth an evening. Moreover, Mr. Reich misleadingly argues that America's elite students (his future symbolic analysts) remain the best trained in the world. This is complacent. Even the best American students do not compare well internationally in such areas as language skills and scientific literacy.
Long suspicious of foreigners, Americans are understandably uneasy about the global economy. Coming to grips with it is a psychological as well as an economic challenge. Mr. Reich wisely warns against a zealous economic nationalism that would not help us and might hurt the world economy. He is also expert in explaining the ways in which many large American and foreign companies are growing more global, moving products, ideas and technologies around the world. But otherwise his book is disappointing. It is littered with meaningless new labels ("symbolic analysts" and "routine producers" are only samples) and flawed generalizations. Mr. Reich strains too hard to be original. In the end he doesn't dazzle his readers so much as confuse them.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 3; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1574 words

HEADLINE: Someone Must Have a Plan

BYLINE: By Dennis H. Wrong; Dennis H. Wrong, a professor of sociology at New York University, is the author of "Power: Its Forms, Bases, and Uses."

 BODY:

THE END OF LAISSEZ-FAIRE
National Purpose and the Global Economy
After the Cold War.
By Robert Kuttner.
304 pp. New York:
Alfred A. Knopf. $22.95. 
 One wonders how many times Robert Kuttner's title, "The End of Laissez-Faire," has been used in the last century and a half for speeches, symposiums, articles, books, even as a slogan. Mr. Kuttner has purposefully borrowed it from what is perhaps its most famous previous use: as the title for an essay by John Maynard Keynes, written in 1926.
Keynes's essay was not concerned with the condition of domestic market economies but with international economics -- with trade balances and currency exchange rates, tariffs and customs unions, the gold standard and world capital markets. Keynes's theme was how to avoid the beggar-thy-neighbor excesses of protectionism without succumbing to the utopianism of free trade, so beloved by orthodox economists then and now. This is Mr. Kuttner's theme, too.
In 1984, in "The Economic Illusion," he argued the case against pure laissez-faire in the management of a domestic economy. This volume amounts to a sequel, extending the argument to the more complex world of the international economy, "a realm in which the forces of private commerce are far more difficult to tame, for the obvious reason that the reach of the nation-state ends at its borders." Mr. Kuttner, an economics correspondent for The New Republic and a columnist for Business Week, insists that his "quarrel . . . is not with capitalism itself, only with its utopian variation, and I quarrel in the spirit of Keynes." His book appears at a moment of transition in world politics and economics that is comparable to the fateful period of postwar instability when Keynes wrote his essay.
Mr. Kuttner observes that his subject is "the second end of laissez-faire." For if Keynes's advice was not heeded in the 1920's, the Great Depression of the 30's and the Government interventions unleashed by World War II had the effect of retrospectively elevating him to prophetic stature. Not only did he become the virtual architect of the fiscal interventionism and, to a lesser extent, the welfare-state policies adopted by the American and British Governments that came after the war, but he also played a leading role at the 1944 Bretton Woods conference. Intended to establish a new international economic order free of the disastrous instabilities of the previous decade, the conference created a global interventionist framework featuring fixed exchange rates and centered on two new institutions, the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund.
Yet after these reforms, belief in laissez-faire made a steady comeback, culminating in the antigovernment policies of the Reagan Administration. "The intriguing question," Mr. Kuttner writes, "is why the utopian vision of a pure market economy proved so potent -- why it came back to life, after being so thoroughly discredited by events half a century ago and after most advanced nations successfully built their postwar societies very much in the spirit of a mixed economy rather than a laissez-faire one." Roughly half of "The End of Laissez-Faire" tries to answer this question, focusing on the United States; the other half advances prescriptions for a new regulated world economic order that, far from challenging American national purpose, could, in Mr. Kuttner's view, reinvigorate it.
The International Monetary Fund and the World Bank never became the genuinely supranational authorities envisaged by Keynes. Essentially, they developed into institutions that provided loans and economic advice, primarily to less developed nations. They were not permitted to take the key step of establishing an international unit of exchange, a standard by which national currencies could be both measured and regulated. Instead, under Bretton Woods, the United States dollar, the currency of the dominant political and economic power in the postwar world, emerged as a kind of international unit of exchange, although philosophically the United States was unprepared to play the role of world banker that its currency's position seemed to require. Washington ardently supported unrestricted free trade on ideological grounds. Moreover, given the productive superiority of the American economy, free trade served American interests just as it had those of Britain in the 19th century, when the British were the major world power and a lack of trade restrictions assured their economic dominance.
The United States, however, has clung to a belief in the unqualified virtues of a free world market long after the loss of its postwar economic dominance, and despite the manifest failure of Japan and Europe to practice laissez-faire, either domestically or internationally. The combined effect of the Japanese and European revival in the 1960's and the domestic American inflation resulting from the war in Vietnam so weakened the dollar that its position as an international unit of exchange became untenable. This led President Richard Nixon to abandon the Bretton Woods exchange rates agreements in 1970. The United States announced it would no longer defend the position of the dollar on international markets and no longer exchange gold for dollars. Henceforth, the American currency "floated."
The pressures on the dollar were due, Mr. Kuttner explains, to the contradictions between the role of the United States as the leader of the Western alliance and its persistent affirmation of international laissez-faire. A good part of his story consists of pointing up those contradictions. Thus he argues that a free market with floating exchange rates would have been catastrophic for the European standard of living after the war, so Bretton Woods and the Marshall Plan, hardly consonant with laissez-faire economics, were adopted to strengthen the Western powers. Mr. Kuttner also devotes an entire chapter to the export controls instituted by the Pentagon in the name of military security. These, he maintains, have resulted in American companies losing high-tech markets abroad to the Japanese and the Europeans.
After the collapse of the Bretton Woods system, though the United States remained the geopolitical leader of the West, its domestic politics turned increasingly away from the Keynesian-welfare state heritage of the New Deal. Finally, Mr. Kuttner contends, "the policies of Reagan and Thatcher . . . all but obliterated the political logic of the postwar mixed economy." The Reagan years brought both an intensification of American militancy in waging the cold war and a further downgrading of interventionist economics.
Mr. Kuttner thinks that the end of the cold war creates an opportune moment for facing the realities of the world economy. (Most of his book was obviously written before Iraq invaded Kuwait, although he briefly comments in the introduction that "the Kuwait crisis underscored the United States' continuing image of itself as a hegemonic power while its major allies retained the habit of acting as free riders on the system.") His general argument is that the United States no longer has a geopolitical-military excuse for turning a blind eye on the partly managed trade policies of its allies, who are clearly not now going to embrace the free-trade faith they rejected even when in need of American military protection. The world, as the title of Mr. Kuttner's penultimate chapter suggests, is "Slouching Toward Pluralism."
Nations can now be distributed along a continuum from mercantilism to free trade, but none are situated at the extreme free-trade end -- not even the United States. As Mr. Kuttner shows, it has never fully practiced what it preaches, neither with regard to steel and semiconductors, sectors that affect national security, nor even in so nonmilitary an industry as textiles. Japan stands close to the mercantilist pole of the continuum, and Mr. Kuttner provides an informed chapter on the Japanese pursuit of export markets, often at the expense of domestic consumers.
Does he, then, urge a protectionist economic nationalism as recently advocated, at least tacitly, by some commentators on both the right and the left? He insists not, asserting that his goal is a global mixed economy that would create the conditions for peace and prosperity: "After a detour of nearly fifty years, we have cycled back to the agenda of 1944: pluralism, peace and planning." He wants a world system that will "discourage individual nations from running chronic trade surpluses" and suggests that European-Japanese trade relations provide a model for such a system.
Critics will contend that in practice Mr. Kuttner's prescriptions would lead to fierce economic competition among nations that would be devastating for the losers, whose ranks might very well include the United States. Mr. Kuttner himself recognizes as "two nagging political questions" the degree of farsightedness of American voters and the relative competence of the American public sector. Acknowledging the prevailing post-Reagan antigovernment mood shared even by the Democrats, he nevertheless expresses a cautious optimism that a new "planning coalition" including segments of business is forming. Whether one agrees with this or not, the richly detailed evidence Mr. Kuttner has assembled will have to be taken into account by anyone assessing the present state of the world economy.

TYPE: Review

PERSON: WRONG, DENNIS H; KUTTNER, ROBERT
