PUB-DATE: March 10, 1991

SECTION: Section 6; Page 32; Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 4031 words

HEADLINE: The Empire Strikes Back

BYLINE: By Craig R. Whitney; Craig R. Whitney is chief of the London bureau of The New York Times.

 BODY:
The Flying Scud is a 100-year-old pub on Hackney Road in East London, where Nazi air raids inflicted such suffering 50 years ago. Since the beginning of the war in the Persian Gulf, its owner, Graham Warden, has had the place decked out in Union Jack bunting, and he doesn't give a damn if brazen patriotism offends the Muslims from Bangladesh and Pakistan who have displaced most other people like him from the neighborhood.
The regulars who come to shoot darts by the doorway include a couple of reservists and even a local named John Major, so Warden claims. For 2.50 ($5), the 33-year-old publican will make you a "Scud missile," with a chemical warhead of Middle Eastern arrack liquor, vodka and bitter lemon, or a "Patriot missile," with American Jack Daniel's, English gin and grenadine. "The place has been called the Flying Scud since the 1880's," Warden explains. "It's actually the foam the wind whips up." 
 At the Flying Scud there has never been any doubt who would win the gulf war, just as there hasn't been any at Buckingham Palace. Soon after the allied ground offensive started on Feb. 24, Queen Elizabeth II, in a rare televised broadcast from the palace, asked the nation to pray that British success would be as swift as it was certain. In short order, Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd said "those of us who have contributed a lot" to the war effort "now have a stake" in the postwar arrangements. In the postwar period, he added, it should be made clear "that Saddam Hussein was completely a bogus, puffed-up frog of a man insofar as he claimed to be spokesman for the Arab world."
The British are fond of saying they may not get much else right but they know how and when to go to war and how to keep a stiff upper lip. Where, they ask smugly, were the Germans and the Japanese when the call to duty came? The British seized it almost gratefully, as though it were another chance to relive their finest hour. Without much ado, they sent more than 40,000 troops east of Suez to help 500,000 Yanks liberate Kuwait from Iraq. It was almost like having the empire back, what with Lieut. Gen. Sir Peter Edgar de la Cour de la Billiere, the commander of British forces in the gulf, rattling around like Field Marshal Montgomery in a desert region Lawrence of Arabia knew so well.
Compared with the American war machine in the gulf, the British contribution hasn't seemed like much, but it has been the biggest British deployment anywhere since World War II and by far the largest European contribution. Supported by a broad consensus of all the major parties in the House of Commons, the Government sent, along with its troops, 11 combatant ships, 12 support vessels, 100 or so attack aircraft, about 60 helicopters, and hundreds of artillery pieces and tanks.
As long as the war lasted, Britain was right in the war zone, with American B-52's flying combat missions from the Royal Air Force base in Fairford, about 70 miles west of London. The big planes had been using the base for years, pulling out last year after the cold war ended. The 2,500 people of the small Cotswold town gave a warm welcome-back to the air crews and the 1,000 Air Force medical personnel who came to run a military evacuation hospital for war casualties. The townspeople collected blankets and donated them to the Americans, who flew in from Texas, Mississippi and California unprepared for the cold.
"The atmosphere is very much like before the start of the last war," Ruth Ritter recalled recently. Ritter is the 65-year-old Mayor of Fairford and widow of a Royal Air Force veteran. "I was a child then, and all the grown-ups were talking about this awful thing that was going to happen, but it had to take its course and we had to make the best of it. We were all terribly excited and rushed outside to dig tank traps and that sort of thing. Now we come to an adult stage, and we are reliving those serious, whispered conversations of our parents then. The war in the gulf is a terrible thing, but it's got to be done."
This time, people rushed off, too -- many to donate blood; others to enlist. In London, at the British Army recruiting office on the Strand near Trafalgar Square, Command Sgt. Maj. Les Griffiths sits in a booth behind a vitrine full of tin soldiers that seems to lure as many tourists as prospective volunteers to the sparsely furnished room. As soon as the war began, Griffiths says, about five times as many volunteers as usual began coming in.
"There was one 63-year-old ex-soldier who was terminally ill," he continues. "He asked us to send him to the gulf and spare one of the young soldiers." The man was gently turned away. The all-volunteer army will take only people who want to make it a life career, and is not upping its national quota of 16,000 male and female volunteers this year, war or no war.
Social class lines still run clear in the British Army, where military leadership style hasn't changed much in 50 years and most officers join their regiments by invitation, usually after an interview at one of the elite public schools, not on Trafalgar Square. Sir Peter is a good example of the creme de la creme, a distinguished-looking aristocrat who wears the sand-colored military beret of the Special Air Service commando regiment, Britain's most elite force. A graduate of Harrow and a member of a Huguenot family, he served for 30 years in Britain's colonial wars in Malaya, Oman and the deserts of the Persian Gulf, and in the campaign to retake the Falkland Islands from Argentina in 1982.
Last September, the highly decorated general was about to retire to hobbies he listed in Who's Who as "family, squash, down market apiculture, tennis perhaps, farming, sailing," when Margaret Thatcher picked him to lead the British forces under Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf of the United States. It is hard to imagine "Stormin' Norman" delivering a line like this one from Sir Peter about Saddam Hussein: "It is the sort of behavior you'd expect from the rather low-grade, second-hand sort of person that he is."
Violent talk or glorification of violence upsets the British, even if violence and war itself don't. Gen. Colin L. Powell, Chairman of the United States Joint Chiefs of Staff, otherwise widely admired, shocked many people in Britain by the way he described what the allies would do to the Iraqi force in Kuwait. "First," Powell said, "we're going to cut it off, and then we're going to kill it." Sir David Craig, an air marshal and chief of the British defense staff, has made it sound more like a pruning operation on a genteel country weekend. "Our overall aim," he said, "has been to cut the limbs and branches from the Iraqi war machine so that it no longer casts its dark shadow over Kuwait."
That was also about all he said. British commanders generally don't like telling civilians any more than they need to know about how they run a war. During World War II, they had complete military censorship, and during the Falklands conflict all British correspondents were cooped up at sea, in military vessels, until British troops secured victory ashore. Some of Sir David's subordinates have the impression he would have liked that kind of arrangement in the gulf.
Although British correspondents in Saudi Arabia have been subject to the same pool restrictions as their American counterparts, in Britain a clubby, informal system of deciding what is fit to print or broadcast is in place, backed by British secrecy regulations that allow Ministry of Defense officials to call up any editor and suppress anything they deem a military secret.

THE UNITED STATES AND BRITAIN have been side by side in the gulf since Saddam Hussein invaded Kuwait last Aug. 2, when Thatcher, then the Prime Minister, happened to be at President Bush's side in Aspen, Colo. There, in the vacation home of the American Ambassador to London, Henry E. Catto, the two leaders agreed in a two-hour talk that Saddam Hussein's aggression must not be allowed to stand.
In the fortress-like American Embassy on Grosvenor Square, Catto -- who will be leaving for Washington this week because Bush wants him to run the United States Information Agency -- mused recently about the nature of the "special relationship" between Britain and the United States.
"It builds on itself like a coral reef, and the longer it lasts, the sturdier it gets," he said. "Anguished Britons asked me all throughout 1990 why suddenly we seemed to be more involved with Germany than with them. I invariably answered that this was a function of the fact that the most dramatic change happening in the world then was in Germany. Britain was not reuniting; Germany was. And it was natural that the President should be more concerned with German affairs when the situation in Britain was quite serene." But, Catto added, "a couple of high American officials" had told him: "It looks like the only people we can really rely on are the Brits."
Since the beginning of the war, Major and Bush have been conferring by telephone every five days or so, even though, according to British officials, Bush is the Commander in Chief, and all the major decisions are his alone. That included decisions on the responses to the Soviet peace initiatives that started shortly before Feb. 15, when Saddam Hussein first acknowledged he would consider a withdrawal from Kuwait, and on the date to begin the allied ground assault.
Britain's voice, however, may carry further after the war. To prepare the way for peace, Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd traveled to the gulf states in early February to elicit ideas on the kind of British and allied presence they would like to have after the war. Senior British diplomats say they do not expect Saudi Arabia and other Arab states to agree to a permanent Western force in the Persian Gulf. "They'd like to have us just below the horizon," one says, "ready to come in and rescue them if they're threatened again." As a former colonial power with extensive knowledge of the region, Britain has expected to play a prominent role in the peace negotiations.
Not everyone has supported the British involvement in the gulf. Tony Benn, a former viscount and the most visible antiwar leader in the House of Commons, not only derides this idea but dismisses the "special relationship" with the United States as an opiate of the British ruling classes. "It became clear to the United States some time ago that Saddam Hussein had gotten too big for his britches and they were going to cut him down to size," he says. "With the decline of the Soviet Union, the United States has seized this opportunity to reimpose control, and the British are piggybacking their way back. It is really the old imperial role."
There are also those who contend that, as with the Falklands war, the British Government has been distracting its people from domestic woes with prospects of a razzle-dazzle military victory in the gulf. In some ways, wartime London 1991 is a surreal reprise of the city in "the last war." Then, Britain had a sagging economy and daily life was reduced to the barest necessities. Today, the economy is in a free fall, driven into a deep recession by anti-inflationary policies the Government can't relax too quickly. Jobs are disappearing at the rate of about 3,000 a day. Unemployment rose to 6.6 percent at the end of January, with the largest monthly increase in five years, and inflation, while on the way down, is still 9 percent, the highest in Western Europe outside of Portugal and Greece. To keep inflation under control, the Government has kept interest rates painfully high, inflicting pain and hardship on hundreds of thousands of homeowners with variable-rate mortgages. As if all this isn't bad enough, hotels and department stores have been almost deserted as business travelers and foreign tourists, terrified of terrorism, have stayed at home.

THE COMPOSITION OF JOHN MAJOR'S War Cabinet tells a great deal about this particular war. There are the usual suspects: Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd; Defense Secretary Tom King; the Chief of the Defense Staff, Sir David Craig; the Prime Minister's foreign policy and security adviser, Sir Percy Cradock, and Thatcher's longtime private secretary, Sir Charles Powell (who is serving Major until the gulf crisis is over). But the group also includes the Attorney General, Sir Patrick Mayhew, for advice on international law, and Energy Secretary John Wakeham, who is also the Government's publicity co-ordinator.
The War Cabinet, in other words, was running the war effort and worrying about its portrayal in the news media. It had plenty to worry about after the American precision bombing, on Feb. 13, of a Baghdad target the Pentagon described as a military command bunker. Hundreds of Iraqi civilians died in that attack, and the BBC and the Independent Television Network showed images of burnt bodies and distraught relatives, with commentators hinting not-so-subtly that a horrible mistake had been made.
Major's Government regretted the deaths but not the choice of target. The jingoistic British tabloid press had no regrets. The Sun, which ran the headline "GOTCHA!," when 368 Argentine sailors were killed on the cruiser General Belgrano during the Falklands war, announced this time: "Saddam Hussein tried to trick the world yesterday by saying hundreds of women and children died in a bomb attack on an 'air raid shelter.' He cunningly arranged TV scenes designed to shock and appall. But the victims were sent to their deaths by the Iraqi leader himself."
War is hell, most of the British people seemed to feel, and if Saddam Hussein didn't want his people to get hurt in a war, he should have pulled out of Kuwait earlier. According to polls taken a month after the bombs started to fall on Iraq, almost 90 percent of the British people supported the war fully, a figure that is not expected to fall since British casualties have been amazingly light. The day of the cease-fire, John Major told the House of Commons that 16 had been killed (9 by so-called friendly fire), 7 were seriously injured and 12 airmen were missing.
 Millions of Britons remember that their country went to war nearly 52 years ago against a rapacious dictator because he had invaded a defenseless, faraway country. Many have taken at face value their Government's reason for getting involved in the gulf conflict: to assert the principles of a new world order violated by Saddam Hussein's occupation of Kuwait.
This has also been broadly accepted across party lines in the House of Commons. Labor's leader, Neil Kinnock, has not let continuing pressure from his party's back-bench radicals, or his own anxieties about a general election after the war, keep him from supporting the war effort and reaffirming that support when the ground offensive began.
After the beginning of the air bombing campaign in January, antiwar protesters held rallies in London almost every weekend, but none of them came close to the size of the 150,000-strong peace demonstration in Bonn at the end of January. The long stretch of bitter cold weather that began when the war did might have something to do with it.
British intellectuals have been remarkably quiet about the war, almost as if those who object to it feel bullied into silence and those who support it feel too awkward to say so. Robert Giddings, a writer who teaches at Bournemouth Polytechnic, says he thinks part of the reason is that leftists opposed to the war feel betrayed by Kinnock, who has suppressed dissent by his back-benchers, forcing five of his shadow cabinet ministers to resign.
New Statesman & Society, the small left-wing weekly, has not been mincing words in condemning the war, and there have been critical editorials and articles in The Guardian and The Independent newspapers. The actress Vanessa Redgrave, who has political aspirations, has deplored, evenhandedly she insists, the bombing of Iraqis by the allies, the bombing of Israelis by the Iraqis and the continuing repression of Palestinians on the West Bank.
In one of the crowded, noisy strangers' rooms -- cafeterias -- at the House of Commons, Tony Benn, the radical Labor Member of Parliament, brews a pot of tea and tries to explain why people like him seem to be in such a minority these days.
"Britain is a feudal society in which the powers of the crown have been undiluted since the 17th century, but are now exercised by the Prime Minister instead of the monarch," he says. "The Prime Minister has unfettered royal powers which can be exercised in times of war. We are a nation of cap-doffers, and people defer to that kind of power without questioning it. And don't forget, the BBC is a state radio, and it suppresses the considerable public opposition to the war. I've had 8,000 letters of support for my position, and only 200 against."
Although little remarked on in Britain, powerful currents of submerged ethnic and racial hostility have also fanned jingoistic flames. "True Brits," as The Sun calls them, were baffled and irritated in 1989 by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's death sentence on the writer Salman Rushdie, a sentence that found widespread support among British Muslims. Now Britons could show what they thought by dropping bombs on Saddam Hussein -- never mind that Syria, Kuwait and Saudi Arabia, their allies, are also Arab, Muslim countries.
The Muslim population -- about one million people in a country of 57.5 million -- is one segment of British society that did not even exist during the last war, and its attitudes toward this one have been decidedly uneasy. Some worship at the golden-domed President Saddam Hussein Mosque in Birmingham, built before the war with the help of a $3.2 million donation from the Iraqi leader, who insisted that the place bear his name. There have been firebomb attacks on at least three mosques around the country, but not there, according to a man who answered the telephone one recent Friday. "We are all British Muslims," says Hazratmia Kazi, president of the mosque. "Our first allegiance is to our Government."
Almost all British Muslims, in Birmingham and elsewhere, are Asians, not Arabs, but the community is more complex and divided than it appears. Some factions are pro-Saudi; others, pro-Iranian. And attitudes about the war range from outright opposition to support but tending mostly to uneasy silence. Some employers and municipal authorities in places like Bradford, with a heavy Muslim concentration, urged their staff not to wear the Union Jack on their sleeves -- as The Sun suggested all patriotic Brits do as a sign of support for the war -- to avoid offending Muslim colleagues opposed to the British presence in the gulf.
In January, the authorities rounded up 52 Arabs living in Britain, putting 34 of them, because of their military status, in a prisoner-of-war camp near Salisbury and placing others in prisons in Yorkshire and London. In all, according to the Home Office, 176 people were served with deportation notices between Aug. 2 and late February, including 164 Iraqi citizens. About 80 have left voluntarily. Besides those in the P.O.W. camp, 44 are being held in civilian jails or reporting regularly to police officers; 16 have won their appeals for freedom.
One of those detained in January was a 31-year-old Palestinian who has lived as an orphan in Britain since 1977 and whose sole offense is that he is a nephew of Abu Nidal, the terrorist, whom he said he had met once at a family gathering in 1976. Another was Abbas Cheblak, a 47-year-old Palestinian writer who has lived in London for 16 years and has a wife and two young children. He is also an executive member of the Arab Human Rights Committee, a group that has campaigned against Saddam Hussein.
Britain doesn't have a written Constitution or a Bill of Rights, and Cheblak and others like him could only look to the Government's own review procedures for protection. British civil courts would claim no jurisdiction. With few exceptions, leaders of British public opinion do not see the detention of Arab residents as a constitutional issue.
Cheblak hired a solicitor and his wife got a Conservative M.P., Sir Dennis Walters, to take up his case. Sir Dennis said he had agreed because the Government had never offered a reason for Cheblak's detention and he felt that in fairness it should have. The Government's advisory panel lifted the expulsion order and set Cheblak free, but never told him why. It let stand the order against Abu Nidal's nephew, whose identity has been kept secret by court order, but allowed him to return to his home in South London -- so that he can apply for asylum in the same country that wants to expel him in the first place.
For officials at 10 Downing Street, these are just two more unavoidable casualties of war. "There are people actually trying to blow us up, you know," one of them says, referring to the recent terrorist attacks by the Irish Republican Army.

EVEN BEFORE THE I.R.A. bombings in London, Americans stopped coming to Britain because of the gulf war. And there has been considerable British griping about the lack of American civilian nerve, as though Americans were the only ones not going anyplace.
"I have to relate a shameful example of apparent mass cowardice -- I cannot, in conscience, employ a less emotive word -- on the part of our American cousins," Stephen Wood wrote to The Spectator the other day, relating his frustration in trying to arrange a tour of Scotland next September by the American Society of Arms Collectors. "I discovered not only that the society's governing council had withdrawn its official backing to the tour but also that, of the original 200 people booked to attend, 112 had canceled," he wrote in "amazement, disbelief and disgust."
One can just imagine what Thatcher would have said about such pusillanimity. Actually, a surprising number of British Government officials have said privately they are relieved she hasn't been leading the British war effort. She would have been provocative and bellicose, they say, much as she was in the Falklands war. And unlike Major, she wouldn't have been content to cash in the opposition Labor Party's support for the war at face value -- she would have probed its divisions and forced its large, repressed antiwar faction out into the open. Judging by the opinion polls, the British people like their new leader's more laid-back style, rating him as the most popular Prime Minister since Winston Churchill, who led the country in "the last war."
Like George Bush, John Major wanted to avoid heavy British casualties in gigantic tank and infantry battles in the desert, and the Government supported a continuation of the air bombing campaign with that aim in mind. Insisting on eliminating Saddam Hussein before ending the war would also have endangered the broad political consensus in support of it, and Major has not pushed the point. Again, like Bush, he has hinted that with the dictator in place, the United Nations mandate to restore peace and stability to the gulf region can hardly be fulfilled.
"He is a man without pity and, whatever his fate may be, I, for one, will not weep for him," Major said in the House of Commons on Jan. 22, soon after seven battered allied airmen, two British fliers among them, were displayed on Iraqi television, with Saddam Hussein declaring that the prisoners would be deployed as human shields at strategic sites. Major's statement was only one of many British hints that Iraqis would be the best judges of the Iraqi dictator's fate after the fighting stops.
And what of the fate of the P.M. himself after peace has been declared? After a clear and quick victory, Major could risk a general election as early as May or June rather than wait for July 1992, when the writ of the current Parliament runs out. If he should fail in the polls, it would not be the first British victory on the battlefield that evaporated during peacetime -- as Churchill, turned out by the voters in his hour of triumph in 1945, would be the first to tell his successors.

HEADLINE: In the Land of Lambada

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE; JAMES BROOKE is head of the Rio de Janeiro bureau of The Times.

 BODY:
ON April 22, 1500, a Portuguese nobleman stood on the rolling deck of a caravel and recorded Europe's first vision of what is now called Brazil: coral reefs, fingers of fine white sand, windblown coconut palms and lush mangrove thickets rich with crabs and splashed with the red and green plumage of parrots.
From the wooden cross that the nobleman, Pedro Alvares Cabral, erected a few days later at Porto Seguro (safe harbor) small Portuguese villages soon grew -- humble stucco cottages dominated by whitewashed churches. But in subsequent decades Portugal's vast South Atlantic colony grew in other directions, and Brazil's Plymouth Rock lapsed into tropical neglect. 
 Principal access to Porto Seguro, 110 miles south of Ilheus, continued to be by sea until 1972, the year a paved road was pushed through to the coast. When pioneering tourists -- largely Brazilian and European hippies -- ventured to Trancoso, a neighboring village, they introduced a money economy to a community that had long since reverted to barter.
Today scheduled airlines bring in tourists daily from Brazil's largest cities. The country's most popular tourist destination in the northeast after Salvador and Recife, Porto Seguro, which has a population of about 5,000, offers comfortable hotels and excellent seafood restaurants in a setting of primeval beauty that struck Portuguese explorers almost 500 years ago.
The hippies' political legacy is a large and militant local chapter of Brazil's Green Party. Zoning laws are zealously enforced to preserve beaches and historic buildings, some of which rank among the oldest in South America. Indeed, much of the coast of southern Bahia State is still wilderness.
Modern American visitors too will feel a sense of discovery here. While Brazilian guidebooks list as many as 100 hotels and guesthouses in Porto Seguro and the neighboring villages of Trancoso and Arraial d'Ajuda, English-language guidebooks devote relatively little space to this remote corner of southern Bahia State. When Americans think of vacationing on Brazilian beaches, they think of Copacabana and Ipanema in Rio de Janeiro. When Rio residents think of vacationing on Brazilian beaches, they head for Porto Seguro.
"Less than 1 percent of our tourists are foreigners," said Cicero G. de Sena Neto, former director of the local trade association and now manager of the Portobello Praia Hotel, one of Porto Seguro's top four hotels.
For visitors strolling the cobblestone streets, shaded by breadfruit and weeping fig trees, Porto Seguro offers a spirit that is fading from Brazil's coastal megapolises -- honesty, amiability and a guileless smile. As tourism has grown in recent years, Porto Seguro has also won a niche in Brazilian mythology for string bikini sensuality and bronzed beach athletics. The town's two international exports reflect this: a world windsurfing champion and the sensuous dance called the lambada.
 Because seasons are reversed between the Northern and Southern Hemispheres, Americans can visit Porto Seguro in the off season, March through June and August through November. During Brazil's summer, December through February, and during winter break in July, the fishing villages can become so crowded that they take on the air of a Brazilian Fort Lauderdale. But off season, prices are lower, restaurants and hotels are less crowded and the local people are more patient with tourists who do not speak Portuguese.
Our trip last June started from Rio's downtown Santos Dumont airport. Shortly after taking off in a 14-seater plane of Nordeste Airlines, the pilot pointed north and the co-pilot settled into reading the sports section of a newspaper. Passengers watched the changing coastline below -- the salt flats of Cabo Frio, the yachts and turquoise-green swimming pools of Buzios and the eucalyptus plantations of Espirito Santo. We stopped to refuel at a southern Bahian town named, appropriately, Caravelas. For scuba divers, Caravelas is now the jumping-off point for boat tours of the Abrolhos National Marine Park, an uninhabited archipelago 40 miles offshore.
 From Porto Seguro airport, it was a 10-minute taxi ride to our hotel, the Portobello Praia. Porto Seguro has several car rental agencies, but with driving reduced to one beach road, we found it simpler to have the hotel receptionist telephone for cabs. The hotel, reflecting local taste and zoning restrictions, is a Mediterranean-style two-story building with a decor of natural materials -- black wood trim, beige roofing tiles and red hibiscus blooms brushing against whitewashed walls.
 Crossing the coast road to Itaperapua beach, a two-minute walk, one appreciated the zealousness of Porto Seguro's Green Party. Viewed from the water's edge, the beach road and the low, setback hotel disappeared behind a long line of native vegetation, largely coconut palms. A series of immaculate beaches and coves runs for roughly 10 miles along the beach drive, protected by offshore reefs and affording good swimming. The only signs of man on Porto Seguro's beaches were palhocas, wooden restaurant-bars with round thatched roofs. At Boto's, the inescapable lambada music blasted from loudspeakers as beachgoers snacked on fried shrimp and sipped batidas de coco, stiff iced drinks of half coconut milk and half locally distilled sugar cane rum.
Lambada is the theme that links the scattered villages of southern Bahia's coast. By Porto Seguro's docks, a few yards from one of two competing crosses that supposedly mark the site of the first Roman Catholic Mass in Brazil, a sandy lane named Discovery Avenue now houses a string of open-air lambaterias. There, tourists from southern Brazil pay loose-hipped dance instructors to discover that they are stiff-jointed.

IN 1988 a French entrepreneur, Olivier Lamotte d'Incamps, visited Porto Seguro and discovered locals dancing the tightly syncopated lambada to a melody that turned out to be Bolivian. With a blitz of publicity, Mr. Lamotte d'Incamps launched the lambada craze, largely by promoting a European tour of Kaoma, a Porto Seguro dance group. Forgettable movies followed.
The lambada meteor eventually crashed , but only after Kaoma sold over seven million records. Down on Discovery Avenue, local teen-agers dance on, dreaming of making it in groups that still tour Brazil under names like "Do Do From Bahia and the Virgins From Porto Seguro."
For more highbrow entertainment, a hike up a nearby bluff takes a visitor to the colonial heart of Porto Seguro. Declared a National Historic and Artistic Monument in 1973 and closed to cars old Porto Seguro includes Our Lady of Mercy Church (1523), reputedly Brazil's oldest church still in use, Our Lady of the Blacks, built by and for African slaves, and a white and mustard-trim town council house and jail whose Baroque style has survived untouched since construction in 1772. Set against a sweeping view of the sea, a roughly hewn white marble marker bears the arms of Portugal and the cross of Prince Henry the Navigator. Erected in 1503, the marker is generally considered Brazil's oldest surviving colonial monument. Every April 22 Portuguese diplomats gather here to celebrate Discovery Day. As Porto Seguro has blossomed into a full-fledged resort, the diplomats' interest in fulfilling this official chore has grown.
Descending a cobblestone lane, one arrives at Porto Seguro's main oceanfront street, Avenida Portugal. Nicknamed Passarela do Alcool, literally Alcohol Alley, the street is lined with sidewalk cafes, stand-up bars, resort-style pizzerias, handcraft boutiques and seafood restaurants. All are housed in the traditional one-story fishermen's cottages, with pastel stucco facades. Items for sale include hand-embroidered cotton tablecloths, painted clay figurines from the rural Northeast and baskets woven locally from white creeper vines.
On the Passarela, Tres Vintens offers rich Afro-Brazilian seafood dishes bubbling hot in earthenware pots. The 1970's decor -- geometric designs by Max Escher -- can seem overwhelming after a few batidas of coconut milk or passion fruit juice. Nearby, Ilha do Mel (Honey Island) offers Charles Aznavour music while waiters serve slices of California pizza (topped with peaches and figs) and glasses of draft beer chilled to what Brazilians call "stupefyingly cold." For dessert, an espresso bar next door serves chilled slices of lime pie and ricotta pie.

A FEW blocks away, on Avenida des Navegantes, the Porto Oriental restaurant offers bossa nova music and Chinese food cooked with local shrimp. With one of Brazil's richest fishing grounds offshore, Porto Seguro fishermen bring home varied catches: shrimp, octopus, mullet, snook, sea bass, red snapper, swordfish, mackerel, anchovies and flatfish.
For excursions out of Porto Seguro, the paved beach road continues 15 miles north to Santa Cruz de Cabralia, a colonial-era village named in honor of the Portuguese explorer. Along the way, it is not worth stopping at Ponta da Coroa Vermelha (Red Reef Point), where there is a brazilwood cross marking another reputed site of the first Mass in Brazil. The site is surrounded by a Pataxos Indian community. Today's Pataxos dress up as Indians and jog alongside tourists' cars, peddling neo-Pataxos trinkets and tomahawks.
Cabralia, the northern terminus of the beach drive, offers a hilltop colonial church and an embarkation point for schooner tours of offshore reefs. We set off for a day tour in the Luanda, a schooner that takes tourists cruising; it is owned by a Portuguese who fled Angola after colonial rule collapsed there. With the inescapable lambada medleys wafting over the waters, the blue and white trim Luanda glided past mangrove swamps until anchoring at Coroa Alta reef. With sneakers protecting their feet, passengers spent the morning clambering over the milelong coral reef, inspecting pools where luminiscent fish were trapped by tides in temporary tropical aquariums. On high ground, two men sold chilled coconuts for 75 cents apiece to the thirsty amateur naturalists.
The $16-a-day excursion rate included a Bahian lunch buffet at a beachfront restaurant accessible only by boat.
Boat tours also head south for the less-visited beaches of Arraial d'Ajuda and Trancoso. But these beaches are generally unprotected by coral reefs and the ride is in the rough open sea. An alternative is to go to the ferry dock in Porto Seguro and cross the Buranhem River in a 15-minute ferry ride (40 cents). On the other side, a city bus will lurch over a pitted dirt road to Arraial (15 minutes) and on to Trancoso (another 45 minutes; $1.20). The road to Trancoso is so bad that it is usually impassable after heavy rains. Arraial's church dates back to 1549. Trancoso's church is comparatively modern, dating only to 1656 -- 36 years after the first English settlement in Plymouth Rock.
 
 
 
PLACES TO EAT, PLACES TO STAY, THINGS TO SEE

 
Getting There
Porto Seguro can be reached by air daily from Rio de Janeiro on Nordeste Airlines (220-4366 in Rio) and Rio Sul every Wednesday and Sunday (210-1215 in Rio). The round-trip fare for the flight, which takes two-and-a-half hours, is $289. Nordeste also flies from Salvador da Bahia three times a day; the round-trip fare is $192. The flight takes one hour and 40 minutes. Varig Airlines flies every Sunday from Miami to Salvador. Taking this flight it is possible to leave Miami Sunday afternoon and, with a switch in Salvador to Nordeste Airlines, arrive in Porto Seguro Monday morning. And starting last Friday Pan Am introduced a Friday evening flight from Miami to Recife.
 
Information
The local tourist office, Bahiatursa, is at Praca Visconde de Porto Seguro (Casa da Lenha); 288-2126. It is open Monday to Friday from 8 A.M. to noon and from 2 to 5 P.M. The area code for Porto Seguro is 073.
 
Accommodations
There is a wide range of hotels, from high international standard, to boarding houses (pousadas) to campsites.
Portobello Praia Hotel, Rodovia Porto Seguro-Cabralia Beach Drive; 288-2329. Rates for two people in a double room range from $87 in high season (December, January, February and July) to $52 a night in low season (the rest of the year).
Porto Seguro Praia, Rodovia Porto Seguro-Cabralia Beach Drive; 288-2321. Double $77 in high season, lower the rest of the year.
Vela Branca, Cidade Historica, Avenidade Antonio Carlos Magalhaes, 585 Pituba; 288-2316. Double room in high season $45; 10 percent discount in low season.
 
Dining
Tres Vintens, 246 Avenida Portugal; 288-2955. Cost for two with drinks and beer or wine $30.
Ilha do Mel, Avenida Portugal; no phone. Serves California pizza. Pizza for two with beer $18.
Porto Oriental, 670 Avenida des Navegantes; 288-2551. Chinese dishes. Dinner for two with beer $40.
 
Sightseeing
Trips on the schooner Luanda, snorkeling trips and fishing trips can be arranged at Agencia do Descobrimento, 330 Avenida Getulio Vargas; 288-2727.
Trips on the Luanda cost $16 a day, with a Bahian lunch buffet.
 
The Weather
At 16 degrees south of the Equator, "winter" in Porto Seguro, June, July and August, means sandals, shorts and 70 degree weather. Winter also can mean rain and mosquitoes, so plan accordingly.
Summer, from December through March, is baking hot, with temperatures into the 90's. -- J. B.

SECTION: Section 10; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 2008 words

HEADLINE: 'Other Boroughs' Strategy Bucks Difficult Times

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
A FIVE-YEAR campaign to lure office development to the New York City boroughs outside Manhattan is scoring scattered new successes but encountering tough resistance because of the city's real estate and business downturn.
The program, called the "other boroughs" strategy during the administration of Mayor Edward I. Koch, has relied on an array of financial incentives -- including tax abatements, moving allowances and cut-rate electricity -- to make development sites in Brooklyn, Queens, the Bronx and Staten Island more competitive. Similar inducements are available to businesses and developers north of 96th Street in Manhattan. 
 Experts say the effort has bogged down, largely because of the weak market for office space in Manhattan, where many landlords are now offering good space for as little as $20 to $25 a square foot. Space in buildings outside Manhattan costs office tenants just as much, even when the savings from the city incentives are figured in.
Some say the program, however well intentioned, is far from well timed. "It is hard for local government to play a counter-cyclical policy game," said Raymond Horton, director of the Citizens Budget Committee, a watchdog group.
But officials of the Dinkins administration say they are not deterred. The long-range intent of the program, they say, is to spur construction and business expansion in the city's dormant or declining neighborhoods and make them more competitive with Jersey City, Stamford, Conn., and other nearby office centers that have been courting banks, securities firms and other Manhattan companies.
"If there is one policy that stands out that is something we have carried over from the Koch administration, it is the emphasis on the other boroughs," said Jeanne P. Nathan, a spokeswoman for Sally Hernandez-Pinero, the Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development.
Yet recent demand for offices outside Manhattan has come mostly from city, state and Federal agencies. And analysts say marketing the space to private companies has become increasing difficult because of layoffs, reduced earnings and tabled expansion plans.
Several transactions that have been completed over the last month or are widely believed to be pending promise a small new flurry of development, particularly in downtown Brooklyn, which has so far emerged as the major focus of the other-boroughs program.
In a deal described by officials of several city agencies, the Brooklyn District Attorney, with a staff of 1,000 lawyers and support personnel, is in final negotiations for a lease on 200,000 to 350,000 square feet of offices in Brooklyn Renaissance Plaza, a complex planned by the Muss Development Company of Manhattan since 1984 above a municipal garage on Jay Street.
Spokesmen for Muss and Charles J. Hynes, the Brooklyn District Attorney, declined to confirm the transaction. But others said the deal is likely to mean that construction will begin this year on the complex, which is to include a 356-room Hilton Hotel, the first new Brooklyn hotel in decades, as well as 600,000 square feet of offices.
Forest City Enterprises, the largest developer in downtown Brooklyn, said in late February that it would join Rose Associates, another development firm, in the long-delayed Atlantic Center project. The complex is ultimately to include 1.8 million square feet of office space, 189 townhouses, stores and movie theaters in a complex over the Long Island Rail Road Station on Atlantic Avenue.
Bruce Ratner, president of Forest City, declined to say how much the firm would invest in the project. Because of the weak office market, he said, construction of housing will begin as soon as two lawsuits that challenge the projects size and density are resolved, but office construction may be put on hold for years.
Forest City is also the developer of Metrotech, a 4-million-square-foot complex of new and rehabilitated offices covering 10 blocks in downtown Brooklyn that is now more than half complete. In a separate development, Mr. Ratner said last week that the Internal Revenue Service had signed a lease for the former Barton Candy Company building, a 300,000-square-foot structure that Forest City had acquired just south of Metrotech on Fulton Street and that rehabilitation of the building had begun.
THE latest round of deals comes amid a spate of new construction that began in 1987 and has been prompted in part by the city's incentives. Over 10 million square feet of offices -- more than the total of the twin towers of the World Trade Center -- was completed, being built or in the planning pipeline by the end of the decade in Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island.
In Long Island City, Queens, Citcorp at Court Square, a 42-story, 1.25-million-square-foot tower completed in early 1989, has been filled by 3,000 executives, data processers and other employees of Citibank. Like several other large banks, Citibank has announced extensive job cuts, saying it would lay off 8,000 workers around the world by mid-1992. It declined last week to say if any jobs would be cut in the Queens building.
Citicorp, the bank's corporate parent, also obtained city approval in the late 1980's to build a second, 1.2 million office tower another site it owns across 43d Street. But it said it has not decided whether to proceed with construction.
On Staten Island, Teleport II, a three-story, 165,000-square-foot office building, was completed in December as part of the five-year-old Teleport complex. Four other office buildings in the complex have already been fully leased by corporate tenants, including Merrill Lynch, Dunn and Bradstreet and the Allstate Insurance Company and New York City's Public Development Corporation said it was seeking other securities firms, banks and high-technology tenants for the new building.
A long troubled building in the Bronx, Fordham Plaza, with 350,000 square feet of offices at Fordham Road and Webster Street, is now more than 95 percent occupied, according to Kathy Zamechansky, a spokeswoman for the building.
Completed in 1985 by a group of private developers, the buiding sat more than half empty for over four years. But several large tenants, including the administrative staff of Montefiore Medical Center, have signed leases over the last 12e months.
In downtown Brooklyn, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said it would begin moving 2,000 workers by May into Livingston Plaza, a 12-story, 500,000-square-foot building nearing completion at Livingston Street and Boerum Place. Built with city incentives by Cohen Brothers Realty and the Starrett Housing Corporation, the building was bought by the mass-transit agency for $120 million in November 1989.
Metrotech, the largest project outside Manhattan, may now pose the biggest test of the city's other-boroughs campaign. Although Forest City had signed leases for most of the complex before it began construction in early 1988, it will have 390,000 square feet ready to rent to new corporate tenants in September. That space is part of a 21 story tower -- the tallest in the Metrotech complex -- in which the Brooklyn Union Gas Company has already leased space for its headquarters.
Because rents have declined in Manhattan, "there are a lot of companies that suddenly won't consider Brooklyn, New Jersey or any other alternative," said Mr. Ratner.
But he added that negotiations are "very active" with several companies interested in the Metrotech space and that Forest City is not considering government agencies as tenants.
The biggest Metrotech tenant, the Chase Manhattan Bank, said last week it has not changed its plan to move 6,000 workers to the complex in October, despite its recent announcement of more than 5,000 layoffs worldwide.
The Securities Industry Automation Corporation moved its headquarters and 800 workers to the complex late last year and the Brooklyn Union Gas Company will move its headquarters into Metrotech later this year.
One benefit of the recent downturn in rents is that, by making Manhattan less expensive, it has prevented some businesses from moving out and persuaded others to expand. But city officials acknowledge that it has made their other-boroughs campaign more difficult.
"As Manhattan rents come down, the role of the other boroughs as a lower-cost alternative changes somewhat," said Carl Weisbrod, president of the Public Development Corporation, the city's development arm. Nonetheless, he added that some areas outside Manhattan, particularly downtown Brooklyn, have established "a center of gravity that supports itself" and could compete even without offering steep price discounts.
 Some real estate executives are unconvinced.
Despite the large leases signed by Citibank, Chase and others in the late 1980's, "we have all be disappointed that we haven't seen continued out-borough growth," said John Ritter, a broker with Sholom and Zuckerbrot, a Long Island City firm that deals in office space throughout Brooklyn and Queens.
He added that many Manhattan landlords, particularly those with older buildings on the side streets of Midtown and the Wall Street area, are now offering space for no more than is asked at Teleport, Metrotech or other new buildings in the other boroughs.
"There is no impetus to move out of Manhattan," he said.
At City Hall, Ms. Nathan of the Finance and Economic Development office said officials do not expect a new surge of large- scale office developments outside Manhattan any time soon.
"You are not going to see humongous projects going up in the middle of nowhere," she said, adding that the aim of the Dinkins administration was to foster small-scale development and business expansion in established office locations and retail strips of Brooklyn, Queens, the Bronx and Staten Island.
INCENTIVES offered by the city's other-boroughs program, established by Mayor Koch and retained by Mayor David N. Dinkins, include the Industrial and Commercial Incentive Program, in which businesses are given tax abatements amounting to $500 for each of their employees for 12 years.
Others include city grants of up to $60,000 to help defray the cost of a business' moving from Midtown or Lower Manhattan to another borough. Additional tax abatements are designed to reduce electrical bills by up to 30 percent for companies that move to another borough.
The Industrial and Commercial Incentive Program is due to expire in December. Ms. Nathan said the her office was preparing a recommendation to the City Council that it be renewed and amended to offer even bigger tax savings to firms moving to what she called the "more distressed" sections of Brooklyn, Queens, the Bronx, Staten Island and Manhattan above 96th Street.
One project that remains in the pipeline after years of planning, and would have a highly visible impact on Brooklyn, is the development of the idle Piers 1 through 5, with 70 acres of waterfront land below the Brooklyn Heights esplanade. The property is owned by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which was forced last year, under pressure from Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and others, to abandon its plan to sell the site to Larry Silverstein and Arthur Cohen, private developers who planned a hotel, shops, marinas and expensive condominiums.
That plan was opposed vigorously by many civic organizations, including the Brooklyn Bridge Park Coalition, an umbrella group that has proposed that more than half the land be set aside for parks, and the remainder be developed in a way that minimizes structural density.
Since Governor Cuomo instructed the Port Authority and other agencies late last year to devise a plan for the site, a series of negotiations have ensued, but so far with little apparent progress. After a meeting on Tuesday, officials of the Urban Development Corporation, the state's development agency, and the Public Development Corporation, said many options remained under study, including building offices, restaurants, shops and apartments.

HEADLINE: 6 Opinions on School Finance Law

BYLINE: By PRISCILLA VAN TASSEL

 BODY:
WHILE the debate in Trenton about education has recently focused on the amount of money that should be shifted from the Quality Education Act, Gov. Jim Florio's sweeping overhaul of New Jersey public school financing, to property tax relief, other aspects of the law continue to provoke controversy.
Dozens of bills have been introduced to amend the act, which took only 22 days last spring to clear the Legislature but will probably take months to reach its final form. 
 Stung by complaints from angry taxpayers that a $1.1 billion increase in state education spending was excessive and by criticism from wealthy communities that the law imperiled the quality of education they can offer, Governor Florio has announced that the entire law is open to being amended. Criticism of the act centers on a number of fundamental issues, including questions of accountability, what a community's fair share of education costs should be and what a "quality education" actually entails.
Several people outside government who have been following the evolution of the act were asked to comment on aspects of the law they felt were most in need of being amended. All thought the law represented an improvement over the current system of financing public education, but still felt there were wrinkles to be worked out.
Dr. Reock says he is troubled by the use of personal income as a measure of what a community can afford to pay for its public education system. Although the current formula relies only on property wealth, the new law weighs property wealth and personal income equally in an effort to address the problem of rapidly increasing property values in the 1980's that far outpaced personal income gains.
"The problem is, school districts can't tax personal income, and when you measure the wealth of a community using that as one of the factors, it causes a lot of anomalies," Dr. Reock said.
Dr. Reock said that among those who would be hurt by the change were people with low incomes who live in wealthy communities and those on fixed incomes. He said he believed that the law would also be a windfall to commercial and industrial property owners in relatively low-income school districts and to seasonal resort properties, where the year-round population is generally small and relatively poor.
Dr. Reock said even urban areas would be hurt by the addition of an income factor since the spread of incomes in these areas is generally less than the range of property values. For example, Orange's property values, when related to school enrollment, are only 30 percent of the state average, while the community's personal income factor is 90 percent of the state average. Thus, its average state wealth will be 60 percent under the new system, as opposed to 30 percent currently.
"If they just did it on property value, they'd get a lot more state aid and their property taxes would be down," Dr. Reock said.
To circumvent the problem, he said, property value should remain the sole index of determining state aid to education, as it has been for 15 years.
Mr. Coe, who presides over the 13,300-member association of mostly small and middle-sized companies, is not averse to a huge increase in new state aid into the schools, but he is concerned how the money will be spent.
"One the greatest things a governor can do in terms of economic development for the future is to invest in education, particularly in the new, knowledge-based economy," Mr. Coe said. "But before doing too much on the money side, wouldn't it be nice to know exactly what you're doing?"
All the changes Mr. Coe would like to see made to the law would actually add to its expense. He wants the state to continue to pay teacher pension and Social Security costs, estimated to be nearly $900 million a year, and he thinks that wealthy districts have been too severely penalized in the way state aid is meted out.
But the biggest problem with the law, as far as Mr. Coe is concerned, is accountability.
"At the same time the State Department of Education has been given the awesome responsibility of overseeing how the money is spent, its budget is being cut from $45 million to $37 million," Mr. Coe said. "From my standpoint, I'd rather be very comfortable that Ellis had the managerial power and the dollars needed to do a superior job in that connection." He was referring to Dr. John Ellis, the State Commissioner of Education.
Last month, Dr. Ellis acknowledged that the proposed budget cuts for his department would make it very difficult for him to insure the funds were properly spent.
Mr. Tractenberg, founder of the Newark-based Education Law Center, which challenged New Jersey's current system of financing public education, had hoped to see New Jersey adopt a system of full state financing of the schools through an income tax. He thinks that the Quality Education Act does not go far enough in assuring that educational spending in poor urban districts and wealthier ones will be equalized.
"There's a kind of hope and prayer approach, but no specificity about it being accomplished," he said.
The act sets up a formula for general education aid that weighs poorer districts more heavily and is subject to periodic review by the Commissioner of Education, but that is not precise enough for Mr. Tractenberg.
"To close the gap it seems to me one could take a somewhat comparable approach to the way aid will be phased out for the wealthy districts," he said. "You can identify the gap now and say the formula has to cut it by 25 percent a year so that equality of expenditure is achieved."
Mr. Tractenberg said he was also troubled by the way state aid for at-risk and bilingual students would be determined. "The figures are based on what's always been the case, without any requirement that somebody really look at what a good program costs and make sure that that money is available," he said.
Mr. Tractenberg said that recent legislative efforts to divert part of the school aid to property tax relief would almost inevitably lead to future court challenges.
"They fly about as directly in the face of what the Supreme Court said as one can imagine," Mr. Tractenberg said.
Dr. Goertz, who has been analyzing New Jersey's system of financing public education since 1976, says that the biggest flaw in the Quality Education Act is the lack of a strong mechanism to force the state to close spending disparities among school districts. In addition, she says she is concerned that the law does not adequately address the problem of insufficient and aging school buildings.
"As we increase the number of services for students, we're going to have to increase the amount of space available," Dr. Goertz said. "For all-day kindergartens, we need to double the kindergarten space, and if we're hiring more counselors, we need some place to put them."
The act allocates $110 a pupil for buildings, enough, Dr. Goertz said, for maintenance. A $600 million general facilities state bond issue is currently before the Legislature, but Dr. Goertz said that would make only a "dent" in the estimated $2 billion to $4 billion needed to upgrade or expand school buildings. She called for a long-range program, lasting 10 to 20 years, to be developed within the act or in separate legislation that addresses the building-improvements issue comprehensively.
"It's a large problem, and it's not only just an inner-city problem," she said.
 Dr. Smith may hold an unpopular opinion in this wealthy Union County community.
"The act itself is a movement in the right direction for New Jersey," he said. "We do need to provide more resources to urban areas and other tax-poor areas, and we also need to shift resources from more wealthy areas to others."
That said, however, Dr. Smith is disturbed at a number of aspects of the law, including the provision that shifts pension costs from the state to local districts, a restricted cap placed on local spending and the virtual elimination of state aid for at-risk students in wealthy districts. But Dr. Smith's chief complaint is a broader, more philosophical one.
"It fails completely to address the continuing problem in New Jersey of the state mandating all sorts of programs and services and then not providing any assistance," he said.
As an example of excessive intrusiveness, Dr. Smith cited state regulations that require aspirin to be dispensed to a child only by a fully certified school nurse.
"What that has done has required lots of school districts to add certified school nurses," he said. "It's conceivable that a school district might choose not to spend the money on that but to spend the money on a music teacher and let the principal give out the aspirin."
With the elimination of minimum aid for wealthy school districts, Westfield will lose at least $4 million in state aid over the next four years. "That means that we're going to have to eliminate $4 million of what we are doing now," said Dr. Smith, a member of a commission appointed by Governor Florio to review the Quality Education Act and make recommendations on changing the law and shaping what the Governor called a "world class" education for the state's schoolchildren.
"As we wrestle with that very difficult situation, I don't think there should be areas that are out of bounds because the state has passed a law about them," he said.
One of the most debated parts of the Quality Education Act is the provision that shifts pension and Social Security costs from the state to local school districts. Pressed by the New Jersey School Boards Association and other education groups, legislators have introduced more than a dozen bills to reverse the move.
"The problem is, though school boards negotiate salaries, they don't negotiate pension benefits and changes in the state system," Dr. Boose said.
Mr. Florio has agreed to a two-year moratorium on the pension issue while the commission he appointed to review the law completes its study.
But the heated debate about pension costs has obscured an even more fundamental problem with the law, Dr. Boose said. He said school districts needed direction as well as money.
"The Commissioner of Education has talked long and hard about a 'world class' education," he said. "The Department of Education has to divine where they'd like districts to be going. That debate has not taken place.
 "It is incumbent upon the department and the Commissioner that once the ink is dried on the next chapter of this act, that that discussion take place."
The recent emphasis on the act as a means of property tax relief has obscured the purpose of the law, Dr. Boose said.
"There's a need for the Quality Education Act to be viewed as the Quality Education Act and not the quality tax reform act," he said. "There has been a major shift by the politicians to make this act, which was an act for children, an act for taxpayers."

Smith Superintendent Of Schools, Westfield; Dr. Robert E. Boose Executive Director, New Jersey School Boards Association (pg. 11)

SECTION: Section 12NJ; Page 1; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1765 words

HEADLINE: Bursting With Change, New Jersey's Soul Becomes More Diverse

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

 BODY:
AFTER Hong Yoon graduated from dental school and set up his Manhattan practice, he wanted to move his family out of the city and into suburbia. In his search for a community that would offer a touch of Korean culture, Dr. Yoon headed across the Hudson River to New Jersey and found what he was looking for in Fort Lee.
When Gary Repetti and his wife, Barbara, both lifelong Hoboken residents, began thinking about starting a family, they wanted to move to a community that had clean air, open spaces and a better-than-average school system. They left Hoboken, headed south on the Garden State Parkway and found what they were looking for in Toms River. 
 And when Brian, Bradley and Bonnie Burns, two brothers and a sister from Closter, left their parents' Bergen County home in search of apartments, and adventures, of their own, they found what they were looking for in Union City, the municipality that their parents left behind more than 35 years before.
 
Shifting Population
 Such scenes, and thousands like them, underlie the statistics that have been pouring out of government computers since the completion of the 1990 Census of Population and Housing. Experts say that those statistics depict a New Jersey boiling with change -- its suburbs rapidly expanding, its cities radically changing character, its soul becoming increasingly heterogenous and its people taking on a more ethnic hue.
 "The state's center of gravity is changing," said Marilyn Marks Rubin, an associate professor of economics and public administration at the City University of New York. "We're seeing a population shift from the older, more industrial areas in the northeast to the newer, more suburban growth areas in the middle and southern parts of the state."
Ms. Rubin said that while such a shift was predicted by experts and officials, the 1990 census figures have ratified those predictions. Essex County, for example, lost 73,098 residents, or 8.6 percent of its total population, over the last 10 years. During that same time period Ocean County gained 87,165 residents, increasing its population by 25.6 percent. And Atlantic County, benefiting from increased employment in Atlantic City, has seen its population grow by more than 30,000 people.
And to the extent that counties like Passaic and Camden managed to show modest gains in population, Ms. Rubin said, those gains must be attributed in large part to massive migrations of Hispanic people into cities like Passaic, Paterson and Camden.
"Without the influx of the Hispanic population," Ms. Rubin said, "I believe you would have seen a continuing decline in all of the state's major urban areas."
According to the 1990 population counts, which are still subject to revision, 17 of the state's 21 counties showed gains in population while four -- Bergen, Essex, Hudson and Union -- showed losses. Over all, the state grew by 5 percent, or 365,177 residents, for a total of 7,730,188 people.
 But of those new residents only 2,998 were non-Hispanic whites; the remaining 362,179 new arrivals were black, Hispanic, American Indian, Pacific Island, Indian, Arab, Haitian, Jamaican, Asian residents and more than a dozen other ethnic and racial minority groups.
"If there is anything about the census that surprised us, it is the increasing diversity of the population," said Dr. James W. Hughes, chairman of the graduate department of urban planning and policy at Rutgers-New Brunswick.
 "During the 1980's we've had some suburbanization of blacks and Hispanics," Mr. Hughes said. "And the replacement populations have been more Hispanics and other new immigrants."
According to the census, the state's black population grew by 111,759, or 12.1 percent. The Hispanic population, which was just short of a half million in 1980, increased dramatically over the last 10 years to 739,861. And other various racial and ethnic groups, which include many new immigrants, grew by 75,359 to 275,407.
 
Asians in Suburbs
 "New Jersey has always been an easy place for immigrants to settle," Mr. Hughes said. "Our cities have always been replenished by immigration."
And while Hispanic and other immigrants are moving into the cities, he said, another growing group of new arrivals is in large part bypassing the cities entirely and moving directly into suburbia.
"Certain groups of Asians arrive in this country almost fully Americanized," Mr. Hughes said. "They fit in almost immediately."
The highest percentage change in any immigrant population over the last 10 years has been with the Asian community. In 1980 there were an estimated 103,800 immigrants of Asian or Pacific Island origin. Since then their numbers increased by 168,673 to 272,521; an increase of more than 162 percent.
"The numbers reflect the changing face of New Jersey," Mr. Hughes said. "Visually people can see it. Just go into any shopping center."
 Yaohan Plaza in Edgewater, while not just any shopping center, provides clear evidence of the foothold that the Asian community has gained in New Jersey. One of six such centers in the country -- the five others are in California -- Yaohan caters almost exclusively to Asian tastes.
 
Asian and Hispanic Influence
 With its large supermarket, food court, specialty stores and even a video rental store with Japanese-language films, Yaohan attracts Japanese, Chinese, Pacific Islander and Korean immigrants from throughout the region. Dr. Yoon, who had originally considered moving to Flushing, Queens, after setting up his dental practice, discovered New Jersey's Korean population as the result of shopping at Yaohan.
And though referred to as the company's "New York store" in advertisements, it was no coincidence that Yaohan U.S.A. Corporation officials put their only East Coast center on the New Jersey side of the Hudson River. Bergen County, long the refuge of white middle-class families fleeing the cities, is now home to more than 54,000 Asian immigrants, the highest such concentration of Asians in the state.
In fact, Asians apparently did for Bergen County what Hispanic people did for the state's larger cities -- help to offset a diminishing population. Even with more than 54,000 Asians living there, the largest minority population in the county, Bergen lost more than 20,000 residents over the last 10 years.
"The empty-nest syndrome is continuing," said Connie O. Hughes, assistant director of planning and development in the State Department of Labor. "In many cases, 20, 30 years ago, couples moved in, bought big houses and had their three kids or what have you." Mrs. Hughes is married to Dr. James W. Hughes.
 
Smaller Households
 But through the 1980's, as property values increased dramatically, many Bergen County homes were priced out of the reach of young families and first-time home buyers, including the sons and daughters of Bergen County residents themselves.
"The reason for the decline in the population in Bergen is the decline in the average household size," Mrs. Hughes said. "The kids have grown up and moved out and the parents are remaining behind."
Helynn Masullo Burns and her husband, Charles, for example, moved into a large house in Closter in 1953 so that their children, Brian, Bradley, Bonnie and Bruce, would not be raised in Hudson County. Now, the children have moved out, and Mr. and Mrs. Burns remain in a house with four empty bedrooms. They had considered, briefly, moving to Florida.
"But my roots are here," Mrs. Burns said, "and my friends. What would I do without my friends?"
Another reason for remaining in Closter, Mrs. Burns said, is that her children are still relatively close by; as close, that is, as Union City.
"They're a half a block away from where we came from," Mrs. Burns said. "They made a complete circle after we worked so hard to get them out here."
 
Change in Hudson County
 Hudson County, the first stop for the huge wave of Italian, Irish and German immigrants who arrived at the turn of the century, has taken on a new, attractive aura after a decade or two of decline. Fueled largely by a substantial Cuban immigration during the 1950's and 60's, the "Gold Coast," as it is often called, is now attracting young, single educated professionals who are bored with the peace and quiet that their parents sought so ardently in the suburbs.
But Hudson is losing residents, though barely. In 1980 there were 556,972 people in the county's 12 municipalities. In 1990, that figure declined to 553,099. The biggest part of Hudson's decline took place in what is considered its most desirable city: Hoboken.
Ten years ago, Hoboken had 42,460 residents. That number dropped consistently through the decade to a present level of 33,397.
Hoboken's business administrator, Edwin Chius, said part of the decline was the result of immigration. Relatively affluent new arrivals, he said, are buying the turn-of-the-century brownstones that used to house two or three traditionally large immigrant families and turning them into one-family showpieces occupied by childless single people and newly married couples.
 
Looking for Fresh Air
 At the same time, the sons and daughters of longtime Hoboken families who are beginning to start families of their own are now being priced out of the Hoboken housing market. Some, like the Repettis , have chosen to forgo the traditional first move that most Hudson County exiles make to Bergen County, and, like thousands of other North Jersey residents, have discovered Ocean County.
"There's fresh air, less crime, better schools and more activity down here," Mr. Repetti said. "Bergen County was out for me; it's a little too crowded. And western New Jersey might have been an idea, but once I got a feel for Ocean County, I fell in love with it."
So did 87,165 other men and women, mostly from the northern part of the state, during the last 10 years. Ocean County showed the largest percentage gain in population of any county in New Jersey. Many who moved there were retirees who flocked to the sprawling retirement villages scattered throughout the county.
But many others, like the Repettis, are young couples who, like their parents, wanted to raise their children away from the turmoil of the city. And many, like Mr. Repetti, who is a Hoboken firefighter, commute from their Shore homes to their jobs in northern New Jersey and Manhattan.
"It's worth the two-hour drive," Mr. Repetti said. "I just put the car on auto-pilot and think of all the time I'm saving by not having to look for a parking space when I get home."

HEADLINE: Campus Life: Maryland;
Scientist Seeks Ways to Speed Growth of Fish

DATELINE: COLLEGE PARK, Md.

 BODY:
The world may soon be able to use genetic engineering or special hormones to make fish grow to market size faster and to increase world food supplies, says a University of Maryland marine biologist who is working to make it happen.
Thomas Chen, a biologist and professor in the biological sciences department at the University of Maryland-Baltimore County, says he already has rainbow trout and oysters growing at least 20 percent faster -- and sometimes as much as 50 percent faster -- than normal, depending on the method used. 
 Dr. Chen said his project was one of several in which researchers are concentrating on fish, rather than cattle, partly because fish could be a readily available, economical food source for much of the world, and partly to reduce the United States' dependence on fish imports. The United States trade deficit for fish products was about $4 billion in 1989, he said.
"The idea to make fish grow faster has been around for a long time," said Dr. Chen, who has been experimenting at the Center for Marine Biotechnology at Baltimore Community College, a two-year college in the University of Maryland system.
"From a scientific standpoint," Dr. Chen said, "fish represent a good model system because there are several different species, from simple to highly evolved. A pragmatic reason is the ongoing situation with population increases and awareness of nutrition. Fish show a great potential to feed people."
 
 A Gene for Growth
 Dr. Chen and two collaborators at other universities are experimenting with two different processes.
The first approach relies on a growth hormone cloned from rainbow trout. Fish are dipped in water that has the hormone dissolved in it for a minute and a half once weekly for four weeks. The second approach involves altering the genetic makeup of a fish by transferring a gene for growth into the fish, which is passed on to subsequent generations.
Unlike humans, fish continue to grow throughout their lives, but Dr. Chen said he and his eight graduate-student assistants are not interested in creating bigger fish. They simply want fish to reach market size faster, thus getting more fish to market in a shorter time and saving fish farmers money.
Dr. Chen has been working on fish growth since 1982, starting at McMaster College in Hamilton, Ontario. He came to Maryland in 1986, when he began his collaboration with Dennis Powers at Stanford University and Rex Dunham at Auburn University. The project is underwritten by grants from the National Science Foundation, the Federal Government and state grants from the Department of Natural Resources and the Maryland University Sea Grant.
 
 Need Further Testing
 The effects of both experimental processes need further testing, Dr. Chen said. He also said that he and his colleagues must research methods for producing large quantities of the growth hormone economically before they can make it available commercially. The timetable will depend on the project's finances, Dr. Chen said.
Dr. Chen says rainbow trout and oysters have responded to both methods, growing 20 to 50 percent faster with the dipping process and 20 to 40 percent faster with the gene transfers.
But he said the researchers needed to determine which nutrients, and in what amounts, to feed to the fish so that they do not grow abnormally.
"A trout usually takes two years to get to market size, which is about a pound to a pound and a half," Dr. Chen said, adding that with the application of the hormones or using the gene-transfer technique, the fish should reach market size in a year and a few months.
 
 'We Only Use a Small Dose'
 Dr. Chen said he could not foresee any negative effects of the techniques on fish, humans or the environment.
"We have done experiments with higher doses of hormones, and they won't make the fish grow faster, so we only use a small dose," he said. And he said, "because the hormone is a protein, the hormone will be degraded in the fish," unlike the growth hormone, estrogen, that was once used to increase growth in beef cattle, but was found to leave residues.
He noted, too, that "We are not letting the fish run free. We harvest every single one. None are released into the environment" to endanger the natural food chain.
With continued research, Dr. Chen said he hoped that the hormone would be available for government approval in two to four years and the gene transfer in five to eight years.
"The work we are doing is especially important for developing countries," said Yan Lin Tang, a graduate student in biotechnology from China, who has been working on the project for three years while attending the College Park campus. "After working on the gene, we can watch the process of evolution, and we can use this gene and this hormone to study from."
