HEADLINE: Stamps

BYLINE: By Barth Healey

 BODY:
There are a lot of collectors -- hoarders, really -- who accumulate modern stamps for the wrong reason: to make money.
A week does not pass without a letter arriving that asks, in effect, "Will my stock of old 3- , 4- and 5-cent United States stamps ever make me rich?" Alas, no. 
 Anyone who stashes away 50-stamp panes of new stamps might just as well keep only the block of stamps with the plate numbers in the margin and use the rest for postage. The same applies to older collections that were started by children, abandoned and have just been found in the attic. Most children, after all, did not spend much on their collections in the 1930's or 40's, acquiring common stamps that remain common today.
A bit of supply-and-demand sense must prevail: There are millions, indeed billions of United States stamps printed each year. There are only perhaps 250,000 active collectors. Supply far outweighs demand.
A review of the quantities of stamps issued by the United States, summarized in Linn's Stamp Almanac, turns up some very large numbers: From October 1981 to October 1985, for example, the issues of all but one of the commemorative United States stamps were over 100 million; for 12 commemoratives, the total exceeded 700 million each. That was when postal rates were changing fairly often, requiring a lot of new stamps.
From May 1964 to March 1972, a time of less frequent rate changes, only three commemorative issues fell below the 100 million mark, and eight topped a billion. In fact, except for some special printings, no commemorative in this century has had a print run of less than a million stamps.
To get an idea of what old stamps are worth, consider the 1941 3-cent stamp marking the sesquicentennial of Vermont statehood, an occasion mirrored Friday with an issue for Vermont's bicentennial. Fifty-four million Vermont stamps were issued in 1941. The Scott catalogue estimates that one stamp would fetch 14 cents at retail today; the wholesale value is less than half that. Taking inflation into consideration, 3 cents in 1941 would be worth about 25 cents today and so the 3-cent Vermont stamps would not seem to have been a particularly good investment. (The plate number block did better; it is priced by Scott at $1.75, but can often be bought for much less.)
There are some exceptions. High-value definitives, of $1 face value and more, have risen in price because fewer collectors buy expensive stamps when they come out.
Error stamps, which might lack perforations, or be missing a color, or show the center of the stamp inverted, can be worth thousands. But the chance of buying such stamps over the post office counter is slight, even though, with high-speed presses and mechanized packaging of stamps, such errors are increasingly common. Some imperforate coil stamps can be had for a few dollars.
And there are the genuine 20th-century rarities. The three zeppelin airmails, which were on sale for less than three months in early 1930 and of which only 62,000 complete sets were printed, are valued by Scott at $2,000 the set. Their total face value, $4.55, was a very large sum to spend on a hobby in 1930.
So what is one to make of the Postal Service's vigorous promotion of stamp sales to collectors? Paul T. Clark, of Hilton Head Island, S.C., asked the service just that question. Mr. Clark said in a telephone interview that, when he began to accumulate panes of new stamps several years ago, he felt the post office was emphasizing investment potential.
Not so, answered Mary Margaret Grant, director of new markets for the Postal Service. In a letter to Mr. Clark, she said: "You are correct in noting that my job is to sell stamps. But, in the 10 years that I have worked in the philatelic department, I have not seen any material from the Postal Service that indicated that stamps would appreciate in value."
The hobby, she added, is merely "educational and pleasant." Mr. Clark now uses his old stamps for postage.

HEADLINE: A June Wedding For Amy Borrus

 BODY:
Mr. and Mrs. Jack Borrus of Princeton, N.J., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Amy Borrus and Richard M. Miller, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George M. Miller of Riverdale, the Bronx.
 Miss Borrus, 34 years old, is a foreign policy correspondent for Business Week magazine in Washington. Her fiance, 37, is the senior economic correspondent for the Americas for Reuters in Washington.
 The prospective bride graduated magna cum laude from the University of Pennsylvania and has a master's degree in international relations from the London School of Economics.  The bridegroom-to-be graduated cum laude from Fordham University. His mother, Marian B. Miller, teaches at the David A. Stein Junior High School in Riverdale. His father, who is retired, was a sales representative for a New York distributor for Anheuser-Busch.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Wages of War: A Dearth Of Capital

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
The war is won. Now the world will get to pay for it. One cost may be higher interest rates.
An emerging worldwide shortage of capital may help to explain the fact short-term rates have plunged while long-term ones have not, despite the Fed's repeated easing of credit. 
 In the 1980's, there seemed to be a surplus of capital, as Japan and rich oil states exported it. But, says Alan C. Lerner, an economist at Bankers Trust, "We won't see the same sort of thing in the first half of the 90's. Western Europe will need capital, Eastern Europe will need capital, the Middle East will need capital and the United States is going to need capital. We definitely don't save enough here to offset our public demands for capital."
The American need for public capital is clear from the budget deficits and the infrastructure problems shown by crumbling bridges. But what is different is the need to rebuild Eastern Europe, coming at a time when the Japanese economy is slowing and the Japanese people are showing less willingness to delay consumption. The Mideast war has turned Kuwait from a huge capital exporter into an importer, a situation that may last for a sustained period of time.
With all those demands for cash, it is easy to imagine a situation of competitive interest-rate increases to attract funds. If that happens, it probably is bad news for stock markets, whose advances are predicated in part on lower interest rates. With most of the English-speaking world in recession, those central banks have been easing credit. But the German and Japanese monetary authorities so far have been reluctant to go along.
Ed Kerschner of Paine Webber is one bull on stocks who thinks those central banks will fall in line with the trend to lower interest rates, producing "the big easy" that drives down interest rates everywhere, and causes long-term bond yields to fall rapidly in this country. But he adds that stock prices here may be overvalued if long-term rates do not fall.
The American markets now are more focused on guessing what the Fed will do. Friday's employment report from February was bad, and some thought they saw a sign of further Fed easing in the Fed funds market. But bond prices still fell, and there is doubt that there will be much more from the Fed until evidence starts to build on just how much of a jump-start the economy got from the public euphoria brought on by the end of the war.
In the meantime, the 3,000 Dow is still an elusive goal. The second assault on that level last week, coming more than seven months after the first one, was repulsed, and the index ended the week up 45.30 points, to 2,955.20.
It may be worth noting that while three-month Treasury bills -- which the Fed strongly influences -- now are 1.64 percentage points below where they were when the last run at 3,000 was made, 30-year Treasury bond yields declined less and have been rising since mid-February, to within 0.14 points of the level last July. Despite the Fed's efforts, long-term capital is not getting less expensive.

HEADLINE: A Financial Giant's Slippery Slope

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
The Tokyo stock market is finally recovering from a vicious year-long plunge, Wall Street is showing signs of a rejuvenation and, most important, financial systems around the globe are being deregulated. It would seem to be a time of fresh opportunity, yet Yoshihisa Tabuchi, the most powerful individual in Japan's financial markets, speaks like a troubled man.
"Over the past few years, we may have overemphasized the positive side of all the changes taking place," said Mr. Tabuchi, president and chief executive of the Nomura Securities Company, the world's largest brokerage house. "There was a relatively small amount of discussion of the negative side, the limits that we would face. Especially when I look at the American financial markets, I see confusion." 
 Indeed, even for a formidable global colossus like Nomura -- it has a staggering $14.7 billion in equity behind it, four-and-a-half times as much as Merrill Lynch & Company, America's largest brokerage house -- these are trying times. The firm's profits are expected to plunge up to 60 percent in the fiscal year ending March 31, from $2.1 billion the previous year.
The performance is expected to be better than Nomura's Japanese rivals, the other members of the so-called Big Four. All were battered by the market plunge, set off by a steep rise in interest rates and then Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. But that is scant comfort since none of the others -- Daiwa, Nikko and Yamaichi -- has set its sights as high, or taken such bold steps to become a global financial supermarket.
Nomura's dominant position in many businesses is under siege, too. For instance, it retained its No. 1 ranking last year for underwritings in the Euromarket, the fourth straight year it has held the top spot. But its market share was slashed almost in half, to less than 9 percent. In Tokyo, it was late in taking up the newest imported fad, computerized program trading, and thus finds itself a distant fourth in the lucrative activity -- behind three American securities houses.
 
Worried and Ambivalent
 The firm's challenges run much deeper than a bad year, however, and that is what worries the 58-year-old Mr. Tabuchi, who became chief executive in 1985. Securities executives have long claimed their business thrives on change, and fundamental shifts are indeed gripping the financial world. But Mr. Tabuchi expressed a thoroughly ambivalent attitude toward those prospects: while fighting to instill new thinking at Nomura, where he has spent his entire 35-year career, Mr. Tabuchi is resisting mightily the fundamental liberalization of the heavily regulated Tokyo financial markets, the source of Nomura's raw power.
It is a contradiction that speaks volumes about Nomura. It also provides a sobering insight into how elusive a goal globalization, in which Nomura had been expected to take a lead, is proving.
There are two types of deregulation being debated here. One is to permit the use of new financial products and to ease outmoded controls, such as those on interest rates. The other type, lowering the rigid barriers that limit competition between different kinds of financial institutions, is much more threatening. Japanese trust banks, commercial banks and long-term credit banks cannot invade each others' turf, and thus enjoy cartel-like benefits.
More important, Japanese banks are prohibited from entering most areas of the securities business -- as in the United States. Those days appear to be ending, however. In a historic move, Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady early last month proposed scrapping the wall separating the two financial areas in the United States. Japan's Finance Ministry has also made it clear that, in one form or another, it intends to force Nomura and the other securities houses to share their cozy domain with Japan's giant banks, perhaps by 1993.
 
Question of Ethics
 Nomura is fighting hard against that threat, warning of the damage liberalization has allegedly caused.
"During the course of deregulation and financial innovation, people tended to forget about the ethics of the market," Mr. Tabuchi said. "Whatever new business you do you must remember to protect your customers and investors. But the tendency was for players to forget these ethics for their own immediate profits. The desirable approach is not to ask who does what and who is not supposed to do what, but how efficient and how convenient the new financial system will be."
"Having said that," Mr. Tabuchi added, in a telling afterthought, "further deregulation of new financial products should progress. That is an entirely different issue, how to innovate and make these new securities available to investors."
Mr. Tabuchi issued his brooding, if ambiguous, verdicts in firm but measured tones, puffing on one cigarette after another in an executive suite that lies on the most elite plane in Japan's securities world. The whisper-quiet hallways at Nomura's squat brick headquarters are elegantly hung with Chagalls and Corots. There is an air of haughty self-assurance, for few Japanese companies dominate their business as Nomura does.
To stand on Nomura's immense, sparkling new trading floor is to be at the center of power in the Japanese market. Along with its affiliates, Nomura, which has total assets of $47 billion, accounts for almost 20 percent of the trading volume on the Tokyo market and about 30 percent of the investment trust, or Japanese mutual fund, business. It has 4,400 retail brokers, the backbone of its business, and another 2,900 salespeople, all women, who peddle stocks and other investments door-to-door.
With that heft, it is widely believed Nomura can manipulate individual stocks, even the market, at will. Officially, that is always denied; in private, Nomura executives occasionally acknowledge that their firm, as well as the other Big Four, can -- and do -- push share prices at times. Nomura, in short, is feared as much if not more than it is respected.
Although expanding profits are important to the money machine over which he presides, Mr. Tabuchi, a hard-driving man who is also a fancier of fine wines and art, has set an even more ambitious goal for his tenure. He is attempting to transform what is essentially a huge distribution network, which relies on raw marketing muscle to outsell everyone else, into a genuinely modern securities house with the innovative savvy of Wall Street's best.
 
New World Order
 Nomura wants to be as comfortable cutting real estate deals, devising new mortgage-backed securities, constructing computer trading strategies, writing sophisticated lease financings, arranging mergers and creating new corporate structures anywhere in the world as it is at sales of stocks and bonds.
A few years ago, in better times, its leap into a greater global role had seemed a modest step considering its success, size and willingness to experiment. But the hurdles in its path are growing more obvious:
* Its once-booming European business has slowed as Japanese companies, stung by soaring interest rates, have pulled back from issuing Euromarket securities. A major portion of Nomura's business in the Euromarkets is still with Japanese companies and institutions, not Europeans. "In 1988 and 1989, the contribution to our profits from Japanese money flowing to the Euromarkets had been staggering," said Hitoshi Tonomura, head of international operations. "That has been substantially reduced."
* Nomura has taken the lead in acquiring a stake in specialized American financial firms to advance into businesses in which it lacks expertise, including mergers, leasing and real estate. Just a week ago, it formed a joint venture with a commodities trading specialist, the Tudor Investment Corporation. Some Nomura executives in the United States have complained, though, that those operations have left Nomura's activities fragmented.
* The firm suffered a black eye with the publication last year of "The House of Nomura," a book that suggested Nomura routinely breaks the rules -- manipulating share prices, for example. Nomura has filed a libel suit against Al Alletzhauser, the author, which is pending in London, but that only attracted more attention to the reported improprieties.
* The firm is still struggling to cast off its image as a "kabuya," a derisive term that might be translated as "stock shop," the way one would refer to a fish store. The moniker suggests the giant securities houses are nothing but merchants, selling their wares for a commission. In fact, since commission rates are fixed in Japan, those simple fees for executing trades still account for 41 percent of Nomura's consolidated revenues. Merrill Lynch, to which Nomura is sometimes compared, gets 15 percent of revenues from commissions.
 
Coveted Role
 Brokerage houses here have traditionally relied on these basic transactions rather than building intimate relationships with the real movers of corporate Japan. That coveted role, which is essential for the future, is held by commercial banks.
"In Japan, the banking industry and the securities industry are oriented on very different cultures," conceded Hideo Sakamaki, Nomura's head of strategic planning and human resources, who is leading the diversification effort.
When Wasserstein, Perella & Company, the American mergers specialist that sold a 20 percent share to Nomura, initially considered taking on a Japanese partner, it spoke first to the elite Industrial Bank of Japan as the best entree to corporate Japan. (A Wasserstein, Perella executive disputed this, but others with knowledge of the dealings confirmed the discussions, led by Joseph Perella.)
"If you come right down to it, Nomura has a franchise called the Tokyo Stock Exchange," said Robert Zielinski, an analyst at Jardine Fleming Securities and author of a recent book on the Japanese market. "They have exploited that franchise to the fullest extent. But except for size, there's nothing to distinguish them from the other Big Four firms. They'll never do as well in any other market as they have here."
Evidence of the struggle to adopt a new image crops up everywhere. Asked if its sales network was not the heart of Nomura, Yoshikazu Kitsuda, who runs the securities sales and trading operations and is rumored to be a possible successor to Mr. Tabuchi, responded crisply, "Exactly! Placement power." He was quickly corrected by Michio Katsumata, a public relations executive, who added, "And brain power, too."
An even more telling sign is the acknowledged weakness of Nomura's operations in the United States, despite years of effort and the expenditure of hundreds of millions of dollars. On Wall Street, Nomura's operations generated just $20 million in pre-tax income in the last fiscal year -- a third of the income Nomura earned in Hong Kong and one-eighth of its income in London. Using another measure, Nomura devoted about 20 percent of its assets to the United States in the last fiscal year, but received just 4 percent of its overall revenues there.
Because Wall Street is the most liberalized major financial market, it is regarded as a test of how well the giant broker can compete in an arena where ideas and an ability to take risks count for more than a huge capital base and sales muscle.
"Nomura has a lot of marketing power in Japan and Europe," Mr. Sakamaki commented. "But we are really just starting in the United States. It will take a little more time."
Max C. Chapman Jr., a former top executive at Kidder, Peabody & Company, is co-chairman of Nomura's American unit. Last year, he was invited to join the parent company's board in Tokyo, the first time an outsider had been so honored. It was a pithy symbol, but Mr. Chapman said he still has to work hard to get Nomura's executives to appreciate that some of the practices that are an asset in Tokyo are liabilities in the more competitive Wall Street arena.
 
Pushing for Change
 These include the traditional aversion to using the firm's own capital in trading, called principal trading; the lack of a history of maintaining tight bonds between the research, trading and investment banking departments in order to create new products, and the practice of rotating professionals every couple of years. That creates generalists who often lack the expertise needed to engage in higher-risk and demanding businesses.
"We have to turn this into more of a principal business," Mr. Chapman said. "That makes them nervous."
Some at Nomura agree such skills might be needed overseas, but shrink from the idea that the firm should adopt them at home. "We have to add some Japanese flavor to whatever we bring back," said Mr. Tonomura.
However, to underscore the need to change the old patterns of thought, Nomura broke out its training division as a separate company, giving it more visibility and influence. Mr. Tabuchi is chairman of the unit, the only subsidiary at which he has a title, another sign of the unit's importance.
As chief executive, he has prodded and pulled at this unwieldy giant, which has 16,000 employees, to try to shake it from its old ways. In one published interview, Mr. Tabuchi even said it might be a good thing if Nomura suffered some sort of failure -- an almost unthinkable calamity for a proud Nomura man -- to pry his executives away from the view that what worked in the past will work in the future.
Mr. Tabuchi has been bold in his overseas moves, something rare at a large Japanese company, and more successful than his Japanese competitors. But the setbacks of the past year have made his task heavier rather than lighter as he moves into what are expected to be the final few years of his rule.
Mr. Tabuchi does not deny feeling frustrated on the road to globalization: "A C.E.O. who has no frustrations better resign at once. Frustration in running a large organization is a burden a C.E.O. has to bear."
 
DANCING TO WALL STREET'S M.&A. TUNE
 If there is one business that symbolizes the kind of firm the Nomura Securities Company hopes to remake itself into, it is mergers and acquisitions. The business involves selling ideas rather than products, requires tact and nimbleness and is becoming increasingly international.
In fact, Nomura has been in the business for some time in Japan. But there is one big difference between the traditional Japanese style of M.&A. and Wall Street's: in Japan, rarely has it generated fees.
"This business was often done by politicians or some kind of fixer, and they would receive a gift, not really a fee," said Mitsuo Goto, head of Nomura's budding mergers practice. "When it was done by a securities firm, it was a free service."
Nomura has set out to change that. It has joined forces with Wasserstein, Perella & Company, the Wall Street merger specialist. The Americans have a great deal more experience in the nuts and bolts of these deals, and if there is one thing Wasserstein, Perella does well, it is to charge fees.
Nomura bought 20 percent of the American firm for $100 million in 1988, and set up a new unit in Japan, the Nomura Wasserstein Perella Company, as a joint venture.
Nomura has picked up another authentic American practice from its new partner: an unashamed desire to grab credit for deals. That is something of a contrast to the discretion expected of corporate matchmakers in Japan, but times are changing.
The shift was never more in evidence than during the acquisition of MCA Inc. late last year by the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company. Matsushita disclosed that its investment banking adviser was Allen & Company. But no sooner had the two sides shaken hands than N.W.P. announced that it had also advised Matsushita, albeit in a secret capacity. That prompted a miffed Matsushita executive to quip that he found it a bit unusual to publicly declare supposed secrets.
"I can say we've learned a lot about M.&A. from the U.S.," said Mr. Goto, president of N.W.P.
The creation of the mergers unit, one of four such partnerships between Nomura and American financial specialists, is an admission of Nomura's inability to develop the businesses from within, Mr. Goto acknowledged, adding that he felt the arrangements had been a success.
"Investment banking is a kind of clubby world," he said. "We were invited to the party, but we couldn't get the business."
Nomura Wasserstein Perella has not engaged in the series of blockbuster deals some had envisioned, but Mr. Goto said it has served as an adviser in 44 completed transactions.
 
HOMEY SIDE OF THE HARD SELL
 To most Japanese, the Nomura Securities Company means hard sell. Its broker force is renowned for its don't-take-no-for-an-answer style.
But there are still many Japanese who disdain such aggressive methods and prefer a homier, traditional approach. Nomura has an answer for them, too: what it calls "middies," women who peddle investment products door-to-door like Avon ladies.
Middies is short for middle-aged, a reference to the fact that the 2,900 troops who fill these slots in the Nomura sales army are women in their late 30's to early 50's. Nomura says they generally are housewives with a family who take the job for the extra money. They are paid a salary plus commissions and usually have a regular group of long-time customers.
Nomura first employed middies in 1953, in the lean postwar years. Housewives were given locked boxes in which they could deposit savings. When the boxes were filled, Nomura sent women around to pick them up in exchange for shares in investment trusts, or mutual funds.
Nomura is not alone. The other large brokerages also employ this shoe-leather approach, and much of the life insurance sold in Japan is peddled door-to-door, by one housewife to another.
The middies are a throwback in more ways than one. They can sell only bonds and investment trusts. Their license forbids them from selling stocks or the fancier products becoming popular here, futures and options. That job is left to the regular branch office sales force, which is largely male.
Nomura says the middies do not account for a major share of its retail sales. But their continued role is a symbol of the firm's deep roots in the retail brokerage business, and the stubbornly traditional style of salesmanship that business demands.

HEADLINE: World Markets;
Searching for the Dollar's Top

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
Since the end of the war in the Persian Gulf, the consensus view on the dollar has reversed quickly. And the change could significantly effect Americans who invest abroad.
Many analysts think the dollar has finally hit bottom. "We now feel we know where the bottom is," said Nicholas Sargen, director of international bond research at Salomon Brothers Inc. in New York. "Now the question is 'Where is the top?' " 
 Since it hit a new record low against the mark of 1.4475 four weeks ago, the dollar has jumped to 1.5694, a rise of 8.4 percent. While analysts disagree on how high the dollar might climb, the fact that a further dramatic fall is no longer expected changes the terms -- especially the outlook for profits -- for Americans investing abroad.
Now, after several years of relatively easy gains from favorable exchange rates, there is a greater risk of a loss when foreign profits are turned back into dollars. "The value in international markets is overseas but you might get killed now by the currency," said Geoffrey Dennis, an international economist and strategist at James Capel Inc. in New York. "If people bought bonds and stocks in Europe as a currency play, they may be wrong a lot quicker than they thought."
One of the pivotal factors in the dollar's rise was the decision in late February by the German coalition Government led by Helmut Kohl to raise taxes to help pay for the unification and reconstruction of the old East Germany. The announcement reverses the pledge against tax increases that Chancellor Kohl made before the first election in unified Germany last year. Many analysts thought Chancellor Kohl would have to raise taxes. But until he acted, they could not adjust their forecasts for interest rates and therefore, the dollar.
The tax increases change the outlook for the dollar by increasing revenues, reducing the growing German budget deficit and, in the process, taking some pressure off the German Bundesbank. The central bank has been raising interest rates to fight the inflationary impact of German unification. The President of the central bank, Karl Otto Pohl had made it clear that interest rates, which last increased at the end of January, might move higher if the Government continued to insist on borrowing to pay for the unification rather than raising taxes.
Now, there is less of a chance that German interest rates will rise any further. In fact, rates could begin to fall by the end of the year, some analysts predict. This helps the dollar by reducing the allure of mark-denominated securities.
Michael R. Rosenberg, manager of international fixed income research at Merrill Lynch & Company in New York, said the tax increases would slow German economic growth and add to inflation. This has forced him to change his economic model forecast for the dollar. Before the German action, he was bearish on the dollar, predicting as recently as two weeks ago that it would end the year at 1.45 marks. But he now projects a rally to 1.70 marks.
The other major factor shaping the new thinking on the dollar was the quick end to the war and the growing belief that the recession in the United States will not be severe. Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, supported this perspective in testimony before Congress last week.
Short-term rates may fall a little further, as was indicated on Friday, when the Federal Reserve may have nudged down the Federal funds rate. But because the recovery appears imminent, analysts no longer expect that the Federal Reserve will have to lower interest rates aggressively to revive the economy. It was this expectation that had sent the dollar to new lows. Lower rates make the dollar less attractive to investors.
"I don't have the expectation any more that the Fed will go pedal-to-the-metal on lowering interest rates," said Mr. Sargen of Salomon Brothers.
The change in view has come so quickly that advice written just weeks ago has become outdated. Mr. Sargen and John Lipsky, a Salomon Brothers research director in London, recommended nondollar bond markets strongly in a report in mid-February. At the time, the dollar was trading at about 1.49 marks, and they assumed that it would decline to new lows near 1.40 against the German mark before rallying a little.
The changing scenario will alter investment decisions. Mr. Sargen and Mr. Lipsky had thought the risk of the dollar rising would not be a worry until the end of this year. Now, said Mr. Sargen, "the risk has been brought foreward. You can not now rush to Europe for the currency play."
But there is a plus side in the rise of the dollar. Stocks of European companies that are major exporters to the United States or that have major subsidiaries here will benefit. The stronger dollar will make their products more competitive and their American earnings will not suffer a currency loss when they are converted back home.
And many analysts argue that European bonds will outperform United States bonds this year because of the expected steeper drop in interest rates there. This means that as a hedge against the rise in the dollar, these nondollar bonds can still be attractive.

HEADLINE: FORUM;
One Way for Business to Go Green

BYLINE: By JACK DOYLE; Jack Doyle is senior analyst of technology and corporate policy for Friends of the Earth in Washington.

 BODY:
Last April, Du Pont's oil subsidiary, Conoco, announced it would build new double-hulled oil tankers designed to reduce oil spills. A few days later, the H. J. Heinz Company said it would no longer fish for tuna on dolphin sightings or use drift nets. And in November, McDonald's announced it would do away with its plastic foam "clamshell" hamburger box. These headline-making actions, and others like them, signal important changes in corporate environmental thinking. Yet, double-hulled tankers, dolphin-safe tuna and abandoned polystyrene packaging -- while praiseworthy -- do not make corporations environmentally responsible.
One way for multinationals like Du Pont, Heinz and McDonald's to become more environmentally responsible is for them to sign the Valdez Principles, named after the Exxon Valdez, the oil tanker that ran aground in Alaska causing a massive oil spill. This is a code of conduct aimed at improving the entire company's environmental performance. The principles not only require companies to respect the environment but also to market safe products and services and accept responsibility for any environmental damage they may cause. These principles require companies to disclose operations that might cause harm to the environment and to appoint at least one director to represent environmental interests. They also require an annual environmental audit. 
 The Valdez Principles are the brainchild of a group of environmental, investor, religious and consumer interests called the Coalition for Environmentally Responsible Economies. This is the largest and most significant environmental and investor coalition now working to change corporate environmental practices. It includes the National Wildlife Federation, the New York City and California state pension funds and the National Council of Churches, among others. Since the formulation of the Valdez Principles in September 1989, the Fortune 500 companies have resisted signing, though a number of large concerns are now negotiating with the coalition. Representatives of the chemical and energy industries have let the word go out that no company should break ranks by signing the Valdez Principles. Instead, these industry groups have advanced their own principles.
But industry codes are not likely to be trusted by a public already skeptical about corporate environmental claims. Who will check on these companies? That is where the Valdez Principles and the annual coalition review could play an invaluable role in communicating progress to the news media and the public. For the Valdez Principles try to establish a standard disclosure process, something that industry needs but cannot provide.
The Valdez Principles can also help companies hone their resource and production efficiencies to competitive advantage. In the 1990's and beyond, a company's competitive position may well turn on its net environmental performance.
What is needed then is a special group of corporate leaders with the courage to sign onto a process with investors, environmentalists and consumers that will not be a cakewalk. Clearly, companies need something more than problem-of-the-month environmental fixes. They need to institute "whole company" environmentalism -- programs that internalize environmental protection throughout the company.

HEADLINE: FORUM;
Blame the Recession on Tax Reform

BYLINE: By RONALD G. WEINER; Ronald G. Weiner is president of Weiner Associates, an accounting firm in New York.

 BODY:
It is clear to all we are in a recession. But what is not so clear is the causal relationship between the Tax Reform Act of 1986 and today's economy. In essence, the act and its successors reduced tax rates and brackets and substantially unified the treatment of taxable income. But it also reduced the incentive to incur debt and take entrepreneurial risk. Investment in real estate also lost many of its incentives.
Because of the 1986 law, consumer spending is down, businesses are weaker and real estate values have been decimated. Trying to revitalize the economy by lowering interest rates alone will not be sufficient. Tax law and policy must be revised. 
 The economics of business investment were profoundly affected by the elimination of the differential between capital gains and ordinary income tax rates. There is no longer the same incentive for making higher risk investments.
The interplay between tax rates and interest costs has a profound effect on the acquisition of capital equipment. When the tax rate was 50 percent and interest was 10 percent, the post-tax cost would have been 5 percent, or roughly today's rate of inflation. But with a tax rate of 33 percent, the post-tax cost is about 7 percent. This means that the investment return must be 40 percent greater than before reform to achieve the break-even point on a leveraged investment decision.
Real estate values were particularly affected by lower tax rates coupled with other restrictions. Before, investors benefited from tax laws that enabled real property to be depreciated over an -- artificially low -- estimated useful life of 18 years. Tax benefits were often created by accruing, but not paying, interest on mortgages.
These benefits were brought to an abrupt halt by the 1986 tax law. Real estate losses became deductible only upon the sale of the property or when offsetting income from other real estate activities. By restricting losses, real estate was no longer viable as an investment vehicle for all but a few.
The basic concept of the 1986 tax law was to create equitable economic decision-making and to discourage consumer debt. These were healthy ideas, but their consequences tilted against our own national interest by lowering asset values. This must be corrected by eliminating restrictions on the deductibility on real business losses, whether from real estate or investments. Artificial noncash losses can continue to be restricted. As an additional step, tax credits or preferential tax rates, should be provided to encourage savings.
Existing tax rates may have to be revised, but given our overall economic condition, it is a small cost for national solvency.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Ronald G. Weiner (Ruby Washington/The New York Times)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Designers Try to Fit The Price to the Times

BYLINE: By ANNE-MARIE SCHIRO

 BODY:
When Mary Ann Restivo founded her business, her prices rarely topped $400, but little by little they rose, like everyone else's, with inflation. Now she has joined the ranks of designers and manufacturers forced to offer shoppers fashionable clothes at more reasonable prices.
"Everybody knows people are not spending a lot on clothes, so we decided to go back to where we were when we started 10 years ago," she said. 
 Designers like Calvin Klein, Ralph Lauren, Donna Karan and Louis Dell'Olio for Anne Klein have accomplished this by adding secondary collections, usually of more casual clothes. But Ms. Restivo, who sold her company to Leslie Fay in 1987, remaining as executive design director, has restructured the business to offer lower prices, which run from $110 for a sweater to $400 for a jacket for fall.
Stores refer to this range as "bridge" because it bridges the distance between moderate-priced clothing and designer lines. As more women have entered the business world, this so-called bridge area has grown tremendously because it offers good career clothes at a reasonable price. The group includes Ellen Tracy, Adrienne Vittadini, Dana Buchman and of course Anne Klein II.
Ms. Restivo has retained her familiar blazers and kimono jackets, shifts and trapeze-shaped dresses but, to lower prices, is concentrating on more basic, less luxurious fabrics.
"We're using gabardine, wool crepe and flannel for the good, solid base clothes," she said, "then adding novelties like houndstooth checks and a plaid fabric woven with loopy yarns. To make the clothes special, we're using details like contrast piping, soutache embroidery and diamond-shaped cutouts."
To compete in the United States, European designers and companies like Giorgio Armani, Gianni Versace, Franco Moschino, Genny, Byblos and Emanuel Ungaro have added secondary lines. But mostly these lines cost more than American bridge collections, often hitting the $1,000 mark. That, too, is starting to change.
 
A Challenge to America
 With the recent introductions of Ungaro's Emanuel and Escada's Apriori, Europe is challenging America's dominance of the bridge market with clothes priced under $500.
Emanuel, which was developed specifically for the United States by Gruppo GFT, is an extensive collection of sportswear that includes basic stretch bodysuits, pants and skirts, draped jersey and velvet dresses, tailored jackets and coats that reverse from printed poplin to fake fur.
The collection adds a sexy French twist to classic American sportswear. A glen plaid blazer, for example, is draped to button on one side, and a checked scuba jacket has Ungaro's gathered sides.
Apriori is the lowest-priced division of Escada, a German manufacturer that also produces the Laurel and Crisca lines. The latest endeavor, first sold in Europe a year and a half ago, has been restyled for the United States. Like Emanuel, it ranges from casual country clothes to dressy career styles.
The sporty segment includes ribbed wool-and-cashmere sweaters, cire anoraks and baseball jackets of patterned microfiber with a silky finish. Citified styles include a long one-button blazer, a cropped plaid jacket and a stretch flannel jacket with a black velvet collar.
Come July, when all these collections reach the department stores, the customer will decide if they tempt her pocketbook.

HEADLINE: Tunica Journal;
The Shacks Disappear, but the Poverty Lives On

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TUNICA, Miss.

 BODY:
The story of Sugar Ditch, America's most famous sewer, came to a quiet close recently when the families of 11 black tenants vacated the last of the shacks beside it.
They left behind leaky roofs, perforated walls, the smell of garbage and the scratch of rats. Some tenants lacked toilets, and all either flushed or carried their waste into the stagnant ditch just yards away. This ramshackle row was tucked away from public view, half a block behind the proud facades of the downtown business district. 
 Their shacks condemned and razed, the families have moved into new apartments filled with comforts that many had never known: not just toilets but freshly painted white walls, hot running water and rooms that keep the rain out and the heat in.
But most had little to say about their new homes.
"I like it all right," Johnnie Mae Milbrooks said of her new apartment, where a Federal subsidy puts her share of the rent at $2 a month.
The new apartments aside, much in Tunica County has not changed, ever since mechanized farming ended the sharecropper system decades ago while offering few jobs to replace it. The 1980 census, which provides the most recent figures, ranked Tunica as America's poorest county, with 53 percent of its 9,600 residents living below the poverty level.
For the county's blacks, political power has been about as elusive as jobs. Though the county is 73 percent black, its Board of Supervisors has a white majority. The 1,300 residents of the town of Tunica, the county seat, are overwhelmingly white. And they control a local government that Federal officials have said discriminates against blacks.
For local black leaders, the new apartments represent a rare victory and a reminder of the legacy of defeat.
"It's a success story in one way, and in another we didn't make no kind of strides," said Henry Pious, an unemployed plumber who was one of a handful of local blacks pushing for changes at Sugar Ditch. "There are still no jobs. The people are still on welfare."
The decrepit homes along Sugar Ditch had been there for decades, but it was not until 1984 that anyone started complaining. Mr. Pious and others involved in a voter registration drive began pointing to the conditions there when stressing the need for more political power for blacks.
At the time, the town had received a $500,000 grant from the Department of Housing and Urban Development -- not to fix the houses but to beautify the downtown business district.
That summer, H.U.D. officials came to Tunica to present the town with an award for its improvement efforts. But after a black State Representative led reporters on a detour to the Ditch, word of the conditions began to spread.
By November, the Governor of Mississippi was standing in Ms. Milbrooks's home, promising to have her out soon. The next year, Jesse Jackson visited three times in one week, trailed by Congressmen and cameramen. The CBS News program "60 Minutes" followed.
If Sugar Ditch was dismal, the program explained, it was not because of a lack of Federal aid. The town had received more than $1 million for sewer improvements, most of them for white subdivisions, in a pattern that investigators from the United States Treasury Department called racially discriminatory.
One person who was not moved by the talk of rats, roaches and racial oppression was Robert Mangum, Ms. Milbrooks's landlord at Sugar Ditch. He collected $50 a month for each of 10 concrete block homes he had helped his father build in 1951.
Mr. Mangum is a gruff, bearded man, who owns a hardware store in Tunica and speaks of "colored" people. He said he is tired of being depicted as a villain.
"They didn't start out rag-shack," he said of his former properties. "It's just time and age."
Though he acknowledged that many of the homes were infested, he said, "Bugs have to do with personal hygiene, not with surroundings, really."
Mr. Mangum lives nearby in a two-story house with four white Corinthian columns. His tone changes when he shows a visitor the Special Olympics medals won by his teen-age son, who has Down syndrome. The boy has brought a special kind of love to his family, he says.
Mr. Mangum said that visitors might ask, "Why should somebody have a nice house like that and somebody else not?"
He offered this answer: "I work 7 days a week, 12 hours a day." As for people who are unemployed or on public assistance, "the ones that are 21 and healthy, I have no cares about what they get," he said.
Publicity came quicker to Sugar Ditch than new housing. One reason for the delay was the fight between voting rights advocates who wanted the 92 black families along Sugar Ditch to stay inside the town limits, and the town government, which said no suitable land could be found there.
Beginning in 1986, Sugar Ditch residents were relocated to one trailer site and three new apartment complexes, all outside the town.
Ms. Milbrooks, who is 40, had lived on Sugar Ditch since she was 13, when she moved there to get away from sharecropper life and arguments with her stepfather. She worked as a maid until the first of her five children was born. Since then, she has been supported by welfare and disability checks.
She described the homes she lived in on Sugar Ditch as "raggery." The first had no toilet, the second had no hot water and both were near a dumpster that in the summer would "be stinking so bad it make you sick."
Did she ever complain?
Ms. Milbrooks found the question ludicrous. "You'd probably get put out of doors with nowhere to stay," she replied.
Though almost seven years have passed since the Governor's promise, she says she is neither angry nor impatient. "Around here, you expect anything," she said. "Never get your hopes up, because you don't know how nothing's going to come out."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "It's a success story in one way, and in another we didn't make no kind of strides," said Henry Pious, an unemployed plumber who was one of a handful of local blacks pushing for changes at Sugar Ditch. He stood on a footbridge over the sewer ditch in Tunica, Miss. Behind him was the area where shacks, formerly occupied by families who have moved into new federally-subsidized apartments, were razed. (Rollin A. Riggs for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Panel Asks Stiffer Preparation for CUNY Students

BYLINE: By SAMUEL WEISS

 BODY:
A faculty panel has recommended that students entering the City University of New York complete a set of college preparatory courses as tough as those New York State requires for its best high-school graduates.
The panel made the recommendations at the request of Chancellor W. Ann Reynolds, who recently convinced the university's trustees to approve a broad plan to toughen requirements to graduate at the university. 
 Under Dr. Reynolds's plan, students entering the university in the fall of 1992 would be expected to have completed a full program of collegepreparatory courses in high school. Those who did not would not be denied admission to the university, but they would be required to make up deficiencies by taking extra courses in college before they could graduate.
University officials say they want to put pressure on the city's public-school system to prepare students better for college work. In approving their broad plan, the trustees did not specify the high-school course requirements to be met by freshmen but gave the chancellor until January 1992 to draw up a list.
In anticipation of this, Dr. Reynolds several months ago charged the University Faculty Senate with preparing a preliminary set of "expectations" to be met by Cuniversity freshmen. A copy of the proposals of the Senate's Advisory Committee on the College Preparatory Curriculum was obtained by The New York Times.
 
University Requirements

The committee calls for students entering the university to have taken four years of college-preparatory English, four years of social studies, three years of mathematics, two years of laboratory sciences, two years of a foreign language and one year of visual and performing arts.
New York State high-school students now earning a Regents-endorsed diploma must complete four years of college-preparatory English, four years of social studies, three years of foreign language, two years of sciences, two years of mathematics and one year of art and music.
 
Admission Is Guaranteed

According to the New York City Board of Education, only about 20 percent of its high-school graduates now earn such a diploma. As an alternative a high-school student can earn a Board of Education diploma by completing a combination of college-preparatory courses, remedial classes and various electives, like business mathematics, that the university would not consider "academic."
Currently admission to the City University is guaranteed to any highschool graduate. Although attention is paid to the student's high-school grade-point average in assigning him to a four-year or two-year college, little attention is paid to the type of classes the students took in high school.
The faculty committee spelled out college-preparatory course sequences that should be fulfilled by entering students. In social studies, for example, it called for students to take global history, American studies, and electives that could be chosen from economics or political science, among others.
In mathematics, students would take elementary and intermediate algebra, geometry and courses that could include trigonometry, mathematical logic and statistics.
While the report concentrates on what it describes as "minimum university expectations," it noted that students intending to major in the sciences should take a year of calculus in addition to the required courses, as well as a third year of science. It also said that for "optimum preparation" for college, students should complete four years of study in a foreign language, instead of the two-year minimum the committee recommends.
 
Approval Is Expected

The panel's proposals, now being circulated in draft form, are expected to be approved by the University Faculty Senate later this month and sent to the Chancellor by April 1. Dr. Reynolds is then expected to review the faculty proposals with the New York City Schools Chancellor, Joseph A. Fernandez, and his staff in detail before submitting her own recommendations to the university' trustees next January.

HEADLINE: It Takes People to Make a Strike: Tales of Fear and Courage at The News

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
It has all the elements of a great Daily News story -- violence, ambition, moral dilemmas and the struggle of common people. For the last 137 days, though, the story has been about the paper itself.
The struggle over the future of The News, once the country's largest metropolitan daily, has been played out on a broad public stage before a bitterly divisive strike began on Oct. 25. But the protracted showdown between The News and its battle-scarred unions has obscured the private sagas of hundreds of News employees. 
 For Joanne Wasserman, a veteran reporter who is six months pregnant, going on strike has threatened the health coverage that she will need in June, when her first child is due.
For Scott Browne, a librarian at the paper, the strike presented an ethical dilemma: whether to stay out on strike with his colleagues or return to protect his job.
For Joanna Hernandez, a single mother hired by The News to replace striking reporters, the labor dispute offered a chance to clear up $20,000 in debts and break into big-city journalism.
And for Larry Farrell, a pressman who has been working almost full time at his union local's headquarters, the strike has stoked the fervor of labor solidarity.
With the battle over The News nearing its culmination, these four workers are among strikers, replacements, crossovers and management supervisors who shared their thoughts and feelings last week. Nearly all took risks -- whether they went on strike, crossed a picket line or replaced a striker -- and many will pay a price no matter what happens.
The fate of The News will be decided in the next few days as the British publisher Robert Maxwell, the paper's nine striking unions and its current owner, the Tribune Company of Chicago, try to wrap up complex negotiations over a possible purchase by Mr. Maxwell. Executives of The News say the paper will cease publication on Friday if the sale cannot be completed.

 
 
 An Untold Story: Producing the Paper
 The News has continued to publish every day during the four months of the strike, produced by nonunion supervisors, replacement workers and union members who returned to work. Matthew Storin contends that the untold story of the strike has been these workers' quiet commitment to putting out the paper. Mr. Storin has some standing for his news judgment: he is managing editor of The News.
"It was easy for people to romanticize people on the picket lines leading the fight, but no one romanticized people putting the thing out," said Mr. Storin, a 48-year-old editor who came to The News in 1989. "We as managers very much felt it was our duty to keep this paper alive and keep the standards as high as we could."
Particularly early in the strike, there was a feeling of isolation in the newsroom on the seventh floor of the News Building on East 42d Street, Mr. Storin said. "We did everything we could to maintain normalcy," he said. "We tried to hold meetings at the same time, to tell the same bad jokes. We asked the same questions. Daily rituals were comforting."
Sometimes, there was comfort in old connections with staff members out on strike. The editors submitted nominations for Pulitzer Prizes, and most reporters nominated were on strike. "We're rooting for them as hard as if they were still working here," Mr. Storin said. Other times, relations were severely strained. Mr. Storin said it hurt when people on the picket lines called him names because he was hiring replacements. "We may not have agreed with everything the Tribune Company did, but we were trying to put out the best paper we could," he said.
Other supervisors shared Mr. Storin's belief that their efforts to keep the paper functioning have gone unnoticed in the attention paid to the strike. Some also went out of their way to distance themselves from the Tribune Company and its hardball approach to the unions.
The deputy managing editor for features, Fran Wood, said she had been working 11-hour days, assuming all sorts of new duties, to help keep The News alive. "What was lost in all of this were the efforts of the people in the editorial department who came back to see the continuation of The Daily News," Ms. Wood said. "We didn't have any interaction with the Tribune Company. I don't think of myself as the Tribune Company. I think of myself as The Daily News."
Mr. Storin said his worst memory was the day when Gail Collins, a respected columnist who was hired by New York Newsday during the strike, came to clean out her desk.
"I wanted to say something, to take note of the fact that the paper was losing one of its most valued contributors, but I could see that she was not open to that, so we had one of those 'Good luck' conversations," he said. "We were not particularly close, but it was what her leaving represented to the paper that got me."

 
 
 Finding Warmth in Fire of Unionism
 While the strike has been a burden for supervisors, at least they had a steady income. The strike is now in its 20th week, and as time has passed, many strikers have found it difficult to get by. Union strike benefits and unemployment insurance have cushioned the blow somewhat, many people said.
Paddy Loughlin, a 61-year-old pressman, said that the strike had cost him about $10,000 so far but that he had got by because he had prepared. "I saw this coming about a year beforehand and started socking some money away," Mr. Loughlin said. "Now most of that is gone."
Like Mr. Farrell, a younger colleague, Mr. Loughlin has been working at union headquarters as a strike coordinator. His motivation is both principled and pragmatic. "I owe something to all the union men who came before me and made a life for me," Mr. Loughlin said.
And Mr. Farrell said the union work had helped preserve a sense of confidence. "Working here every day has kept me focused," he said. "It's been a therapy of sorts that's kept my mind on winning this strike and off things like 'How am I going to pay for things? And how am I going to get on with my life when this is settled?' "
Mr. Farrell, who has worked on the presses at The News for 11 years, said the strike had galvanized his interest in union affairs. He recently began taking college courses in labor relations and hopes someday to work as a union official. "I always had the fire of unionism in my belly, but this has put gasoline on it," Mr. Farrell said.
Both men were pleased when Mr. Maxwell stepped in as a possible savior of The News, but their hopes are tempered. Mr. Maxwell said Thursday that he was looking to trim at least 800 jobs at the paper.
"This guy is very savvy, and he's not in it to do us any favors," Mr. Farrell said. "Hopefully, we can work something out. But I'm sure that if we are lucky enough to do that, a lot of us won't be going back to work."

 
 
 Living New Life; Wishing for Old One
 Many reporters who are on strike have found opportunities for freelance work at magazines and at television production companies. But many hope that they will soon be returning to The News.
JoAnne Wasserman has been a reporter at The News for four years and worked at The New York Post for seven years before that. During the strike, she has been preoccupied with her pregnancy and with her fear that she will give birth without the benefit of health insurance. Ms. Wasserman and her husband, Stuart Marques, also a News reporter, have found temporary work.
"I would have liked to have gone through my pregnancy without having to worry about this," she said. "That's why it would be great to go back, to go back to the routine. I wouldn't mind going back to my desk on the seventh floor."
Martha Southgate, a feature writer in the entertainment section, has been freelancing at magazines. Ms. Southgate and her husband had wanted to buy an apartment, but the drop in her income forced them to postpone their plan.
Ms. Southgate is concerned that she will not be invited back to work if the strike is settled. Because she came to The News last year, Ms. Southgate, who is 30, has little seniority.
"I'm prepared for that," she said. "This has been so long and so nasty. I probably would go back, but I'm not dying to. The whole thing has been so strenuous, and I don't feel the same way about the place."

 
 
 Making the Most of a Rare Chance
 Hundreds of replacement workers are aware that they are not likely to be working at The News after Friday, whether the paper is saved or shut down. Mr. Maxwell has said all replacements would be dropped if he took over the paper.
Even so, many of the replacements view their experience as a singular opportunity. Ms. Hernandez has worked at The Bridgeport Post in Connecticut and at a weekly paper in New Haven. But since the New Haven paper shut down a year ago, she did some freelance writing and worked temporarily as a secretary. With two children to support by herself -- she has a 13-year-old daughter, Sheena, and an 11-year-old son, Gary -- Ms. Hernandez slipped quickly into debt.
Ms. Hernandez, who is 33, had applied for a reporter's job at The News in March 1990 and got no response. The paper invited her in for an interview the day after the strike began last October. She said she had some qualms about taking a striker's job, but her financial needs overcame her concern.
"I decided I would only work there if they paid enough to provide for my children and get me out of debt," Ms. Hernandez recalled. She braced herself for a tough negotiation with The News, but the paper offered her $200 more a week than she had been prepared to ask. Like most of the replacement reporters, Ms. Hernandez is making about $900 a week.
She is working as a police reporter. Occasionally, people have refused to be interviewed by her or to cooperate in any other way because she was a replacement worker. Ms. Hernandez said she had also received messages on her telephone answering machine calling her a scab.
Ms. Hernandez knows her time at The News is limited, and she has been sending resumes to large newspapers across the country. She hopes her clips from The News will help her land a permanent position at a large paper. "I came here to give my career a boost," she said. "That's what I've gotten."

 
 
Breaking Old Ties to Try to Save Job
 Scott Browne, on the other hand, went back to work to save his job at The News. Mr. Browne crossed the picket line five days into the strike and returned to his job in the paper's library. Mr. Browne, who is 39, has worked at The News for more than 14 years. He said he had returned because he feared he would never work at The News again if a replacement took his place.
"People yelled 'scab' at me, and 'Jew bastard,' " Mr. Browne said. "I had many sleepless nights."
"I know there are some people I will never speak to again except professionally," he said of colleagues who have remained on strike. "I ran into someone I knew today on the street. He said, 'Are you out?' And I said, 'I'm in." And he said, 'Well then, I can't talk to you.' "

HEADLINE: Alabama Leads Push for Cleaner Offshore Drilling

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DAUPHIN ISLAND, Ala.

 BODY:
Here aboard the drilling platform Glomar Highland IV, a vibrating cacophony of shouting men and squealing steel, the Mobil Oil Corporation is tapping into one of the largest strikes of natural gas ever made in North America.
But the size of the gas reserve buried deep beneath the floor of Mobile Bay is only part of the story. Prodded by stringent state law, public sentiment and aggressive enforcement, Mobil and two competitors, Shell and Exxon, have taken extraordinary steps to protect a marine estuary renowned for its rich catches of shrimp, oysters and fish. 
 Instead of discharging chemicals and sewage into the water, a practice followed on nearly all the 3,600 offshore drilling platforms in the United States, the companies are collecting thousands of barrels of drilling mud, lubricant, human waste, even rainwater that drips off equipment, and are putting them into barges for treatment and disposal on land. Mobil says it is spending up to $150,000 a week on waste disposal alone.
As the Bush Administration prepares to open vast undersea tracts off the East Coast, Florida, Southern California and Alaska to exploration for oil and natural gas, such costly measures are becoming the focus of intense debate. The offshore oil industry, though proud of its environmental record here, says requirements like Alabama's are unnecessary and could even prove hazardous. Environmental groups and state officials reply that Alabama has established a model of ecological safety that should be the nationwide standard for drilling operations close to shore.
 
Many Rules, More Rewards

In February, the Environmental Protection Agency proposed tightening regulations for discharges from offshore platforms in Federal waters, which begin three miles from shore in most states. The regulations, though not as strict as Alabama's, would require more thorough treatment than currently practiced before wastes could be discharged.
Environmentalists here and in other states say the experience in Mobile Bay shows how far the oil industry is prepared to go to gain economic rewards from offshore drilling. Mobil's natural gas reserves beneath Mobile Bay are estimated to be worth at least $650 million at current prices.
Neither Mobil nor the two other oil companies agreed willingly to abide by Alabama's rules. Almost a decade ago, after Mobil was discovered pouring untreated sludge and toxic drilling mud into the bay, the company paid a $2 million penalty to the state and agreed to pay at least $500,000 to dredge up yards of chemical-soaked bay bottom.
And it agreed to Alabama's zero-discharge rules, which environmentalists say are working well. "It's a pretty clean operation. It really is," said Dr. George F. Crozier, a marine biologist and executive director of the Dauphin Island Sea Laboratory who has been one of the oil industry's sharpest critics in Alabama. "The bay is relatively healthy, and their plans for drilling 12 more wells over the next three years are not likely to have any profound environmental effects."
 
Safeguarding Shrimp
 Aboard the Glomar Highland, an 11-year-old drilling platform, Mobil employees from supervisors to the roughnecks who man the equipment are eager to describe the steps they have taken not to harm "a single little shrimp," as one roughneck put it.
Each week thousands of gallons of drilling solution, pulverized rock, motor oil, and lubricant are pumped into one of two barges tied to the platform. Rainwater and sewage go into the second barge. Employees caught throwing garbage into the bay have been dismissed, and workers say men even spitting into the bay have been reprimanded.
Elray Foret, Mobil's 49-year-old drilling superintendent, says it costs the company $58,000 to dispose of each barge of chemical wastes, and $28,000 to treat and dispose of a load on a sewage barge. "It's a lot of money, but we're doing it," said Mr. Foret. "Over in Florida, I can't understand why they don't want us. You can see, this ain't going to hurt the environment. There's nothing here that can hurt the environment."
The company's engineers say similar controls on discharges from platforms in the ocean are unnecessary and warn that in a heavy storm, waste barges could smash into the steel legs of a deep water platform and threaten the lives of the crew.
 
The Focus on Natural Gas
 Federal law already requires sewage to be treated on drilling rigs before it is released into the water, and the proposed regulations would tighten those standards. Lubricants and hazardous chemicals are collected in barrels and transported to shore for disposal. Specialists for Mobil say the ocean dilutes other wastes, like drilling mud and pulverized rock, rendering them harmless.
"Around our deep-water offshore platforms, the fish are doing just fine," said H. Lew Herrin, an environmental engineering adviser for Mobil. "You know, we're required to treat our wastes. But stand out there and watch 150 dolphins swim by. The Government doesn't require treatment of their wastes."
In other respects, the activities in and around Mobile Bay signal the direction the American offshore industry is likely to take in the 21st century. The prize here is natural gas, a cleaner alternative to oil that can also be processed into liquid methanol and burned as a substitute for gasoline.
The United States gets 25 percent of its natural gas from offshore wells, and the White House energy plan envisions that at least 60 percent of the fossil fuels recovered offshore in the 21st century will be gas, not oil.
 
The Gleam of Oil
 Although drilling for gas can be dangerous because of the chance of an explosion, it does not present the same risks to the environment. Gas evaporates into the atmosphere and cannot wash up on shore. Mobil transports gas to shore here through a pipeline buried beneath the bay bottom and beneath the marshes near its new processing plant.
Environmental groups are not quieted by such assurances. They argue that the Administration and the oil industry also have every intention of tapping the 18 billion barrels of oil believed to lie offshore. At the nation's current rate of demand, 17 million barrels a day, that is about three years' supply -- not worth the risk of a catastrophic oil spill, the environmental groups say.
"The oil industry would like us to believe they have the technology to acquire these supplies safely," said Robert Sulnick, executive director of the American Oceans Campaign, an environmental group in Santa Monica, Calif. "But this is not a debate about hardware. It's a debate about the future security of the nation."
Among the most influential supporters of this school of thought are the Governors of Florida, North Carolina, New Jersey and California, who oppose the Administration's offshore drilling plan because of concern about the safety of their states' coasts.
In the oil industry, there is a strong sense of frustration with the views of coastal governors and residents. Since 1969, when a Chevron well blew out in Santa Barbara, Calif., smothering beaches and birds in 3.25 million gallons of crude oil, the offshore industry has developed new kinds of blowout prevention devices and advanced equipment to monitor oil and gas wells, technology that has largely prevented oil spills from offshore platforms.
 
Despite Better Safety, Suspicion
 According to a report by the Department of the Interior, the cause of most oil spills is oil tanker accidents, like the grounding of the Exxon Valdez in 1989. Not since 1969 has the offshore industry been responsible for an oil spill that exceeded 800,000 gallons, less than one-tenth the size of the Alaska spill, and the industry says most of the oil was dissipated at sea.
"I tell you, let me be President and I'd fix the whole thing," said Mr. Foret. "If we didn't give another drop of oil to Florida, or North Carolina, or California, they'd all be begging to let us come to drill. Take no time at all."
Opposition to the drilling boom that began in 1979 has never been overwhelming along Alabama's coast, but there was a lingering suspicion among residents about the oil industry's willingness to comply with state environmental laws. Fishermen and shoreline homeowners kept a close eye on Mobil's drilling rig, and in 1981, after a fishing crew pulled up a catch of flounder coated in oil, Mobil and the state began an investigation.
"What these guys were doing was putting the discharge hoses between the barges, and all that lubricating oil and drilling mud was dropping straight into the bay," said Dr. Crozier, who assisted investigators. "I took a state inspector out there one day and we put a probe down and came up with muck drenched in oil.
"There's always been a resistance to big money in this part of the world, sort of a bit of native spite," he went on. "Once Mobil was caught polluting, the die was cast, and people here simply said the oil industry will not be allowed to proceed without strict controls."
