HEADLINE: An Exception to Rule of War: Inflation Threat Is Receding

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
From the Revolution to Vietnam, virtually every American war has sparked a round of inflation. But the Persian Gulf war looks as if it will be an exception. A barrage of signals -- including cheaper oil and raw materials, softer prices at factories, swelling cattle herds and shrinking bonuses for sales workers -- suggests that inflation may retreat.
The drop could be striking, and price increases could well stay low for years. The most compelling reason for thinking so is the Federal Reserve's four-year spell of stinginess in pumping cash and credit into the economy. Since 1987, the money supply has grown, on average, at just half the rate of the early 80's. 
 "We've built the foundation for lower inflation," said W. Lee Hoskins, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland, noting that the Federal Reserve Board and its chairman, Alan Greenspan, have been committed to nudging inflation down by gradually reducing money growth.
 
Economy Would Gain
 If inflation stays low, the economy would benefit. The United States would fall closer in line with such rich and powerful nations as Germany and Japan, whose inflation rates have averaged half of the United States rate, or less, in the last decade. And long-term interest rates could edge down as investors' fears of future inflation eased.
What is more, future recessions would probably be milder than the harsh downturns that ruptured the high-inflation years. One reason that most economists expect the current recession to be shorter and shallower is that inflation has not raced out of control.
Many forecasters, including those at the Federal Reserve, expect consumer price inflation to average 3 to 4 percent this year, compared with an annual rate of almost 7 percent in the second half of 1990. For the next few months, the rate could hover around 2 percent, forecasters at DRI/McGraw-Hill said, as the lower cost of a barrel of crude oil works its way into a broad spectrum of consumer prices. Last fall, spot oil prices shot toward $40 a barrel; now, oil is trading at about $18 a barrel.
That would give consumer buying power a welcome boost and help stabilize spending. "It's like a $16 billion personal tax cut and is worth $170 per household," said Roger E. Brinner, the chief economist at DRI/McGraw-Hill.
Among the reasons the Persian Gulf War seems not to have been inflationary are that it lasted only 42 days, quickly contained the threat to oil supplies, was financed in part by American allies and was fought with armstaken from inventory. Ordinarily, military spending overheats the economy as production surges to supply the war effort, leaving fewer goods available for civilian consumption. As a result prices rise.
 
 More Room for the Fed

The lower oil prices now give the Federal Reserve more room to fight the recession. "Because a lessening of cost pressures has improved the outlook for prices, the easing of policy has been possible without raising new concerns in the financial markets about inflation prospects." Mr. Greenspan testified before Congress on Wednesday. And on Friday, the Federal Reserve once again pushed down interest rates.
This low-inflation scenario could stumble if, for example, oil prices took off again, the dollar suddenly plunged, or state and local governments jacked up taxes sky high in an attempt to solve their budget problems. But the Federal Reserve's semiannual monetary policy report, issued on Feb. 20, alludes to the "downward tilt of the underlying inflation trend." That view is shared by Administration and Congressional economists, as well as many private forecasters.
There has already been a basic improvement in price trends -- as any driver who has recently pulled up to a gasoline pump can attest -- but it has been largely obscured in official inflation measures because of a rash of one-time events and statistical flukes.
 
 One-Time Hits

To take just one example: Higher Federal excise taxes on gasoline, alcohol and cigarettes will probably exaggerate this winter's inflation rate by more than one-third, John F. Peterson, an economist at the Congressional Budget Office, estimated. Other special factors were the 17 percent postal rate increase that went into effect last month and the second installment of the minimum wage increase. These onetime hits should be absorbed in a month or two.
Four forces are helping to beat down inflation, most economists agree: weaker commodity prices, especially for energy and food, which together account for about one-fifth of consumer spending; the recession, preceded by a year and a half of extremely sluggish economic growth; slackening wage gains, and, finally, signs that productivity outside manufacturing is holding up better than expected during the downturn. A major factor in each, most analysts say, is the Federal Reserve's monetary restraint in recent years.
The immediate source of relief is, of course, cheaper crude oil. At around $18, oil prices are back where they were in the first half of 1990. They should bobble around $20 in this year's second half, down from $24.40 in the comparable period last year, said Adam E. Sieminski, an economist at the Washington Analysis Group.
Richard D. Rippe, chief economist at Dean Witter Reynolds, commented, "Indirectly, that's slowing prices charged by metals and paper manufacturers, on the one hand, and airlines and hotels on the other."
And David D. Hale, chief economist at Kemper Financial Services, said, "The prices of key industrial commodities are falling because the world economy is much weaker now."
California's drought and recent freeze notwithstanding, food prices are also moderating. Prices had been climbing at close to a 6 percent rate for the last two years, faster than inflation. Now the Department of Agriculture's official forecast calls for advances of 2 to 5 percent, with the department's chief forecaster, Ralph Parlett, saying that "awful things would have to happen to hit the upper forecast range."
Though the Fed has been loosening gradually since the spring of 1989 and more aggressively this winter, money growth on average has been far lower in the last four years than in the first half of the 80's. In particular, the Federal Reserve did not react to last summer's oil price shock by flooding the economy with money. "That was a very important decision," said Lynn Reaser, an economist at First Interstate Bancorp. "Very few companies were able to pass on the rise in energy costs."
 
Sluggish Growth
 The consequence of monetary restraint was sluggish growth even before Saddam Hussein toppled the economy into recession. "Spare capacity in factories and looser labor markets make it harder for business and workers to push for price and wage gains," Mr. Rippe of Dean Witter Reynolds said.
As a consequence, compensation costs are moderating. The Bureau of Labor Statistics' employment cost index rose 4.6 percent in December from a year earlier, down from an increase of 5.2 percent in June. Slow growth and recession pushed unemployment up to 6.5 percent in February from its low of 5.3 percent last June. As long as unemployment stays above what is considered full employment -- which most economists put at 5.5 to 6 percent -- employment costs should keep moderating.
The trend is especially evident among service companies that are squeezing some of their highest-paid help, salespeople, real estate agents and stockbrokers. "The upscale labor market is flabbier than it's ever been," said Stephen Strongin of the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago.
 
Basic Change Seen
 Smaller raises may reflect a fundamental change in the job market, suggested Daniel J. B. Mitchell, a professor of management at the University of California at Los Angeles.
Workers are less cushioned from market forces by union contracts or paternalistic employers; union membership is down to 12 percent of private, non-government workers. While small-business payrolls swelled by 15 million during the 80's, Fortune 500 companies shed 2 million jobs. In deciding how much to raise pay last year, Mr. Mitchell said, "employers looked to conditions in the labor market, not to some notion of protecting workers' purchasing power."
But permanent progress on the inflation front ultimately depends on faster productivity growth, almost everyone agrees. "The only way to have strong growth without inflation is to increase productivity faster," said Mr. Hale of Kemper Financial Services. Otherwise, he said, low inflation comes at the cost of stagnating living standards.
There has been an early sign that the productivity trend might be improving. Productivity rose slightly in the recession's first quarter, instead of declining along with output as it usually does at the start of a downturn. At the beginning of the 1981-82 slump, by contrast, productivity plunged at a 5.5 percent annual rate. Since companies laid off workers a lot sooner in the current slump, some economists say, once output picks up in a recovery, productivity gains could be sizable.

HEADLINE: 3 Unions at The News Would Bear Brunt of Job Cuts, Leaders Say

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
As talks on the fate of The Daily News continued last night, union leaders negotiating with Robert Maxwell said that almost 700 of the 800 jobs the British publisher wants to eliminate would be from three large unions, the pressmen, the drivers and the Newspaper Guild.
The proposal would reduce the number of pressmen at The News to about 200 from 400, the union leaders said. The drivers would lose 300 of 700 jobs, and the Guild, which represents newsroom, advertising and clerical employees, would lose about 180 from the current level of more than 700 workers. 
 The union officials, who acknowledged that large job reductions would be required to make the paper profitable, said they would be making counterproposals, as the deadline of 10 A.M. tomorrow imposed by Mr. Maxwell approached.
Michael Alvino, president of the drivers' union, said that Mr. Maxwell had held out the possibility of rehiring some of those laid off, if The News could regain the circulation it lost during the four-month strike.
 
Talks Have Until Friday
 If the prospective buyer and the paper's nine striking unions can agree on new labor contracts, Mr. Maxwell, who owns a number of media properties in this country and abroad, would then try to complete his conditional agreement to buy The News from its corporate parent, the Tribune Company of Chicago. If the talks fail, executives of The News have said they would cease publication of the 71-year-old paper, once the nation's largest daily, on Friday.
 
'Doing Their Best'
 At 1:30 P.M. yesterday, Mr. Maxwell ambled through the lobby of the headquarters of Macmillan Inc., the publishing company he owns, on Third Avenue near 53d Street, saying that he "just wanted to take a breath of fresh air."
Mr. Maxwell, who was alone, said that negotiations were going "fine" and that he continued to be "reasonably optimistic." He said that the unions were "doing their best" but that the outcome was still uncertain.
"Lovely day you're having in New York," he said as he strolled north on Third Avenue. He returned about five minutes later.
 
Maxwell Seeks Huge Reductions
 The possible sale to Mr. Maxwell apparently represents the final chance to save The News, which has lost money for most of the last decade. Negotiations between the paper's management and unions, which had gone on intermittently for 13 months, were abandoned 10 days ago with the sides deadlocked. Nine of the paper's 10 unions have been on strike since Oct. 25.
Mr. Maxwell contends -- as did the Tribune Company -- that he needs huge concessions from the unions to make The News profitable. During the talks that began Thursday, he told the unions that he needs reductions of more than $70 million a year in labor costs.
That is the equivalent of about 800 jobs, or a little more than a third of the unionized positions at The News. The proposal would not necessarily mean that 800 people would lose their jobs, because some savings could be achieved by eliminating guaranteed overtime and other work rules.
Mr. Maxwell's bargaining with the unions, which is taking place out of public view on the 14th floor of the Macmillan building, appears to be going better than did the talks between the unions and the Tribune Company.
Labor leaders said Mr. Maxwell initially made some major concessions on issues common to all the unions. He pledged not to keep permanently any of the 800 or so replacement workers who are filling strikers' jobs at The News. He also told the unions that a condition of his letter of intent to purchase the paper was that the Tribune Company would drop lawsuits it filed against the unions during the strike.
The union leaders also complained repeatedly during the last year of negotiations that the Tribune Company would not specify in dollars how much it wanted to cut its labor costs. Instead, they said, management kept insisting on the absolute right to set staffing levels and other working conditions -- issues that had traditionally been the subject of collective bargaining.
Although Mr. Maxwell is bargaining in the manner favored by the unions, by stating his economic objectives, the reductions he seeks are very large and may be difficult to obtain. He is demanding staff cuts and work-rule changes that would produce annual savings of between $72.8 million and $83.6 million.
 
No Charge for the Paper
 If the unions and Mr. Maxwell can reach agreement, he will then have until Thursday to complete his purchase agreement with the Tribune Company.
The potential transfer of ownership of The News is correctly called a sale, but its terms are highly unusual. Mr. Maxwell would not directly pay a penny for the paper, which has suffered circulation declines and operating deficits for most of the last decade. Both circulation and advertising have dropped precipitously during the four-month strike.
The Tribune Company would pay Mr. Maxwell $60 million for taking over the paper and assuming most of its long-term liabilities. Those include severance pay in the event of a shutdown, estimated at $25 million, and lifetime guarantees to the paper's printers, whose value has been estimated anywhere from $20 million to $100 million.

HEADLINE: Hard Days for Sports in Eastern Europe

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY

DATELINE: SEVILLE, Spain

 BODY:
Lia Manoliu, the president of Romania's national Olympic committee, arrived in London last week for two days of meetings with other European Olympic officials. Then, she was scheduled to return home. What she really wanted to do was come here to Seville first and watch a day or two of the world indoor track and field championships. Romania has a small team competing, and track and field, after all, remains her first love. She was the Olympic discus bronze medalist in 1960 and 1964.
But such a change was impossible, of course. Her round-trip ticket was booked on Tarom, the national airline of Romania, which accepts lei, the Romanian currency, which is virtually useless elsewhere. To extend her trip would have required pounds or dollars or marks or francs, all of which are scarce in Romania and were even scarcer in her handbag, as she sat in her hotel lobby wishing the impossible. 
 "I would like to see our team," she said, looking ever so sad. "If only I had the money."
She is hardly alone in disappointment.
All across Eastern Europe, in countries now trying to build democracies after decades of rigid Communist rule, dire economic conditions persist. The sports communities, no longer high priorities in countries where citizens stuggle to obtain food and the bare essentials of living, have been severely affected.
No longer are governments fully subsidizing the national sports systems and Olympic programs. With so many more urgent needs, they can no longer afford it. As a result, athletes now find themselves competing as much for sponsorships and support as medals and records. Coaches, trainers and medical experts are losing their jobs. Travel has been reduced significantly. Romania is sending a team of gymnasts to the United States later this year for a dual meet only because the United States Gymnastics Federation agreed to pay for everything.
From a national standpoint, a change has left five of the countries -- Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Poland and Romania -- faint hope for improvements over their more recent Olympic efforts. A sixth, East Germany, gained an advantage through unification with West Germany.
But in a larger context, the possible erosion of high-performance sports in the other countries, combined with continuing struggles of third-world nations to develop competitive teams, could eventually lead to an unsightly imbalance in which the wealthiest countries, like the United States and Germany, would dominate the medal standings even more than they do now.
The International Olympic Committee, well aware of the potential domino effect, is either powerless or unwilling to throw foundering countries much of a life jacket. As caretaker of the Games, the I.O.C. selects sites, negotiates marketing and television contracts, then does everything possible to make sure every country shows up. Aside from disbursing revenues to the national Olympic committees that participate in the Games, covering the costs of participation and holding marketing seminars, the I.O.C. has not engaged in any large-scale charity work.
"Assuming we even had the funds to finance them, that is not the answer," said Francois Carrard, the director general of the I.O.C. "That would be artificial support. We have to change the mentality and habits of these countries and try convincing the governments to keep within their priorities an interest in sport. Our hope is that they start to reconsider."
While money for sports remains tight throughout all of Eastern Europe, nowhere does the financial pinch seem more acute than in Bulgaria and Romania, countries that have generally fared well in the Summer Olympics. In the 1988 summer Olympics in Seoul, South Korea, Bulgaria won 35 medals, most among Eastern European countries after East Germany, with 102. Romania was next with 24.
In Bulgaria, one of the last of the countries in the region to throw out its hard-line Communist leaders, the Government has almost eliminated support for sports as an item in the national budget. Before, said Ivan Slavkov, an I.O.C. member since 1987 and the son-in-law of the last Communist ruler, Todor Zhivkov, "we got 80 percent of our support from the Government."
"Now," he said, "they are not paying any attention to sports because sports are not considered the most important. And they're not the most important." Meanwhile, with high prices, soaring inflation and a market economy still embryonic, the sports community has been left in a vacuum.
Like other Eastern European national Olympic committees, Bulgaria's has appealed for help to the I.O.C. and the international sports federations, which sponsor major events.
"We're contacting all international federations," Slavkov said. "That's the only way we can survive."
The Bulgarians have also sought help from other national Olympic committees, including those of Japan, South Korea, Taiwan and the United States. They have heard from only one, the United States. "They're not interested," Slavkov said.
In Romania, the post-Ceausescu Government continues to support sports programs, designating 500 million lei this year, double the figure for 1990. But the figure is misleading, and problems there may be worse than in Bulgaria. Lei are virtually worthless outside Romania, and the Government's attempt to change the economy has led to higher prices on all goods, effectively reducing buying power to a level below last year's. Further, most of the factories and enterprises that for years had supported local sports clubs have stopped doing so, and federal law requires all athletes to pay 50 percent of the hard currency they win as taxes.
The right each citizen now has to travel has also hurt the sports system. Manoliu said that at least 40 elite-level coaches and trainers have left the country in the last year, including Adrian Goreac, the 1988 Olympic gymnastics coach, who has moved to France.
"We have lost so many of our sportsmen," she said. "The secret of our success was our coaches, and it's difficult to remake them."
Unlike the United States and other countries that send as many athletes as possible to the Olympics, Romanian officials set unusually high qualifying standards and sent only those athletes they felt could win medals. As a result, only 62 Romanians participated in the 1984 Los Angeles Olympics, and 73 in Seoul four years later. The strategy worked, as Romanians won 53 medals in 1984 and 24 in 1988.
It was a crafty strategy, in that it kept down costs and maintained pressure on athletes at the highest level to produce, thus justifying the government's investment.
But Manoliu wants to change all that by lowering standards and sending as many Romanians to next year's Games as possible. No matter how autonomous the Olympic committee may be, she fears the Government will not allow her to implement her ideas.
"I am still dreaming. I have so many ideas," she said. "Even when I tell these ideas to my people, they are still afraid. They are not used to someone asking their advice without being guided. They don't dare say I am crazy, but I feel they think it."
So far, Czechoslovakia, Hungary and Poland have endured somewhat less severe economic stress than Bulgaria and Romania. By no means wealthy, these countries at least have had a head start with democracy and market economies, although convincing political leaders that Olympic programs deserve more than passing attention remains a difficult sell.
The United States Olympic Comittee, which has become one of the richest national committees, earning an automatic 10 percent of any contract between an American television network and the I.O.C., has not turned a completely deaf ear to the weaker nations. But these days, the U.S.O.C. is less inclined to write a check. Rather, its marketing officials have offered to show countries how to adapt to the new market conditions. In one recent project, the U.S.O.C. sold at cost several hundred thousand dollars worth of American-made merchandise, like T-shirts, windbreakers and sweatshirts, to Yugoslavia's Olympic commttee for a newly opened store in Sarajevo. The store keeps all the profit.
"We want to provide the seeds, rather than the flower," said John Krimsky, the deputy secretary general of the U.S.O.C. and its chief marketing officer. "Absent direct funding, which we cannot do, all sorts of things are possible."
It is that period before the bloom, however, that most worries the I.O.C, an organization ever so concerned that world opinion might not regard its quadrennial party as the best sporting event on earth.
"These countries had been perfectly structured for top sports," said Carrard, the I.O.C. officer. "With their systems of administration, if you properly lobbied the leaders of the country, you got what you wanted. Now, these same people have no idea how to raise $2,000. They are completely at a loss. They just don't know where to start."

HEADLINE: Baseball Notebook;
He Missed Series, but He's Happy

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS

 BODY:
Ron Robinson has a red beard on his face but no World Series ring on his finger. "I spent a lot of time there," he said of his six years with the Cincinnati Reds. "I wish I had been there. But" -- and it was a big but -- "I felt I wasn't treated right there and it was time to move on. Instead of fighting for a job there, I have a job here."
 Here is the Milwaukee Brewers, who traded for Robinson last June 9, which happened to be the 62d day of the 178 days the Reds spent in first place. Robinson wasn't around for the final 116 days of Cincinnati's seasonlong stay in first or the 17-day period in which the Reds won the National League pennant and the World Series, but given his circumstances and his feeling about Lou Piniella, he was willing to forgo the festivities for the artistic and economic success he achieved with the Brewers. 
 "I got frustrated sitting on the bench in Cincinnati," said Robinson, who compiled a 12-5 record and gained a three-year, $3.3 million contract after leaving the Reds. "I was healthy, but I wasn't pitching. Lou Piniella didn't know who I was. He didn't know anything about me. He told us in spring training everybody was the No. 1 pitcher. Nobody was better than anyone else. But then he went right back on his word."
 When asked about Robinson, Piniella said: "We had a very short spring training and very little time to get pitchers in shape, plus we had eight or nine veteran pitchers. He wasn't ready when we left spring training so he wasn't pitching on a regular basis, and because of that he wasn't happy."
After making 100 consecutive relief appearances for the Reds in 1986 and '87, Robinson moved into the starting rotation in 1987 and remained there for two and a half seasons, except for the times his right elbow wouldn't let him pitch. He had three operations on his elbow in 18 months, but was healthy when the Reds began the 1990 season with Piniella, and not Pete Rose, as their manager.
 "Lou told me one time I'd never pitch in that uniform again," Robinson related. "That was April 15. They said they couldn't trade me because no one wanted me, which I knew was a lie. But on April 29 I pitched because Danny Jackson got hurt."
 What prompted the temperamental Piniella to erupt at Robinson?
 "I got tired of what was going on and I kept pressing him to find out what was going on," Robinson said. "I wanted to pitch. In your free-agent year, you don't want to sit on the bench. I'm only 29. Lou's a smooth talker. He can make it sound good. But they said I was a me-me-I-I guy. Who's going to look out for you? Not Bob Quinn. Lou isn't. Now I'm making a pretty good living. If I had been there all year, I wouldn't have this contract. I'd still have to prove myself."
 Robinson, who in two months with the Reds last season started sporadically, pitching not at all for 10 days after reeling off 13 successive scoreless innings in two starts, compiled a 2.91 earned run average in 22 starts with the Brewers.
 "The Reds said I couldn't pitch complete games," he said. "Nobody left me in there. I pitched seven here."
 Robinson hasn't dismissed Piniella completely. "Maybe Lou and me will cross paths later in life," he said.
 
Backman Optimistic
 Even though the ingredients for self-destruction are on the surface for everyone to see, Wally Backman does not believe the Pittsburgh Pirates will single-handedly wreck their chances for repeating as National League East champions. Barry Bonds and Bobby Bonilla, the Pirates' two most menacing players, are unhappy with their $2-million-plus salaries, and Bonds's outburst last week was one of the best in recent years.
 "Knowing the type of guy Jim Leyland is, I don't think it'll happen," said Backman, who played for Leyland and the Pirates last year. "In one year's time, I got to know him well. He'll keep things under control. He's the easiest guy I ever played for. You'll always have contract problems, but once you go between the lines, the kind of manager Jimmy is, he'll have them ready to play."
 Backman, who has moved east on the Pennsylvania Turnpike to Philadelphia, said that Bonds's tantrum at cameramen and assorted Pirates employees did not surprise him.
 "I wouldn't expect that will happen with Barry again this year," he said. "He respects Jimmy, but sometimes he gets in a mood where he thinks everybody comes down on him. He might have said some things that got him in trouble, but he's a good player."
 Off the field, Backman explained, Bonds sometimes alienates people with his comments.
 "You have to be more team-oriented as opposed to being self-oriented," he said. "He'll say things about himself where he should be talking about the team. He gets himself into jams. He won't admit mistakes. When he gets in these situations, he'll argue."
 More than the effect an unhappy Bonds and Bonilla might have on the Pirates, Backman said, could be the impact of Sid Bream's absence.
 "I think they're going to miss him more than people think," Backman said of the first baseman, who went to Atlanta as a free agent. "Sid was one of the biggest assets on the club. He was right there with Barry, Bobby and Andy Van Slyke. Down the stretch, he was one of the guys you wanted out there."
 
Parker Makes Some Points
 He would not talk about his contract, Dave Parker said. He had nothing to say about the rumors that he wants Milwaukee to improve the contract or give him an extension. "I have no comment on that," said Parker, who has a $1.4 million salary this year and the same next year if the Brewers exercise their option. Many less productive players will earn more than he does, and he is reportedly unhappy about it.
 But he would talk about how people had him washed up as far back as 1982 and how, nine years and three teams later, he is 408 hits from 3,000 and 72 home runs from 400, dual levels attained by only Hank Aaron, Willie Mays and Carl Yastrzemski. He also talked about how he really didn't mind moving around as he has in recent years.
 After two World Series in two years with Oakland, he said, it was time to move on. "It was a contract thing," he explained. "They didn't want to give me more than one year, and I went out and got more than one year."
 Then, without breaking verbal stride, he went on: "The market exploded after I went to Milwaukee and guys doing what I'm doing are making $2 million and $1 million more than me. The way the market has exploded I feel there should be an adjustment salarywise."
 But he wouldn't talk about his contract.
 
Mariners' Eternal Struggle
 With each passing year, the litany grows more aggravating and makes the albatross heavier: Never in their history have the Seattle Mariners finished with a .500 record. This will be the 15th year that the Mariners try to pluck the wings from the albatross, but Jim Lefebvre, the Mariners' manager, has opted for a new approach this season.
 "We have to forget the .500 mark," he said. "We have to think about being a contender. Everybody talks about .500, but there's no question in our mind we would've been over .500 if we didn't have all the injuries last year."
 The Mariners were at or over .500 from June 29 through Aug. 18 last season, but they collapsed under the weight of their injuries and finished with a 77-85 record.
 "We hate the question," Lefebvre said, meaning the .500 question, "but we're going to keep hearing it until we do it."
 
Trials of a Prospect
 Lance Dickson must have thought he was a traveling salesman last year. After pitching for the University of Arizona in Tucson, he became the Chicago Cubs' first-round choice in the June draft and proceeded to play in Geneva, N.Y.; Peoria, Ill.; Charlotte, S.C., and Chicago.
 He did a great selling job in his first three stops but had the door slammed in his face in Chicago.
 At Class A Geneva, he had a 2-1 record and 0.53 earned run average in three starts; at a more advanced Class A Peoria, 3-1 and 1.51 in five starts and at Class AA Charlotte, 2-1 and 0.38 in three starts. In a total of 76 1/3 minor league innings, he allowed 40 hits and 18 walks -- an average of 6.8 base runners per nine innings -- and struck out 111.
 With the Cubs, however, the left-hander had an 0-3 record and 7.24 e.r.a. in three starts, permitting 20 hits, four walks and 15.8 baserunners per nine while striking out four in 13 2/3 innings.
 "Everybody said what a great curveball he has," Don Zimmer, the Cubs' manager, said. "Tommy Helms called me and said what a great curveball he had. But I didn't see the curve. After two or three starts, we told him to shut it down and go home. He had thrown so many pitches in college and in the minors, he wore out."
 If Dickson, 21 years old, can show Zimmer his "great curveball" consistently in the next four weeks, he would have a chance of stealing a spot in the Cubs' starting rotation.
 
Reggie Reflects
 Reggie Jackson reflected on Jim Palmer's attempted comeback six years after he last played and disclosed that he, too, had considered trying to play again.
 "I had thought about it a couple times," said Jackson, who last played in 1987. "People say, 'Gosh, Reggie, you look a lot better than when you played.' But once your reflexes and quickness are gone, you can't get them back. The thought that has overridden my thoughts about coming back is the picture I've left with people when I left the game. That outweighs my thoughts about a comeback attempt."
 Jackson is back in uniform, as a part-time coach for Oakland, some of whose games he also will work on cable television.
 "I'm fortunate to come in on this level, the major league level," Jackson said. "It satisfies a need Reggie Jackson has. I appreciate that. For me to be involved with this organization, with these people, is a star for Reggie Jackson, a stripe on my sleeve."

HEADLINE: Back to Reality;
U.S. Sets a Cautious Course on Mideast Peace

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
JUST as President Bush was about to go to Capitol Hill for his address to Congress on the war last week, his advisers rushed up with a change for the speech. It was only seven words, but for them it was the definition of the postwar Middle East, the heralded "new world order."
 In the original text, Mr. Bush cautioned that "even the new world order cannot guarantee an era of perpetual peace." Some advisers felt that sounded too pessimistic. So Mr. Bush added: "But enduring peace must be our mission." 
 As the United States begins the work of postwar diplomacy, the change in tone seemed to make at least three things clear: The Administration is still sorting out its approach to the long-intractable problems of the Middle East. It is adjusting the vision that was needed to bring the country into war to suit the realities of the region. And, at least for now, the President's plans seem to be more modest than might have been suggested by his expansive wartime talk of lasting peace rising from the flames in the Persian Gulf.
 "It's very high tone and kind of limited," a senior official said, explaining that Mr. Bush was not aiming for "some vision of universal peace with democracy everywhere."
 Just as the President's determination to stop Iraq's expansion reflected his fear of being another Neville Chamberlain, he is now rejecting the mantle of Woodrow Wilson. Indeed, Mr. Bush said last Wednesday night in Congress that his war against Iraq "was not waged as a 'war to end all wars.' "
 "What it means is really not a lot more than, 'You can't invade your neighbor,' " an official said. "We're not going to intervene everywhere, force the Arabs to recognize Israel and the Israelis to deal with the Palestinians. Progress of democracy, yes, but in an incremental way, a la Eastern Europe."
 This not to say that Mr. Bush is abandoning his promise that "no one will work harder for a stable peace in the region than we will." He may be trying to diminish expectations, but he is on record as saying that the best prospects in decades for a broader peace now exist. What it does suggest is that the effort will be conducted in classic George Bush fashion -- striking for the center, and not committing to anything until the odds of failure are reduced as much as possible. That is the reason Mr. Bush sent Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d to the Middle East last week and it is the style in which he conducted the war, making sure the coalition backed each step and that every weapon was cocked before fighting started.
 American officials are keeping much of what they intend for the Middle East secret, but it is possible to discern some of what they are most eager to accomplish and what they believe is feasible.
 At the top of Washington's priorities is Saddam Hussein. Mr. Bush insists he is not trying to overthrow Mr. Hussein, but seems prepared to use force again to keep the pressure on. Administration officials said the Pentagon mapped possible air strikes on Friday after intercepting an Iraqi order to use poison gas against rebels in Iraq. "We can't live with him, period," an official said, adding that the only question was how long he could stay in power.
More easily solved is the domestic and international political imperative of bringing home American troops. "There have been two equally important parts to the equation of Bush's credibility," a senior official said. "One is that he said we would come to the aid of the Saudis and Kuwaitis. We did. The other is that he said we would get out quickly. We will."
 This conflicts with the desire to end the Arab-Israeli race to acquire the biggest and most modern armies; if American troops are withdrawn, that makes it militarily dangerous and politically impossible to seek to disarm friendly countries. The United States argues that the war proved that territory and large armies cannot guarantee security, but officials acknowledge that the Middle East will not reduce its armies until it sees progress toward an Arab-Israeli peace.
 So Washington suggests reducing the spread of ballistic missiles, and chemical and biological weapons. This is a smaller problem that can be addressed outside the region with the few countries, including the United States, France, Germany, Britain, the Soviet Union and China, that have such weapons.
 Similarly, the United States seems to be trying not to approach the Arab-Israeli and Israeli-Palestinian conflicts head-on. Although Mr. Bush said he was fighting Iraq to enforce the principles of national sovereignty, the rule of law and peaceful coexistence, that does not mean the Administration is ready to enforce them across the region.
 The Administration is counting on its Arab allies, especially Saudi Arabia, to repay the United States for its military aid by taking steps toward settling the Arab-Israeli disputes. But Administration officials say there will be no call for a large international conference on the Palestinian question. "We're not going to try to settle the question of who will represent the Palestinians and we're not going to push the Arabs to recognize Israel," an official said. Although Mr. Bush has suggested that Israel contemplate territorial concessions, officials said he will not apply heavy pressure to do so.
 Instead, the Administration will encourage smaller steps: notification of each other by the Middle Eastern countries before conducting military maneuvers; an exchange of Arab and Israeli prisoners; an easing of Israeli travel restrictions in the occupied territories; water-sharing agreements between Israel and Jordan, and Israel and Syria; a re-evaluation by Arab states of their financial support for the Palestine Liberation Organization, and a lowering of voices on all sides.
These are Mr. Baker's "confidence-building" measures. At the same time, the end of the war raises anew an apparent conflict between the American policy of promoting democracy and the restoration of the Emir of Kuwait. But Administration officials say there will be no push for rapid democratization in the area. Instead, Mr. Baker is offering "suggestions" for reducing the gap between rich and poor, hoping economic stability will lead to eventual reform. In a region where the most organized political opposition is either fundamentalist Muslim or radical Palestinian, it is not clear to the Administration that speedy elections are in its best interests.
 As it strives, again, for small steps in inter-Arab relations, the Administration has been encouraged by evident improvement in Saudi Arabia's relationships with Syria and Egypt, which symbolize divisions between rich and poor. "The Saudi-Egypt relationship at this point is very, very good," a senior official said. "The whole Camp David aspect is probably behind them."
 Mr. Bush may have one major advantage as he confronts these issues. "He is the first popular President ever to tackle the Middle East," said William Quandt, who worked on the National Security Council under President Jimmy Carter. "Lyndon Johnson was tied down with Vietnam and finally threw in the towel. Nixon had Watergate. Carter's fortunes were going downhill before Camp David. Reagan didn't bother."
 But Zbigniew Brzezinski, who was Mr. Carter's national security adviser, said Mr. Bush will have to risk his political fortunes in peace as he did in war. "American leverage in the Middle East requires the President to put himself on the line," he said. "I don't know if the Administration is ready to bite the bullet, but if they don't, the question arises: What did the war accomplish?"

HEADLINE: The World;
The Sun Has Trouble Setting on the Soviet Empire

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN

DATELINE: MOSCOW

 BODY:
GEORGE SMILEY might have felt some sympathy for the old Soviet commissars and generals watching Americans take Iraq apart.
Like them, Le Carre's aging British spy had been reared to serve an empire, not to watch from the sidelines as old enemies made mincemeat of old allies. Smiley, to be sure, would never have let his pique show quite so blatantly as the Soviet cold warriors did, shouting in the Supreme Soviet and in their newspapers that the United States was trying to obliterate Iraq and slaughter its people to gain hegemony in the Middle East. 
 There was nothing really surprising in this behavior, especially while their military budget was being slashed, their Warsaw Pact was being trashed and the Red Army was being shooed out of Europe. It would have been more curious, in fact, if the generals and hero-workers who had spent years arming Iraq and decades fighting the cold war had taken to cheering Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf as he took out their Scuds, T-72's and MIG-29's.
The reaction of the old guard was a reminder that the habits of a superpower cannot be erased with a presidential decree and a dash of perestroika. The growls came instinctively when the adversary of 40 years unsheathed new weapons within a cannon shot of Soviet land, and an arms client of long standing came under threat from NATO.
The more intriguing question was why Mikhail S. Gorbachev decided to launch an 11th-hour mediating effort, if he knew, as Soviet satellites and analysts must have told him by early February, that a rout was imminent.
On the face of it, perhaps, the move made some sense. However reduced in strength, the Soviet Union as a major Asian power with its own restive Moslem population cannot be denied a permanent interest in the Middle East. In this case, America was poised to take out a major regional power, and Moscow's interest in averting a land war so near its borders, or at least in staking out some turf in the postwar realignment of forces, could be understood.
 
Under Fire at Home
 Mr. Gorbachev is also under pressure at home, and here he had a chance to mollify his right wing, to show that he had done what he could, as he approached a political showdown with his archrival, Boris N. Yeltsin.
If the East-West romance were still in full bloom, these explanations might have sufficed. This was Mr. Gorbachev the peacemaker and master politician at work again, and if it interfered a bit with President Bush's planned finale, it was only sporting to give Saddam Hussein a last chance to back down.
What made it different was that Iraq was the first major test of Mr. Gorbachev's foreign policy since he shifted rightward, shedding what one former ally called his liberal dilettantes for a team of hard-nosed commissars. Eduard A. Shevardnadze, the architect of "new thinking" in foreign policy who had aligned Moscow firmly behind Washington at the United Nations after Iraq invaded Kuwait, had departed in December, and the noises from the Kremlin had begun to sound harsher.
The West's reaction to the shift and its outcry over the shootings in Lithuania and Latvia seemed to sting Mr. Gorbachev to the quick. Western visitors described him in a huff over what he perceived as hasty judgment, and he complained how quick the world was to forget all he had achieved.
So when Mr. Gorbachev suddenly declared that the anti-Iraqi coalition was about to overstep its mandate and dispatched an aide, Yevgeny M. Primakov, to talk to Saddam Hussein, Western eyebrows rose. Did Mr. Gorbachev tacitly share the wounded pride of his generals? Was he reverting to old habits, maneuvering for some political advantage in a regional crisis?
The war ended too quickly for an unambiguous answer. The mass surrender of Iraqi troops, the unilateral halt of its land offensive by the coalition, the evidence of Iraqi atrocities in Kuwait all took the wind out of the right-wing campaign, and Mr. Gorbachev's mediating effort became all but lost in history.
Mr. Gorbachev's spokesmen dropped peevish hints that Washington had never really considered the "Gorbachev plan," and had resolved on a ground offensive all along. But they took pains to stress that there had been no deviation from the line of East-West friendship, that the Kremlin had never wavered in its allegiance to the cause for which the coalition fought.
 
Staying the Course
 In the end, Mr. Gorbachev appeared to recognize that whatever his domestic political imperatives, he could literally not afford to abandon the course of seeking closer ties with the West. With the Soviet economy in deep crisis, there was simply no way to re-enter the debilitating arms race, nor could Moscow relinquish economic assistance from the West. The arms race, Mr. Gorbachev told critics in Minsk last week, had "exhausted our economy."
Washington and its allies, for their part, chose to declare that they had no bone to pick with Mr. Gorbachev, that they in fact appreciated his support and his efforts. Whatever they really felt, they appeared to conclude that Mr. Gorbachev was still the man to back in the Kremlin, especially since he probably had helped force Mr. Hussein to recognize the folly of resistance.
But none of the declarations from Washington or Moscow could fully conceal the pique and suspicion. If the gulf crisis opened with the romantic notion of two great superpowers teaming up to establish a new world order, it ended with the realization that mutual trust remained a brittle commodity when confronted with real wars, popular passions and old suspicions. As Mr. Gorbachev noted in Minsk, progress in United States-Soviet relations remained "very fragile," and a "great sense of responsibility" was needed to avoid destroying what was already achieved.
There were those, like Aleksei Vasilyev, an expert on Mideastern affairs, who took a pessimistic view. "After the Persian Gulf," he wrote in Komsomolskaya Pravda, "Moscow and Washington will never trust each other to the degree that cooperation in establishing a 'new world order' requires."
But Mr. Shevardnadze, the architect of that cooperation and now head of a new liberal think-tank, argued that there was no going back. "I do not think that this failed initiative caused or could cause any serious friction in Soviet-American relations, as some argue now," he said in an interview with Moscow News last week. "Our relations have moved too far, and they promise too much in the future, for something like this to darken them."

HEADLINE: The Nation;
Medicare Prognosis: Unwieldy Growth Fueled by More Fees and Beneficiaries

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
MEDICARE has emerged from 10 years of aggressive cost-control efforts as the fastest-growing major program in the Federal budget, and experts see little chance of slowing its growth as the elderly become more numerous and live longer while costs, led by payments to physicians, continue to rise relentlessly.
The nation's bill for Medicare, the Federal health insurance program for 33 million elderly and disabled people, grew 14 percent last year, or twice as fast as Social Security, which serves a similar population. 
 Medicare outlays totaled $110 billion last year, or 9 percent of all Federal spending in 1990. By comparison, military spending accounted for 24 percent of the Federal budget.
One of the biggest factors in Medicare's increased costs has been a dramatic rise in the volume of physician services used by the average Medicare beneficiary. Critics say doctors have themselves generated some of the extra business by prescribing additional and sometimes unneeded services to compensate for cutbacks in Medicare reimbursement.
Over the last decade, Medicare outlays for inpatient hospital care grew an average of 9.9 percent a year, while spending for doctors' services rose 15 percent a year, quadrupling in 10 years. Growth in the volume of physician services completely offset the effects of a Federal law that froze Medicare physician fees from 1984 to 1986, the Congressional Budget Office found.
The growth of Medicare reflects several other trends as well:
* The elderly population grows slowly but steadily: 2 percent a year, or double the rate for the United States population as a whole. Moreover, the elderly population itself is aging, with a larger proportion consisting of people over 75 years old, who require more care than those 65 to 75.
* Doctors' fees, hospital charges, drug prices and other health-care costs have risen rapidly, outstripping the Consumer Price Index for all items.
* A cutback in one type of service, like inpatient hospital care, often produces a surge in other services, like outpatient care in clinics and doctors' offices.
Medicare covers 40 percent of all hospital patients and accounts for more than 25 percent of the average doctor's income from the practice of medicine. Two-thirds of hospitals report that they lose money treating Medicare patients. Doctors' total incomes, which averaged $155,800 in 1989, are about five times the average for all workers in the United States, just as in the early 1970's. And while the Government has moved to restrain payments to hospitals, a number of experts say the savings have been largely offset by increases in payments to doctors.
Medicare spending for doctors' services is "absolutely out of control," said Dr. Philip R. Lee, chairman of the Physician Payment Review Commission, established by Congress in 1986 to advise lawmakers on the payment of doctors under Medicare.
Dr. John M. Eisenberg, a professor at the University of Pennsylvania School of Medicine, said: "I would estimate that 10 percent of physician services are of no real value to the patient. A larger proportion of services, perhaps 20 to 25 percent, are of some small value to the patient, but it's not clear whether they are worth the cost in society's eyes."
For their part, doctors insist that Medicare payments often fail to cover their costs. To make up the difference, doctors may increase their charges to other patients and to private insurers. Doctors also complain that Medicare is crushing them with paperwork and inappropriately second-guessing their clinical judgments.
"Medicare makes it difficult for me to care for my patients," said Dr. Nancy W. Dickey, a family physician in Richmond, Tex., expressing the concern of many of her colleagues across the country. "In its efforts to control utilization and cost, Medicare denigrates the doctor-patient relationship, suggesting to my patients that I am incompetent, doing unnecessary procedures and charging too much."
The dispute underscores the broader questions being asked about Medicare among lawmakers, hospital groups and representatives of the elderly. Has Congress failed in efforts to control Medicare costs? Has the increase in spending produced a commensurate improvement in the health of Medicare beneficiaries?
Next year the Government will introduce a new method of paying doctors, with a national fee schedule meant to reduce wide disparities in the prices of specific procedures. The Government will also set overall goals for the growth of Medicare spending on physician services.
The system, mandated by a 1989 law, is not explicitly intended to save money at first, but could easily be used for that purpose in later years. Since Medicare started paying hospitals a fixed amount for each admission in 1983, the growth of Medicare spending for hospital care has slowed considerably, and a national study concluded that the quality of care did not suffer.
Other components of the Medicare program are surging. The use of diagnostic tests and procedures has increased dramatically because of new technology and equipment. In addition, many doctors perform extra tests to protect themselves against malpractice suits. Medicare payments to independent laboratories doubled in the last four years, to $1.4 billion in 1990. Payments for home health services have risen as Medicare prods hospitals to discharge patients sooner, sometimes even before they completely recuperate.
For the Government, the administrative costs of Medicare are relatively small, amounting to less than 2.5 percent of total Medicare outlays in recent years.
But doctors and hospitals say Medicare imposes a substantial administrative burden on them. After years of Congressional efforts to curb its growth, Medicare is so complex that patients, doctors and hospitals can no longer calculate how much they are entitled to receive for any service.
The complexity creates countless opportunities for doctors, hospitals, laboratories and suppliers of medical equipment to manipulate the system and maximize their reimbursement, often with the help of consultants who tell them how to do it.
Dr. Lee, who is director of the Institute for Health Policy Studies at the University of California, San Francisco, said that many surgeons "unbundle" services, billing the Government separately for three or four procedures that should be reported and reimbursed as a single operation. A total hysterectomy, for instance, might be listed as several separate procedures, including exploration of the abdomen, removal of the ovaries and Fallopian tubes, appendectomy and cutting away scar tissue in the pelvis.
Likewise, Dr. Lee said, doctors often bill Medicare for a more costly service than they actually perform. A doctor might charge $35 for an extended office visit, though entitled to only $27 for a shorter visit. Such "upcoding" is possible because doctors have wide discretion in deciding whether to classify an office visit as brief, intermediate or extended.
In a recent study of Medicare records, John F. Holahan, a health economist at the Urban Institute here, found that the number of claims for brief office visits was decreasing while claims for more expensive extended visits were increasing, with the result that Medicare payments were rising. In each medical specialty, there has been a shift toward "the highest-paying procedures," Mr. Holahan said.
Whatever strain the Federal budget experiences with the ballooning Medicare costs, the burden of medical expenses for the elderly remains. Medicare generally does not pay for outpatient prescription drugs, and it covers little of the cost of nursing home care, which averages $25,000 a year.
Households headed by an elderly person spent 12.5 percent of their after-tax income on health care in 1988, up from 7.8 percent in 1972 and 1973. As long as that trend continues, Congress will find it politically difficult to cut Medicare benefits or require any but the most affluent beneficiaries to pay more for their coverage.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 5; Column 1; Week In Review Desk

LENGTH: 1030 words

HEADLINE: The Nation;
For a Key to Economic Health, See the 'Help Wanted' Ads

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
FOR days, there were signals that the recession might be lifting. New figures showed that factory production rose a bit in February. The war's end suggested that consumers would soon be in a spending mood again. The stock market boomed, and home sales even began to rise. But then on Friday, the Labor Department dashed these incipient hopes, announcing in effect that the recession's end was not in sight after all.
When it comes to spotting an upturn in the economy, the Labor Department's monthly employment numbers outweigh all other data. No matter how favorable the other economic indicators, a recession isn't over, most economists agree, until jobs increase -- or at least stop disappearing by the tens of thousands. And last month 208,000 jobs disappeared in the private sector, mostly because of layoffs. The unemployment rate, as a result, swelled to 6.5 percent from 6.2 percent. 
 Perhaps no forecaster has been more optimistic in recent weeks than Edward Yardeni, chief economist at Prudential-Bache, the Wall Street investment house. He insists that the recession is on the verge of ending. Still, the February job loss jolted him. "Employment is the make-or-break number for anyone's forecast," Mr. Yardeni said, "and if you get a really bad number like February's, then you might just as well take the rest of the month off while you hope for a better figure for March."
The economics that make the job figures so important are simple enough. If jobs are disappearing and incomes with them, then people cannot afford the spending that reawakens an economy. Not only have 1.2 million private-sector jobs disappeared since last August, but with them more than $52 billion in wages and salaries. If that money had been earned and spent instead, the recession might never have occurred.
Somehow, the spending has to resume for the recession to end. Maybe a few million consumers will dig reluctantly into savings to replace a dilapidated car or an old suit or to take a long-delayed vacation. Or maybe foreigners can be talked into importing much more of the output of American factories than they already buy.
 
Still in the Woods
 Only then might demand be sufficient to justify hiring again at retail stores, auto showrooms, restaurants, appliance outlets and, above all, factories. The rehired workers, in turn, would use their wages to multiply spending, and the recession would end.
"Until you see the employment upturn, you don't know you're out of the woods," said Alan Blinder, a Princeton University economist.
Some economists already see signs of enough sales to get hiring going again. Sales of American-made cars, for example, have reportedly risen in recent weeks to the point that cars are being sold faster than they are being manufactured. If such sales hold up, car manufacturers will soon have to increase production to satisfy the new demand, rehiring enough people to assemble the extra cars.
The manufacturers will not be able to wait because auto dealers have no big inventories to draw on. Neither, for that matter, do clothing stores or appliance dealers or numerous other businesses. For many economists, the unusually small inventory backlog in this recession justifies optimism that the upturn can come quickly -- if people would only be willing to buy again.
"You can't have an economic upturn until jobs increase, but powerful forces are in place to bring about the turnaround," said Stephen S. Roach, senior economist at Morgan Stanley & Company. "The main one is the low level of inventories."
Whatever the forces, the rehiring has not yet materialized. Quite the contrary, 125,000 manufacturing jobs disappeared last month and for those who were left on the job, the number of hours worked each week declined. The Labor Department data painted similar pictures for retailers, wholesalers, airlines and the trucking, banking, real estate and finance industries. Only health care, government and food processing showed much job growth, the latter apparently to meet the needs of American forces in the Persian Gulf, said Thomas Plewes, an associate commissioner of the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics.
Another troubling statistic also surfaced on Friday. Usually, about 5 million Americans hold part-time jobs but would prefer to work full-time, if they could get such a job -- a preference that adds them in a fashion to the unemployment rolls. Their numbers rose to 5.5 million from last summer through January, and then in February alone the number leaped to 6 million. Economists wondered if so huge a one-month jump was a statistical error, but Mr. Plewes said that the number of "involuntary part-timers" has jumped similarly in the past.
The 6 million figure was projected from the Labor Department's February survey of 60,000 households. "Part-timers who really want to work full-time often take a while to admit this to us," Mr. Plewes said.
Still, as gloomy as the February numbers are, they might be out of date. For one thing, the data were gathered during the week of Feb. 12, before the gulf war ended, and consumers perhaps became more willing to spend. For another, recessions end when output -- at factories, stores, restaurants, even law firms -- rises, and that can sometimes happen without raising employment levels, said Lawrence Katz, a Harvard University labor economist.
An auto manufacturer, for example, might increase efficiency by replacing two assembly-line workers with an engineer or a computer specialist. National income might rise, or at least not fall, because the engineer might be paid as much as the two line workers combined.
Some of this occurred in the 1980's and also in the current recession, as hundreds of companies became more efficient. And with this in mind, many forecasters said they would have declared the recession near an end last Friday if no more than 100,000 jobs had disappeared. Instead, 208,000 were lost in the private sector, and there was a net loss of 185,000 when the rise in government employment is included.
 "The bottom line for the economy is income, and that still means jobs and hiring," Mr. Plewes said.

HEADLINE: Oil Profits Made the Mideast a Weapons Bazaar

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In 1961, Iraq claimed Kuwait and mobilized on its border. Iraq stopped when the British flew in about 5,000 troops. Thirty years later, it took half a million and huge devastation. 
 The difference was in massive oil revenues, which gave Iraq the cash and credit to invest in armaments with which to seek two great oil revenue prizes: first Iran, then Kuwait.
About $3 trillion (at 1991 prices) have flowed to the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries since their cartel took off in 1971, following the Teheran "agreements" for which our State Department rightly claimed credit. And it is clear from the remarks of Richard T. McCormack, Under Secretary for Economic Affairs, to Leonard Silk (Economic Scene column, March 1) that they still have no idea that high oil prices resulted not from some vague political acts, but from a group of nations forming the mother of all cartels.
These nations, like good managers and good soldiers, knew how to seize opportunities, some of which they created. But their aim was and is simple: maximum wealth. Much of that wealth will go into arms, however we try to "regulate" the traffic.
Letting the price find a competitive level, which would be less than half the current level, would be in our political as well as economic interest. At the very least, we should be firm to reject any attempt to shore up the price or any policy that would have that effect. We might also reflect that a gasoline tax would in large measure fall not on consumers, but on the producing countries. That they hate such taxes shows they understand the market.
 
M. A. ADELMAN
Cambridge, Mass., March 3, 1991
 
 The writer is professor emeritus of economics at Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Capital Games

 BODY:
President Bush's campaign to lower the capital-gains tax has clung to many rationales. The tax cut, its supporters have claimed, would lower the Federal deficit, spur investment and growth and energize venture capitalists. Yet all these ration-ales are unproven, and it's plain, even from the fine print of White House testimony, that many of these claims are wildly exaggerated.
Now there is a new rationale floating around Washington. Why cut the capital-gains tax? To save the banks! The idea is that the tax cut would prompt real estate values to rise, and that, in turn, would pump up collateral for many bank loans. 
 This claim is even more pathetic than the other rationales. It makes about as much sense as attacking Scud missiles in Iraq by carpet bombing the entire Middle East. A sweeping tax cut would provide troubled banks with only a little relief, and then only at the risk of wrecking the tax code and damaging the economy.
 Proof that the President's tax-cut proposal wouldn't help the economy very much lurks in the White House's own estimates: the deficit would fall by about $11 billion and economic production would rise by about $60 billion over five years. These numbers, though exaggerated, are nevertheless insubstantial. During the same five years, the economy is expected to generate $30 trillion of output and $5 trillion in Federal taxes.
Neither would the tax cut do much for the banks, which do not directly invest in real estate. True, real estate values would rise a bit, so fewer developers would default. And loans that did sour would have higher salvage value. But this relief would be indirect and limited. Indeed, all the proposal would accomplish for the banks is to drive up the value of real estate by the amount of the tax cut. In essence, Mr. Bush would transfer to developers money from taxpayers, who would have to make up the revenue losses.
Other approaches, more carefully targeted, would help banks far more than indiscriminately showering billions in windfall profits on wealthy investors. Congress can start by adopting the bank reforms recently proposed by the Treasury. They include permitting banks to create branches across state lines and enter the insurance, mutual funds and securities industries. If Congress decided a quicker boost was needed, it could grant a temporary tax break to banks.
Here's an even better idea: Pay interest to banks on the funds they are required to deposit with the Federal Reserve System. That could pump about $3 billion into the banks, enough to offset recent hikes in premiums they must pay on insured deposits. The $3 billion would come out of the profit that the Fed returns to the Treasury each year -- a modest drain, especially if the interest payments were made only until the banks recovered.
If Congress chooses instead to cut the tax on capital gains, it will resurrect the wasteful, corrosive tax shelters that were killed off by the 1986 tax reform. The half-empty office buildings and shopping centers that dot the Southwest stand as monuments to the old law that created private profit out of social waste.
This newest entry in the parade of justifications for the tax cut is even less credible than its predecessors. Mr. Bush's obsessive campaign deserves a burial, this time for good.

HEADLINE: Topics of the Times;
Pay Cut

 BODY:
Public interest in Michael Milken, the king of junk bonds, has focused on how long a sentence he would be ordered to serve. Originally, it was 10 years, and the sentencing judge later recommended that he be paroled after three years. Now that he has begun serving his time, at the Federal Correctional Institution in Pleasanton, Calif., attention turns to another way of measuring the transformation of his life.
Mr. Milken was the highest-paid financier in history. Between 1983 and 1987 he made $1.1 billion from Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. plus income from other investments. 
 His earnings exceeded those of many corporations and the gross domestic product of some third world countries. In 1987 alone, he made $550 million. That comes to $275,000 per hour.
Mr. Milken is about to start a different job. Depending on whether he is assigned to be an electrician, cook or other job, the hourly pay of Federal prisoner 16126-054 will now be, at most, 40 cents.
