SECTION: Section 6; Page 27; Column 2; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 6051 words

HEADLINE: The Struggle Within

BYLINE: By Judith Miller; Judith Miller is a Times correspondent and the author, with Laurie Mylroie, of "Saddam Hussein and the Crisis in the Gulf."

 BODY:
Mohammed glared at the depressingly familiar mustachioed face that filled the screen. The giant television occupied a place of honor inside his vast Bedouin-style tent, complete with satellite TV receiver and crystal chandeliers.
Within the permanently pitched structure next to the house in a suburb of Riyadh, enclosed by walls assuring privacy, Mohammed and his young friends were sprawled on the Oriental carpets, leaning against replicas of camel saddles covered with sheepskin throws, sipping sweet tea -- and arguing. 
 "The Americans should never have been invited here," declared Abdul Rahman, drawing quickly on his Marlboro. "We've become an occupied country."
"Would you prefer to have been occupied by Saddam Hussein?" snapped Mohammed, gesturing in disgust at the screen.
"Why was that our only choice?" said Abdul Rahman. "What happened to the billions and billions we spent on defense?"
Mohammed ignored the question. "Saddam Hussein is a monster," he replied. Mohammed knew that firsthand. Soon after Iraq's invasion, he had driven into Kuwait to rescue his sister, who was married to a Kuwaiti. Their uncle had been recovering from heart surgery in a Kuwaiti hospital when Iraqi troops rolled across the tiny sheikdom. Soldiers had burst into the hospital and severed his life-support lines. Then they shot him in the head.
"Saddam," Mohammed said, almost as a curse. "We would have been next. We had no choice."
Abdulaziz, who had been silent, spoke up. "I hate Saddam Hussein," he said. "He's ruined the hunting season." He was not joking.
 THERE IS NO SINGLE response to the Persian Gulf war in Saudi Arabia. But on one point Saudis agree: the cataclysmic event has turned this devout, puritanical and deeply conservative society topsy-turvy.
The tranquillity of the desert skies has been shattered by screeching jet fighters and C-130 supply planes. Business and leisure are disrupted. In their place is a rare and unsettling spontaneity. The argument inside Mohammed's tent in January would never have occurred had it not been for Saddam Hussein -- and surely never in front of a foreigner, an infidel and a woman.
Not since the kingdom discovered oil in 1938, six years after its unification under the young and ambitious King Abdel Aziz ibn Saud, has there been such ferment in the house of Saud. Saudis at all levels of sophistication and wealth are passionately debating their future. Almost everyone accepts the rule of the Saud family and the notion that the country should be strictly governed by the laws of Islam. But for the first time, there are public, and growing, demands for increased participation in decision-making and for greater accountability, if not Western-style democracy. People want to see more of, and hear more from, their reclusive King. They want him to end the corruption around him. They want greater access to him and greater responsiveness from him.
Many Westernized liberal Saudis -- known as the technocrats -- are also fed up with the restraints on public discussion and the press. They are demanding, also for the first time, an end to censorship. They want the right to organize politically and socially. They want the right to debate publicly without fear of being ostracized or stigmatized by the dreaded appellation "kafir," nonbeliever.
These educated young Saudis -- the country's seven major universities graduate thousands of men and women every year -- are restless, underemployed. There are too few jobs, with the lack of opportunity most acute for women. The crisis in the gulf last fall spawned a messy and much publicized demonstration by women, who dumped their chauffeurs and drove in convoy, defying an informal ban on driving by women. The incident prompted a vicious campaign against them by religious fanatics, with Government acquiescence.
Underlying these strains is the question of how much power the religious establishment should have, particularly the religious police, or mutawwa. The rank and file of these guardians of moral virtue are drawn both from older salaried men and young fanatical volunteers whom the Government wants to monitor. They patrol the streets and shopping malls, telling women to cover their faces and young men to pray.
Longstanding tension between religious radicals and liberal reformers has traditionally been mediated by the King. But the war has polarized the two sides, and many Saudis anticipate a fierce, even violent, clash.
Still, Saudis are euphoric about their new ability to discuss these issues more or less publicly. Many declare that the debate itself signals liberalization. The expression "baad al azimah" -- after the crisis -- has been on people's lips since the war began.
But a few are pessimistic. "After the crisis, this Government will have to respond -- either by opening up or cracking down," said Kiren Chaudhry, an expert on Saudi Arabia who teaches political science at the University of California at Berkeley. "I suspect they'll crack down."
 THE WAR IS THE SECOND profound event in the short history of the current kingdom. The first was its breathtaking transformation in less than three decades from a primitive land -- mud huts, no roads, slavery -- into a technologically advanced society.
This is the third kingdom of Saudi Arabia. The first Saudi state emerged in the late 18th century, drawing its enduring legitimacy from a partnership of religious and political forces.
Mohammed bin Abdul Wahhab, the strict and literal-minded teacher of Islam, and Mohammed bin Saud banded together to spread Islam and Saudi political power. But in 1818 the first state and its capital, Diriyah, were destroyed by Egypt at the urging of jealous Ottomans. The second state, a turbulent series of efforts by competing Saudi princes in central Arabia, culminated in civil war that ended in the 1890's with the temporary displacement of the house of Saud by a clan in northern Arabia. The modern kingdom, less than 60 years old, is again the product of political ambition and religious fervor, with a difference -- oil.
Oil had not been discovered in 1902 when Abdel Aziz ibn Saud set out from exile and impoverishment in Kuwait to reconquer his country. The Nejd, the modern-day conservative heartland, was still controlled by the rival clan; the north was the preserve of nomadic tribes; the east and the west were under Ottoman control. By 1932, he had unified these into one enormous kingdom a third the size of the continental United States.
Then, less than a decade later, the Sauds became the political guardians of a quarter of the world's oil reserves. Suddenly the house of Saud held the key to almost unimaginable wealth. Seemingly overnight God had played a trick on the more numerous, more cultured, more sophisticated Arabs in Damascus and Cairo. He had placed these enormous resources in the land of the relatively few and ostensibly more primitive Saudis. No longer were they merely the custodians of Islam's two holiest shrines in Mecca and Medina -- and the grateful recipients of charity from Egypt and other Arab states that helped finance the annual pilgrimages. The Sauds had become, in fact, the custodians of three mosques -- the most envied being the Saudi treasury. Their neighbors would hate them for it.
It was oil that paid for the modern state: the world's most advanced highway and telecommunications systems; spectacular public architecture; vast and lush gardens, including more than a million date palm trees in Riyadh alone. And gratitude to the Sauds lingers. Saudis recall with no nostalgia conditions a mere 30 years ago: 120-degree days without air-conditioning; never eating at a table with knife and fork; leaky mud-brick houses; the goats, sheep, snakes and spiders that shared those houses. Some even remember hunger.
"This society is obnoxiously, knee-jerk status quo because, after all, it made us rich," one Saudi professional observed.
Some Saudis today denigrate these achievements. "Any idiot could have developed the country with some $564 billion to spend," said one Saudi professional. They stress instead what many regard as the Sauds' true genius -- the family's ability to maintain stability by balancing competing forces, by paying off and playing off rivals, by rewarding friends generously and bribing enemies, also generously. "Toe the line and we'll make you rich," is how one young Saudi businessman put it. In domestic and foreign policy, what is now derided by many intellectuals as "riyal politik" (for the national currency) worked brilliantly for years.
Unlike its neighbors, Saudi Arabia did not succumb to the seductive, secular and ultimately tyrannical ideologies that gripped the region in the 1950's and 60's -- Baathism in Iraq and Syria, the various Arab nationalisms spawned by Gamal Abdel Nasser from Egypt. Because it carefully pitted its military factions against one another, Saudi Arabia did not become a military dictatorship. The price was to be dependence on foreign military rescue in a crisis.
"Saudi stability is anchored positively by the Government's ability to insure prosperity and security," said Abdulaziz H. Fahad, a Saudi lawyer who writes about Saudi political life, "and negatively by a lack of encouraging alternatives." These pillars, coupled with Saudi Arabia's guardianship of what is widely viewed as pure Islam, have been responsible for the country's remarkable steadfastness in the face of modernization.
Yet even before the gulf crisis, the foundations were under attack. Young fanatics were criticizing the puritanical leadership of the Government-appointed religious hierarchy as insufficiently pious. In sermons from mosques and in cassette-recorded homilies, these extremists attacked the Government as corrupt in a way that no other political force dared do.
The collapse of oil prices in the 1980's and the recession that followed meant that there were fewer large contracts with which to buy the loyalty of the business community. Many of its American-educated "modernists" were both terrified by the religious extremists and angered by the monopolization of a declining pool of business by certain princes.
When Iraq invaded Kuwait, defying Saudi mediation and most political calculations, the kingdom's stability was threatened. Suddenly everyone -- from religious fanatics to the merchant class to those who desired a stronger military -- was demanding changes in the Saudi system. The debate about the kingdom's future, and its stewardship, had begun.
 CALLS FOR GREATER PARTICIPATION IN decision-making were the first and most obvious political effect of the crisis. The Government responded predictably. In a speech in October, King Fahd promised, almost apologetically, that he would create a majlis al shura, or consultative council, that would compensate for weaknesses in the system and previous unresponsiveness.
This majlis would be a formal national body, unlike the traditional majlises held by members of the royal family in their homes several times a week. These are forums for age-old popular grievances -- disputes about land, blood feuds, requests for financial or political help -- and their shortcomings have long been acknowledged. It would be lese majesty for a citizen to broach the state of the economy, the need for political liberalization, corruption among the elite or other delicate subjects within the kingdom.
King Fahd's pledge was familiar. When Abdel Aziz proclaimed the kingdom in 1932, he established a shura, which technically still exists though it is inactive. Every Saudi king has reiterated the goal. In 1982, King Fahd said a council would be established "soon." In December 1984, he told The Sunday Times of London that the council would be formed within three months.
"King Fahd seems prone to bouts of amnesia when it comes to promises of political reform," said one Saudi businessman.
Such skepticism is fed by the repression of the official press. Even the most anti-Western Saudis rely on the BBC or Voice of America, never the Saudi press, which has no credibility.
The contrast between what Saudis know and what they can read in their newspapers and magazines or see on their two television channels has been sharpened by the arrival of CNN. For between $20,000 and $25,000, well-connected Saudis can affix satellite dishes to their roofs and get the news the rest of the world is watching. At night, ministers, Government officials and Saudi businessmen congregate to follow the latest developments in the region.
The war has highlighted the failings of the local media. For three days after Iraq's seizure of Kuwait, the Saudi press contained nothing about the event -- silence that triggered panic within the kingdom. "Then the King figured out where he stood and invited foreign forces and, bam, there was instant glasnost -- Saudi-style, of course," one Western diplomat said.
Though few visas have ordinarily been issued to journalists, the Government gave out more than 1,500 after the invasion.
Suddenly, the Saudi press reverberated with diatribes against Saddam Hussein, whom the kingdom and the rest of the gulf had ardently supported during the Iran-Iraq war and only days before the invasion of Kuwait. Saddam Hussein was a monster. Full stop. Baathism was a bankrupt ideology. Period. The Arab world was appalled by what was taking place in Kuwait.
Every part of the Saudi news media did its share to reeducate public opinion. In September, Sayidaty, a women's magazine that usually features cheerful stories about family life, ran a harrowing account of a Sudanese woman's rape by Iraqi soldiers in Kuwait. The English-language Arab News published excerpts from the U.S. State Department's 1989 report on the status of human rights in Iraq. Publishing a document so critical of an Arab state's internal affairs would have been unthinkable before the crisis.
But the freedom given the Saudi press has not been extended to domestic matters. No Saudi newspaper, for example, would dare publish the American Government's human rights report on Saudi Arabia. And there have been many great gaps in coverage that have invited scorn in Riyadh. Saudi newspapers, for example, waited a full day to report that Tel Aviv had been hit by Iraqi Scud missiles in the early days of the war.
"Although there was no official comment on the attack, we wrote two editorials about it," said Turki al-Sedairi, the chief editor of Al Riyadh, one of the kingdom's largest Arabic daily newspapers.
Neither his paper nor the other Saudi dailies covered the women's driving protest. 'We feel it is our duty to lessen the gap between opposing trends in this society," Sedairi said, "not to aggravate it through our coverage." Saudi Arabia, he stressed, wanted to avoid the clashes between modernizers and fundamentalists that have gripped Tunisia and other countries in North Africa. "We don't treat news just as news, but in a social context."
Despite such comments, Sedairi is no apologist for the Saudi Government. He was once dismissed from his present job by the late King Khalid for a scathing attack on the Ministry of Information, which he called little more than a "Ministry of Denial." A few months later, he was forgiven and reinstated, once again through a royal order.
The editor's fortunes show how sensitive the Saudi Government is to everything published or broadcast. That sensitivity starts at the top.
A portrait of King Fahd reading Al Riyadh hangs over Sedairi's desk. And, in fact, the King does read the paper -- every word of it. "He's a real addict," Sedairi said. "He doesn't call up, but when he's displeased, we know about it."
What Sedairi did not say was that King Fahd is the country's chief censor. It was he who quietly decreed that no senior Government officials would speak about the crisis without his personal approval. He personally barred reporters and editors who work directly for the Ministry of Information -- like radio and television journalists -- from granting interviews to the foreign press. He ordered the news blackout on the Kuwaiti invasion.
"When he was a minister, and even when he was Crown Prince," a Saudi official said of King Fahd, "he used to surround himself with a fairly wide circle of intellectuals, writers and foreigners. But now he meets with almost no one. And he's become enormously sensitive to even a hint of criticism."
 SINCE THERE IS NO free press or consultative council, Saudis can only complain among themselves. That means that Riyadh is drowning in rumors -- some true, many false, all widely believed. One of the chief complaints these days is about corruption.
"There really is no petty bribery or corruption in this country, as there is in Egypt and other Arab states," said one Saudi businessman who travels widely. "Here, it's at the top."
Consider gas masks. The capital was in near turmoil when, despite weeks of advertisement, the gas masks ordered by the Civil Defense Directorate failed to arrive. After the first attack of Scud missiles against the capital, thousands of Saudis and foreign workers scrambled for masks, but the 70 local distribution points had been given just a few hundred each. Only later did an explanation begin to trickle out in Riyadh.
Prince Mohammed bin Nayef, the son of the Minister of Interior, had been awarded a noncompetitive contract to import the masks, a well-connected Saudi businessman said. After war erupted and insurance rates skyrocketed, the contract became less profitable; the Prince told authorities that he could not afford the higher rates. Four weeks into the war, there was still a gas-mask shortage in Riyadh. Neither Prince Mohammed nor the Civil Defense Directorate would be interviewed for this article.
Gas masks are not the only windfall contract of the gulf crisis. Television has proved to be another lucrative source of princely income to those with what is known as "Vitamin O" -- for the Arabic word "wasta," or influence, which begins with a letter that resembles an "o."
One beneficiary is a production company called ARA International, owned by Khaled Al-Ibrahim, one of the King's brothers-in-law. ARA is richly rewarded to produce slavishly laudatory mini-films and songs for the kingdom. One Saudi businessman said the King himself occasionally assisted in the final editing.
The commission issue is a longstanding one in Saudi Arabia. The King and his younger brother, Prince Sultan, who is the Defense Minister, are among the principal recipients. This bestowal of enormous sums enrages many Saudis, who maintain that control of the Saudi treasury and the stipends given every prince by the royal court are more than enough for the royal family. Many senior members of the family are said to oppose these commissions. Among them are Prince Salman, the Governor of Riyadh, and his son, Prince Abdulaziz, both of whom enjoy a reputation for financial probity.
Prince Salman, who refused to be interviewed, is said to have fierce integrity, tinged with a temper that he has occasionally displayed publicly before princes and wealthy Saudis. When a Saudi businessman was said to have provided drugs to a high-ranking young prince, Prince Salman summoned the businessman to his majlis and beat him. When the same businessman, a Palestinian by birth, lost several million dollars in a much-publicized gambling binge in Monte Carlo at the beginning of the gulf crisis, Prince Salman seized his passport, effectively barring him from leaving the kingdom.
Earlier this winter, Prince Salman had a young prince named Bader publicly flogged for getting into a fistfight with members of the religious police who had supposedly harassed his female relative at a downtown shopping center.
But such men are the exceptions in the Saudi system. Most princes, unable or unwilling to live on their stipends, supplement their incomes with huge commissions from foreign companies that do business in the country. The system, which is as Saudi as sand, is nonetheless increasingly resented by many of the technocrats.
 WHILE CORRUPTION IS widely seen as a problem whose solution lies with the country's political leadership, other issues seem beyond the Government's ability to solve by edict or example.
Among the most difficult is the subservient and totally segregated role of women. While the Government, including the King, is known to support more freedom for Saudi women, the response to the women's protest over driving illustrates the lengths to which the Government is willing to go to accommodate the religious conservatives.
Some Saudis -- men and women -- were deeply impressed by the women's tiny rebellion. The only people with spine in this society were the 47 women who drove, one Saudi intellectual said. "And look at what happened to them. They were thrown to the wolves." The Government, in fact, punished them as severely as it would any public protesters. Virtually all of those who taught at one university were dismissed by order of the King. The women, as well as their husbands and even some of their other relatives, were forbidden to leave the kingdom, a particularly harsh measure in the mobile Saudi society. They were ordered not to meet with Western reporters or to discuss their situation with any outsider, and they were warned of further reprisals if they attempted to drive again or stage any other demonstration.
But the Government's abuse of these women was mild compared with their treatment by the religious establishment, particularly the Islamic extremists who have increasingly challenged the Government-dominated religious hierarchy.
Before the women were dismissed or harassed by the Government, the fundamentalist sheiks denounced them from one of the kingdom's most powerful political platforms, the mosque pulpits. In the Friday sermons after the protest, the women were branded as "red communists," "dirty American secularists," "whores and prostitutes," "fallen women" and "advocates of vice." Their names, occupations, addresses and phone numbers were, in violation of traditional Saudi insistence on "protecting" women, distributed in leaflets around mosques and other public places. One leaflet accused them of having renounced Islam, an offense punishable by death in Saudi Arabia. Another called upon "every Muslim to cut out the roots of this evil plant before it spreads to every part of our holy land."
Several of the women who met with me, despite the ban on such contacts, said they had feared for their safety and that of their families.
Soon after the protest, Sheik Abdulaziz bin Baz, the head of the Council of the Higher Ulema, Islamic scholars who are the Government's religious authority, issued a fatwa, or religious decree, forbidding women from driving for the time being.
"I was, of course, disappointed in the decree," one of the women said. "But I was more disappointed that the King did so little for us. And even more disappointed in some of our friends."
Many of those who initially voiced support abruptly shunned the women after it became clear that they would be punished. The modernizers and technocrats, who would have been natural allies in this struggle, were silent. The leaflets circulated against the women also attacked modernizers and liberals as "dirty secularists."
Three months after the crisis, a strong self-serving consensus developed in Riyadh that the women had not only acted inappropriately, they had done immeasurable harm to the cause, at least in the short-run. "I support women driving," said Ahmed Al-Tuwaigeri, dean of the College of Education at King Saud University, "but their timing and their methods were counterproductive."
Several of the women have remained unrepentant, convinced that eventually the issue of their status will be addressed. "The issue is not driving," one of them said. "It is that here in Saudi Arabia, I exist as a person from the bellybutton to the knees."

TRADITIONALLY, THE Government, especially the King, pioneered daring social changes that were essential for modernizing the country.
In the late 1940's, King Abdel Aziz introduced radio, over loud objections from the religious establishment. In 1959, his son, Faisal, permitted education for girls, and he sent troops to protect the television station in 1965 when it was besieged by a tiny band of religious extremists. His nephew was killed in the ensuing clash.
Religious opposition to change is a fact of life in Saudi Arabia. "There was a fatwa against radio, a fatwa against television," one Saudi intellectual said. "This country is littered with fatwas that the Government has disregarded when the interests of the kingdom were at stake. What has weakened is the King's determination to promote change in the society."
At the beginning of the war, some Saudis hoped King Fahd would use the occasion to enhance employment prospects for women and shed some of the restraints on their mobility and independence. After all, the kingdom was threatened. The crisis had highlighted to the six million to eight million Saudi Arabians (the Government insists that there are at least 13 million, but experts say this is a gross overestimate) the risk of their dependence on more than four million foreign workers. Many of the foreign workers tried to leave shortly after the invasion and had to be induced to stay through large bonuses.
The wisdom of barring Saudi women from vast sectors of the work force was widely discussed last fall after the crisis began. It would have been natural, many of the Saudi modernists argued, for the King to have permitted women doctors and other female medical personnel to drive to their jobs to assist Saudi soldiers and others in need.
But King Fahd did not do so. Many technocrats and diplomats note that the paralysis is typical, that unlike his predecessors he has almost never been willing to challenge religious forces.
Some Saudis attribute the King's reticence to his personal life. The dynamic founder of the Saudi state, King Abdel Aziz, and Fahd's more recent precedessors were deeply austere and pious rulers above moral suspicion. King Fahd, by contrast, had a well-documented reputation in his younger years as a gambler and rake. Although a new Fahd has emerged since he became King eight years ago, a sober (and thinner) ruler who has relinquished his indolent ways and a taste for the good life, some Saudis believe he is unwilling to challenge the religious extremists because he feels vulnerable and must constantly prove his piety and Islamic credentials.
Others say the issue is temperament. This King is somewhat lazy, they maintain, and avoids potentially bruising confrontations.
There are those who ardently contest these explanations. It was this King, they argue, who had the courage to risk Saudi and Arab scorn by inviting the infidel Americans into the kingdom to protect it. It was Fahd, they argue, who abandoned the self-deluding mythologies and empty rhetoric of Arab solidarity in the face of new realities imposed by Saddam Hussein. And it was he who insisted that Saudi Arabia's friends and supporters stand up and be counted as part of a new Arab order, a more sober and pragmatic order in which Riyadh would be a major factor.
These Saudis see a shrewd calculation in his decision to abandon the women to Islamic radicals and not to press for jolting changes at this time. When King Fahd's predecessors imposed change, said Fahd A. Al-Semmari, a history professor at Imam Mohammed ibn Saud Islamic University in Riyadh, they knew that a majority of the country supported them. This was not the case with women driving. "It's the opposite today," he asserted. "A minority favors it and most still oppose."
And some see an urgent pragmatism. "The King could not take the women's side because of the war," said one well-respected analyst of Islamic politics in the kingdom. "He needed the support of the sheiks and muftis -- all of them, especially the extremists -- for the war and Saudi Arabia's stance."
Another Saudi professor agreed: "It was a political compromise, pure and simple. The religious opposition opposed both the foreign troops and the women's driving. He gave them one, and demanded acquiescence, if not outright support on the other. And he got it."
Some evidence supports the theory that there was such an implicit deal. The pamphlets and cassettes attacking the foreign troops that circulated last fall have all but disappeared. The Friday sermons at fundamentalist mosques have recently dealt with subjects other than the war. And when Sheik bin Baz issued his controversial fatwa in January authorizing a holy war against Saddam Hussein and blessing all those -- including non-Muslim foreign forces -- who helped Saudi Arabia in this crisis, the fundamentalist preachers remained silent.
Some of the extremists, however, interpreted the trade-off as a sign of weakness by the Government. After the women's driving incident, the religious police outraged liberals and modernizers by a series of well-publicized raids on the compounds of rich and politically well-connected Saudis. In one of these highly unusual raids, the King's translator was arrested and detained in prison for attending a party at which alcohol was consumed and single women were present.
The Government responded by appointing a new head of the mutawwa, known for his pliability. He quickly signaled that such raids would end. In an interview with Okaz, an Arabic daily newspaper, he argued that the role of his organization was not only to urge prayer but also to set a good example by praying.
 THE FUNDAMENTALISTS terrify many Saudis, including some in the royal family. Who are these people that can spread such fear and paralyze a King? And what is their source of power?
Though their spokesmen number fewer than a dozen and tend to be young -- most are under 35 -- their names have become well known in Saudi households. Their pulpits are the public mosques or college classrooms, through which they have organized a devout and devoted following.
Some of the religious establishment dismiss them. The extremists are "a tiny minority," said a senior Government-appointed religious official, who spoke on the condition that he not be identified.
"This Government and the society at large adhere to Islamic principles," he said. "We never abandoned Islam, so there is no need to 'return' to it as there is in other societies."
But others disagree. They believe that the fundamentalists are gaining strength, fueled by the double standards and hypocrisy that infuriate many Saudi liberals. Much of what is officially "haram," or forbidden, to the less influential Saudis is readily available to the rich and well-connected. Alcohol, for example, is banned, but a good bottle of Scotch, smuggled through Yemen and foreign embassies, can easily be purchased for $240 a bottle on the black market. So while raiding the houses of the rich and famous was unpopular among liberals, many ordinary citizens, subject to intense scrutiny by the religious police for minor offenses, felt it was long overdue.
The extremists have also been fueled by resentment over the growing maldistribution of wealth. While almost no Saudi goes hungry or wants for the necessities of life, the gap between the princes and their commission-bolstered incomes and the salaried Saudi has bred envy that is often fodder for extremist forces.
To some extent, the problem is perception. "This is a very large family, and I know princes who have a hard time paying the rent," said Prince Abdullah bin Faisal bin Turki, president of the Royal Commission for Jubail and Yanbu and one of the younger generation of princes respected for his modest life style and hard work. But flamboyance and ostentation are more typical among the kingdom's 5,000 princes and princesses. And while their proliferation is viewed as a source of stability, it is also a growing problem for the kingdom.
 A SIMPLER EXPLANATION for King's Fahd's unwillingness to confront the extremists -- who are, in effect, challenging his rule -- is that the legitimacy of the royal family has always rested on Islam.
All public debates in the kingdom are contained in an exclusively Islamic context; Islam is, in fact, the only vehicle for political opposition. Criticism in the name of Islam cannot be silenced and must be rebutted in the same terms, a confrontation that is usually stacked against the modernizers.
The Sauds' reluctance to crack down on the fundamentalists also reflects their general attitude toward dissent. Unlike most other Arab regimes, the Saudis are extremely hesitant to resort to force. While Saudi Arabia is no paradise for free political discourse, neither is it a police state.
The lavish subsidies that the Government has bestowed on the Saudi citizenry are a reflection of the desire to preempt confrontation. In any other society this would be a time of national sacrifice, with imposition of a draft for the army and taxes to finance the enormous cost of battle. Instead, the war became an occasion for the Saudi Government to forgive two years of debt repayment on housing loans, to slash domestic air fares and to increase the subsidy on grain, a gift to the Bedouins. Such largesse was all the more remarkable since the war had depleted the kingdom's treasury; these gifts would be financed by foreign borrowing.
 IT IS SAUDI ARABIA'S great and good fortune -- America's as well -- that Saddam Hussein is not a patient man. Had he waited five more years to seize Kuwait and fulfill his grandiose ambitions, his arsenal would have been far deadlier and the Saudis still woefully unprepared.
Saudi Arabia is likely to emerge from the crisis with a more aggressive foreign policy, as Prince Bandar bin Sultan, Washington's effective Ambassador, has long advocated. While the Saudis are unlikely to abandon their penchant for buying off trouble, from now on there may be no alternative but to pursue Saudi interests more openly and to help those who stood with the kingdom in time of need. The Saudis, not just the Americans, fought bravely and with a success that astonished them.
"We are certain to have a better appreciation of who our friends are," said Prince Abdullah of the Royal Commission.
"What happened to us is rather simple," said Prince Abdul Aziz bin Salman bin Saud, at the age of 30 a senior consultant at the Ministry of Petroleum. "You have a neighbor, a longtime friend. And one day another neighbor comes to his home, rapes his wife, kills his children for trying to resist, ransacks his house and occupies it and declares it his own. Your neighbor and friend cries out for your help. What do you do?
"There is only one answer. Yes or no. Not maybe, or not in this fashion, or I'll consider if you do the following 10 things. Just yes or no. I'll help or I won't."
But in terms of domestic policy, things for Saudi Arabia will not be as clear. To continue modernizing the kingdom, the King will eventually have to challenge the Islamic extremists, most diplomats and liberals agree. To do so, he will need the support of the technocrats, who do not enjoy the organizational base of the mosques.
Because of its extreme sensitivity toward any public debate on any contentious issue, the Government has undermined its natural allies in this impending power struggle. The technocrats are frightened. So despite official American certainty that a crackdown on religious extremism is likely after the war, many people fear that King Fahd will shrink from such a confrontation.
The outcome of the gulf war is likely to strengthen the King's position. Had the conflict been long, bloody or indecisive, Fahd would have been weakened. Saudi xenophobia would have reasserted itself; the fundamentalists would have been emboldened.
But the war was short, relatively bloodless for the allies, and the victory decisive. The King's judgment to invite the Americans into Arabia was vindicated. So King Fahd, having triumphed over the greatest external challenge to his sovereignty thus far, is now in a strong position to confront the dangerous internal opponents of his system's own creation. The question is: Will he choose to do so?

CORRECTION-DATE: March 10, 1991, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article in The Times Magazine today about Britain's role in the Persian Gulf war says that after the war began, British authorities put 34 Arabs in a war-prisoner camp because of their military status, and put other Arabs in prisons in Yorkshire and London. On Wednesday, after the magazine went to press, Britain freed 32 Iraqi men who were held in the camp. On Friday Britain said it would drop all actions against 33 other Arabs it had sought to deport as possible threats to domestic security.

PUB-DATE: March 10, 1991

SECTION: Section 6; Page 40; Column 1; Magazine Desk

HEADLINE: Power Skating

BYLINE: By Jared Lubarsky; Jared Lubarsky is an American journalist based in Tokyo.

 BODY:
You don't have to know much about figure skating to know that something special is happening when Midori Ito executes a triple Axel. Skimming -- sprinting -- across the rink at 20 miles an hour, she pushes off with her left foot, leaps clear of the ice, spins three and a half times in midair and lands on her right foot, skating backward. The crowds roar. Rival coaches shake their heads. The triple Axel, named after Axel Paulsen, a Norwegian skater from the early 1900's, is one of the most difficult jumps rated by the International Skating Union. In 1988 Ito became the first woman to perform it successfully in international competition.
In fact, until recently, Ito -- the 1989 world champion and Japan's best hope for a gold medal at the 1992 Winter Olympics -- was the only woman to have landed the jump in competition. She last executed the triple Axel in January at the All-Japan Figure Skating Championships in Yokohama, which she won, to nobody's surprise. Then, last month, at the United States Figure Skating Championships in Minneapolis, Tonya Harding duplicated the feat, won the women's title and instantly became Ito's most formidable rival. Barring an unforeseen mishap, both women will compete at the World Figure Skating Championships this week in Munich, Germany. (For a moment in mid-February, there were doubts that Ito, who underwent surgery a few weeks earlier on her jaw, would make the trip.) 
 To watch Ito in action is to realize that she is in a category all her own, notwithstanding the challenge from Harding. For one thing, she doesn't even look like other figure skaters. She is just 4 feet 9 inches tall and weighs 98 pounds. Her legs are short and sturdy and, well, a little bowed. At presentation ceremonies, the runners-up standing one step down on the medal-winners' stand can look the champion square in the eye. Nor does she perform like other skaters. Waiting their turn on the ice, her rivals are keyed up like race horses, shrugging their shoulders, shaking the kinks out of their legs. Ito is impassive, almost grim-faced. The gate opens for her, and she goes through it like a gladiator into battle: This space is mine.
Figure skating is partly showmanship. Skaters work "Saturday Night Fever" poses into their routines; they make dramatic finishes on one knee; they smile automatically as they glide past the television cameras. Ito's routines are not that different from those of other skaters, but she carries the field not so much as a better performer than as an immeasurably better athlete. She moves faster, jumps higher, covers more of the ice. Most skaters can manage a triple jump (a half-turn short of a triple Axel) followed by a double; Ito can do consecutive triples. Most skaters also need the whole rink to build up enough momentum for a triple jump; Ito jumps with room to spare.
"Actually," she confesses, "I didn't do as well as I wanted to in Yokohama. I've missed a lot of practice this year." On top of her recent hospitalization, the 21-year-old skater has been suffering from a number of leg injuries.
Ito has consented to be interviewed not at home but in the office of the Osumo skating rink in Nagoya, where she has been training since 1974. The office is a small cramped space at the back of the building. Small boys on rented skates crowd around the snack bar outside, its concrete floor littered with food wrappers and discarded chopsticks. Ito hardly seems to notice her surroundings.
Soft-spoken, her hair pulled back from her face, Ito in person shows little of the sheer presence that she displays on the ice. Questions don't open into conversations. She answers them one by one -- briefly, soberly -- speaking only in Japanese, and stops, earnest and composed in her chair, to wait for the next question. What stands out most about her responses is that she refers to herself in the third person, as Midori. It's a habit that children develop early in Japan and usually drop by the age of 5 or 6, when they first go to school. Some women hang on to the habit into their teens and 20's, but only with close friends and family. Most Japanese, hearing Ito speak of herself this way to outsiders, would assume that she was simply immature.
The assumption would be hasty. Until 1985, Ito was just a promising local skater, having yet to win even a national competition. Four years later, she was a world champion, bathing in the peculiar adulation the Japanese reserve for those who achieve something -- anything -- outstanding in the outside world.
Although little in Ito's background prepared her to deal with people on the scale that her sudden celebrity demands, she gives the impression of having mastered the problem the way she would master a new jump, with the same deliberate homage to form and technique. She is self-confident without being self-absorbed, aware of the limelight but determined to keep it at a distance. Crowds -- delighted audiences -- make her happy; individuals make her cautious.
Midori Ito was born in Nagoya, the fourth-largest city in Japan, on Aug. 13, 1969. She started skating at the age of 4, when her parents began taking her once a week on family outings to the Osumo rink. One day, seeing Machiko Yamada coaching a group of preschoolers in the middle of the ice, she asked if she could also take lessons.
"I've been coaching for 25 years now," Yamada says. "Most of the kids I work with start at about age 5 or 6. Still, the first time I saw Midori, I felt there was something unusual -- something different -- about her. There was a kind of concentration about her already, for somebody so young. You could tell that she'd been thinking a lot about what she wanted and how to get it."
Ito's formal training began when she was 5. The bond between student and teacher was immediate and strong, so much so that when Ito's parents separated the following year she began to spend more and more time with the Yamadas at home. When she was 10, she moved in, and she has been there ever since. Over the past 10 years, she has had little contact with her own family (she has an older brother and a younger sister), who still live in Nagoya, and in that time they have not seen her skate in competition. Neither Ito nor Yamada will discuss what happened; it is a part of their lives that they have successfully hidden from the notoriously inquisitive Japanese press. "I don't really remember much," Ito says. "It all just seemed to work out that way before I knew it."
The Yamadas live in a brick-front, two-story house in a largely residential area about 10 minutes by car from the Osumo rink. The living room is overfurnished; like many middle-class Japanese, the Yamadas have abandoned the traditionally spare interior decor for the often cluttered Western look. A sideboard along one wall is piled high with Ito's trophies. Along the entire opposite wall there is an array of hi-fi equipment: decks and amps and mixers that might well belong in a professional studio. The equipment is a hobby for Yamada's husband, Hiroki, who is general manager of a local motorcycle and automotive tire company. Machiko Yamada uses it to edit the music for Ito's skating programs.
"When Midori was younger," she says, "we used to put selections together from marches -- upbeat pieces with nice clear tempos. Now she's become fond of classical music." Ito's interest in Western music does not really go beyond what appeals to her sense of rhythm as a skater, but she will spend hours in record shops, browsing for new pieces. This year she got interested in piano concertos.
"Yamada-sensei is very strict as a coach," Ito says, "but at home I have a very ordinary life. Her daughter, Mikiko, is my age. They treat me like her sister."
Yamada has a slightly different view of the relationship. "After all, we're two women," she says. "When we get grumpy with each other at the rink, a lot of times we can't just leave it there; we wind up taking it home. Luckily, there's the rest of the family. My husband or my daughter -- she has no interest in skating -- can usually get us talking about something else."
A trim, handsome woman of 47, her long hair dyed a fashionable auburn, Yamada could easily be taken for 35. She is comfortable with people, has a sense of humor and a low and throaty laugh. She talks easily about Ito, and seems to be able to step back from their relationship. One imagines that achieving that psychic distance, balancing her roles of coach and foster parent, took some effort. This is obvious when Ito competes. Other coaches are there -- touching, encouraging, calling their skaters to the fence during warm-up sessions to dispense last-minute instructions, raising the emotional ante. Yamada, who sometimes appears at the rink in an ankle-length fur coat, seems almost to ignore her protegee. The connection is invisible, but it never wavers.
"The toughest time was when Midori was 13 or 14," Yamada continues. "That's a rebellious time of life for kids anyhow, and whatever you said, she would take the opposite tack. At one point, she wanted to give up skating altogether. Now that she's older, she's not what you would call feminine, but she has developed a basically cheerful disposition. I think we get along pretty well."

AT AGE 11 ITO QUALIFIED TO COMPETE in the World Junior Figure Skating Championships in London, Ontario. She finished eighth. "I thought then she just might make an interesting competition skater," Yamada says, "but I never figured that she would turn out as strong as she did. Here in Nagoya we sort of expect the top skaters to come out of Tokyo." This kind of deprecating comment is often heard in Nagoya. An industrial giant of 2.2 million people, the city nurses a half-envious, half-resentful vision of the capital, two hours north by train.
In 1983, at the world junior championships in Sapporo, Ito finished third -- qualifying, although she was only 14, to compete as a senior the following season. "It never crossed my mind then that I could be a world champion," she says. "I just wanted to do my best in every competition. I'd watch skaters like Katarina Witt or Scott Hamilton, and think, 'Wouldn't it be great if I could skate like that someday?' "
Ito made her international debut as a senior at the 1984 world championships in Ottawa. Over three days of competition she rose from 16th to 7th place; digging herself out of the hole was becoming her trademark. "Even so," she says, "starting way behind and moving up was a lot better than starting high and falling back."
For the next few years, playing catch-up was mostly what she did. Why? Simply put, the girl who would become the world's best woman figure skater could barely muster a competitive figure eight.
Until last year, competitions sanctioned by the International Skating Union had been made up of three events: an individually composed short, or original, program of 2 minutes, 40 seconds; a choreographed free-skating program of 4 minutes, and the compulsories, which gave the skater no latitude at all. The rules called for the execution of selections from 41 different figures, performed to instructions that specified even whether the skater should trace the line on the ice with the inside or outside edge of the skate. Each figure had to be repeated twice, "without skids or scrapes, double tracings or unpermitted changes of edge." It was akin to an archer putting an arrow through a previous bull's-eye, then splitting the second arrow with a third. Mistakes, flawed circles, deviations from the axis were easy to determine; the judges went out on the ice when the skater was finished and examined the traces. The compulsories were often called school figures. Traditionalists believe that the combination of grace and precision they demand are the very heart of the sport.
According to Kashio Takizawa, director and secretary general of the Japan Skating Federation, "Japanese skaters have never done very well in the compulsories because they don't get enough practice on clean ice, where they can see the tracings." In all of Japan, there are only 28 skating rinks open year round; just 13 of these are 30 by 60 meters (about 100 by 200 feet), the competition size. All of them are jammed throughout the day with recreational skaters, chewing the surface.
The Osumo rink in Nagoya, where Ito trains, is a notable handicap. Built in 1953, it is a little smaller than standard. Legions of wobbly recreational skaters have left it with scars that never have time to heal. As a child, Ito would practice there in a group from 6 to 7:30 A.M., go to school, and come back again from 5 to 8 P.M.
"I've never had any confidence about my figures," Ito confesses. "I could never really trace well." Still, this is not simply a matter of practice; it's a matter of temperament. The compulsories demand a submission to the geometry; Ito wants to dominate the rink. "For the compulsories," Yamada says, "you have to skate slowly, deliberately -- you have to be composed. That's just not Midori's personality at all. Her style is quick and energetic. She's an attacker."
In June 1988, the attacker got her big break. The International Skating Union met in Davos, Switzerland, to consider eliminating the compulsory figures from competition. Opinion was divided. Member countries traditionally strong in the figures -- among them the United States and Canada -- were reluctant to give them up. They also happened to have lots of year-round skating facilities where training could be done. Member nations not so happily endowed, including Japan, were ranged on the other side.
"Spectators," Takizawa notes, "can't see the tracing on the ice. Most of them have no idea why one skater gets a higher score than another." The compulsories were more than a mystery, the argument went. They were time-consuming and downright dull. Without them, figure skating would draw more attention.
"Of course, we depend a lot on television for financial support," says Katsuichiro Hisanaga, chairman of the Japan Skating Federation's figure-skating committee. "The compulsories were taking up enormous amounts of time, and the television networks just didn't want to cover them."
In the end, the majority of voters favored the figure-skating audience. As of July 1, 1990, declared the I.S.U., the compulsories would no longer be a required event. The short program would count for one-third of the overall score and free skating for two-thirds.

BUT UNTIL THE RULES were changed, Ito managed the best she could. At the 1985 world championships in Tokyo, she wanted to become the first woman ever to land a triple Axel in competition.
All the jumps in the figure-skating repertoire end with the skater gliding backward. Except for the Axel, all the jumps also begin with the skater gliding backward, and the spin involves one or more complete 360-degree rotations of the body. With the Axel, the skater enters the jump facing forward, into the direction of the glide, so in order to land facing backward, a skater has to execute an extra half-rotation: two and a half spins for a double Axel; three and a half for a triple Axel. Jumping high enough to make three and a half spins requires tremendous strength in the legs and arms -- and superb balance. Few performers -- men or women -- have the strength to get high enough for the extra 180-degree spin.
The day before the championships, however, Ito broke her right leg in a practice session. "It was just an accumulation of strains," she says, with no hint of the enormous disappointment that must have meant. She couldn't start training again for six months.
Ito finally landed the triple Axel on Nov. 2, 1988. Hardly anyone noticed. The occasion was a small free-skating competition in Aichi prefecture, where Nagoya is located, and Ito's feat received only local coverage. The following week, however, when Ito landed the jump at the All-Japan Figure Skating Championships in Osaka, it was a different story.
"I don't think too many people watching really knew what happened," recalls Hirotaro Yagami, a reporter for the daily Sports Nippon newspaper who has followed Ito's career closely. "But the next day the major national papers were all over it." By the end of the day, the whole country knew that Midori Ito had done something extraordinary, something no woman had ever done before.
Nine months before, at the Winter Olympics in Calgary, Alberta, Ito gave a dazzling free-skating performance and for the first time gained worldwide attention, but she finished just out of the running for a medal. It wasn't until the World Figure Skating Championships in Paris in 1989 that Ito finally managed to be strong enough in the original and free-skating programs to overcome her weak compulsory figures, becoming the first Asian skater ever to win the gold medal. At the end of the first day, she was well back in sixth place. Winning the second round of competition with a nearly impeccable performance -- two of the judges gave her the only perfect scores of the day -- she moved up to third place. On the final day, Ito's routine included six different jumps, including the triple Axel, and she won the title.
The 1989 world championships were a kind of watershed for the entire sport. Figure skating would no longer be dominated by the flowing, elegant style of European and North American skaters like Brian Orser and Katarina Witt. From then on it would belong to more dynamic and acrobatic performers like Ito -- and it promised, for a while, to belong to Ito alone. "She's the only woman I've seen," commented Canada's Kurt Browning, the men's gold medalist, "who could compete with the top men. Her jumping ability is incredible."
Ito's victory brought to the fore an old debate: Is figure skating essentially balletic or gymnastic? In the long run, the decision to drop compulsory figures promises to dissolve, rather than resolve, the debate.
Coaches still make their students learn the compulsories, especially in the early stages of their training. Although some feel that Ito is in the vanguard of a new breed of athletes poised to turn the sport into acrobatics on ice, figure skating continues to demand a special dimension of grace and style.
Performances in the short and free-skating programs are still scored in two categories: technical merit and artistic impression. In the free-skating program, moreover, if two competitors get the same number of points from any judge, the skater with the higher score for artistic impression is ranked higher. Artistry is clearly no small factor. If the athlete has the edge now, the graceful athlete has an even greater edge.
Still, Ito may be a special case; her scores for technical merit have been so high that she could afford to give away the edge. The future of the sport is likely to belong to skaters with a combination of athletic strength and traditional grace -- like Kristi Yamaguchi, 19, and Tonya Harding, 20, both of the United States, and Surya Bonaly, 17, of France.
At the recent United States Figure Skating Championships in Minneapolis, Yamaguchi was the odds-on favorite to win the women's title until Harding overtook her with her flawless completion of seven triple jumps, including the Axel. Bonaly, who was last year's world junior champion and the surprise winner of the European Figure Skating Championships in Sofia, Bulgaria, in January, began her career as a gymnast. She also has the distinction of having landed a quadruple jump in exhibition, something Ito had hoped to do in Munich, but which is now unlikely.

WITH HER VICTORY IN the 1989 world championships, Midori Ito became a national hero. The Japan Amateur Sports Association awarded her a group "A" category stipend of about $1,500 a month. In December 1989, she was awarded the 39th annual Japan Amateur Sports Grand Prix, given for the top performance of the year by an athlete or team; she was the first figure skater to win it, and the first woman in 13 years.
Ito's Japanese fans were now taking it for granted that Ito would run away with another world title. The 1990 championships, in Halifax, Nova Scotia, was the last international competition to include the compulsory figures. But Ito turned in a catastrophic performance during the first round and ended up in 10th place. Leading the field at that point was Jill Trenary, the three-time United States national champion. Ito won the original program, advancing to fourth place. On the final day, her winning routine again included seven triple jumps, one of them the triple Axel. The nine judges awarded her three 6.0's (perfect scores) and six 5.9's for technical merit. But Trenary -- who outscored Ito only in the compulsories -- took the gold.
"Everybody said it was too bad," Ito notes, "but I didn't go into it with the feeling that I was defending my title. Sure, I wanted to win -- but you know, it's hard enough to be world champion even once. I did the kind of original program and free program I wanted to. I don't have any regrets."
Now, without the compulsories to worry about, Ito's one remaining vulnerability is a want of grace. Her scores for artistic impression are still a little low, but they have been getting better in the past two years. The ballet lessons she started when she was 11 are paying off.
"Midori's improvement has more to do with her age," Yamada says. "She's had some experience of life now. She's centered more, and it shows up in her sense of self-expression."
Last April, Ito graduated from Tokai Gakuen Junior College in Nagoya (her major: home economics) and was hired by the Prince Hotels. She is nominally to work in the general-affairs department of the company headquarters in Tokyo, although she continues to live and train in Nagoya. Like American universities, leading Japanese corporations recruit aggressively for outstanding athletes. A lot of prestige is on the line.
In Ito's case, she does not skate "for" the Prince Hotels, but her official affiliation is now the company's own skating club. Twice a week, on the average, she takes the train up from Nagoya to Tokyo, puts on the company uniform and shuffles some of the routine paper work normally assigned to new employees. Otherwise, she is free to do what she does best. Her salary is the same as any other first-year clerk's: about $1,100 a month.
It was natural that Ito would join the Prince Hotels. The Prince chain is the flagship company of the Seibu Railway Group. Its chairman, Yoshiaki Tsutsumi (according to the Sept. 10, 1990, Fortune magazine, the seventh-richest man in the world), is the eminence grise of Japanese winter sports. The Seibu Group sponsors the strongest hockey team in Japan's company league; operates 34 ski resorts, and owns 11 of the country's 200 or so hockey rinks, including the sites of the last three All-Japan Figure Skating Championships.
So far, the current season -- which ends this week in Munich -- has not been good for Midori Ito. At the Skate America competition last October in Buffalo, she placed second to Kristi Yamaguchi. Her performances in January at the national championships in Yokohama were good enough to win, but most observers agreed they were cautious and uninspired.
"Midori's legs haven't been in really good shape for a while," Yamada explains. "She had that break in 1985, then trouble with her knees -- one thing after another. She could ignore all that when she was 18; now she doesn't have the same stamina. Katarina Witt used to have two or three different triple jumps at most in her programs; that's why she could compete until she was 22 or 23. Midori has five different triples and the triple Axel, and her jumps are higher than anybody else's."
Ito cut back considerably on competition appearances for the 1990-91 season, saving herself for Munich. She has also adopted a less demanding training schedule. (For every week of practice, she spends three to five days in a Prince-owned hotel at the Yunohana hot springs in Hakone, a resort area near Mount Fuji.) Then, in late January, she was briefly hospitalized for removal of a stone in a salivary gland.
Ito tends to turn aside questions about her retirement from amateur figure skating or about her future plans. "I like to take one season at a time," she says. "I have this vague feeling that the Olympics are coming up, and it would be great if I could go, but right now I just want to do well in Munich."
"The Olympics," her coach says, "will probably be the last time Midori competes as an amateur."
One career Ito absolutely rules out is coaching. "She's been watching me do what I do for 15 years now," Yamada says, "and she admits she hasn't got the temperament for it."
Skaters of Ito's stature occasionally turn professional -- become entertainers in ice shows and exhibitions -- and this she finds attractive, although the chances are slim that she would find the backing in Japan to develop and produce her own show. Would she join an existing show? Hire an agent? Skate abroad?
"What should I do, what should I do?" she says, and the stern little face wrinkles in dismay. "I really don't know." It's hard to take that dismay seriously. Midori Ito, after all, has been thinking about what she wants and how to get it since she was 4 years old.

HEADLINE: Harvard Panel Narrows Its Search for President

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 7

 BODY:
The committee to select a successor to Harvard University's president, Derek C. Bok, has narrowed its search to four or five finalists, but with its self-imposed deadline approaching at the end of this month, the committee is still seriously divided, university officials say.
The result, they say, may be a decision to turn to Henry Rosovsky, the acting dean of the Faculty of Arts and Sciences, who has long been the favorite of many Harvard faculty members. 
 But choosing the popular and widely respected Mr. Rosovsky would be difficult, because at the age of 63 he is considered too old for the job and because he is a member of the eight-person search committee. In addition, Mr. Rosovsky announced last summer that he would not be a candidate to succeed Mr. Bok, who will retire in June after 20 years as Harvard's president, often considered the nation's most prestigious academic position.
The committee's finalists, university officials say, include Martin S. Feldstein, 51 years old, a professor of economics at Harvard and a former chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers under President Ronald Reagan; Philip Leder, 56, a professor of genetics at the Harvard Medical School, and Neil L. Rudenstine, also 56, the executive vice president of the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation, who was the provost at Princeton University for 10 years.
Friends and colleagues of each of the three men say they have been intensively interviewed by the search committee in the past few weeks.
Another contender, some officials say, is Gerhard Casper, the 53-year-old provost of the University of Chicago, who was born and educated in Germany and taught at the University of California at Berkeley before going to Chicago as a professor of law.
In addition, The Harvard Crimson, the undergraduate daily newspaper, said last month that the committee is still considering several other candidates. It named Jeremy R. Knowles, a British-born professor of chemistry at Harvard; Michael B. McElroy, a professor of atmospheric science at Harvard; Stephen G. Breyer, chief judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit, in Boston, and a former law professor at Harvard, and Donald C. Hood, a professor of psychology at Columbia University and a former vice president there.
Mr. Feldstein and Mr. Leder are graduates of Harvard College, the undergraduate school, in the past a prerequisite for being president. Mr. Rudenstine graduated summa cum laude from Princeton but received his Ph.D. in English literature from Harvard.
 
'There Is No Perfect Candidate'

Members of the search committee refuse to comment on their work. The committee is made up of five members of the Harvard Corporation and three members of the Board of Overseers, the two bodies that govern the university.
But one official knowledgeable about the committee's work, speaking on the condition of anonymity, said: "The committee didn't realize that there is no perfect candidate. They are all impressive, but none of them quite strikes it. So the committee is deadlocked."
If that remains the case, this official added, "We already have the guy here who can step in -- Henry Rosovsky."
Mr. Rosovsky, who was born in Poland, won a large following while serving as dean of the Faculty of Arts and Sciences at Harvard from 1973 to 1984, when he pushed through a new undergraduate curriculum, known as the Core Curriculum. During that time he turned down an offer to be president of Yale University.
Although he has publicly renounced any intention to be president, friends say he would still like the job.
Harvard is about to embark on a $2 billion fund-raising campaign, the largest in the history of American education, and the new president will have to spend much of his time seeking contributions from alumni at a time of economic austerity.
Harvard also faces a deficit in its operating budget for the first time in many years, and despite having the largest endowment of any university in the nation, it is taking tough steps to try to reduce expenses.
A major question for the next president will be whether to continue Harvard's tradition of decentralized management, under which each of the university's component schools is responsible for its own finances.
The new president will also confront growing concern that Harvard has given priority to its graduate and professional schools at the expense of undergraduate education, with many professors more interested in research and consulting for business or government than in teaching.
To further complicate the situation, the search committee is expected to make a recommendation on whether Harvard should establish a new post of provost. Because of the decentralization of the schools both financially and academically, some officials see a need for better coordination among them, and they believe that the committee will suggest the creation of a provost, although his selection would be up to the next president.

HEADLINE: Route From College to Career Keeps Getting Bumpier

BYLINE: By ANDI RIERDEN

 BODY:
AS a sophomore at the University of Connecticut, Steven Hopley began priming himself for success. With dreams of a stellar career in advertising or public relations, he said, he took on an internship at an advertising agency in Hartford without pay or college credit. He then served as the assistant to the university's director of public relations for two years, organizing the mailing of news releases and planning major events. Hoping to keep in touch with professionals in the field, Mr. Hopley said, he joined a statewide public relations association. All the while, he said, "I kept telling myself, 'This is going to pay off.' "
But now, after spending hundreds of dollars on postage, resumes and phone calls to dozens of companies, only to hear that most had no openings, Mr. Hopley, who graduated in December, said he is revising his goals. "At this point, I'd be satisfied just to find a job that pays for food," he said. 
 Educated in the highly confident 1980's, Connecticut's college graduates of the 1990's are confronting the stark realities of a recessionary job market. With companies throughout the region trimming expenses by hiring fewer people or considering only experienced applicants, the job prospects for new graduates have narrowed considerably, said employers and career counselors. Their observations coincide with a survey from Northwestern University, which reported recently that of 320 companies around the nation, 42 percent said they were hiring fewer people with bachelor's degrees.
Career counselors at colleges across Connecticut said that on-campus interviews with company recruiters have decreased by at least 20 percent from a year ago. And among the recruiters who still visit, some were uncertain if their companies would have openings by the summer, the counselors said. Other indicators of the tight market include the overall decline in employment advertising in newspapers in the Northeast; it dropped by one-third since last year, said the Conference Board, an organization in Manhattan that tracks economic trends.
Steven Spinner, an ecomomics major at Wesleyan University in Middletown, is one of the students and recent graduates who have learned about the economic downturn firsthand. "Even a year ago, the strongest candidates at Wesleyan got first-round interviews at all the top investment banks," he said. "Now, students are getting rejection letters left and right from firms that in years past were not that difficult to get job offers from."
In a three-bedroom suite on the Yale University campus, Matthew Neely, a history major, and two of his roommates, both ecomomics majors, have plastered the four walls of their living room with a combined total of 60 rejection letters. "We call it the Wall of Shame," said Mr. Neely.
The 22-year-old senior, who helped to create and coordinate a number of mentor programs involving Yale students and a New Haven elementary school, said that after graduation he will return to his home in Oakland, Calif., where the job market is more promising.
"If you're already from out of state, now's the time to get out of New England," said Mr. Neely.
Accountants, engineers and health care professionals remain in demand, said employment experts around the state, but opportunities in banking, insurance, teaching and finance have been dwindling. Campus counselors said they were scrambling to help seniors adjust to the shift in employment options by redesigning seminars on resume writing and interview skills.
Job counselors at Fairfield University recently offered a workshop called "How to Get a Job in a Recessionary Market," which urged participants to seek out industries that have not been hard hit. Career planning at Wesleyan includes an off-campus recruitment program in which students will visit businesses and nonprofit organizations during their spring break.
Students' frustration is clearly rising, counselors said. "We've had more incidents of students swearing at staff and throwing resumes in their faces," said Douglas Daring, UConn's director of career counseling. "There's a lot of heightened intensity."
Mr. Spinner of Wesleyan said he sent resumes last fall to several Wall Street investment banks. So far, he said, he has received rejection letters from two of them and has had interviews with two others. Mr. Spinner, who also serves as the captain of the university's cross-country track team, said he prepared himself by undergoing several videotaped mock interviews and a workshop in corporate table etiquette. He also keeps himself informed on current events, he said, in case such subjects should arise in an interview.
"These days, job searching is like taking another subject," said Mr. Spinner. "You kill yourself getting together cover letters and resumes and preparing for the interviews. Then the waiting begins."
Kara Marchetti, a marketing major at Fairfield University, said she opted to work part time at the university's career counseling center this year to keep up with job offerings and hone her interview skills. She attends job seminars regularly, she said, and takes advantage of a reciprocal job-search program with Boston College to find out what firms are hiring in Massachusetts.
"So far, the response has been positive," said Ms. Marchetti, who was recently interviewed for a job as an insurance underwriter and for a training program in marketing and sales for an international liquor distributor.
 
Struggling for Interviews
 Other students, like Christine Pina of Wesleyan, are also broadening their job searches, determined to cover all bases. An African-American studies major who has served as a residential adviser and spent two summers as a congressional intern in Washington, she recalled spending hours this fall on her resume, accenting her most marketable skills.
Now pursuing opportunities in education and business, she said, she has lined up interviews with an investment banking firm in Manhattan and has also been offered a teaching job at a private boarding school. But overall, said Ms. Pina, "many students are really struggling to get that first interview."
Those who work at career centers, like Ms. Marchetti of Fairfield, have observed that students are hustling to secure job offers before they graduate by sending out resumes earlier and in greater volume. "A lot of students feel that now isn't the time to be picky," she said.
Recruiters and personnel managers around the state say they are noticing the growing sense of desperation. K.M.S. Advertising in Stamford reported a 20 percent jump in resumes from a year ago. And incoming resumes have increased at Chubb & Son, the insurance company, in New Haven, which now limits campus recruiting "only to schools where we've been successful," said Michael Dayton, a recruiter.
Nonprofit organizations are also sensing the panic. When the Legal Aid Society in Hartford advertised recently for someone to screen incoming phone calls, it received 350 applications in one week, said Lucy Potter, a staff lawyer. The applicants, she said, included college seniors, lawyers and other professionals.
Some students said they hoped to ride out the recession by attending graduate school. Nancy Dart, associate dean of UConn's law school, said the admissions office sent out 13,000 catalogues last year, up 3,000 from 1989. Law applications have also increased at the University of Bridgeport, said a university spokeswoman.
 
Hoping for Any Job
 A growing number of students are considering alternatives like the Peace Corps and Teach for America, which recruits students to teach in disadvantaged schools. Many are adopting attitudes similar to that of Ms. Pina of Wesleyan. "It's important to me to find a job that's meaningful and that doesn't necessarily mean making a lot of money," she said.
Others said they simply hope to find a job, period.
As for Mr. Hopley, the University of Connecticut graduate, the quest continues. Like clockwork, he said, he drives every Monday from his home in Windsor Locks to a newspaper stand in Boston that carries The Los Angeles Times, The Atlanta Constitution and other far-flung papers. If he spots any possibilities, he sends out his resume the same day, he said. In addition, he pores over local newspapers and employment newsletters, and he asks friends, neighbors and relatives if they know of any leads.
Unless he finds something soon, said Mr. Hopley, he will move to California and find a job that pays minimum wage while he searches for opportunities in advertising or public relations. Though his spirits remained high, he said, he was still in shock over his lack of job options.
"I never thought I'd be saying this," said Mr. Hopley, "but it's a real jungle out here."

HEADLINE: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Vail, Colo.;
The High End Is Flying High

BYLINE: BY CONNIE BRACKEN KNIGHT

 BODY:
THOUGH the recession may have eroded property prices and sales elsewhere, it has had no effect on expensive houses in this ski resort.
In the six weeks ended Jan. 25, for example, the Multiple Listing Service reported five new homes -- three of them built on speculation -- sold for a total of $8.425 million. 
 Now a group of investors headed by Phillip E. Hoversten, former chief financial officer of the Macmillan Publishing Company in New York, is building a speculative 6,000-square-foot house on a half-acre lot that the group bought last June for a record $2.75 million.
The house, which its architect, Craig Snowdon of Snowdon & Hopkins of Vail, described as a rugged Western mountain ski lodge, is priced at $6.5 million, making it Vail's most expensive private home.
Land is expensive here because it is scarce; the village is only about four square miles in area and is surrounded by National Forest Service land.
In May, another home built on speculation by Mr. Hoversten's group sold for $4.35 million.
"We are selling to three-generation families," said Craig Denton, a partner with Mr. Hoversten along with a realtor, Rocky Cristopher, and a contractor, George Shaeffer, who is doing the construction.
Many of the buyer families, he added, already have two or three homes, including vacation homes in the Hamptons on Long Island, and most pay cash.
Developers here also shy away from financing.
Among them is Ron Byrne, a realtor-developer who has sold more than 30 luxury homes since 1985, including about a dozen he developed with wealthy limited partners who put up the money.
"We're fortunate we don't have bank loans and are not under pressure to sell," Mr. Byrne said. "We literally go in for the long haul. It's at least a year to 18 months from the time we break ground until we sell."
The pace of sales has remained unchanged: On average, a luxury home is sold within six months of completion.
Mr. Byrne and his partners currently have three speculative homes on the market, two of them under contract.
The third, called Chateau de Foret, is listed for $5.7 million and has high valuted ceilings, an elevator, a heated flagstone driveway, temperature sensors and $500,000 worth of furnishings, including voluminous velvet draperies, Icelandic sheepskin carpets and Irish linen pillows. Unfurnished, the 7,000-square-foot, three-story house on about half an acre is priced at $5 million. It was designed by Gordon Pierce of Vail.
