LENGTH: 1814 words

HEADLINE: As Unemployment Rises, Jobs on L.I. Decline

BYLINE: By LINDA SASLOW

 BODY:
SINCE the 1987 stock-market crash, which signaled a halt to the economic boom on Long Island, the job market has sustained a double-barreled assault.
The number of available jobs on the Island has declined, and the unemployment rate has climbed. 
 The Island saw a net loss of 28,700 jobs in the year beginning December 1989, the first time since 1975 that the Island lost jobs. That contrasts with 1989, when there was an increase of 5,900 jobs. In 1988 the Island gained 13,900 jobs. The peak year was 1984, with an increase of 51,900.
 
'Makes the Figures Look Good'

The unemployment rate for the Island in December, the most recent month with available data from the State Labor Department, was 4.3 percent, compared with 3.8 percent in December 1989, 3.5 percent in December 1988 and 2.7 percent in 1987.
Despite the number of jobs lost, the unemployment rate is lower than in many other regions and on paper is not very high, said Suffolk County Planning Director Arthur Kunz. He added that the numbers did not include the many early retirees or people leaving the Island.
"These two segments of the population don't show up as being laid off," Mr. Kunz said. "And this makes the figures look good. But 1990 was our first year with a net loss of people working."
The numbers may indicate a turning point in the across-the-board decline in the Long Island economy. The dropoff can be seen in lagging home sales, declining sales-tax revenues and increasing foreclosures and bankruptcies. Because more people are retiring as the population ages and others have also stopped looking for work, they are no longer counted as unemployed.
The numbers are solely for jobs on Long Island and do not include residents who work in New York City or elsewhere off the Island. People holding two jobs were counted twice.
The chief economist of the Long Island Regional Planning Board, Dr. Pearl Kamer, said the largest losses were in manufacturing, with 12,700 jobs lost, of which 10,200 were in durable goods, mostly for the military, and 2,500 in nondurable goods like soft materials. The other job losses were in retailing, 12,400; construction, 6,600; government, 2,700, wholesaling, 2,100, and finance, insurance and real estate, 700.
Service jobs increased 6,800, and transportation and utilities were up 1,700.
The president of the Long Island Association, James L. Larocca, said it was useful to keep in mind that the Island's numbers were still below United States figures.
"When western New York hit bottom several years ago, they looked at unemployment figures in double-digit numbers," he said. "We are dealing with numbers that in many parts of the country are seen as at or near full employment. As concerning as these numbers are, they are, relatively speaking, still healthy numbers."
Data from the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics show a loss of 21,000 jobs on the Island from January 1990 to last January, with the number of employed people on the Island dropping, from 1,110,000 to 1,089,000.
The discrepancy between the figures is attributed to different information data and different periods.
The unemployment rate has remained slightly higher in Suffolk than in Nassau. For last December, the Nassau unemployment rate of 3.6 percent compared with 5 percent in Suffolk. But the rates in both counties were lower than the state's, at 5.4, and the nation's, at 5.9.
The highest recorded December unemployment rate for the Island was in 1976, at 10.4. For Nassau, the worst year was 1975, with a rate of 10.1 percent. Suffolk hit a high of 10.9 in 1976.
 At any rate, for those out of work, the situation appears grim. Despite the hopes of jobless Long Islanders, the end of the Persian Gulf war is unlikely to have an immediate effect on employment, Mr. Kunz said. "We can more realistically hope for a resurgence in consumer confidence that will trigger more spending and boost the economy," he said.
 
Strong Response to Ad

Without the expectation of major military spending, it is likely that Grumman, the Island's largest private employer, will continue to lay off workers unless it obtains new contracts, Mr. Kunz said.
For a company looking for an employee, the choices can be vast. Last month a store-display manufacturer in Hicksville, Econoco, advertised in a newspaper for a switchboard operator. A vice president, Mark Zelniker, said he received 206 responses.
He added that a year ago, when the 100-employee company placed a similar ad, there were fewer than 12 responses, out of which six people appeared for interviews.
People who are out of work are embarrassed, and many are terrified, said Bill Smolinsky, manager of the Hicksville office of the unemployment insurance division of the State Labor Department. Some unemployed people have not even told their spouses that they are out of work, he said.
Being unemployed is depressing and demoralizing, said an electrician who has been out of work since the end of January. Since being laid off with 1,000 workers in his union, the 43-year-old Jericho resident, who insisted on anonymity, has made more than 75 telephone calls and applied for driving jobs at 5 taxicab companies, 10 limousine companies and several bus companies. and he has looked for work at several gasoline stations, movie theaters and cable television operations.
"I can't work as an electrician, because as part of the union, I don't have a license, and that would be 'scabbing,' " he said. "If any employer finds out I'm a member of the union, he wouldn't hire me.
"And there's no job out that will pay the $1,000 a week that I was making. Unemployment insurance pays me $260 a week, and only lasts for six months. "Nobody is looking for help. Some places have taken my name and said they'd get back to me, but I haven't heard from any of them. Every day I look through the papers, but there's nothing out there. During the days I do errands and work on house projects, but the days drag and I hate this."
A single mother of two children from Bellmore who was a showroom manager and was laid off in December when the management changed hands, said her $150 a week from unemployment insurance was not nearly enough to pay her bills.
"I have a teaching degree and have been trying to find jobs as a substitute or teaching assistant, but there are no jobs," she said. "And with the state cutbacks, school districts are talking about more cuts next year.
 "I look in the papers every day and have answered ads for showroom managers and receptionists, but there are no openings. Nobody's hiring. It's an impossible time to get a job, and there's no light at the end of the tunnel."
The immediate prognosis is not encouraging, said Gary Huth, senior economist for the Labor Department and Long Island labor-market analyst.
"We've been in a downturn on Long Island since the end of '89," he said. "And I expect that there will be more job losses through the middle of 1991, with a possible upturn by the end of 1991. Even when the economy improves, the return to stronger job growth will be at a slow rate."
 
Where Is the Bottom?

Through most of the year the Island can expect a flat to declining economy, with continued layoffs in military industries, Dr. Kamer said, and commercial and industrial construction will be flat, as extra space waits to be absorbed.
But, Dr. Kamer added, there will quite likely be a rebound in home sales and construction, which would mean a pickup in the real-estate market and ultimately, more construction jobs.
The problem is determining the bottom, Mr. Larocca said.
"There are indications that the commercial-space market in Nassau County may be bottoming now," he said. "Then there will be readjustments, followed by some resuming of activity."
Residential real estate may also be changing, he said, adding, "If the indications are real, we may begin to see evidence that the readjustment period is beginning."
 
Real Retail Decline of 9.5%

Mr. Larocca said the hardest-hit industries were financial services, banking, brokerage, military and retail.
In retail sales, the first 11 months of last year showed a decline of $22.3 billion, a 3.3 percent decline in dollar terms, Dr. Kamer said. "But if you add in inflation," she added, "the decline in sales was actually 9.5 percent, compared to the first 11 months of 1989."
Retail is consequential and a compounding problem, Mr. Larocca said.
"It is a manifestation of other matters and affected by consumer confidence," the head of the business group said. "Retail remains hit hard, but everybody is looking for hopeful signs. A break in the weather and an end to the war might help overall the psychology of the economy."
 
3 WHO WANT TO WORK AGAIN
 ANTONIO MARRA of Bethpage has been out of work since November. Along with five other workers, he was laid off from the small construction company for which he worked because there was no business in the winter months.
He has been looking for any kind of work to pay the bills, he said, but added, "There are no jobs available, and the few that there are want to pay nothing."
 Mr. Marra enjoys spending time with his 2-year-old son, Antonio Jr., he said, but he desperately needs a job.
"The unemployment check doesn't cover my bills," Mr. Marra said. "I'm just hoping to get back to work by the spring."
 
'Rewarded for Lying'

In the Hicksville Unemployment Insurance Office there is usually a steady stream of people filling out applications, waiting to be reviewed and picking up checks. On a recent morning, most were reluctant to talk about being unemployed.
"It's a Catch-22," said a man who would not give his name. "You can't admit to working off the books, or they'll cut off your unemployment insurance. If you tell them you're trying to work part-time, they cut down on your compensation. So the bottom line is you are rewarded for lying."
It has been almost two years since Pamela Robertson of Levittown, a former bus driver for the Metropolitan Suburban Bus Authority, has worked. Ms. Robertson drove a Nassau County bus for five years, she said, and was earning $15 an hour. "Now they're making $17," she added.
"I'm waiting for Job Service to find a driving job," she said. "I have my own car, a Class II license, and I'd be willing to work anywhere on the Island. I checked the classified every day and have made phone calls and gone on interviews, but no luck. Nobody's hiring. I looked in waitressing, but they want experienced only.
"I was on welfare for a while and I'm not eligible for unemployment insurance. Now they're threatening to turn off my electric. Last time I was here they asked me if I'm willing to relocate, but I was born and raised on Long Island, and I've been here for 36 years. I'm not going to move."

Some unemployed people do not tell their spouses that they are out of work because they are so embarrassed, according to one unemployment office manager. The Island saw a net loss of 28,700 jobs in the year beginning December 1989, the first time since 1975 that the Island lost jobs. (Barton Silverman for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Vancouver, B.C.;
Utility Builds In the Suburbs

BYLINE: BY HARRIET KING

 BODY:
THE B.C. Hydro and Power Authority, one of this city's largest employers, is planning to build a corporate complex in suburban Burnaby that will be linked by the SkyTrain light rail system to an office tower the public utility corporation is building downtown.
The suburban development is expected to cost about $57 million in United States dollars and the downtown tower about $35 million. 
 David Shipman, property manager for the utility, which now has 3,000 employees downtown, said the suburban project is the most notable outgrowth of the Greater Vancouver Livable Region Plan, developed by officials here and in surrounding communities. The regional plan urges companies to locate offices away from downtown and take advantage of SkyTrain for commuting.
The 14-mile-long SkyTrain runs east from Vancouver through what seems like one continuous residential area, running through Burnaby and then New Westminster before ending in Surrey near the United States border.
The power authority is planning a 1.7-million-square-foot development in Burnaby at the Edmonds Station, 20 minutes from downtown. This was the only SkyTrain station site where B.C. Hydro could assemble 20 acres. The company paid about $26 million for the land. It will build 850,000 square feet of space on part of the site, and sell the remaining land to developers who are expected to erect three more office towers.
In the first phase of its project, which will begin this summer, B.C. Hydro will spend $65 million to build a 250,000-square-foot high-rise, three low-rise buildings with 80,000 square feet each and a 50,000-square-foot warehouse. It will relocate 2,300 of its employees there. Another 250,000-square-foot high-rise and another low-rise complex are being planned.
For operations that must remain downtown, the company is putting up an 18-story, $40 million office building with 292,000 square feet plus four levels of underground parking, near the SkyTrain line. About 700 employees will work there.
The company sold its 33-year-old downtown high-rise, which it had outgrown, for about $49 million.
A bedroom community at the eastern city limits of Vancouver, Burnaby has in the last 15 years experienced rapid commercial growth. Phillip Sanderson, the city's economic development coordinator, said he welcomed the B.C. Hydro project, noting that its objective "is to decentralize Vancouver so that people live and work in their own community."

HEADLINE: Caribbean Tourism

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: BRIDGETOWN, Barbados, March 10

 BODY:
Caribbean tourism grew by only 3 percent in 1990 because of the recession and the Middle East crisis, the Caribbean Tourism Organization says. In 1989, tourism in the region's 32 countries grew by 5.5 percent, to 10.8 million visitors. The organization said on Friday that the slow growth was a result of difficult economic conditions in the United States, Canada and Britain and a drop in travel since Iraq invaded Kuwait.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Traders Left Confused By Latest Jobless Data

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
The credit market this week is expected to focus on the meaning of the Government's employment data and the Federal Reserve's move on interest rates, after an uncommonly volatile session on Friday that erased all of the week's price gains.
What caused long-term Treasury securities to fluctuate wildly was the market's different interpretations of the Government's employment data for February and the subsequent intervention in the credit market by the Federal Reserve. 
 The credit market will try to decide whether the intervention by the Fed on Friday was technical, or whether it was indeed aimed at cutting interest rates to stimulate the economy. The market will also try to determine what the rise in joblessness shows about the economy.
 
Unemployment Climbs to 6.5%
 Before the New York markets opened on Friday, the Government reported that the unemployment rate had climbed to a four-year high of 6.5 percent in February, from 6.2 percent the month before. While the figure was well above most economic projections, a sizable number of market participants believed the figure was actually a conservative reading of the situation.
When the Fed moved several hours later to lower the Federal funds rate, which is what banks charge each other for temporary loans, it led many to believe the central bank had moved to ease credit. Normally, this would have bolstered prices of fixed-income debt issues because it would mean lower yields on future bonds offered to investors.
But the Treasury bond market reacted negatively to the Fed's move. The Treasury's benchmark 30-year bonds, which had opened with a yield of 8.19 percent, saw prices erode all day and finally end with the yield at 8.30 percent.
 
Widely Perceived Target
 Why did so many question the purpose of the Fed's intervention? After all, the Fed's infusion of reserves into the banking system did cause this key lending rate to decline from 6.25 percent, to 5.875 percent at the close on Friday. And the 6.25 percent funds rate had been widely perceived as the Fed's target for this bedrock cost of credit.
"Of course the Fed eased interest rates," said Philip Braverman, senior vice president and chief economist at DKB Securities Corporation, the domestic arm of the giant Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank of Tokyo. "Any time the Fed adds reserves to the banking system it is bound to cause the funds rate to decline, especially on a Friday when demand for these funds shrinks."
What caused much of the confusion, Mr. Braverman continued, were the varying interpretations of the Government's February employment data.
"For example," he noted, "Washington said there was a decline of 184,000 non-farm jobs last month, or some 30,000 above most estimates. But the Government's February data include 552,000 part-time workers. Part-time worker cannot buy houses, cars or other goods that will bring us out of the recession. The fact remains that people simply do not have the means to spend, and no amount of glowing forecasts about the impending end of the recession or rising consumer confidence has changed that basic fact."
 
A More Optimistic Outlook
 But Irwin L. Kellner, chief economist at Manufacturers Hanover Bank, is far more optimistic. As he said in an interview last Friday:"Many of those who don't believe the Fed has eased believe so because it would probably mean that the Fed's funds target would be 6 percent, which is same as the Fed's discount rate to banks. This group would become believers if the Fed cut its discount rate first. Well, there are often times when the Fed has moved to cut the funds rate before it reduced its discount rate."
As for the employment figures, Mr. Kellner held that they were positive on balance and may indeed be signaling an end to the recession. "If we look at the household employment number for February, we find that only 4,000 jobs were lost," he said. "We must also remember that the gross employment figure used by the Government is based on payroll data. It does not include self-employed people, only those who work for others."
Mr. Kellner said another sign that the recession might be bottoming out was a sudden sharp rise in demand for raw materials, as measured by the Commodity Research Bureau index of futures prices. The index, which uses a 1967 price base of 100, soared to 221.95, from 217.98, in just the past week.
"The stock market is also telling us something," he added. "Despite continued poor corporate earnings, it has advanced 25 percent since last October's lows."
Another view was offered by Maria F. Ramirez, who heads a financial investment management and advisory group bearing her name.
 
'Monetary Policy Is On Hold'
 "We think the Fed's current monetary policy is on hold, despite any particular action it may take on a given day," she said on Friday. "Yes, we are among those who believed the Fed did move to ease credit this morning. But we also think this was the Fed's last such move. The Fed now has little further room to ease."
If, as she and many credit market experts believe, the Fed's new funds target is 6 percent, Mrs. Ramirez said "it won't necessarily follow that the Fed will cut its discount rate from the present 6 percent."
"Past experience tells us," she said, "that the Fed usually cuts its discount rate to bank borrowers after a half-point decline in the funds rate."
The Fed's discount rate has also become far less a significant psychological factor in the marketplace than the prime lending rate offered by banks to favored customers. The reason is that banks now have other sources of funds to tap here and in overseas markets and thus are no longer as dependent on the Fed as they may have been years ago.
Consequently, Mrs. Ramirez believes the market this week will be paying more attention to such basic economic factors as the employment statistics.

HEADLINE: OPEC Cuts: How Much and Whose?

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, March 10

 BODY:
When OPEC ministers gather on Monday in Geneva for their first meeting since the end of the Persian Gulf war, they are expected to try to rein in overproduction, seeking to prevent a collapse of crude oil prices.
Oil analysts say the ministers will probably reaffirm the organization's prewar target price of $21 a barrel. That is about $3.50 above current levels for crude oil from the gulf. But oil experts say the meeting could grow tense when the ministers debate how much production should be cut, and by whom, to re-establish the $21 price. 
 "There is a tremendous desire among all OPEC countries to prevent an oil-price collapse," said Mehdi Varzi, a London-based oil analyst with Kleinwort Benson Securities Ltd. "They all recognize they have to cut output collectively for the second quarter. But how they do it? That's where the problems arise."
 
Crippled Export Capacity
 Since the oil-production and export capacities of Kuwait and Iraq are crippled, many analysts say it should not be difficult for the 11 other OPEC members to carve up their production into a new system of quotas, but in the highly charged postwar atmosphere that may not be so easy.
With Saudi Arabia accounting for about 8.3 million of the nearly 23 million barrels a day that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries pumped last month, other OPEC members are expected to put pressure on the Saudis to absorb the bulk of any cuts. But the Saudis say they will fend off such pressure. After incurring some $50 billion in expenses in fighting Baghdad, as well as huge investments to increase output to offset the embargo of Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil, Saudi Arabia does not want to be the only country to cut production.
Oil analysts say the Saudis do not want prices to rise quickly, since a price jump could be seen as a slap in the face to the United States and other Western nations that joined Riyadh in fighting Iraq. What is more, the Saudis recognize that a jump in prices could undermine a recovery of the slumping American economy.
 
Agreement on Price
 "What they will quickly agree on is the price will go to $21," said John H. Lichtblau, chairman of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation, based in New York. "The question is whether the price will go up right away."
Some analysts suggest that Washington would not be disappointed if OPEC moved to re-establish a price of $21 a barrel, which is usually about $2 a barrel below the price of West Texas intermediate, the benchmark American grade of crude oil. In February, OPEC's average price was $17.55 a barrel.
"Twenty-one dollars is realistic for everyone, even the U.S.," said Pierre Terzian, editor of Petrostrategies, a Paris-based oil journal. He said that level would just reaffirm the July price target, to which Washington did not object. He added that because the dollar has plunged against the Japanese yen and most European currencies, oil, which is priced in dollars, is far cheaper for Japan and Western Europe than it was five years ago.
 
A Glut in the Offing
 Oil experts say that if OPEC continues to produce oil at the February rate of 23 million barrels a day, a glut could develop quickly. Prices would plunge as a result, because daily demand for OPEC oil is expected to be between 21 million and 21.5 million barrels in the second quarter.
Demand for oil historically falls by more than two million barrels a day from the first quarter to the second as spring weather comes to the Northern Hemisphere. Also weighing on the market is some 120 million barrels of oil stored in tankers at sea, far more than the 45 million barrels usually stored that way.
In Geneva on Sunday, the Oil Minister of Indonesa, Ginanjar Kartasasmita, said: "OPEC will take all the necessary steps to stabilize the market. If a cut is necessary, then we will do it."
Saudi Arabia's former oil minister, Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, said that if nothing was done to control the glut, oil prices could drop to $12 a barrel. He said Friday that there was a 50 percent chance that OPEC would agree on new production ceilings at the Geneva meeting.
Sheik Yamani said one possibility that could drive down prices was a resumption of Iraqi exports by June. Some experts said the country's northern oilfields were only partially damaged by allied bombing. But many analysts said it would take much longer for Iraqi oil to enter export markets, because of the continuing embargo against Iraq and the destruction of that country's electric power stations.
OPEC's Market Monitoring Committee, which is not empowered to decide on production quotas, meets on Monday to review the supply and demand situation. Oil analysts say there is a good chance the ministers will turn the committee's talks into a full-scale emergency meeting to decide on quota levels.
Last July, OPEC set a production ceiling of 22.5 million barrels a day, but those quotas were suspended in September, when the 4 million barrels a day produced by Iraq and Kuwait were embargoed after the invasion of Kuwait.
Many oil analysts predict that OPEC will agree to set a production ceiling of 21 million or 21.5 million barrels a day. "If they cut to 21 million barrels, it won't take long to establish the $21-a-barrel price," said Mr. Varzi of Kleinwort Benson. "If they cut to 21.5 million barrels, it will take longer."
In recent days, OPEC ministers have maneuvered to put pressure on Saudi Arabia, the world's largest exporter, to cut production. In a comment that many construed as a suggestion that Saudi Arabia had become a vassal of Washington, Algeria's Oil Minister, Sadek Boussena, who is also the president of OPEC, said the gulf countries had to "show their capability of pursuing an independent oil policy, despite the new balance of forces in the region."
Some of OPEC's price hawks fear that Saudi Arabia wants to keep its and OPEC's production high to please Washington, since this would help hold down prices. But Saudi officials deny they are doing Washington's bidding, noting that they have long opposed high prices.
Saudi production is some 3 million barrels a day higher than the 5.3 million barrels a day the country produced before Iraq invaded Kuwait.
The key to the meeting, many analysts say, is whether the Saudis can persuade other members to cut production as well.
Analysts expect the Saudis to balk at accepting a quota of less than seven million barrels a day. Indeed, OPEC officials say Kuwait is negotiating with Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates so they could produce part of Kuwait's 1.5 million-barrel-a-day quota. This would help pay for Kuwait's reconstruction. Kuwait would, in theory, repay this production when its oilfields are up and running.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
New Kuwait Oil Output
 KUWAIT CITY, March 10 (AP) -- Kuwait hopes to start producing 50,000 barrels of oil a day in the next two months to run its power stations, an executive with the Kuwait Oil Company said today.
Officials have estimated that between 80 and 85 percent of Kuwait's oil production capacity was damaged by fires set by fleeing Iraqi troops, but the executive, Ahmad Murad, said some wells were unscathed.
"We have identified about 30 to 40 wells which are not on fire, but they could have been affected," he said at a news conference. "There are a number of wells that are not even damaged. In fact, I saw 7 by my own eyesight."
Mr. Murad said tentative plans call for American firefighters to start tackling the blazes on Friday after equipment is brought from the United States. He said that once Kuwait starts producing crude for the power stations, the next goal will be to start producing another 50,000 barrels a day to refine into gasoline for the local market.

HEADLINE: Returning Part of Everglades To Nature for $700 Million

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOMESTEAD, Fla.

 BODY:
For a century, man has been swallowing the Everglades in a storm of concrete, smoke, and steel. Now state and Federal authorities are trying to make room for nature in South Florida.
Several steps are planned: returning a river north of Lake Okeechobee to its original meandering channel, filling in or redesigning miles of deep canals, building thousands of acres of experimental marshes to cleanse water of agricultural pollution, and adding 107,000 acres to the Everglades National Park's 1.4 million acres. 
 The project, likely to cost more than $700 million and take at least a decade, is intended to reverse years of destructive meddling and recover the natural flow of the waters that have nourished one of the world's largest marshes and its wildlife for thousands of years.
The Everglades once were a shallow river of pure water and unbroken marsh that began in Lake Okeechobee and spilled across the lower Florida peninsula in a sheet 40 to 60 miles wide. So lazy was the current that water leaving the lake in March would not reach Florida Bay, at the tip of the peninsula 100 miles away, until the following February.
 
Hints of What Was
 Alligators and crocodiles filled the Everglades' sloughs. Egrets, herons, spoonbills, wood storks, anhingas and bald eagles fed on schools of fish, and panthers prowled the high ground hummocks of mahogany and palm.
An inkling of the magnificence of this natural setting can still be seen at sunset in the Everglades National Park as crimson mist settles over the sawgrass prairie, osprey alight on the top branches of mangroves and the natural warfare of life diminishes to an eloquent quiet.
But on the horizon, Miami's lights grow closer every year. The wooden skeletons of hundreds of new homes are now separated from the second-largest national park in the lower 48 states by nothing more than a 50-foot-wide canal. From daybreak to sunset, trucks raise trails of dust as they roll north, loaded with half the winter vegetables sold in the United States.
Never before has government set out to restore a natural landscape this large. If the work is successful, the lessons may be invaluable for projects to reverse the destruction of other bodies of water, especially Long Island Sound, the Great Lakes, the Chesapeake Bay, the lower Mississippi River and San Francisco Bay.
 
Alarm in Washington
 "The nation's waters have been damaged by the poisonous byproducts of 20th-century society," William K. Reilly, Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, wrote in the January issue of The E.P.A. Journal. "Whatever their specific designation -- lake, estuary, or aquifer; sound, bight, or gulf; bay, wetland, or river -- our great water ecosystems are increasingly troubled."
The restoration of the Everglades National Park, which makes up more than half of the entire Everglades region, is a test of political skills every bit as daunting as the engineering.
Scientists, public officials and leaders in the National Park Service have known for years that the Everglades are dying. The sense that something had to be done led to a 1988 lawsuit, filed by the United States Justice Department, seeking to compel the state to enforce its environmental laws and prohibit contamination of the water that flows into the Everglades National Park and a national wildlife refuge near West Palm Beach.
Complicating the restoration are two factors, one purely natural, the other economic and political. A four-year drought made the competition for water among farms, cities and the park itself much more fierce. And wealthy sugar and vegetable farmers south of Lake Okeechobee have continued to jealously guard the Federal rules that exempt them from having to decontaminate runoff from their land.
While helping farmers avoid costly systems to treat their waste water, these exemptions under the Federal Clean Water Act are responsible for the largest source of pollution left uncontrolled in the United States.
 
Governor Gets Involved
 The newly elected Governor, Lawton Chiles, inserted himself into the struggle in January. Last month, Mr. Chiles and the Federal Government agreed that the suit filed in 1988 would be stayed for two months, creating time to try to work out a settlement that could be used to solve other issues related to the ecology of the Everglades. The negotiations, now under way, are the first effort by all parties to resolve obstacles to restore the Everglades.
"Floridians have spent most of the 20th century trying to destroy the Everglades, and much of it trying to save the Everglades, often at the same time," Mr. Chiles, a Democrat, said in January. "I hope to see the day, before the end of the 20th century, when we have restored as much of the Everglades as we can, when we have finally learned to live in peace with the Everglades, when we can simply allow it to be."
The Governor's remarks echo the words that appear in "The Everglades: River of Grass," the seminal 1947 book by Marjory Stoneman Douglas, which sounded an early and loud warning that the Everglades were imperiled. "There are no other Everglades in the world," wrote Mrs. Douglas, who is now 100 years old. "They are, they have always been, one of the unique regions of the earth, remote, never wholly known."
Today's farms and cities would not have been possible without the lacework of drainage canals, more than 1,400 miles of them, that were cut through the black muck and porous limestone of the Everglades starting at the turn of the century. But interruption of the natural water flow has severely damaged the park's ecology.
"This is regarded as the most threatened park in the National Park System," said Robert S. Chandler, the Everglades park superintendent. "It is at a stage of biological collapse."
 
Tinkering With Nature
 After World War II the Federal Government began to control the flow of water, but the Everglades have sometimes suffered from that control. Too much water in early spring, for instance, ruins nesting sites for alligators. Not enough water in the dry season destroys feeding grounds for fish on which most of the birds depend.
Moreover, waste water from farms has raised the levels of phosphorous in the water to more than double the natural levels, resulting in extensive stands of cattails that crowd out the sawgrass and upset the region's biology.
Since the park was established in 1947, the number of wading birds has dropped 90 percent, scientists say. Fourteen species of animals in the park are considered endangered, among them the Florida panther. Last year, a panther was killed by mercury poisoning. Rangers trapped raccoons that also had unusually high concentrations of mercury in their blood. The source of the mercury has not been identified.
Plants not native to the Everglades, including the Brazilian pepper, a tough fast-growing tree popular among South Florida landscapers, and melaleuca, a tenacious Australian tree that developers use to drain wet areas, have established themselves.
 
Dismantling the Plumbing
 Reversing the decline of the Everglades means returning to nature a system too tightly controlled by man. The first step involves uncoupling parts of a gigantic plumbing system so the shallow sheet of pure water that used to flow naturally into the park is restored.
Among the more expensive jobs will be reclaiming the Kissimmee River, which feeds Lake Okeechobee, the headwaters of the Everglades. In response to flooding, Congress paid the Army Corps of Engineers to convert the 98-mile-long river into a 300-foot-wide, 30-foot-deep channel.
During construction from 1961 to 1971, thousands of acres of wetlands vanished, replaced by cattle farms. The transformation increased the flow of damaging nutrients, particularly phosphorous, into Lake Okeechobee, threatening its very survival.
 
Beginning Steps Taken
 Moving to address the Federal Government's failure to control agricultural pollution, the State Legislature two years ago required 49 large dairies north of the lake to capture manure and waste water and use the waste water to irrigate their pastures.
At the same time, the Corps of Engineers and the South Florida Water Management District, the state agency that oversees the system of canals and supplies water to five million people, have proposed a project costing more than $300 million to restore the Kissimmee River to its natural channel.
Another step is to cleanse the water flowing out of Lake Okeechobee and the farming area south of it of nutrients that damage the Everglades. The water management district has proposed converting 25,300 acres of sugar fields south and east of Belle Glade into marshes planted with cattails and other plants to soak up phosphorous. The $150 million project is designed to cut in half the phosphorous in the water flowing to the Loxahatchee National Wildlife Refuge and the Everglades National Park. Farmers have already agreed to spend $40 million on the filtration marshes but may be asked or directed by the state to contribute more.
Environmental groups say the land devoted to the cleansing marshes should be doubled or tripled. "It appears to us that the present scope of the project is insufficient," said James D. Webb, Florida regional director of the Wilderness Society.
Computer models by the water district's experts say 25,000 acres is enough. "We propose taking the steps that can be supported scientifically and economically," said Thomas K. MacVicar, an engineer and the deputy executive director of the water management district.
Finally, the Corps of Engineers has been authorized by Congress to design a system of breeches and gates in a canal that cuts through a large marsh just north of the Everglades National Park, and to elevate parts of U.S. Highway 41, the roadway from Miami to the Gulf Coast. This $74 million project, a year away from start of construction, will take water out of the canal, spread it across the wetland, direct it under the highway and into 107,000 acres of wetlands that are being added to the national park.
The $40 million purchase of 107,000 acres of wetlands that are now privately owned will provide room for the water to sweep across 30 miles of a shallow basin known as Shark River Slough. Scientists hope that the repair will keep the Everglades wet during the winter dry season and more evenly spread water during the wet season.
As Mrs. Douglas wrote in 1947, "Perhaps even in this last hour, in a new relation of usefulness and beauty, the vast, magnificent, subtle and unique region of the Everglades may not be utterly lost."

HEADLINE: U.S. Seeks Broad Ban on Computers

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
American and Japanese officials will meet in Tokyo on Friday to try to renegotiate a seven-year-old secret accord under which the United States and Japan agreed to limit the sale of supercomputers, United States Government officials said this weekend.
Until now the two countries have effectively blocked the spread of supercomputers to Eastern Europe and the third world. But American officials say they are concerned because four, possibly five, Western European countries are on the brink of producing supercomputers. 
 Unless the United States-Japan agreement is expanded to include Britain, Germany, France and possibly the Netherlands and Italy, American officials believe, machines capable of supercomputer performance could soon be available to countries that have not signed the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty.
"We don't want supercomputer exports to go unencumbered from those countries," said an Administration official who spoke on the condition that he not be identified. "Secondly we want to make certain that a level playing field is maintained between United States and Japanese manufacturers."
The United States hopes that Japan will join it in inviting the Western European nations to sign a new agreement that would curtail the export of high technology.
All those Western European nations, as well as Japan and the United States, are members of the Coordinating Committee on Multilateral Export Controls, known as Cocom, whose members agree to restrict certain exports to Eastern Europe. But current Cocom agreements do not control exports to many countries capable of developing nuclear and other advanced weapons.
 
Nonmilitary Uses Permitted
 Supercomputers are vital tools in the design of nuclear weapons and advanced missiles. The United States has permitted the sale of the systems to some countries, including India and Brazil, but only with stringent safeguards limiting their use to such nonmilitary applications as weather forecasting, scientific research and engineering.
American computer makers have become increasingly concerned that unilateral export controls would put them at a disadvantage against foreign competitors. When the accord was first signed in 1984, only two American companies, Cray Research and the Control Data Corporation, both headquartered in Minneapolis, along with Fujitsu Ltd. of Japan, made computers that reached supercomputing speeds.
But in recent years, a new class of computers, known as parallel computers, have made it possible to reach supercomputer performance ratings without the specialized components used by companies like Cray. Parallel computers chain together conventional microprocessors and then employ software that breaks up problems into portions that can be computed simultaneously to obtain greater speed.
 
Disagreement Over Definition
 American computer industry executives said one potential significant disagreement in the Japanese-American negotiations may be over what level of speed is needed for a computer to be defined as a supercomputer. Japanese manufacturers are said to be in favor of a much higher level for what defines a supercomputer.
A proposal circulated by the Hitachi Corporation argues that the definition of a "true" supercomputer should be set as high as two billion calculations a second. This would restrict the definition of what is a supercomputer to the manufacturers of the five or six fastest computers in the world.
The proposal also specifies a second, lower limit to exclude work stations and general-purpose mainframe computers at 800 million calculations a second. Both definitions are far higher than limits specified last year by the United States Government in a draft definition of a supercomputer that was established as part of an effort to relax regulations on the export of high performance computers. The draft standard had a lower limit of 100 million instructions and an upper limit of 300 million instructions a second.
That draft document has now been finalized but has not yet been made public, several Government officials said. It includes a modest rise in performance from the originally published figures, they said.
Several industry officials said the Japanese would probably accept United States wishes for setting a lower level. But one executive said there was some concern that the Hitachi proposal would be adopted by Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry.
The need to broaden the original United States-Japan agreement has been prompted largely by the widespread availability of inexpensive very-high-speed microprocessors which do not fall under strict export controls. In Britain, for example, the Inmos Corporation is working on a version of a popular microprocessor known as the Transputer. That chip has become the basis of a number of supercomputer projects in both England and France. Additionally, Germany has a number of state and privately financed supercomputer efforts.
 
Computer Scientists Skeptical
 Many computer scientists are skeptical about the United States' ability to control the spread of supercomputers.
"The Government has a real problem," said C. Gordon Bell, a computer designer for a number of computer companies and a former National Science Foundation official. "The knowledge of how to build these things is better and better understood all the time. Anyone can build these things."
The Technion, an Israeli university that was denied an export licence to buy a United States supercomputer, said last year it was considering either buying a supercomputer from a German manufacturer or designing its own parallel computer. The United States has so far refused to sell supercomputers to Israel because of concerns that they could be used in developing nuclear weapons.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
What Is Driving Rallies in Europe?

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer

 BODY:
AS world stock markets rallied last week, many brokers in Europe were buying for their clients with one hand and scratching their heads with the other. They were wondering what fundamental economic factors were causing the surge, which began with the Persian Gulf war and picked up after the cease-fire was declared.
The rallies have carried the stock indexes in some European markets close to levels that analysts had predicted in December would not be reached until the end of this year. 
 In France, the CAC-40 index closed last week at 1,828.14, up 20.4 percent from the end of last year and not far from the UBS Phillips & Drew year-end projection of 2,000. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange Index in London finished at 2,455.0, just below its all-time high close of 2,463.70 and just below UBS's forecast of 2,500 for year-end. In Switzerland, the Swiss Performance Index ended at 1,056.4; the year-end estimate was for 1,150.
One reason for the rally seems quite clear: panic. There are institutions and investors with cash who initially missed the upturn in stocks and now want in. The right risk for a portfolio manager now seems to be equities -- and bonds -- as opposed to the cash so many managers and institutions favored before the Persian Gulf war began. This pyschology has limited all the market dips so far, as eager buyers have piled in fairly quickly.
Another reason is the situation in the United States: The Dow is near new highs and the Standard & Poor's 500 index reached a new high. The rest of the world has followed, drawn by the postwar glow and the growing belief that the recession in the United States is near its end.
In Europe and Japan, the rallies have also been pushed by the hope for lower interest rates there, although only the British have cut rates significantly so far. And in focusing only on what they choose to, the markets are ignoring weak corporate earnings, recessions and slowdowns in Europe and Japan, fixated instead on the American recovery.
At the middle of last week, with the Dow Jones industrial average flirting with closing above 3,000 for the first time, the world rally appeared ready to move even higher. Then came a pause on Thursday, as the Dow fell after failing to close above 3,000 on Wednesday. But on Friday, markets in Asia and Europe rallied again, with the Frankfurt and Tokyo markets reaching 1991 highs. In New York, however, the Dow failed to make another real run at 3,000 and was down 8.17 points on Friday, to 2,955.20.
Marcus Grubb, the European strategist for UBS in London, said the strong rallies have sharply altered the valuations of the markets, making some look a little too expensive when the yields on equities are compared with bonds or when the ratios of prices to earnings are compared with historic levels.
"Valuations are stretched now, and you should take some profits into cash," he said. "Unless we get the interest rate cuts that are expected, we could see a very major correction in the markets."
For Steven H. Nagourney, chief international strategist at Shearson Lehman Brothers in New York, the key to the future is the performance of Wall Street, the outlook for inflation and the performance of the bond markets.
He said Wall Street would pull Europe and Japan with it, but that that would change soon, especially when it becomes clearer how much the European economy is slowing down. He said that he did not expect a collapse in Europe, but that over all, Europe would underperform the United States.
While he is fairly confident about the American rally, he said bond yields in the United States would have to fall soon to keep it going above 3,000. Otherwise, stocks would begin to look too expensive compared with the yields from bonds.
But he said positive data on inflation that could push bond yields lower will not be available until April, when economic reports for March -- the first full month of activity after the war -- are released.
"Because of that long wait for bonds we could see some consolidation, but no more than 4 to 7 percent," he said. Mr. Grubb sees the same problem with bonds and stocks in Europe. His worry is that the cuts in short-term rates, when they come, will not filter through to longer-term bonds.
In Europe, Mr. Nagourney is most sour on Germany, where he thinks the current level of 1,602.29 on the DAX index of 30 leading issues requires either "a significant decline in interest rates or a significant increase in earnings." He added, "I do not see any one of them happening."
But he and Mr. Grubb still like the markets in France and Spain, partly because they expect interest rate cuts there to fight slowing economies, making equities more attractive than bonds.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR: ISRAEL;
4 Israelis Slain on Eve of Baker's Visit

BYLINE: By JOEL BRINKLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, March 10

 BODY:
An Arab assailant who told the police he was sending a message to Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d stabbed four Israeli women to death tonight and wounded at least one other woman in the center of West Jerusalem.
A policeman who was passing by shot and wounded the attacker, a 26-year-old Palestinian from the Jabaliya refugee center in the Gaza Strip. He was identified as Mohammed Abu Galla, a nurse who has been working in Jerusalem with a permit issued by the Israeli military. 
 The victims, all from Jerusalem, were identified as Rosa Eliafsur, 32 years old, Mercedes Banitah, 57, and Miriam Biton, 20. All were Jewish, the Israel radio reported. The fourth victim, who died later in the evening, has not been identified. The police said she was in her 50's.
After Mr. Galla was interrogated at a hospital, Jerusalem's police commander, Haim Albaldes, said, "The assault is related to Baker's visit tomorrow."
 
Baker Arrives on Monday
 The Secretary of State is to arrive here on Monday on a visit intended to calm fears and stir confidence among Israelis that they might eventually settle their conflict with the Arab nations and Palestinians in the Israeli-occupied territories. But the slayings are certain to complicate that task.
As Israeli analysts noted tonight, the killings may remind the United States, fresh from a convincing military victory, that diplomatic gains in the Middle East are seldom as easily won as the Persian Gulf war.
At the scene of the attack, a bus stop in a Jerusalem neighborhood heavily populated by Soviet Jewish immigrants, Israelis chanted this afternoon, "Death to Arabs, revenge!" and "Baker go home!" One man cursed Mr. Baker, adding, "You are responsible for the murder of Jews!"
The attack also inflamed passions among Israel's leaders, who had declared earlier today that Israel was willing to show little if any flexibility to make peace with its Arab neighbors.
 
Bush Faulted for Speech
 The Deputy Science Minister, Geula Cohen, a leader of the far-right Tehiya Party, said she had no doubt that the stabbings "were encouraged by the latest declarations from Bush."
In a speech to Congress on Wednesday, President Bush said that any American initiative in the Arab-Israeli conflict would be grounded in "the principle of territory for peace." Israel's leaders said in effect today that they would rather have the land than the peace.
Early this morning, someone set fire to the door of the American Cultural Center at the United States Consulate in Jerusalem. The arsonist painted a message in English: "America, do not interfere in our business."
Moshe Friedman, Jerusalem's deputy police commander, predicted that "extremist elements will try to whip up tempers, and there could be disturbances as a result of the visit."
Later in the morning, Dov Shilansky, the Speaker of Parliament, flew to the Golan Heights to mark the beginning of direct airline flights to and from Tel Aviv. Israel captured the strategic plateau from Syria in the 1967 war. The land was later annexed, and thousands of Jews have settled there.
 
Deliberate Signal to Baker
 Visiting one of these settlements, Mr. Shilansky said he would not be unhappy if people assumed that he timed his trip to send a message to Mr. Baker. If the Secretary of State asks, Mr. Shilansky said, the Israeli Government will tell him that Israel considers the Golan Heights to be an integral part of Israel, the same way that "Illinois is a part of the U.S.A."
Syria, which is Israel's most heavily armed adversary now that Iraq has been defeated in the gulf war, has signaled that it might be willing to open talks with Israel if the Golan Heights were returned.
But after a long and sometimes rancorous Cabinet discussion today, Economics Minister David Magen said, "The Golan Heights is not on the discussion table." Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said he agreed.
The Cabinet also decided that the Government's peace initiative of May 1989, offering elections and limited autonomy for residents of the West Bank and the Gaza Strip, was still in effect. The debate was fierce at times, with several right-wing ministers expressing anger that Israel would advance the 1989 proposal again. A year ago, Mr. Shamir scuttled the proposal just as an initiative by Mr. Baker seemed to move the plan forward.
 
Israelis Talk of Balking
 Today, Israeli officials said they had received reports that Mr. Baker would come with a promise from several Arab nations to recognize Israel if the country agreed to abide by United Nations resolutions calling on Israel to withdraw from occupied territory. In addition to recognition, one of the benefits for Israel would be secure borders.
But to that idea, the Government is evidently prepared to say no.
After the Cabinet meeting, Transport Minister Moshe Katsav, speaking for the Government, said he hoped Mr. Baker did not expect Israel to "pay a price for its restraint in the Gulf war."
Mr. Shamir said flatly that if Mr. Baker asked the Government "to do things that will be too difficult to carry out," Israel would simply refuse.
As the Iraqi military continued to fire Scud missiles toward Israel during the gulf war, officials said Israel was earning political capital by deciding not to respond. Now the Government seems prepared to spend that capital. Mr. Katsav said: "The formula 'territories for peace' will lead to a Palestinian state, and that is why I and my fellow ministers oppose it."
 
Emotional Funerals Expected
 As Mr. Baker seeks concessions from the Israelis in the meetings that begin on Monday, television news coverage will also be focusing on the funerals for the stabbing victims. Such funerals are usually highly emotional events.
Teddy Kollek, the Mayor of Jerusalem, who is known for showing restraint when others' emotions are running high, said: "I am among those who always tried to walk the moderate path. Now our patience is running out."

HEADLINE: New York Lacks Money To Buy Land

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TUPPER LAKE, N.Y.

 BODY:
Early last fall, a decade of negotiations produced a deal that was literally and figuratively trailblazing for 22,000 acres along the Raquette River northwest of this Adirondack village.
The arrangement between New York State and the International Paper Company would finally open for public use one of the state's most magnificent stretches of evergreen forest and whitewater river. And because the deal let the company grow and harvest timber on remote parts of the land, it was expected to serve as an important model for other negotiations with timber companies. 
 But for now, that deal is off. So are dozens of other plans that would have protected open space in virtually every region of the state, from the Pine Barrens on Long Island to the Catskill watershed to the Lake Erie waterfront.
New York State, which just a few months ago was sketching one of the most ambitious land-preservation programs in the country, now has none.
 
Environmental Bond Act Defeated
 The reason for the reversal is simple: the state has run out of money to buy land. After the narrow defeat of an environmental bond act in the election last fall, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo vowed to oppose any new spending on land programs this year. With the state in fiscal turmoil, the Legislature does not seem inclined to overrule him.
Not everyone regrets that the state cannot continue its heritage of land preservation, which stretches back to the days of Theodore Roosevelt and the creation of "forever wild" forest reserves in the Catskills and the Adirondacks. Some upstate counties, concerned that the bond act would take huge plots of land out of local control, voted it down by margins of 8 to 1.
But without any money for land, the state cannot act on programs that were aimed not only at preserving esthetic treasures, but also at protecting drinking-water supplies, stemming pollution and controlling development.
In the Catskill watershed, which provides much of New York City's water supply and where city officials say land purchases are a critical means of protecting the supply, neither the state nor the city can act right now when property goes on the market. And in Orange County, a private developer has filed plans for a housing subdivision for parts of Sterling Forest, an 18,000-acre parcel that is the largest woodland left in the New York metropolitan area.
Here in the Adirondacks, at least two major parcels of land for which the state was negotiating, one on Lake Champlain and the other on Forked Lake, have been put up for sale. Another parcel, one of the longest undeveloped stretches on Lake George, was bought by the Adirondack Land Trust, a private conservation group that planned to sell it to the state. Now the group is struggling to raise contributions to keep from defaulting on its mortgage payments on the $2.5 million property.
One of the more innovative approaches the state mapped out in recent years involves agreements known as conservation easements, in which a private seller agrees to open land to the public or to forego some uses of it, like development, in return for a payment from the state. Nearly half the 300,000 acres covered by two now-expired bond acts approved by the voters in 1972 and 1986 were preserved that way.
Aside from being a less expensive way to protect land than buying it outright, the arrangement has proved particularly attractive to forest-products companies because it can significantly lower the tax bill on company-owned property. That concept was at the heart of the Raquette River deal near here, as well as several other negotiations with timber companies.
"This is a very critical time, and just as a lot of these companies are deciding to get into the game, it turns out that we can't ante up on our side of the table," said Neil Woodworth, conservation director of the Adirondack Mountain Club, a private group that has lobbied extensively for protecting the Raquette River property.
 
'When All You Have Is a Nickel'
 The broad economic downturn may well discourage some private purchases of land regardless of whether the state can compete for it. Still, many environmentalists contend that the state should move ahead now precisely because the land is cheaper than it will be when the economy rebounds.
"That could well be true," said Governor Cuomo's chief adviser on environmental affairs, Frank Murray. "But when all you have is a nickel, it doesn't matter if land costs 25 cents or if it costs a dollar. You can't afford to buy it."
The state's land program was at the heart of the $1.975 billion environmental bond act that was defeated last fall. If the measure had passed, $800 million from bond sales would have been set aside to buy land or to secure the kind of public access to it envisioned in the International Paper deal.
But now other economic efforts are getting higher priority. Lawmakers, under intense pressure from local governments, are expected to come up with some money for sewage treatment, landfill closings, recycling and other programs that would have been financed by the bond act. And, despite complaints from environmentalists about misdirected priorities, Mr. Cuomo has included about $20 million in his budget for new snow-making equipment at state-owned ski areas, renovations at state golf courses and other recreational programs that were also included in the bond act.
 
Cuomo Prefers to Wait
 But the support for the land programs is more diffuse. Moreover, Governor Cuomo, who pushed hard for land acquisition in last year's campaign, often describing it as "the ultimate selfless act," now cites controversy over it as the chief reason the bond act lost.
And though his own Environmental Conservation Department had already identified dozens of environmentally sensitive parcels in anticipation of using bond act money to buy them, Mr. Cuomo now prefers to wait while new advisory committees work out recommendations on where to buy land.
"In these difficult times involving limited public resources, we must do it intelligently and persuasively," he said last week in explaining why he was turning to the new committees to study land-preservation efforts.
 
No Money From Trust Fund
 While Mr. Cuomo included a provision for land acquisition in his proposal for a state trust fund for environmental purposes, he said there would be no money for it soon.
In the meantime, deals like the one involving the 21-mile Raquette River property near here remain in flux.
Environmental groups met with the Governor recently and said they were encouraged that he had at least included a provision in his environmental fund that would allow land purchases sometime in the future, but many still urge that money be found now.
"Certainly by not having any money available at all for land, we are going to lose out on some critical parcels," said Lee Wasserman, executive director of the Environmental Planning Lobby, a nonprofit group based in Albany. "And the longer we wait, the riskier it becomes."

HEADLINE: New York State to Sue to Stop Evictions in Rent-Law Fight

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

 BODY:
A New York State lawsuit to prevent a Federal agency from evicting hundreds of rent-regulated tenants from co-operative and condominium apartments in New York City will be filed today in Federal court in Manhattan, state officials said yesterday.
The suit, by Attorney General Robert Abrams and Angelo J. Aponte, commissioner of the state's Division of Housing and Community Renewal, seeks to bar the Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency in charge of the nation's savings and loan bailout, from evicting tenants occupying apartments the agency has acquired from failed thrift institutions. 
 Simmering for months, the dispute, which came to a boil last month with a Federal decision to evict nine rent-regulated tenants from a Manhattan condominium, brings the savings and loan bailout program into direct conflict with strict state laws protecting renters, a hallowed keystone of New York City housing.
"For the Resolution Trust Corporation to abrogate the leases of rent-regulated tenants protected by state law is an unprecedented and outrageous attack on the citizens of New York State," Mr. Aponte said yesterday.
 
A Question of Authority
 In the joint announcement, Mr. Abrams said the court would be asked to enjoin Resolution Trust from evicting any rent-regulated occupant of a co-op or condominium under its control and to issue a declaratory judgment saying, in effect, that the Federal agency had no authority to abrogate statutory tenancies or leases protected by state law.
"This lawsuit seeks to stop a reckless attempt by R.T.C. to go far beyond the authority granted to it by Congress, by trying to place the cost of the S & L bailout on the backs of innocent New Yorkers," he said. "New York will not allow the Federal Government to disregard the fundamental protections enjoyed by tenants during the co-op and condominium conversion process."
Felisa Neuringer, speaking for Resolution Trust, said she could not comment on the suit until its lawyers had studied it. But she contended that the agency was not exceeding its authority. She said the evictions were needed to stem the loss of almost $1 million a year and noted that low- and moderate-income tenants would not be evicted.
Since last September, when Resolution Trust said it planned to evict nine rent-regulated tenants from a luxury condominium at 444 East 57th Street near Sutton Place to sell apartments it acquired when it seized the assets of the Nassau Savings and Loan Company of Brooklyn, the Federal agency and state officials have been at loggerheads over the issue.
 
Protecting Nonbuyers
 The nine tenants did not buy their apartments when the building was converted to a condominium in the mid-1980's, but stayed on under laws intended to protect nonbuyers from eviction. They pay rents of $475 to $1,700 for apartments, each with two or more bedrooms, in one of Manhattan's most expensive areas.
Resolution Trust, after postponing action for five months, announced on Feb. 25 that it would repudiate the nine leases and said it also might move to evict the tenants of more than 900 other rent-controlled and rent-stabilized units it had acquired in 10 other buildings. By the end of this year, it expects to acquire 1,000 more apartments.
The agency also filed a suit naming Mr. Abrams and Mr. Aponte and asking the Federal court to nullify state rent regulations if they are used to prevent evictions or rent increases in buildings that have come under the agency's control. The action is pending.
Resolution Trust officials contend that they have been ordered by Congress to obtain the best financial return from real estate acquired from failed savings and loans. They say Congress gave the agency authority to supercede state laws, withdraw from contracts, evict rent-regulated tenants and sell unprofitable apartments to carry out its mandate.
But state officials argue that Congress granted Resolution Trust no explicit authority to abrogate leases, and that evictions would disrupt the lives of hundreds of tenants and undermine state laws that protect renters and maintain order in the conversion of units to co-ops and condominiums.
"It is unconscionable that the Federal Government has asked New Yorkers to pay once again for the savings and loan debacle," Mr. Abrams said.
And Mr. Aponte added: "The savings and loan crisis requires a national solution. We will not allow the Federal Government to run roughshod over state laws and regulations and trample on the rights of innocent families."

HEADLINE: Credit Card Reviews Stir Dispute

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
As banks are increasing efforts to distinguish between good and bad credit card customers, they are being accused of discrimination by lawmakers who object to more stringent credit standards for customers in economically depressed regions of the country.
Lawmakers from New England are asking whether a unit of the First Chicago Corporation crossed the line between prudent business judgment and discrimination earlier this year when it conducted a special review of credit card accounts in nine Northeastern states. 
 The review, which was criticized by political leaders in the region, resulted in the cancellation of 7,800 cards and reduced credit limits on 1,100 cardholders out of 1.7 million accounts that were reviewed.
First Chicago, which has 6.6 million credit card accounts and is the nation's third-largest card issuer, said in a response to questions from Representative Edward J. Markey, Democrat of Massachusetts, that its review was not discriminatory toward New England.
The banking company noted that it had made special reviews of customers in other parts of the country when economic conditions and cardholder behavior raised red flags.
 
Increased Bankruptcies Cited
 Scott P. Marks Jr., the chairman of FCC National Bank, the First Chicago unit that handles its credit card business, said in the letter that bankruptcies among its New England cardholders in the first nine months of the year were 65 percent higher than in the comparable period last year.
Because of the rise, he said, the company decided to study some accounts before the regular renewal reviews that are held every two years.
Customers in Maine, Vermont, New Hampshire, Massachusetts, Connecticut and Rhode Island, as well as New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania, were part of the review.
The accounts selected for a closer look were those that had been delinquent within the last 14 months or had an unpaid balance above the credit limit. The First Chicago review was also limited to accounts that had not been renewed in the last six months or were due for regularly scheduled reviews in three months.
Mr. Marks's letter said the credit standards applied in the Northeast were the same as those the bank normally used.
 
Need for New Law Questioned
 Federal law does not prohibit discrimination by geographical region, but some lawmakers are considering whether legislation is needed to prohibit the practice. Existing laws forbid discrimination on the basis of age, race, sex, or national origin.
Representative Joseph P. Kennedy 2d, Democrat of Massachusetts, said last week that the oversight and investigations subcommittee of the House Banking Committee would hold a hearing on March 22 on different credit standards for cardholders in different regions. "When people with the same income and creditworthiness are treated differently because of where they live, then I am concerned," he said.
Representative Kennedy, a member of the Banking Committee, has often criticized banks for discrimination in mortgage lending and for failure to provide low-cost services to the poor.
Aides to Representative Markey said they were studying how to modify existing anti-discrimination rules to include a ban on discrimination by region.
John Y. Coffman, the president of Management Decision Systems Inc., an Atlanta company that helps card issuers compile statistics on customers, said location was not an important consideration. "Some people once used ZIP codes to adjust for the inherent risk in certain areas, but now they don't do that because of political and legal implications," he said.
"It's prudent for card issuers to protect themselves when the economy" is weakening, he said. But too much emphasis on regional difficulties could mean a bank would lose good business when the regional economy improves, he said.

HEADLINE: Once, Welfare Meant Someone Else, But Recession Brings Home Its Sting

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FRAMINGHAM, Mass.

 BODY:
Last June, unmarried and six months pregnant, Beth Chiaet, 28 years old, sat stunned as a caseworker told her what it would take to get her application for welfare approved.
She had to produce her birth certificate, a letter from her former employer stating the reasons she lost her job, a Social Security card, a driver's license and certification from her doctor that she was pregnant. 
 "I looked like a cow," she recalled, sitting in the cluttered room she rents in the basement of a house here. "How could I not be pregnant?"
To Ms. Chiaet (pronounced shy-ETT) the question, with its implications of distrust, only underscored how much her life had changed since she left her $18,000-a-year job as a nurse's assistant at a Massachusetts geriatric hospital.
Ms. Chiaet was forced by complications with her pregnancy to request a medical leave, but she said the hospital did not want to hold her job open at a time when the state was reducing its work force. Since beneficiaries of unemployment insurance must be willing and able to work, Ms. Chiaet could not qualify for its benefits. Her only option was welfare.
 
A Word That Didn't Apply
 Experts say more and more middle-class and working-class Americans are going through similar experiences as the recession deepens. Many of these new welfare clients have never received public assistance, and many never dreamed that the word "welfare" would ever apply to them.
There are many such families in this neatly tended Boston suburb, which has been hit particularly hard by the end of the high-technology boom that carried the area through the 1980's. But Framingham is hardly alone.
As the economy worsens, the nation's welfare caseload has exploded. A record 4.21 million families were receiving payments in December under Aid to Families With Dependent Children, the nation's largest welfare program, according to the American Public Welfare Association, a group representing state and local welfare agencies.
And many of the new clients were never on welfare before. There are no nationwide figures, but a survey of welfare offices in Maricopa County, Ariz., which includes Phoenix, indicated, for example, that 54 percent of new applicants had never received welfare. In Maryland, the Center for Business and Economic Studies of the University of Baltimore has estimated that 36 percent of all new cases in the state were receiving welfare for the first time.
"Many of these new cases are families that had been making it -- not comfortably, to be sure, but families with strong work histories," said Cesar A. Perales, Commissioner of the New York State Department of Social Services. "This recession, as one might expect, has brought new families into our offices in record numbers."
 
Documenting Lives
 Once there, many of these newly impoverished families find themselves feeling lost in a labyrinth of regulations, intended to prevent fraud, that force them to document every aspect of their lives. At the same time, they are torn between their need for financial help and the perceived stain of being on the public dole.
 "I felt like I was begging," said Shahidah Graham, 51, who was laid off from her job as a receptionist last June and who exhausted her unemployment benefits in January. "It was weird. It took me awhile just to get enough motivation to go down and apply."
A young Framingham couple with four children spent six months on welfare after the husband was laid off from his job as a manager with a computer company in November 1989 and exhausted his unemployment insurance. (He has since found a job selling computers, and the family is no longer on welfare.)
When the couple shopped for groceries, they would scout the aisles of the local supermarket to see if any friends or neighbors were inside. If they were, the couple, fearful of being seen using food stamps, would leave without buying anything.
They agreed to be interviewed only on the condition that their names would not be used. For several days, they agonized over that stipulation. On one hand, they said, they wanted to stand up as examples of middle-class people who, through no fault of their own, could end up on welfare. But in the end, they were overcome by the embarrassment such a disclosure would cause them and their families.
 
The Children Don't Know
 A divorced 36-year-old woman from Lexington, Mass., who spoke only on condition that her name not be used, is also concerned about the effect on her family of being identified as a welfare recipient. She has not told her two children that the family has started collecting benefits.
Several of those interviewed complained about what they termed the distrust and paternalism of the welfare regulations.
After her daughter was born, Ms. Chiaet returned with her baby to the welfare office to apply for an increase in her monthly payment. Her case worker told her that she needed to provide documents proving that her daughter had been born.
"We live in a society where you are innocent until proven guilty," said Ms. Chiaet, who has been unable to find work since her daughter, Shaina, was born six months ago. "In the welfare office, they treat you like you are guilty until you prove otherwise."
For families who have long thought of themselves as hard-working, honest citizens, this apparent unwillingness to be taken at their word is jolting. "Why can't they sift through their applicants and figure out who are upstanding citizens who have worked hard and tried to do the right things?" the Lexington woman asked.
 
A Bewildering World
 Running through many of their comments is an undercurrent of having crossed a divide, of having moved from what was familiar and respectable into a bewildering world they had thought of only in myths, misinformation and stereotypes -- when they thought about it at all.
Though his unemployment benefits ran out in July, the 38-year-old former telecommunications projects manager did not apply for welfare until September; he thought that only single women with children could qualify. At the same time, he and his wife were finding it increasingly difficult to buy enough food for their four children. The couple also fell four months behind on their mortgage payments and were $900 in arrears on utility bills.
It was only after a $3,000 hospital bill for their 13-month-old daughter and a friend's suggestion that the couple began to explore the possibility of getting public assistance.
Having made the decision to apply for welfare, all of those interviewed expressed shock at how little money the system provides. Ms. Chiaet, for example, gets $486 a month, plus $137 a month in food stamps, but her rent is $400 a month.
Before the woman in Lexington began receiving public assistance in February, her only income was the $500 she received monthly in child support payments from her former husband. Now, she gets $579 a month in public assistance, plus $190 a month in food stamps and Medicaid.
But the state confiscates her ex-husband's child support checks to offset its payments to her. The rent for her three-bedroom house is $1,100, and the woman says that if she does not find a job before the next rent payment is due she does not know how she will pay it.
Sucking on a pacifier, Shaina Chiaet fell asleep as her mother rocked her back and forth. As she cradled her sleeping child, Ms. Chiaet was asked about the lessons she would take away from being on welfare.
"I don't know," she said, "I really don't. Except, I know it's going to make me think twice about ever asking anyone for help again. I don't like the feeling. It's too degrading."
