HEADLINE: Cuomo Scolds G.O.P. for Assailing Democrats on Gulf War

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 10

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo today harshly criticized Republican leaders for political attacks against Congressional Democrats who voted against the war in the Persian Gulf, and said that the allied victory does not necessarily mean that the decision to go to war was the best one.
Mr. Cuomo, who supported the position of some Democratic leaders that sanctions against Iraq should have been given more time, said in a telephone interview that it still was impossible to know whether war was preferable to sanctions. 
 The Governor, like Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia, the Democratic chairman of the Armed Services Committee, has maintained that continued economic pressure against Iraq might have accomplished President Bush's initial goals: forcing the Iraqi Army to leave Kuwait, restoring the Kuwaiti monarchy and gaining the release of hostages held by Iraq.
"Logically, you cannot say that if the President had had his way with that negotiation that it would have been less desirable than all the taking of lives and all the environmental damage and all the expense that followed," Mr. Cuomo said. "Can you say now that if the President had gotten his way with those three conditions that that would have been a failure, that that would have been appeasement? I don't think so."
 
Was War the Best Decision?
 Mr. Cuomo stressed that he was not saying that war was the wrong decision, only that it was impossible to know whether it was the best decision. He said he chose to address the issue, in response to a reporter's questions, because "the debate is leaving it out."
The Governor, who is frequently mentioned as a potential Democratic presidential candidate, gave his responses about the war and its political aftermath against the backdrop of a national euphoria over the end of the war and the return of the first American soldiers. Public opinion polls have shown support for Mr. Bush at record levels, leaving Democratic officials to question whether they can mount a credible challenge to him in 1992.
Republican political leaders have tried to capitalize on the public support for Mr. Bush by saying that Democrats who opposed the war, even as a matter of conscience, can expect to have their positions used against them in coming campaigns. Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, chairman of the National Republican Senatorial Committee, has called opponents of the war "appeasement-before-country liberals." The New York Conservative Party ran a full-page advertisement in The New York Times last week asking, in reference to Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan's vote against the war, "Where was Pat Moynihan when Americans needed him?"
Mr. Cuomo called the tactics "cheap" and "foolish" and said they stood in stark contrast to this year's high-minded Congressional debate over whether to authorize the war.
"It's a shame that that magnificent debate should be desecrated now by tawdry politics that reveal conservative and radical Republicans at their very worst," he said. "What the conservatives have revealed is that what they're best at is negativism. Their whole philosophy is a sort of Willie Horton campaign technique."
 
'Candles to the God Mars'
 Mr. Cuomo said Republicans had erred by "holding themselves out as the party of war, which is the way it sounds."
"This country doesn't want somebody who burns candles to the god Mars," he continued. "We want somebody who can win a war that is forced upon us and made inevitable and can win the peace just as effectively."
The Governor, who stirred a controversy last fall by suggesting that the White House should try to negotiate with Iraq, said that Mr. Bush had in fact tried to negotiate an end to the conflict, directly through Secretary of State James Baker and "vicariously" through United Nations Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.
"I don't think we could ever be faulted for not having tried to negotiate," he said.
Mr. Cuomo, who has said that he has no plans to run for President, repeatedly commended Mr. Bush and American troops for handling the war "superbly well." But he said the country's exhilaration would be multiplied if the White House could prove it was equally adept at making peace.
"We've proven that we're very good at war, and you need to be," he said. "Imagine the joy this country would experience if we could prove now we're very good at peace, which we haven't done yet."

HEADLINE: TURMOIL IN SERBIA DEEPENS DIVISIONS

BYLINE: By STEPHEN ENGELBERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, March 10

 BODY:
The political turmoil in the Yugoslav republic of Serbia, which continued today with the arrests of important anti-Communist opposition leaders, adds a new impetus to the forces pulling this multi-ethnic nation apart. The trouble comes after recent moves by Slovenia and Croatia toward seceding from the six-republic Yugoslav federation.
Political parties opposing Slobodan Milosevic, the former Communist who won Serbia's presidential election last year, said that at least 15 of their members were in jail in the aftermath of violent clashes on Saturday between police officers and demonstrators. 
 Armored units from the Yugoslav national army, sent to quell unrest after two people were killed and scores injured, rolled down the main streets of Belgrade late Saturday and guarded downtown buildings for nearly 24 hours before withdrawing. Late this evening, the police used tear gas in an effort to break up a crowd of several thousand young people, mostly students, who assembled for a rally near a downtown shopping district. There were no reports of injuries.
 
Serbia's Position Weakened
 Serbia, the country's most powerful and populous republic, has been the leading advocate of maintaining the existing federal system. Other republics, including Slovenia and Croatia, the two most northern regions, want a much looser arrangement and have taken initial legal steps toward secession.
Now Serbia finds its economy near collapse and its government unable to keep order in the streets. The Serbs thus appear less able to set terms in the negotiations among the republics over the future of the country. The talks have been stalled for months.
"These events leave Slovenia and Croatia in a substantially better position in the negotiations," said Slaven Letica, a former adviser to Croatia's president. "We've been expecting Serbia to explode for months."
The street battle on Saturday, in which a teen-ager and a 54-year-old policeman died, was viewed today by opposition leaders as the beginning of a decisive struggle to oust what they regard as a Communist Government by another name -- Socialist.
"We are entering a new era of political life: the slow and painful birth of democracy," Desimir Tosic, vice president of the Democratic Party, one of the opposition groups, said at a news conference today.
 
Western Policies Criticized
 Among those arrested over the weekend were Vuk Draskovic, the leader of the Serbian Movement for Renewal and the organizer of Saturday's demonstration. Other opposition leaders were reportedly detained today in Belgrade and other cities.
Officials in Slovenia and Croatia said today that they planned to use the crackdown in Serbia in their campaign to persuade Western nations to change their policy toward Yugoslavia.
The two republics argue that the policies of the United States and of European nations in supporting Yugoslav unity have encouraged the national army to believe that it would have a free hand to intervene, if necessary, in opposing the breakup of the country.
Milan Kucin, the President of Slovenia, warned on Friday that "as long as the international community chooses to overlook the Yugoslav reality and prefers an integrated, united Yugoslavia, it contributes to keeping Yugoslavia a focus of instability."
 
Serbian Nationalism
 Slovenia and Croatia often portray their differences with the Serbs as a fight between Westward-looking democracies and "crypto-Communists" or "Bolsheviks."
The pivotal figure in the competing visions of the Yugoslav conflict is Mr. Milosevic. When Serbia's Communist Party dissolved in 1989 and its leaders formed the Socialist Party, they chose Mr. Milosevic, a former banker and leader of the Communists, as their presidential candidate. Emphasizing Serbian nationalism and a cautious attitude toward a market economy, he won an easy victory.
Earlier that year, the elections in Slovenia and Croatia were won by avowedly anti-Communist parties that emphasized nationalism but also pledged to move quickly towards privatization and free-market reforms.
Thus, the stage was set for conflict. As the Yugoslav economy continued to falter, Slovenia and Croatia, the wealthiest of the republics, contended that they were being dragged towards economic ruin by Serbia.
 
Economic Issues
 The giant firms that dominate the Serbian economy are sliding toward bankruptcy; many have not paid salaries in months. In an apparent attempt to shift public attention elsewhere, Mr. Milosevic has repeatedly raised nationalist issues, such as the plight of the Serbian minority in Croatia.
But on Saturday night, many demonstrators in the crowd said such problems were no longer very important to them. They said they had come to protest the economic hard times, particularly the rising unemployment that idles many young people.
Jelko Kacin, the deputy defense minister of Slovenia, said the weekend's violence would speed the pace of Yugoslavia's dissolution because it would restrain Mr. Milosevic from using nationalism in the future as a political weapon. "Now, people in Serbia have realized that the basic problem is not in the other republics -- it's in Serbia," Mr. Kacin said.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR: DIPLOMACY;
8 ARAB COUNTRIES BACK BUSH'S PLAN ON MIDEAST PEACE

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, March 10

 BODY:
Six Arab countries of the Persian Gulf, along with Egypt and Syria, today endorsed President Bush's broad framework for dealing with the Middle East in the wake of the war with Iraq, including plans for a continuing and enhanced American military presence in the gulf.
American and Arab officials portrayed as a watershed event the fact that the Arab countries -- in particular the traditionally anti-American Syria -- were backing an American plan for stabilizing the Middle East that will include the presence of American naval forces and occasional visits of American ground troops. 
 Saudi Arabia's Ambassador to Washington, Prince Bandar, alluding to what appears to be a new, powerful, moderate Arab coalition, said after a meeting between Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and Arab foreign ministers, "You should not minimize the meaning of this."
 
Clear Differences on Israel
 The endorsement of Mr. Bush's plan meant that the Arab countries agreed that the American military presence in the gulf region, now being reduced, would continue to be larger than it was before the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2,
But despite this broad agreement, the first high-level conference between the United States and its Arab allies since the gulf war revealed that the Arab ministers clearly differed with Mr. Baker on one very important detail: how to make peace with Israel.
With the Secretary of State due to visit Israel on Monday, Mr. Baker's mission was further complicated today by what Israeli political leaders said was an Arab terrorist attack in West Jerusalem. An Arab assailant, who said he was sending a message to Mr. Baker, stabbed four Israeli women to death and wounded at least one other woman, the Israeli police said. [Page A8.]
 
Arabs Firm on Israel
 If public statements from the Riyadh meeting are any indication, the gulf war does not yet appear to have in any way reshaped the Arab consensus on how to deal with Israel. The Arab ministers said they shared Mr. Bush's desire to address the Arab-Israeli dispute, but they reaffirmed their traditional stand that they would deal with Israel only through an international conference under the auspices of the United Nations.
Mr. Baker, by contrast, said an international conference would not be appropriate at this time. Privately, American officials describe such a conference as a "total non-starter," since Israel, which insists on direct talks, would never attend.
Mr. Baker emphasized that he spoke with each of the Arab officials about their taking new confidence-building steps to ease tensions with Israel, in return for parallel steps from the Israelis. He argued, after the meeting, that until he had had a chance to speak with the Israeli Government on Monday, to see what it is prepared to do, and then convey that to the Arabs, it would be premature to declare that nothing is new or possible.
 
Breakthrough in Relations
 "It is not surprising," said Mr. Baker, "that you don't have Arab governments coming out and unilaterally making statements about the steps they might be willing to take."
Whatever the Riyadh meeting leads to on the Arab-Israeli front, it will be remembered as something of a breakthrough in Arab-American relations. In their final statement, the Arab ministers endorsed the four-point approach outlined by Mr. Bush in his address to a joint session of Congress last Wednesday. In that speech, Mr. Bush called for an expanded American naval presence in the Persian Gulf, as well as continuing "American participation in joint exercises" with Arab gulf countries "involving both air and ground forces."
In addition, the Bush plan calls for arms control agreements to halt the spread of weapons of mass destruction, economic development programs to bridge differences between the Arab haves and have-nots, and a renewed effort to open talks among Israel and the Arab countries and Israel and the Palestinians. The talks would be based on the principle of trading Israeli-occupied Arab lands for peace treaties between the Arab countries and Israel.
After today's two-hour meeting at the Riyadh guest palace, Saudi Arabia's Foreign Minister, Prince Saud al-Faisal, issued a statement in the name of the Foreign Ministers of Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Qatar, Bahrain, Oman, the United Arab Emirates, Syria and Egypt.
It said they "expressed their appreciation for the statement delivered by President George Bush before the United States Congress, which dealt positively with the security of this region and the Palestinian question."
 
Baker to Meet Soviet Aide
 The statement added, in a clear allusion to the future American presence in the gulf, that the Arab ministers agreed that the task of establishing peace and security in the Middle East was "for all the peoples of the region and outside parties prepared to play a constructive role."
Considering the role the United States has assured for itself in the future of the gulf, it was no accident that Mr. Baker telephoned the Soviet Foreign Minister, Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh, immediately after the meeting and asked that the Soviet Ambassador to Egypt meet Mr. Baker at his hotel in Cairo to be briefed on the Riyadh talks.
On the question of arms control, Prince Saud said the Arab group agreed to "endeavor to transform the Middle East into a region free from weapons of mass destruction," which means nuclear, biological and chemical weapons.
The Arab ministers made no reference to reducing the flow of conventional arms to the region, something that Mr. Baker once proposed but which the Bush Administration now appears to be abandoning given the demand of its Arab allies for better tanks, planes and artillery to protect themselves.
 
Good Opportunity Seen
 On dealing with the Arab-Israeli dispute, Prince Saud's statement said the Arab countries believed that the phase "following the liberation of Kuwait" provides the best opportunity to encounter the challenges "confronting security and stability in the region and to bring about a just and comprehensive solution to the Arab-Israeli conflict and the question of Palestine."
The statement added that the Arab ministers "are of the view that the convening of an international peace conference under the auspices of the U.N. is an appropriate framework to bring an end to the Israeli occupation of the Arab territories and to insure the national rights of the Palestinian people in accordance with relevant U.N. resolutions."
Mr. Baker, by contrast, said the American position remains that an international conference, properly structured and at the appropriate time, "might be useful." But he immediately added, "This is not the appropriate time."
The substance of the meeting suggests that where the gulf Arab countries feel their survival is on the line -- in confronting Iraq -- they are prepared to consider all sorts of unprecedented approaches, including a continuing and open military cooperation with the United States. But on secondary issues, such as the Palestinian-Israeli dispute, they still prefer the safety of the Arab lowest common denominator -- at least for now.
 
Parley With Palestinians
 Mr. Baker said today that "some Palestinians" from the occupied territories had expressed an interest in meeting with him when he arrived in Israel on Monday and he would like to do so. The Palestine Liberation Organization in Tunis has reportedly approved a list of Palestinians to meet with the Secretary.
When asked if a meeting between Mr. Baker and the Palestinians approved by the P.L.O. would not constitute a tacit resumption of the dialogue between the United States and the P.L.O., a senior Administration official said no. That dialogue was severed by Washington in June 1990 after the P.L.O. refused to condemn a terrorist attack by one of its member groups.
The official said all of the Palestinians being proposed to meet with Mr. Baker are known to the United States and have previously met with either American or Israeli officials. The official added that if the Palestinians "are serious" about a meeting with the Secretary of State, they are not going to send people who are known P.L.O. operatives.
Today's meeting of Arab ministers with Mr. Baker, which followed a meeting in Damascus last week among the same Arab countries, suggests that America's Arab allies in the gulf war intend to try to stick together after this conflict as a new Arab power bloc. Given its combination of wealthy oil lands, and muscular manpower countries, such as Egypt and Syria, this coalition could have extensive influence in setting the Arab agenda -- if it holds together.
As Prince Saud's statement put it, the eight Arab countries "recognize the importance of working together to prevent a recurrence of a similar aggression to that which befell Kuwait."
 
Some of the Ingredients
 The countries, he added, have a "common approach to the questions that greatly impact the future security, political and economic situations in the region."
On the question of a security structure to replace the 500,000 American troops still in Kuwait and Iraq, Mr. Baker said he and the eight ministers agreed it would consist of an Arab peacekeeping force made up of the six Arab gulf states plus troops from Egypt and Syria and an enhanced American naval presence in the Persian Gulf, along with regular joint training exercises between American air and ground forces assigned to the region on a non-permanent rotating basis. It would also include the prepositioning of large amounts of American equipment in Saudi Arabia and elsewhere so that if American troops had to be reintroduced quickly into the region, part of their weapons and supplies would already be in place.
Overlaid on this, Mr. Baker said, would probably be a United Nations observer force to monitor at least the Kuwait-Iraq border, something Washington was expected to push for in the Security Council very shortly.
The Arab ministers in their statement went out of their way to emphasize that this security structure was not aimed at Iran, which has expressed displeasure with the concept, and could end up actively opposing it.
As Prince Saud said, the eight Arab states "are keen to develop cordial relations with Iran." He added: "They reiterate that whatever arrangements they may agree upon shall not be directed against any other party. In fact, the reference in the Damascus Declaration to a dialogue with Islamic and international parties clearly indicates a willingness on their part to have a dialogue with Islamic countries, including Iran."

The participants endorsed President Bush's framework for dealing with the Middle East in the wake of the war. (Associated Press) (pg. A8)

HEADLINE: Square D Rejects Schneider Offer

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: PALATINE, Ill., March 10

 BODY:
The Square D Company said today that its board had unanimously rejected an unsolicited takeover offer from Groupe Schneider S.A.
Square D had advised its shareholders last week not to tender their shares to Schneider, which is based in Paris. The French manufacturer of fuse boxes had begun a $78-a-share tender offer for Square D last Monday. The action taken today represents a formal rejection of the $1.98 billion offer, a Square D spokeswoman said. 
 "Your board strongly believes that this is not the right time to sell the company," Jerre L. Stead, the chairman of Square D, wrote in a letter to stockholders. He said the board had carefully reviewed the company's businesses, financial condition and future prospects. Square D makes electronic switches and controls.
 
Price Called Inadequate
 Mr. Stead said Goldman, Sachs & Company, the company's financial adviser, considered the $78 offer inadequate. He said the company's outside business consultant, Boston Consulting Group Inc., considered Square D's business potential over the next five years to be substantial.
Square D said that in light of Schneider's offer and pending litigation against the company, it had decided to hold its annual meeting on May 24, rather than in late April.
Schneider has said it will try to elect a new slate of directors at the annual meeting, but the new meeting date appears to give Square D more time to fight the replacement of its directors.
Schneider responded to Square D's statement, saying, "We believe our offer is full and fair, and we are confident that the shareholders of Square D will agree with us."
 
Estimating a Price
 Analysts have said Square D could bring $80 to $90 a share based on recent similar acquisitions. Square D executives have said they are not seeking potential buyers and declined to comment on speculation that a friendly buyer might step forward.
In his letter to stockholders, Mr. Stead said Schneider was trying to take advantage of the recession in the United States and the depressed American dollar.
"We will continue to explore all alternatives consistent with our long-term strategy to serve the interests of our stockholders and other constituencies," Mr. Stead said.
Square D is based in Palatine but is incorporated in Delaware, where state law requires a hostile bidder to receive the votes of 85 percent of the outstanding shares.
The shares of Square D closed on Friday at $80 each, up 50 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.
 
Lawsuit Is Filed
 Square D has filed a lawsuit in a state court in New York seeking an injunction barring Schneider from disclosing or using confidential information it received from Square D.
Square D said Schneider, which obtained the information in joint-venture talks that failed, illegally used the information to shape the tender offer.
In a separate lawsuit filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan, Square D said it would challenge the bid and an expected proxy fight by Schneider on antitrust grounds.

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
Democrats Don't Need Sacrificial Lamb for '92

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 9

 BODY:
Presidential elections are not canceled because the incumbent President is skyrocketing in the public opinion polls.
As a result, Democrats are putting on their game faces and beginning to confront the hard realities of the 1992 campaign. 
 This is still a pessimistic party as President Bush basks in the afterglow of the Persian Gulf war. But personal ambition and party imperatives are beginning to produce a few signs of life among the Democrats.
"I will admit that today it looks somewhere between unlikely and impossible that a Democrat will win the Presidency," said Robert S. Strauss, chairman of the Democratic National Committee in the Carter Administration. "But six months from now I don't know what it will look like. They haven't called off the election, and as long as it stays set there, the Democrats should field someone who can responsibly make the case on the issues the country must face."
Regardless of the Democrats' chances of recapturing the White House in 1992, the party has a compelling interest in producing a strong nominee. Democratic control of the Senate is at stake next year: The class of 1986, many of whom were elected with the narrowest of margins, will be back on the firing line.
 
Burden on the Party?
 In the House, redistricting and retirement could produce as many as 100 open seats, raising the possibility of major Republican gains there. Many party leaders worry that a weak Presidential nominee could be a heavy burden on Democratic candidates in some of these intensely competitive races.
"We should not be talking about a sacrificial lamb," said Nathan Landow, chairman of the Maryland Democratic Party. "We should be pursuing the strongest possible candidate to help all Democratic elected officials around the country."
The potential candidates, meanwhile, are trying to discern the political landscape beyond the war celebrations. How long will Mr. Bush's remarkable approval ratings hold? How lasting is the postwar optimism? Where is the economy headed?
Many Democratic strategists argue that the top tier of potential candidates still has the luxury of waiting until late spring or summer, when some answers may be more clear, before making their decisions. Their name recognition, established political networks and ability to raise money enables these hopefuls to mount a candidacy quickly. By many accounts, this group would include Gov. Mario M. Cuomo of New York, Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, Senator Al Gore of Tennessee and Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House majority leader.
While this is already a late-starting campaign, in part because of the war, some Democrats argue that there is still wisdom in waiting. "I think the country ought to be allowed some time to reflect on the war, to deal with the fact that we've won," said Bob Shrum, a Democratic consultant. "We don't have to go from a campaign in the Persian Gulf to a campaign in Iowa in a day."
Still, one party strategist said, some Democrats are quietly arguing that one of the big candidates should take the plunge sooner rather than later and try to pre-empt the field.
 
Gore Attracts Attention
 There is a rationale for this approach -- some believe it a good way to wrap up the nomination early -- but it also reflects a longing among some Democrats for a heavyweight to enter the fray. In recent weeks, George McGovern, who led Democrats to a landslide defeat in the 1972 election, has been one of the most visible Democrats testing the waters.
Mr. Gore is sending some of the clearest signals of his interest in a run for the nomination. His star rose among some political handicappers because he was one of the few potential candidates who voted for the resolution authorizing the use of force in the gulf. And with Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia now considered unlikely to run, Mr. Gore would have a clearer shot at offering himself as the candidate who is strong on national security.
A spokeswoman for the Tennessee Senator said he is "thinking very seriously" about a race.
But both Mr. Gephardt and Mr. Gore have a decision to make: Is 1992 the year to run their second campaign for the Presidency? If they lose, can either run a strong enough campaign to position him well for 1996? Or do they begin to acquire the aroma of perennial candidates?
The strategic considerations are different for the long list of other potential candidates who have never run before, and can use 1992 as a year to make their name and build their credibility for 1996.
 
Risks on Either Course
 The notion of positioning for 1996 is a popular one among some Democratic strategists, who suggest, as one put it, "A lot of these people who think they can bypass '92 and wait for '96 will be very sorry." Either way, there are risks: Not running and being usurped by some hardy warrior who emerges from 1992, or running and being politically destroyed in a doomed crusade.
Some Democrats say the party needs to take the long view and seek a nominee with staying power. "They're looking for somebody who can run a credible race in 1992, take advantage of a negative if it exists, but can run again in '96 and be President of the United States," said Tony Coelho, the former House majority whip.
In the meantime, Democrats continue to look for bright spots. Bob Squier, a Democratic consultant, suggested one last week: Politics is often a game of beating expectations. Right now, that will be easy for Democrats.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "I will admit that today it looks somewhere between unlikely and impossible that a Democrat will win the Presidency," said Robert S. Strauss, former national Democratic chairman. (The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Unions Offer Cooperation to Dinkins

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
The leaders of New York City's municipal unions yesterday set aside their differences with Mayor David N. Dinkins over the removal of his chief labor negotiator and urged the Mayor to take the lead in a team effort to solve the city's worsening budget problems.
The union leaders, echoing concerns raised last week by business groups, urged Mr. Dinkins to convene a panel of union officials, bankers, realty developers and other prominent New Yorkers to negotiate a multi-year plan to close the city's budget deficits through shared sacrifices.
The group, they said, should be modeled after a similar group set up in the mid-1970's to bail out the city, then close to bankruptcy.
 
Name-Calling Last Week
 Yesterday's calm comments by the municipal union leaders were in sharp contrast with their angry name-calling last week, when they complained about "lies" and demanded the resignation of Budget Director Philip R. Michael. At that time union officials were upset by the disclosure of a city plan to defer wage increases won by hundreds of thousands of city workers to help close a city budget gap of more than $2 billion. 
 Instead of dismissing Mr. Michael, Mr. Dinkins accepted the resignation of his labor negotiator, Eric J. Schmertz, whom the union leaders strongly supported. Mr. Schmertz had previously threatened to quit, but the Mayor had persuaded him not to.
Rather than further inflame the union leaders, however, the resignation stilled them, at least for now.
"We are not going to comment on those kids fighting in the park," said Barry Feinstein, president of a teamsters' local that represents city workers. "Who said what to whom is of no moment. We want a forceful Mayor to take control and work together with us. If they don't do this, I don't know how they are going to survive."
In an interview yesterday, Mr. Feinstein said the unions considered any wage-deferral proposal out of the question except as part of a long-term plan to solve the city's fiscal problems.
He said he did not want to ask workers to defer wages in one year to solve a short-term budget problem, only to see the workers lose their jobs the next year if the city finances continued to deteriorate.
Norman Steisel, the city's First Deputy Mayor, said on Friday that the administration would support a labor-business forum modeled after the one used during the 1970's fiscal crisis. But he said yesterday that he was not yet sure what form the forum should take or how much authority it should have.
He noted that one group, the Mayor's Management Advisory Task Force, which includes both union leaders and business people, was examining policy alternatives, like an early-retirement plan for city workers.
 
Turmoil 'Has to Stop'
 During the 1970's, when the city was struggling to raise cash to stave off bankruptcy, business and labor leaders worked closely together. After intensive negotiations, union pension funds bought city notes, and major realty developers agreed to prepay taxes to help the city find the cash it needed.
But the close cooperation between union and business groups only occurred after the pressure of an imminent default on the city's notes, and it is not clear whether any group set up now would be able to cooperate as closely without that kind of drastic deadline pressure.
Mr. Feinstein was joined in his call for a new forum to work out the city's problems by Stanley Hill, executive director of District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, the largest of the city's unions.
Mr. Hill, in an interview on WNBC-TV's News Forum, which was broadcast yesterday but recorded on Friday -- before Mr. Schmertz was forced out -- said the administration was "locked into financial turmoil that has to stop."
"We are ready," he said, "to come to the table and work with this administration and the people of the city -- the real-estate community, the banking community and all of the communities that have an interest in seeing us survive -- and do it as partners."
 
'We Lost a Good Man'
 In an interview yesterday, Mr. Hill said it would be "counterproductive" to discuss Mr. Dinkins's decision to accept the resignation of his chief labor negotiator.
"I pointed out to the Mayor there is no sense in beating a dead horse," he said, "We lost a good man."
As the union leaders envision it, the new labor-business forum would have a wide mandate. But Mr. Feinstein said it would not work unless Mayor Dinkins personally convened it and attended meetings and union leaders were made "equal partners" with the Mayor and other groups. City officials said it was unlikley that the Mayor would cede his authority to any business-labor groups.
The shift in tone of the union leaders -- from that of street brawlers complaining that the administration was "in the toilet" to that of labor statesmen -- was abrupt, and the reasons for it were not clear.
In the dispute over wage deferrals, the union leaders said Mr. Michael had lied when he sent a confidential memorandum to a bond-rating agency saying that negotiations had begun on the issue. Mr. Schmertz supported the union's view.
Later Mr. Michael provided copies of several memos showing that Mr. Schmertz was aware of the discussion about wage deferrals and had discussed them with several union leaders. One of the memos -- from Mr. Schmertz to Mr. Michael -- also suggested that negotiations were under way.
Asked if they were swayed by the memos that apparently supported Mr. Michael's version of events, the union leaders said they had not changed their view that he had lied to the bond-rating agencies, but they refused to discuss it further.
City officials said that despite the flap over the memorandum, the city was still seeking wage deferrals. Its worsening budget situation might require, they said, more than the 1.5 percent wage deferral called for in the memorandum.
 
Deeper Layoffs Suggested
 If the unions are unwilling to agree to wage deferrals, the city would need other savings, like deeper layoffs, to close its budget gap, they said.
Alan J. Proctor, the executive director of the state's Financial Control Board, which oversees city finances, said the board supported the suggestion by the union leaders that the city work out detailed plans to close its budget gaps over the next several years.
But he wondered whether the unions could be equal partners in the process. "It sounds like the unions want to get into the Mayor's brain, and he has no obligation to do that."
Others in and out of city government said the administration would have to find a permanent replacement for Mr. Schmertz quickly to avoid a prolonged period of labor unrest. Mr. Dinkins has appointed the First Deputy Labor Commissioner, James F. Hanley, as acting Commissioner, and asked Milton Mollen, the Deputy Mayor for Criminal Justice, to assist him.
While the city has settled several large contracts this year, well over a hundred others, including those with police, fire and sanitation workers, have yet to be negotiated. The contracts negotiated to date are all short-term, covering only a year to 15 months. They expire toward the end of 1992.
"The loss of Eric Schmertz is very sad," said Sandra Feldman, president of the United Federation of Teachers, "because he understood at least the problems of the unions and the union leaders.
"I don't know what will happen now. It seems that there will be tremendous problems in terms of labor relations in the city."


GRAPHIC: Photo: Eric J. Schmertz, whose resignation as Labor Commissioner was accepted over the weekend, talking with reporters outside Gracie Mansion before a news conference held by Mayor David N. Dinkins on Saturday. (John Sotomayor/The New York Times)

SECTION: Section B; Page 2; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk

LENGTH: 1306 words

HEADLINE: British Tycoon Tries Proven Tactics To Negotiate a Daily News Takeover

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
Robert Maxwell, the 67-year-old British entrepreneur, has a reputation for being as unpredictable as he is hyperactive. Guided by whim and instinct, he buys and sells businesses at a furious pace and runs through subordinates like paper clips. He once even dismissed one of his sons, Ian, for showing up late for a meeting.
But there is a remarkable consistency to the recovery program that Mr. Maxwell wants to carry out at The Daily News; it seems almost a carbon copy of the formula he applied to the London mass-circulation tabloid The Daily Mirror in the mid-1980's. 
 At The News, Mr. Maxwell says he wants to cut costs by more than $70 million a year by slashing roughly 800 jobs, or more than a third of the 2,300-member work force. In 1984, after he bought the Mirror Group Newspapers, Mr. Maxwell moved quickly to cut the payroll by 2,000 workers, or a third of the 6,000-person force.
At the Mirror Group, which includes six newspapers, led by The Daily Mirror and The Sunday Mirror, the Maxwell cost-cutting plan proved a great success. Today, the privately owned Mirror Group is a solid moneymaker and is estimated to be worth roughly $1 billion, or five times what Mr. Maxwell paid for it. Mr. Maxwell said recently that he ranks turning the Mirror Group from "a dead duck into a highly profitable enterprise" as one of his greatest achievements.
 
An Avowed Socialist
 Mr. Maxwell's personal wealth is placed at about $2 billion, making the once-impoverished Czechoslovak Jewish immigrant one of Britain's richest men. He was born Jan Ludwig Hoch on June 10, 1923, one of nine children, the son of unemployed farm workers. At 15, he fled his homeland, eventually joining the French Resistance. When France fell, he served in the British Army, changing his identity several times for security purposes when fighting behind enemy lines. Finally he settled on Ian Robert Maxwell, but he seldom uses his first name.
He is an avowed socialist and a former Labor Party member of Parliament. No matter how severe the cutbacks he has sought from journalists and printers, Mr. Maxwell has always negotiated with their unions.
That has made him very different from another outsider, Australian-born Rupert Murdoch, the British press tycoon, who one night in January 1986 moved his British newspapers to his modern plant outside London and locked the unions out, printing The Sun, The Times and other periodicals from a fortress surrounded by barbed wire and police guards.
Those who have been locked in negotiations with Mr. Maxwell find the experience singular and unforgettable. He is a man for whom 18-hour work days, seven days a week, are the routine, and the pace is accelerated during crucial talks. Round-the-clock sessions are not unusual. "You walk into a building to negotiate with Maxwell and you never know when you'll get out," said Brenda Dean, general secretary of the Society of Graphical and Allied Trades, which represents 180,000 printers and paper workers in Britain.
 
Fluent in Six Languages
 Ms. Dean, who sat across the table from Mr. Maxwell during the Mirror Group negotiations, recalled his disconcerting habit of attending to the details of his far-flung business empire while in the talks with the unions.
He would effectively be conducting three or four meetings at a time, one in person and the rest by telephone. Often, Mr. Maxwell, who is fluent in six languages, would shift from English to French to German in speaking to different parties. He would use this orchestrated chaos, Ms. Dean said, along with a large measure of brinkmanship, to keep the union negotiators off guard and try to extract additional concessions.
"With Maxwell, you think you've got a deal and you haven't," she said. "It's just bizarre."
In the case of the Mirror Group, the two sides eventually reached agreement. But Mr. Maxwell has not been hesitant to walk away from a deal if the terms do not suit him. Last October, for example, Mr. Maxwell dropped his plans to buy three of the United States' largest supermarket tabloids from Globe International Publishing Inc. of Montreal. Mr. Maxwell announced in May that he would buy the three tabloids -- The Globe, National Examiner and The Sun -- but walked away from the deal when he and Globe International could not agree on a price.
After he bought The Daily Mirror, Mr. Maxwell's imprint and face were all over the paper. Stories of his own exploits were regularly reported. When The Mirror started a circulation-boosting bingo contest, Mr. Maxwell's picture was on every card.
 
Thrives on Publicity
 But after a short while, when it became apparent that that approach was counterproductive, Mr. Maxwell changed and now meddles less in the paper's daily operations. Still, if the globe-trotting publisher meets with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, as he does on occasion, the Mirror readers are likely to see a picture of it the next day. Unlike his archrival, Mr. Murdoch, who rarely makes public appearances, Mr. Maxwell seems to thrive on publicity. His French-born wife, Elisabeth, keeps annual scrapbooks for his press clippings, which typically tip the scales at 50 pounds.
"Bob Maxwell is a politician-turned-businessman," explained Joe Haines, a columnist for The Daily Mirror and, at one time, press secretary to former Prime Minister Harold Wilson. "And he behaves like a politician."
Today, The Daily Mirror serves up a blend of short and sometimes sensational news stories, editorials supporting the Labor Party and pictures of scantily clad young women. The Mirror sells more than 3 million copies a day, trailing only The Sun, a Murdoch paper, whose stories tend to be more sensational and whose models wear a bit less than in the Mirror.
The Mirror Group -- a private company owned by Mr. Maxwell, his family and a Lichtenstein trust called the Maxwell Foundation -- would acquire The News if his talks in New York City with the paper's striking unions produce an agreement. But today, the largest part of the Maxwell business empire is the public company, the Maxwell Communication Corporation, in which Mr. Maxwell, his family and the trust hold a two-thirds stake.
In the last few years, Maxwell Communication has become much more an American business, mainly through a pair of big corporate takeovers. In 1988, Maxwell Communication paid $2.6 billion for Macmillan Inc., the New York-based book publisher. The company then bought the Official Airline Guides, which publishes schedule guides and other travel information, for $750 million. At the same time, the company has sold most of its contract printing operations for about $1.4 billion. In the fiscal year ending this month, analysts expect Maxwell Communication to report pre-tax profits of more than $330 million on revenues of $2 billion.
The company has debts of about $3.2 billion, which has worried some investors who note the repayment problems other heavily indebted magnates, including Mr. Murdoch, have recently experienced. But Maxwell Communication has been steadily reducing its debts from a peak of $3.9 billion in 1989 and analysts doubt he is in trouble, since his next large repayment to his bankers is not due until 1992. "He's not facing any imminent cash squeeze," said Angela Bawtree, an analyst for Warburg Securties in London.
Today, Maxwell Communication derives 60 percent of its sales and income from North America. Mr. Maxwell has said he expects that to soon rise to 80 percent. With his growing business interests in the United States, Mr. Maxwell may want a larger public presence as well. That, some say, could be a motivation for his pursuit of The News.
"Robert Maxwell wants to be a household name in America," said Ms. Dean, the union official. "And a large metropolitan newspaper would give him that."

HEADLINE: ON BASEBALL;
Puckett Isn't Part of Sympathy Lineup

BYLINE: By Claire Smith

 BODY:
DOES Rickey Henderson make you shake with anger with his "Brother, can you spare a million?" cant?
Feel let down when that all-American fellow Ryne Sandberg stepped out of character and threatened to become a free agent after the 1992 season if the Cubs did not acquiesce on his contract demands this spring? 
 Does Barry Bonds's constant "Can I have some more, please?" sniveling make you nauseous?
Well, baseball fans, take heart. As improbable as it may seem, there is still a $3 million-a-year ballplayer you can love: Kirby Puckett of the Minnesota Twins.
Puckett has long represented everything that is good about baseball. A veritable whirling dervish on the field, his signatures are as unique as his bald, shining dome.
Close your eyes and the memories come easily, pleasantly: Kirby Puckett leaping high up on the pliable center-field fence in the Metrodome to steal away home runs. Kirby Puckett, arms pumping to propel his bowling-ball body around the bases. Kirby Puckett, winning smile constantly affixed, his joy infectious.
Those qualities are counted on, not only by Twins fans and the public but by Puckett's peers.
"If two guys ever started whining -- Kirby Puckett and Robin Yount -- that's when I take my cleats off and go home," said Don Baylor, once a teammate of Puckett's and now a coach with Yount's Milwaukee Brewers.
Have no fear, sir. The Younts, the Pucketts don't whine.
Puckett didn't gloat when he became the highest-paid player in the history of the game in November 1989, signing a three-year, $9 million contract. Nor did he pout when all sorts of players, many arguably less-talented, overtook him even before the ink even dried on his contract.
A problem? "I signed a contract; I think I should honor it," Puckett said.
The player, thoughtful and precise in his beliefs, continued.
"Money and everything is great, and we all know that, but I want to have fun at what I do," he said. "I'm fortunate to have a job that, when I was a kid, I dreamed of doing. Every day I come to the ball park I am living a dream."
So even as Henderson stayed out of camp in search of sympathy to his plight as an "underpaid" $3 million-a-year player, Puckett dutifully reported to camp in Fort Myers, Fla.
He brought with him no baseball complaints even though he's being shifted from center field to right to make room for young Shane Mack. As for his place on the money roster, he said, "a lot of people say 'aren't you upset because a lot of guys have passed you?' I'm not upset. It's just their time. Maybe when my contract's up, it will be time for me."
No one group breathes more heartfelt sighs of relief than the Twins.
"When I see a guy like Ryne Sandberg with his almost-perfect image trying to get the Cubs to meet a deadline on a deal that has two years to run, I am grateful," Andy MacPhail, the Twins' general manager, said last week. "When I see the Rickey Henderson situation, I am grateful. Kirby has never uttered the word 'renegotiation.' "
Not that Puckett wouldn't listen if the Twins wanted to extend him. He's respectful of the document, but he's not stupid. And MacPhail acknowledged a desire to do something as long ago as December 1989, after players began to leap-frog over Puckett. Nothing has happened yet.
"Things have moved so fast and are in such a state of flux we're at a loss as to what would be appropriate," MacPhail admitted. "Our payroll is about $15 million, now, and we're concerned about whether or not we can sustain that. But we're in the process of sorting things out. One thing that helps us is Kirby. Even though he's been passed by, Kirby never loses sight of the fact that he is making $3 million a year."
Instead of being driven mad by the long green as well as the green-eyed monster, Puckett is filled with a wonderful perspective. "I grew up in the ghetto in Chicago," he said. "I can feel for how the other side feels."
He talks about the recession, acknowledges that the public, caught in real-world financial dilemmas, is growing intolerant of players' complaints. Though he will not condemn other players for those complaints, Puckett cannot make himself say the same things.
Instead, he just does his job, happily part of a quiet, honorable legion of players who think that's the way to go as they wait patiently for another chance to leap on the salary escalator. Until then, Puckett simply says, "The Twins have been good to me and I don't think I'm doing too badly."
Amen to that.

HEADLINE: Gorbachev The Great

BYLINE: By Stephen F. Cohen; Stephen F. Cohen is director of Russian studies at Princeton University.

 BODY:
Six years after Mikhail Gorbachev came to power, on March 11, 1985, many commentators say his reform efforts have failed miserably. Some charge he has betrayed his betrayed his promises or that he has always been an imposter-reformer. They point to growing economic chaos and ethnic unrest, to his unpopularity at home and recent adoption of authoritarian measures. They conclude he is no longer worthy -- or never was worthy -- of our support.
This view is based on false assumptions. The first is that Mr. Gorbachev has had time to carry out his reforms and thus demonstrate his real intentions. In reality, he has undertaken the most ambitious changes in modern history. Their goal is to "dismantle" the state controls Stalin imposed and to achieve an "emancipation of society" through privatization, democratization, and federalization of the 15 republics. Such proposals were bound to face old traditions, social obstacles and political opposition. They could not have unfolded quickly or smoothly. Even if successful, they will need decades to sink roots, with traumatic setbacks along the way. 
 The second assumption is that the persistent economic problems and continuing absence of a market economy prove that Mr. Gorbachev already has failed. Perestroika is in crisis, but its achievements are remarkable. In the equivalent of a U.S. Presidential term, 1985 to 1989, despite stubborn opposition, Mr. Gorbachev legislated most of his radical proposals aimed at virtually replacing the existing system with a democratic and market system. No American President with such a record would be considered a failure.
Even more, Russia has come closer to democracy than ever before. Though democratization remains exceedingly fragile, how can this be dismissed as a failure? Mr. Gorbachev's economic policies have also made gains. Many conservatives have given up dogmatic opposition to market economy. Five million people now work in the cooperative sector. Grassroots struggles to create private enterprises are under way.
The third dubious assumption: Mr. Gorbachev has betrayed his professed goals by not allying himself with "radical democrats" led by Boris Yeltsin on the basis of a 500-day leap to a market economy; instead, he has turned to the military, K.G.B. and party to save himself.
In fact, radical democrats are few in number, weak in power and deeply divided. Moreover, their plan asked Mr. Gorbachev to inflict on tens of millions of citizens extreme anti-welfare and inflationary measures no U.S. politician would advocate.
Rapid privatizing cannot be carried out primarily from above, because the vast bureaucracy controls 90 percent of the economy and opposes it. A market economy must be carried out by millions of citizens who have been empowered to do so by Mr. Gorbachev's legislation and are willing to become risk-taking entrepreneurs. Opinion surveys show relatively few are ready to do this.
Faced with growing destabilization and opposition, Mr. Gorbachev is trying to save perestroika from collapse or overthrow by forming a coalition with new conservatives who have emerged in traditional bastions of power. While resenting the "excesses" of Mr. Gorbachev's political reforms and demanding that he hold the union together, they substantially support a market economy and even some democratization. They are not the despotic "reactionaries" Eduard Shevardnadze warned against when he resigned as Foreign Minister.
We may regret Mr. Gorbachev's new political strategy, but it is frivolous to disregard the circumstances that compelled it, and a larger truth: authentic reform will be gradual and consensual or it will be nonexistent.
The fourth false assumption is that all democratic-minded Soviet citizens oppose Mr. Gorbachev and support Mr. Yeltsin, and so must we. This generalization applies mainly to Moscow-based liberal intellectuals, from whom our media get most of their political perspectives. Many pro-democracy intellectuals in the provinces are far less radical, and large segments of the populace remain allergic to all the reforms.
Nor is it true that all Moscow democrats have fully repudiated Mr. Gorbachev. They have rightly denounced the bloodshed in the Baltics, but some have long urged him to resort to other authoritarian measures to save the reform process. Not a few mistrust Mr. Yeltsin. Do the impatient radicals who have given up on Mr. Gorbachev really understand their own political possibilities? Or are they continuing the intelligentsia's long tradition of maximalism that has undermined reform in Russian history?
None of this means Mr. Gorbachev has been a faultless leader -- only that he has entered history as a great reformer and, if Eastern Europe is included, liberator. If reform is to succeed, another and different kind of leader eventually will be needed. But for now there is no persuasive evidence that one has approached center stage or that his time has come.

HEADLINE: Careers;
Technology Help Needed In Northeast

BYLINE: By Elizabeth M. Fowler

 BODY:
AFTER a period of broad prosperity in the early 1980's, thanks mainly to the high-technology industry centered on Boston, the Northeast finds itself going through a recession more severe than that in most parts of the country.
Now hopes for recovery in the region are riding partly on biomedical and biotechnology companies, according to Dr. Jerome Krasner, professor and department head of electrical/electronic engineering technology at the Wentworth Institute of Technology in Boston. "At least these companies will keep our local economy from getting worse," he said last week, adding that some will need more engineers and technologists. 
 "My area is biomedical, not to be confused with biotechnical," Dr. Krasner said. He describes biotech as "wet chemistry," which involves processes that replicate proteins, generate artificial insulin and deal with molecular biology.
In contrast, the biomedical area is concerned with the development and operation of medical equipment, including prosthetic devices often individually tailored, monitoring units for patients in hospitals, and new methods for blood analyses. "There is a continuous demand for new types of medical devices to meet doctors' needs," he said.
"As demographics change," he added, "the focus will be more on geriatric needs of an aging population. Biomed is a multibillion-dollar business in Massachusetts alone, with some 1,500 biomedical companies here."
He called a Hewlett-Packard subsidiary "one of the biggest, having about 46 percent of the patient-monitoring market."
Others in the biomedical field in the Boston area include units of the Kendall Company, C.R. Bard Inc., as well as Ciba Corning Diagnostics Corporation, a joint venture of the big foreign chemical company and the American glass maker to make blood analysis devices.
Currently, Dr. Krasner said, the biomedical companies have to import many engineers and technologists from out of state. For example, Hewlett-Packard tends to hire those with degrees from Stanford University and the California Institute of Technology, as well as from M.I.T., with a background in mechanical or electrical engineering or computers. They learn on the job to relate their expertise to the biomedical field.
He hopes to help remedy the shortage of technology experts in the Northeast by training more people in the biomedical field at Wentworth, where he introduced a course last September called Basic Principles of Biomedical Engineering.
"We have 27 students in it now, including 7 either out of work or considering career changes," Dr. Krasner said. "One has a background in manufacturing, three are electrical engineers, one is a mechanical engineer, one is a computer expert and the seventh is a young lady who works with A.T.& T. in the communications area and who thinks biomedical technology is the wave of the future."
Wentworth is a little different from many engineering schools in that it offers an associate degree in engineering technology after two years, thus producing technologists. If students continue for two more years to take engineering technology and a variety of liberal arts courses they can earn a bachelor of science degree in engineering technology. "About 70 percent continue for this degree," Dr. Krasner said.
Wentworth's competition for producing engineers with technology backgrounds comes mainly from Purdue and Penn State, he said, adding: "We graduate about 1,000 a year with associate or bachelor of science degrees in technology, not necessarily medical technology.
"At Wentworth, we determined industry needs more engineers with hands-on experience, so we have a cooperative program in the biomedical field. And our students work at places like Children's Hospital and the New England Medical Center. I have more cooperative jobs available with hospitals and research companies than co-op students to fill them."
By "co-op students," he meant juniors and seniors who are required to work in jobs related to their studies for two semesters.
Another growing field, Dr. Krasner pointed out, is hospital risk management, in which engineers handle and repair the highly sophisticated equipment. He said the need for such engineers would increase in the fall when a new law becomes effective that requires hospitals to report the failure of equipment. The institutions may face fines if patients are injured.
Salaries for biomedical specialists with associate degrees range from $22,000 to $27,000; with a bachelor of science degree they can receive $30,000 and up. At the supervisory level, pay ranges from $52,000 to $90,000, Dr. Krasner said.

HEADLINE: Business Scene;
The 'Right' Price For Oil in the U.S.

BYLINE: By Louis Uchitelle

 BODY:
THE gulf war made one thing clear: Even with Iraq and Kuwait not producing, the Middle East can flood the world with enough oil to push crude oil prices down to $15 a barrel and perhaps lower. The United States, in sum, might find itself back in the old days of cheap oil. Is that good news for the American economy? Or would $10-a-barrel oil, once such a blessing, be a curse today?
The answers vary. Homeowners who use oil heat would applaud; so would car owners who drive a lot. The airline industry might use the savings from lower fuel bills to invest in more planes and, similarly, a United Parcel Service might buy more delivery trucks and hire more drivers. "Low oil prices stimulate investment in energy-intensive industries, and this promotes economic growth," said Michael Keran, chief economist at the Prudential Insurance Company of America. 
 But that is in the short run. Cheap oil also means rising usage and, inevitably, more oil spills that damage the environment and more engine fumes that pollute the air, raising the cost of health care. Outlays for solar energy and other alternatives to high-priced petroleum would probably be canceled or delayed. Cheap foreign oil also cuts into the profits of the American oil industry, whose production costs are so much higher than Saudi Arabia's.
"When I fill up my Toyota, the price of gasoline should reflect all the environmental, social and health costs for American society," said Eric Hirst, an expert in energy efficiency at the Oak Ridge National Laboratory in Tennessee.
There are more pros and cons. But divisive as they are, through most of them runs the suggestion of a compromise -- a price range apparently acceptable to the various interests. The compromise range is generally $17 to $23 a barrel for crude oil. Albert T. Sommers, a senior economist at the Conference Board, for example, puts the "neutral" figure for the economy at $20 a barrel.
"That balances all of the interests," he said. "It does not waste our oil reserves. It is not so high as to impair consumption. And it contributes to conservation more than a lower price."
Crude oil at over $17 a barrel might be expected to anger consumer advocates. But Edwin Rothschild, energy policy director at Citizen Action, a consumer group, says that consumers seem to accept an unleaded gasoline price of $1.10 a gallon, which comes with $20-a-barrel crude. "That is public reality," he said, adding that Citizen Action also favors conservation and less pollution -- goals achieved partly through higher-priced oil.
Free-marketeers might also be angered at attempts to keep crude oil prices above $17 a barrel, when an oversupply could drive the price well below $15, once Iraq and Kuwait return to production. One rule of thumb cited by economists holds that for every $10 decline in the price of crude oil, Americans save $60 billion a year that can be spent to improve their living standards.
But some free-market advocates also distinguish between the free-market price and the right cost of oil for the American economy. If the free market dictates a $10 price, then Americans should pay only that price to Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and other producers in the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countires, meeting this week in Geneva. Within the United States, however, an extra $10 could be raised through a tax on imported oil or some other method that channels funds into pollution control, the development of alternative fuels and the like.
The price, in effect, would be $20 a barrel, but for imported oil, half the outlay would stay at home.
The gulf war has helped to convert some economists to this view, among them Prof. Alan Blinder of Princeton University. Once an opponent of an oil surcharge, he would use a surcharge now to guarantee access to Middle Eastern oil. "My rationale is that it is a national defense surcharge, to pay for the periodic wars and other outlays that might be necessary to assure a supply of oil," he said.
There are exceptions, of course, to the view that oil should be valued within the United States at $17 to $23 a barrel. Charles DiBona, president of the American Petroleum Institute, notes that at nearly $20 a barrel today, 1,000 drilling rigs are exploring for domestic oil, while in 1981, with the price at $30 a barrel, 4,600 rigs were in action. From a different viewpoint, petrochemical companies might object to an import tax, arguing that their cost of crude, from which plastics are made, would be higher than that of overseas competitors, paying the free-market price.
But such opposition appears to be outside the mainstream view. As Daniel Yergin, president of Cambridge Energy Research Associates, put it: "I would guess that if you poll people who think of these things, they would say a range between $17 and $23 a barrel would be the healthiest for the United States economy."

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR: Egypt;
Baker Tells Cairo He'll Put in a Good Word With the I.M.F.

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CAIRO, March 11

 BODY:
Declaring that the United States is encouraged by Egypt's progress in reforming its economy, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said today that he hoped to press Cairo's case for further help from the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.
"The U.S. is frankly very encouraged by and appreciative of the efforts the Government of Egypt is making in the reform of its economy," said Mr. Baker, who met with President Hosni Mubarak and Foreign Minister Esmat Abdel-Meguid on his Middle East tour. "We would like to assist. to the extent that we can, with the I.M.F. and with the World Bank." 
 Because Egypt is expected to play an important role in the postwar era in the region, Egyptian officials have been hoping the United States can use its influence to help break a three-year-long deadlock with the I.M.F. The international lending agency has demanded a tough package of economic reforms from Cairo in return for a new loan and, more important, its imprimatur on new credits.
 
Wide-Ranging Talks
 The talks between American and Egyptian officials here today ranged widely over several areas, including the Arab-Israeli dispute and regional security in the wake of the war with Iraq. Although Mr. Baker said the discussions did not involve specific questions of aid to Egypt, he did say they covered "overall economic cooperation" in the Middle East.
Among other things, he said, there was a discussion about whether the World Bank should play a larger role in the development of the Middle East as a whole, including the possiblity of creating a regional development bank.
In response to demands from the I.M.F., which functions as a sort of clearing house to approve the creditworthiness and financial soundness of developing nations, Cairo has reduced subsidies on some consumer goods and abolished fixed interest rates on loans and desposits. Last month, Egypt also took steps to introduce a fully convertible pound, the value of which is tied to international currency markets.
But the I.M.F. has insisted that Cairo also take other steps as part of a complete package of economic reforms, including reducing Government subsidies on sales of gasoline to consumers.
 
Next Move Is Egypt's
 An official close to the I.M.F. in Washington said that the two sides were close to agreement, but that Egypt still had to come up with a final plan.
Although the United States has one-fifth of the votes on the I.M.F.'s executive board, it is not clear just what Washington can do on Egypt's behalf. "The U.S. has as much interest as the I.M.F. in making sure that the Egyptian economic program is sound and worthwhile," the official said.
Cairo has recently asked several Western governments to press the I.M.F. to ease its terms.
At the core of Cairo's economic difficulties is an external debt that was estimated at more than $50 billion before the beginning of the war with Iraq. Egypt's revenues have been further damaged as a result of the Gulf war, even thought the United States and the Arab Gulf nations helped ease Egypt's debt burden recently by forgiving some $13 billion worth of debts.
In addition to the loss of millions of dollars in income from Egyptian workers forced to flee the Gulf, Egypt has seen a decline in transit fees through the Suez Canal as a result of a decrease in shipping, and a sharp drop in tourism. Government officials estimate that Egypt has lost more than $2 billion in tourist revenues during the winter season, because visitors were afraid to travel to the region during the war.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Gold Declines in New York; Silver Prices Fall Sharply

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Prices of precious metals futures fell yesterday on the Commodity Exchange in New York as the market reacted to the dollar's strength and a decline in crude oil prices.
Gold settled $5 to $5.20 lower. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery fell $5 an ounce to settle at $364.70. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid for gold of $365.00, off $4.50. 
 Silver prices fell sharply in what traders called a technical correction. Since the end of the Persian Gulf war, prices had advanced about 70 cents from an 18-year low.
 
Correction Was Expected
 Silver had advanced in recent weeks, based partly on speculation that the end of the war would speed an economic recovery in the United States and bolster demand from industrial users.
Analysts said a correction in silver prices was expected after recent gains.
Bette Raptopoulos, an analyst with Prudential Securities Inc. in New York, said gold futures fell as the dollar strengthened and crude oil prices eased.
Copper futures declined sharply on the Comex, reflecting what brokers called internal market influences. Copper was 1 to 2.35 cents lower, with the March contract at $1.0990 a pound.
 
Grain and Soybeans Off
 Grain and soybean futures prices closed lower on the Chicago Board of Trade as weekend rains in Brazil and lagging export business weighed on the market.
Soybean futures were under pressure as a result of widespread rain in southern Brazil during the weekend. Joel Karlin, an analyst with Research Department Inc. in Chicago, said it was unclear how the unexpectedly heavy late-season rainfall affected that nation's crop. But it is likely that areas of Brazil that planted late will benefit.
Corn and wheat futures were pushed lower by spillover selling, with wheat also under pressure by forecasts of rain at midweek in the Plains States.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Moderately Higher Despite Central Bank Moves

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar made moderate gains yesterday against foreign currencies despite two concerted efforts by central banks to rein in the postwar advance.
Central banks in Europe, apparently with the exception of France's bank, aggressively sold dollars to try to drive down the value of the American currency and curb a flurry of buying by overseas investors, traders said. 
 The Federal Reserve later joined a second round of interventions when exchanges in the United States opened to another burst of buying.
The unified selloffs helped knock the dollar off its highs for the day. The dollar, which traders said peaked at 1.5870 German marks earlier in the Unitied States session, ended at 1.5815 marks.
But traders said the interventions failed for the most part to curb the market's widespread belief that postwar euphoria has primed the United States for an economic recovery.
The advance came despite two factors on Friday -- a negative unemployment report and declining interest rates -- that would ordinarily drive down the dollar.
"The underlying bullish sentiment is definitely prevailing," said Marc Cohen, a vice president in foreign exchange at Fuji Bank Ltd. in New York.
Continued skittishness about unrest in the Soviet Union also supported the dollar's advance by pushing down the German mark. Traders said they were worried about the possibility of losses on German loans to the Soviet Union and about the chances that Germany's economy could suffer from unrest in neighboring countries by forcing it to absorb refugees.
Weekend demonstrations were held throughout the Soviet Union attacking President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and calling for his resignation.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.8505, from $1.8720 late Friday. The pound also slipped in New York, where 1 fetched $1.8515, less expensive than $1.8645 late friday.
Earlier in Tokyo, the dollar closed at 138.07 yen, up 1.77 yen from the Friday close of 136.30 yen. Monday's close was the highest since the dollar bought 138.30 yen on Sept. 12. Later, in London, the yen was quoted at 138.05.
In New York, the dollar settled at 138.20 yen, up from 136.82 on Friday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with the late Friday rates, included: 1.3705 Swiss francs, up from 1.3692; 5.3845 French francs, up from 5.3515; 1,180.00 Italian lire, up from 1,174.00, and 1.1558 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1614.
Other late dollar rates in Europe included: 1.5800 German marks, up from 1.5625; 1.3710 Swiss francs, up from 1.3640; 5.3795 French francs, up from 5.3210; 1.7810 Dutch guilders, up from 1.7610; 1,179.75 Italian lire, up from 1,167.50, and 1.1555 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1618.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR: Israel;
Israelis Kill 6 Armed Arabs Entering From Jordan

BYLINE: By JOEL BRINKLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, March 11

 BODY:
Israeli troops shot and killed six heavily armed Arab gunmen who had crossed the border from Jordan this morning, hours before Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d arrived for talks intended to foster Arab-Israeli peace, officials said.
The army said the guerrillas were the largest and best-armed group to attempt entry from Jordan in memory. They carried automatic rifles, rocket-propelled grenade launchers and dynamite. Three Israeli soldiers suffered slight or moderate wounds in the two-hour gun battle near kibbutz Tirat Zvi, just south of the Sea of Galilee. 
 Brig. Gen. Yitzhak Mordechai, commander of the area, said the army believed the guerrillas, like the Palestinian who stabbed and killed four Israeli women Sunday evening, intended "to perpetrate a grandiose attack before the American Secretary of State."
The killings bring to 10 the number of deaths during the last 24 hours in violence related to Mr. Baker's visit.
The number could actually be 12 if an incident in the Gaza Strip this evening proves to have been deliberate, not accidental. A Gaza resident ran down an army patrol just outside Gaza City, killing two soldiers and wounding two, the army said. The driver fled.
"We don't know what happened yet," an army officer said. "We still don't know if it was an accident."
 
Visit to Old City Canceled
 While still in Cairo, State Department officials announced that Mr. Baker had canceled his tour of Jerusalem's Old City, which had been scheduled for this afternoon, because they believed the situation here was too tense. The army had already closed off Jerusalem to all Palestinians.
Despite the growing violence, the office of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir reiterated today that the Government had no plans to show any new flexibility to Mr. Baker.
 
Soviet Emigre Among Dead
 If, through Mr. Baker, "the Arabs come and tell us that territory is the primary objective of negotiations," said Yossi Ben Aharon, the Prime Minister's chief of staff, "it is a sign that they are not really aiming for peace."
Mr. Ben Aharon said the deaths had only hardened Israel's view, while Israelis of the political left said the killings showed that Israel must compromise with the Arabs and make peace to end the violence.
The deaths "show the need of Israel to be strong and to be capable of dealing with these threats to the safety and the security of these people," he said.
As he spoke, funerals were under way for the four Israeli women stabbed and killed Sunday by an Arab assailant from Gaza. Among them was Bela Levitsky, 60 years old, who had immigrated from the Soviet Union two months ago.
"We had heard about the intifada" before the move, Mrs. Levitsky's daughter-in-law Jana, said through tears at the funeral. "But we had never imagined it would reach us. She had really wanted to immigrate to Israel and be with her children here."
 
Sharon Sheds Immigration Role
 Israeli officials and Soviet immigration specialists have been openly worrying that the tense security situation, and deep cuts in economic benefits for immigrants, might dissuade thousands of Soviet Jews from moving to Israel.
In the last two days, the Israeli press has been filled with vivid pictures showing hundreds of recent Soviet immigrants rooting through the garbage at an outdoor market, looking for food.
As a result of these and many other problems, Housing Minister Ariel Sharon announced that he was resigning as the nation's "immigration czar" because of what he called the Government's "total failure" to provide jobs, housing or adequate benefits for the immigrants. He will remain as Housing Minister but will no longer be in charge of coordinating the overall immigration strategy.
Mr. Sharon complained that the Government was unsupportive and inattentive to the immigrants' plight.
 
'Baker, Go Home!'
 During demonstrations this afternoon at the site of the knife attack, protesters debated Mr. Baker's visit.
"Baker, go home!" one man shouted. "You want to give them a country?"
Sooner or later, Israelis expect the United States to ask them to give up territory in exchange for peace. An opinion survey published in Yedioth Aharonoth today shows the public evenly divided on whether Israel should trade land for peace; 49 percent favor the idea and 49 percent oppose it.
Another demonstrator this afternoon belonged to the other camp.
Zvi Ginsburg, who carried a placard advocating capital punishment for the killer, said Mr. Baker's trip was positive. "He should try to convince the Likud and the other people who make the decisions right now that to negotiate we must give up territories. Otherwise we and our children and our grandchildren will have to live in war. We must come to an understanding with the Arabs."

HEADLINE: Virgin Atlantic Cutting Fares

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: LONDON, March 11

 BODY:
Virgin Atlantic Airways said today that it was cutting its trans-Atlantic fares by 15 percent and offering other promotional fares. Certain New York flights are being offered for as little as $184 one way.
The 15 percent cuts are in celebration of the Government's decision to open access to Heathrow Airport to new airlines, the carrier said. 
 The cuts apply immediately to full economy and advance- purchase fares on flights out of Gatwick Airport to New York, Miami and Los Angeles through the summer. A one- way full-economy flight to New York on a weekend would be cut cut to $558 from $657.
Virgin Atlantic said it hoped to start service from Heathrow to New York, Los Angeles and Tokyo in June.
On its special promotions, Virgin Atlantic is cutting its New York fare to $184 each way until April 1. From April 1 to June 30, its round-trip promotional fares will be cut to $556 from $692 for New York; to $649 from $817 for Miami, and to $742 from $939 for Los Angeles.
