HEADLINE: Low Oil Prices Are Bad, Some U.S. Experts Say

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD, Special to The New York Times

 BODY:
American oil experts are closely watching a fractious OPEC as it meets in its first session since the Persian Gulf war, with many hoping for the same things that some OPEC members want: a new agreement that will hold down production, so prices will stabilize or rise.
Saudi Arabia, Venezuela and other members abandoned all production restraints during the war to stop prices from getting out of control. Now that the war is over, they are arguing over who should cut back and by how much. 
 Government officials have said at various times that the United States does not have a target oil price, and that this country favors prices in the range of $18 to $20 a barrel. Before the war in the gulf, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries set a target price of $21 a barrel, which would mean prices in this country of closer to $23, but OPEC was well shy of that price when the target was set, and exceeded it last year only because of the war.
 
Paying for the War
 Theodore Eck, the chief economist of the Amoco Corporation, said: "The signal has been, we understand that OPEC exporting countries have to pay for the war, the cleanup and all this kind of stuff, and they're going to need some money."
In fact, regardless of any signaling by this country, many of the oil companies are hoping for a price in the OPEC target range to bolster domestic drilling. So are people in businesses linked economically to oil companies and to the economies of oil-producing regions in this country.
But the organization, by its own calculation, is producing substantially more oil than the world demands, raising the prospect that prices will fall. While the Bush Administration has not publicly articulated the point, many analysts contend that this is bad for the United States.
"Prices may fall to the mid-teens, and this is a disaster for the United States," said Charles Ebinger, an energy expert at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, in Washington. "What we're likely to see at those kind of prices is a further erosion of domestic oil-producing capacity, and rising imports, precisely from the region where we just saw this conflict," he said. "We are setting ourselves up for a situation where in 5 to 10 years imports will be 60 to 70 percent of our consumption."
 
Encouragement to Consume
 Wilfrid L. Kohl, the director of the international energy program at the Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies, said that the impact of a price decline on this country "depends on where you sit," with consumers benefiting and producers suffering. But if the price stays down, he said, "it encourages consumption again, which we certainly don't want to do." And with no agreement now, he said, it will be harder still when Kuwait and Iraq eventually repair the damage to their oil industries and resume exports.
Not everyone agrees that a new OPEC accord is desirable for this country, or even of much importance. Philip K. Verleger Jr., a fellow at the Institute for International Economics, said stocks were too low and companies would not build inventories until the price of oil on the spot market was sharply lower than the price offered on the futures market for delivery one year hence. That price has lately been around $18.50, and re-stocking would occur if the price for immediate delivery hit $15.50, he said.
Mr. Eck of Amoco said that to him, world demand and world supply seemed pretty much in balance. "The end of the war was a non-event," he said, speaking of the effect on oil supplies. Spring usually brings a global decline in demand of about 2 million barrels a day, he said, but this year, maintenance work in the North Sea, which is outside OPEC's control, will push down production there.
In previous years, he added, a spring price decline occurs because the Soviet Union increases exports in that season. But noting that country's economic decline, he added, "this year, who knows?"

HEADLINE: Weicker, Citing Union Delay, Says More Staff May Be Cut

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HARTFORD, March 11

 BODY:
Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. said today that unions representing state workers had failed to give any "positive response" in negotiations over givebacks to reduce Connecticut's budget deficit and that he would re-examine his budget plan for further cuts in personnel.
A spokeswoman for the Governor added that everything would be considered for the fiscal year beginning July 1, including layoffs above the 1,100 he estimated in his budget address last month. 
 Mr. Weicker has asked the unions to accept a pay freeze and other benefit reductions, totaling about $400 million. Today's announcement came as his plan for an income tax on wages was also about to face its first major tests in the General Assembly.
Two alternative budget plans, one proposed by Republicans, the other by Democrats, are moving through the Assembly, and neither includes an income tax.
Mr. Weicker, an independent governor with no members of his own party in the Legislature, has argued that the wage tax, however unpopular it may be, is the only way to fill a $2.4 billion shortfall in state revenues and still allow cuts in business taxes that he says are necessary to stimulate the state's economy.
His budget plan , announced last month, also counted on cutting about $700 million from the spending plans made formulated last year by state agencies, and also on $400 million in pay and benefit reductions from the state's 50,000 employees.
 
Unions Urge Long Talks
 Discussions with the unions have produced no agreements, and Mr. Weicker's abrupt announcement today came after union officials proposed a long-term schedule of discussions that would extend into April.
"Unfortunately, the budget crisis does not permit for protracted dialogue on the size or shape of the table," he Mr. Weicker said. "As of 3:30 P.M. today, I am going back into the budget to address personnel matters."
A spokesman for the union coalition, Robert J. Krzys, said state employees were not trying to delay the talks, process, but rather trying to "crystallize them discussions and move them forward." He said an extended timetable was necessary because so many union contracts were already signed and would have to be re opened. "We're not going to get anywhere by not talking," he said.
Mr. Weicker's budget would cut the 8 percent sales tax, now the highest statewide rate in the nation, almost in half, to 4.25 percent, but greatly expand the goods and services subject to it.
The plan would also reduce the corporate profits tax to 11.5 percent from 13.8 percent. The state's 7 percent tax on capital gains and the tax on interest and dividend income, which peaks at 14 percent for income over $100,000, would be eliminated.
Instead, all income, including capital gains and dividends and interest, would be treated alike, taxed at a 6 percent flat rate on all income over $25,000 for a family or $12,500 for an individual.
The Democrats' alternative plan, being formed this week by the leaders of the Finance, Revenue and Bonding Committee, would leave Mr. Weicker's spending cuts mostly in place, including the $400 million in employee reductions. Instead of an income tax, the sales tax would be greatly expanded to include many items not now taxed.
 
Taxing Gasoline and Utilities
 The final list has not been agreed on, but the preliminary list includes an 8 percent tax on everything from gasoline and to all household utility bills, including heating oil and electricity.
Extending the sales tax to cover brokerage commissions on for sales of real estate and stock, and also rent for commercial buildings, is also being considered. Another proposal in the committee would raise the dividends and interest tax to a peak of 15 percent.
The Republicans' plan will not be completed until April, after the formal public comment is over, but they say that it will include some constitutional cap on spending growth and some unspecified tax increases.

HEADLINE: A State's Fight to Save Babies Enters Round 2

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: INDIANOLA, Miss.

 BODY:
Mississippi has turned infant mortality statistics that were once the nation's worst into those that many states envy. But now comes the hard part.
Much of the progress has come from an unusually generous expansion of medical insurance for poor women, allowing them to get regular prenatal care and be hospitalized when their children are born. But while medical insurance addresses one cause of infant death, lack of access to health care, it does not address others. 
 Mothers who eat poorly, smoke or drink during pregnancy risk having babies who are sick or who die. So do mothers who become pregnant at too young an age, or who do not allow adequate time between their pregnancies. So do those whose children return to rundown homes, where the risk of disease is high. And many women are caught in webs of poverty and chaos that keep them from seeking out care, even when it is available.
 
A Second Set of Programs
 To address these problems, Mississippi is starting a second, and in some ways more uncertain, set of initiatives, based not in hospitals but in homes. One experimental program sends teams of nurses, nutritionists and social workers into the homes of high-risk mothers to promote healthy behavior. Other programs organize women as peer counselors and try to establish health networks among community leaders.
"We've largely fixed the part about providing access to care," said Dr. Alfio Rausa, the regional health officer, who has worked in the Mississippi Delta since 1966. "We're getting into areas of basic living: having a good roof over your head, a stove to cook on, getting the food to cook, and cooking it. It's fundamental."
To encourage such efforts, the Bush Administration has said it will award $171 million next year, up from $57.4 million this year, to communities with great need and promising approaches. Critics have called that a paltry sum and have denounced the Administration for proposing to take much of the money from other maternal health programs. Officials in Mississippi fear that their Federal financing may be cut to help pay for the Administration's proposal.
The politics of infant mortality caused the White House embarrassment last year after the disclosure that it had ignored the recommendations of an internal study group that called for $500 million in additional spending.
The short life of C. L. Briggs helps illustrate the forces these community programs must confront. Medicaid, the insurance plan that Mississippi has expanded, paid for the hospitalization that brought him through a premature birth. But a hard home life caused by decades of poverty contributed to his early death.
His mother, Betty Briggs, is a farm laborer's daughter with a sixth-grade education who grew up in a succession of wooden shacks where 5 of her 12 siblings died in infancy. Now 34 years old, she is single, unemployed and raising her four other children on a welfare grant of $168 a month.
She said C. L.'s problems began during her pregnancy, when her father shot at her during an argument, causing her to flee and fall. She thinks this contributed to C. L's birth a month premature at 5.5 pounds.
Medicaid paid for his hospital care, perhaps saving his life. But C. L.'s problems continued when he returned to a home where adult nutrition runs low -- meals of neck bone and Kool-Aid are common -- and the risk of disease is high. He caught pneumonia from Ms. Briggs's mother and died in January, one day short of a half-year old.
Ms. Briggs has preserved his memory in five dim Polaroids of his cradle-sized coffin.
"I feel like dying myself," said Ms. Briggs, who keeps the pictures hidden inside a stereo receiver so she will not be tempted to look at them. "It entered my mind that God might want to punish me for something I didn't do right. Every time I look at the pictures, I cry."
And for Ms. Briggs, the threat of infant death is not yet over. She is pregnant again and unable to stop smoking a daily pack of hand-rolled King Albert cigarettes.
 
A Drop, but Not Enough
 The rate of infant death in the United States has dropped every year for decades, in part because of new medical technologies. But the rate has not dropped fast enough to meet the goals of the Public Health Service. And the fact that 19 other countries have better rates remains what many have called a mark of national shame.
One reason that infants die in such numbers is that many women still lack access to care. While Mississippi's expanded Medicaid program has left only 6 percent of the state's pregnant women with no insurance, most other states have not been as generous. And even women with Medicaid can have difficulties getting care because some doctors refuse to accept the insurance, saying the pay is too low and the risk of problem deliveries and malpractice lawsuits too high.
As recently as 1965, when Congress created Medicaid, black babies in Mississippi died at a rate of 54.4 for every 1,000 births, by far the nation's worst. By 1988, the last year for which figures are available, the state's black infant mortality rate of 16.1 was better than the national average. Any death before a child's first birthday is included.
The death rate for white babies in Mississippi has also improved considerably, from 24.5, close to the nation's worst, to 8.7, just slightly worse than the national average of 8.5. The fact that the state ranks worse than average as a whole simply reflects its large black population.
 
Advice Not Followed
 But as Mississippi turns its attention beyond its proliferation of orange-striped Medicaid cards, it is fighting problems that may be even harder to fix. Health care workers here say it is often difficult to get poor women to follow their advice, either because they fail to understand its importance or they lack the resources to comply.
In Rosedale, Miss., they point to the case of Shonta Fitzgerald, who has six children, no husband and a 10th-grade education. She developed problems during her fourth pregnancy, when she was 19, and doctors told her she should remain in bed.
But Ms. Fitzgerald said she felt bored and uncomfortable in bed and ignored the advice. Her daughter, Shaneka, was born two months prematurely, weighing 3 pounds, with kidney problems that contributed to her death at age 2. "I hate that I didn't lay in bed with her when I was pregnant," Ms. Fitzgerald said.
To monitor situations like Ms. Fitzgerald's, the state has started the Perinatal High-Risk Management Program, putting high-risk mothers under the watch of a nutritionist, a social worker and a nurse. "The idea is to chaperone people through their pregnancy," said Dr. Rausa, the regional health officer.
Few people here speak more highly of the program than Rosie Scott, a 38-year-old school librarian who lives in a hamlet called Gunnison.
Her previous four pregnancies had ended in two miscarriages, one still-born birth and one ambulance dash to Memphis, where she delivered a 2-pound son saved by 70 days in intensive care. The unpaid hospitalization bill exceeded $100,000.
Ms. Scott's husband works for the county but does not receive health insurance for his family. So, she faced all the pregnancies without health insurance because as recently as 1985 women here had to be single and earn less than 39 percent of the poverty income standard to qualify for Medicaid. Now the state provides insurance to single and married women, and allows their families to earn up to 185 percent of the poverty line, or $1,408 a month for a family of four.
During her most recent pregnancy, which was covered by Medicaid, Ms. Scott said she saw her doctor much more often than when she had to pay $40 in cash for each visit. She also saw a parade of health care workers in her home, as her case managers made about 10 visits.
 
First Healthy Delivery
 Under their instruction, Ms. Scott, who suffers from high blood pressure, began soaking her cold cuts to rid of them of salt, began avoiding margarine and began taking special vitamins. At their urging, she quit her job and remained in bed during the most dangerous stage of her pregnancy.
It ended with an 8-pound-10.5-ounce portrait of health named Jokomis, in her first healthy delivery in 18 years. Would it have happened without the program? "I doubt it," she said. "I don't think they've started something better yet."
Other approaches are also being tested here, including ones that use laymen rather than trained professionals. The Freedom From Hunger Foundation, based in Davis, Calif., is testing two such models.
One, called the Community Health Advisory Network, tries to identify people in low-income neighborhoods, from preachers to homemakers, to train in basic health and nutrition. The idea is to turn social relationships into networks that might help solve health problems -- by making referrals to state agencies, offering transportation and urging good eating habits.
A second project sends paraprofessionals, often single young mothers themselves, directly into poor women's homes as a sort of all-purpose pregnancy counselor.
 
'It Made a Difference'
 The program includes a lesson plan that is not immune to recitation. On several recent visits, counselors read from textbooks while young mothers followed along, appearing more dutiful than engaged.
"When you say 'No, no,' always be firm," explained Ida Potlow to her client, Alice Banks, 23. During 30 minutes of such instruction, Ms. Banks nodded often and said little.
Asked later to name the benefits of the program, Ms. Banks quickly named several. For one, she said she ate better. Then she tried to explain something about the importance of simply having someone to talk to during a difficult time that was marked by feuding with her mother.
But this story broke off, interrupted by tears and protests that the recollection was too painful.
Then she added this about Ms. Potlow, pointing to what may be the program's biggest benefit: "You have someone who's been through what you are going through. It made a difference."

HEADLINE: A Standoff As OPEC Talks Open

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GENEVA, March 11

 BODY:
OPEC ministers, after jousting with one another today over cutting oil production quotas, failed to reach an accord and scheduled another meeting for Tuesday morning.
Officials of Saudi Arabia, which spent some $50 billion in the war against Iraq and invested huge sums to expand oil production, said at the tense session that they did not want to be pressured into cutting output. 
 Several other members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, notably Iran, asserted that an oil glut was developing and that prices would collapse unless members, particularly Saudi Arabia, made substantial cuts. Saudi Arabia is by far OPEC's leading exporter.
 
First Postwar Meeting
 The meeting in Switzerland that began today was the first OPEC gathering since the end of the Persian Gulf war and was called to discuss postwar production and pricing.
Iraq did not send an oil official to today's meeting, leaving Iran as the group's most powerful price hawk. In the view of some experts here, the meeting could boil down to a test of wills between Teheran and Riyadh.
The "atmosphere is not very easy," said the Iranian oil minister, Gholam Rezah Aghazadeh.
Despite the standoff, several officials said the meeting might conclude with an informal accord to cut output to help keep oil prices from collapsing, even if a formal accord could not be reached. Saudi officials asserted that a production-cutting pact would be premature since there was no formal cease-fire in the Persian Gulf and the region remained in flux.
 
Price Slides 32 Cents
 After remarks here Sunday by the Saudi oil minister, Hisham Nazer, that his nation was reluctant to cut production, oil prices slid today in trading in London and New York. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, crude oil for April delivery closed 32 cents lower, at $18.99 a barrel.
Many OPEC members have expressed eagerness to reaffirm the $21-a-barrel target price set last July and have said that substantial cuts will be needed to achieve that price.
The organization's secretariat predicted today that demand for OPEC oil would be 21.4 million barrels a day in the second quarter, down from 23.1 million barrels in the first quarter. Oil experts estimate that OPEC's 13 members pumped 23 million barrels a day in February.
Saudi officials, however, estimate that demand for OPEC oil will be a generous 22.5 million barrels a day in the second quarter, as the United States rebounds from recession and Soviet oilfield troubles and miners' strikes cut into Soviet oil exports.
Nonetheless, several OPEC officials and oil analysts here suggested that the meeting might conclude with a loose agreement in which Saudi Arabia agreed to scale back production along with the other countries that have substantially increased output since Iraq invaded Kuwait.
 
Saudis' Tougher Stand
 But even an informal pact could get tripped up, oil analysts here said, because Saudi Arabia, newly emboldened by the victory over Baghdad, does not want to absorb the bulk of the production cuts.
The United Arab Emirates, Venezuela and Iran lifted their output by slightly more than a million barrels a day to compensate for the loss of 4 million barrels day of oil resulting from the embargo on Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil. Saudi Arabia has raised its output by 3 million barrels a day, to about 8.3 milliion barrels.
The Nigerian oil minister, Jibril Aminu, called for a production ceiling of 21 million barrels a day. Several officials said that would help push prices back to OPEC's target price of $21 a barrel.
The pivotal issue, many oil experts here say, is how much Saudi Arabia produces. Some ministers would like Saudi production to drop to 7 million barrels a day or even lower, from 8.3 million barrels at present, but Saudi officials say they are reluctant to go below 7.6 million barrels a day and will rein in production only if others join in.

HEADLINE: Dinkins Vows Broader Role In Fiscal Issues

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins, facing criticism that his administration's fiscal policy was adrift, vowed yesterday to take a "much further personal involvement" in "all areas" of managing the city's fiscal affairs.
Mr. Dinkins's comments, made to reporters at City Hall, were an effort to regroup after a tumultuous week of staff disputes, labor unrest and fiscal confusion that ended with the forced resignation of his Labor Relations Commissioner. 
 "What I'm suggesting is that I will spend more time, not with minutiae, not so as to bog down or slow down the process, but to get information more quickly, because I'm at the table more often," the Mayor said.
Mr. Dinkins's remarks suggested a shift in a management style that critics said amounted to presiding over, rather than controlling, his administration. But, when asked if he felt compelled to double-check his staff's discussions or to rein in staff members, the Mayor said, "I just think that my presence can be useful."
 
Need to Take Control
 Mr. Dinkins made his remarks after a weekend of news coverage that stressed the need for him to take control, or as a front-page headline in New York Newsday put it yesterday, "Stand Up and Act Like a Mayor." The headline paraphrased the complaints of municipal union leaders that Mr. Dinkins had not taken a forceful enough role in working with them and others on a comprehensive fiscal plan.
The Mayor's chief political aide, Deputy Mayor Bill Lynch, said the efforts would range from meeting more often with his commissioners -- something Mr. Dinkins has long said he intends to do but has largely not done -- to talking with outside advisers. In recent days, the Mayor's senior aides have said he intended to work more closely with outside fiscal and management advisers, including business, labor and civic leaders, whom he already relies on to help devise cooperative solutions to the city's problems.
First Deputy Mayor Norman Steisel said: "We have not yet concluded what's the best way to do that. Clearly, there is a need. We're thinking of a number of ways."
Mr. Dinkins, when asked if his comments meant that he would take back authority he had delegated to aides, said: "No, no. It's not possible to run a corporation with a budget of $29 billion and a quarter-million people and on and on without some delegation, obviously."
"Now it is not useful for the Mayor to be there all the time, even if the Mayor had nothing whatever else to do," he said. If the Mayor is involved in every negotiation or dispute, he said, "you've got no place to buck it, you've got no court of appeal."
Mr. Dinkins said his Council of Economic Advisers, a group that includes primarily local business executives, and his Management Advisory Task Force, which includes executives, former government officials and union leaders, would be involved in his stepped up efforts.
But even as he vowed to take a stronger hand in seeking cooperation on the city's fiscal problems, one union leader warned him not to expect an easy time.
Sandra Feldman, president of the United Federation of Teachers and an important early backer of the Mayor, wrote in her column in the union's current newsletter that despite its agreement last fall on a 5.5 percent pay raise for teachers, the administration should not assume the union would be content when that contract expires in September.
"As far as I'm concerned," Ms. Feldman wrote, "5.5 percent was not good enough, not enough to attract and retain the best and brightest educators for the kids of this city. So fiscal crisis or not, we will, at the appropriate time, go out there and wage a bitter battle for a better contract.
 
'A Multiyear Solution'
 Ms. Feldman said the union, which agreed to defer some of the recent raise to save the city $40 million in the short term, said it would not grant another deferral.
But in a telephone interview she did say the union would be willing to negotiate ways to help the city confront its fiscal problems.
"If there were the possibility of sitting down to a multiyear solution and plan, there are lot of things that we could do, though I'm not going to get specific here. We could be very creative in a multiyear situation.
"A multiyear plan," she said, "is absolutely essential. Otherwise you have a constant crisis, from budget to budget."

HEADLINE: High-Tech Stocks Lead Market Decline

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
High-tech stocks tumbled yesterday in heavy trading, and the broader market weakened as well despite clear signs that the Federal Reserve eased monetary policy over the weekend.
Analysts forecast that because of the slow economy the Fed might have further declines in interest rates in the works. . 
 The Dow Jones industrial average slid 15.84, to 2,939.36, with declines leading advances, 3 to 2.
New York Stock Exchange volume dipped to 161.6 million shares, from 206.9 million Friday. Birinyi Associates said program selling knocked only 8 points off the Dow.
Still, money seems to be pouring steadily into the market.
Indata, an investment service in Stamford, Conn., said cash held by 54 stock funds it tracks dropped in the week ended March 8 to 9.9 percent of $22.4 billion in investments from 10.1 percent two weeks earlier. On that basis $448 million in new mutual fund money came into stocks over that period, for an average of almost $45 million a day for the 10 trading days.
Forty-four stocks rose to new highs, including Morrison-Knudsen, which tacked on 2 1/8, to 59 5/8, after a new high of 60 3/4. It said on Friday that it had joined with a Kuwaiti company to help rebuild the country.
Over-the-counter stocks, as measured by the Nasdaq composite index, sank 1.7 percent, or nearly 50 Dow points, because of a big selloff in computer and other high-tech stocks.
The Pacific Stock Exchange index that measures the performance of high-tech stocks slid 2.3 percent.
A big part of the high-tech decline was attributed to Thomas Kurlak and Daniel Mandresh, Merrill Lynch analysts.
Mr. Kurlak, who for three years has recommended Intel, the semiconductor producer, downgraded the stock to "neutral." Mr. Mandresh downgraded I.B.M. from "strong buy" to "above average." Traders reasoned that what held for these two market leaders also held for other high-flying technology stocks.
I.B.M. slipped 2 1/8, to 129 1/8, on 1.8 million shares while Intel topped the Nasdaq list of the 10-most-active over-the-counter stocks, sinking 5 3/4, or 11 percent, to 45 3/4, with 8.8 million shares changing hands.
Microsoft, No. 2 on the Nasdaq active list, slumped 3 1/4, to 99 1/4, on 2.3 million shares. Traders attributed the drop to the Merrill Lynch downgrades, although a Federal court ruled on Friday that parts of displays used by Apple Computer were not licensed to Microsoft or Hewlett-Packard.
Apple lost 1 1/2, to 63 1/2, while Hewlett rose 3/8, to 49 1/4.

Tokyo Stocks Advance
 TOKYO, Tuesday, March 12 (Reuters) -- Stocks in Tokyo closed higher today. At the end of trading, the Nikkei index of 225 issues was up 58.05 points, or 0.22 percent, to 26,727.42.

HEADLINE: Facing Cuts, Arts Lobbyists Plan to Alter Their Approach in Albany

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN

 BODY:
"Nuts to cuts!" say the placards and banners being carried by some 200 lobbyists to Albany for Arts Day today.
"If we don't cut the arts, then what do we cut?" Anne Crowley, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's press secretary, said yesterday. "There's a $6 billion deficit. Every area of the budget has to be reduced. What's the alternative? Cutting more from assistance to crippled children, the school budget?" 
 What has stirred both sides is Governor Cuomo's proposed 56 percent cut in support for the New York State Council on the Arts, coupled with the 17.5 percent reduction in the city culture budget recommended by Mayor David N. Dinkins. The proposed cuts are the largest faced by arts institutions since the creation of the New York State Council on the Arts in 1960.
For their part, the lobbyists plan to drop their familiar sentimental "the arts tell us who we are" pitches of the past in favor of what they consider to be more politically sophisticated arguments about economic impact, education and equal treatment.
"What we're fighting for," State Senator Roy M. Goodman, Republican of Manhattan, said at a rally last week, "is not simply the enduring contributions which the arts make to mankind, but for the arts as a giant magnet which attracts to New York City and State the people who go to our hotels and restaurants, who build our sales-tax base."
But not everyone accepts the economic-impact argument. "It kind of begs the question this year," said William Stevens, a spokesman for Senator Ralph J. Marino, Republican of Long Island who is the majority leader. "The question this year is what the state can afford to do."
Arts advocates have also been quick to point out that cultural institutions are being more roughly handled in the Governor's proposed budget than other comparable areas of state service. For example, the State University is reduced by only 2.5 percent, and parks and recreation by 19.5 percent.
"The one thing legislators understand," said Nathan Leventhal, president of Lincoln Center and a former deputy mayor, "is that somebody is being picked on. We're distributing leaflets not saying 'Don't cut' but 'Cut us in proportion.' "
 
Cows or Lambs?
 Senator William J. Larkin Jr., Republican of New Windsor and another member of the budget subcommittee, agreed. "The Governor said we don't want any sacred cows," he said, "and that's true, but we also don't want any sacrificial lambs."
Mindy Duitz, director of the Brooklyn Children's Museum and an active member of the Cultural Institutions Group, an umbrella organization of 32 arts groups, said recently, "When we visit public officials, we always make a point of the fact that four million schoolchildren a year are served by C.I.G. groups in special, formal programs."
"Arts institutions aren't just icing on the cake," said Senator David A. Paterson, Democrat of Harlem. "They keep youth off the streets where they get a different kind of education."
It is possible for a state or city legislator to concede all these arguments and still support a reduction in the culture budget. The deficits, after all, have to be made up from somewhere. Consequently, the question, many city and state elected officials privately concede, is not whether, but how much. The outcome, they say, will depend largely on the intensity and effectiveness of the campaign now being waged by the arts lobby.
Governor Cuomo's provisional budget, announced in late January, calls for reducing the outlay for the state arts council by nearly $25 million from its present level of $46.7 million, bringing it down to $21.9 million.

HEADLINE: Auction Houses Are Being Drawn To Unified Germany

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BERLIN, March 11

 BODY:
The man who will represent Sotheby's in Berlin spends a lot of time conferring with builders these days. The newest outpost of the London auction house is a soaring neo-classical palace, just off the boulevard Unter den Linden, that bears the burden of Prussian history on its walls. Built by a merchant in the 18th century, it was bequeathed to Frederick the Great when business failed. Transformed into the Prussian Finance Ministry in the 19th century, it became the seat of the Soviet-German Friendship Society when the Red Army marched into Berlin and planted Communist rulers in the eastern portion of the city.
But now, with Germany reunited, Barclays Bank and Salomon Brothers have moved in, and when the carpenters, masons and painters are done, so too will Sotheby's. For if the recession is hurting auction business in England and America, Germany's economy booms, and with it trade in art and collectibles. With the Berlin wall gone, Sotheby's and its rival, Christie's, which has set up shop in western Berlin, are poised to acquire art treasures hidden for decades during Communist rule. 
 "With the breach of the wall it was urgently necessary that we come here," said H. Josef Konig, director of Sotheby's new Berlin office, "since you have the large area of East Germany, and Berlin is no longer an isolated city. Naturally, the turn from Communism was the spark for all of this."
 
Contrasting Sites
 Both Sotheby's and Christie's have been in Germany since the 1970's. If their move to Berlin signals the city'srevival as a major art center, after London and Paris, their new addresses also say something about lingering divisions in this outwardly reunited metropolis. Christie's chose a safe setting just off the fashionable Kurfurstendamm, alongside established dealers like Westphal and fashionable shops like Fendi and Cartier. By contrast, Sotheby's plunge into the East mirrors beliefs by Mr. Konig, not a Berliner at all but from Munich, that the former old center of the city will live. Clearly, both houses are convinced that the flow of art from the impoverished East to the wealthy West will accelerate.
Sotheby's has opened an office in Budapest and plans an office in Prague. While Christie's has no plans for other new offices, Jorg-Michael Bertz, Christie's director in Germany, said that Berlin's eastern location makes it the ideal staging area for the entire region.
"Geographically, you are already there," Mr. Bertz said. "Distancesare negligible, and it's nothing to fly from here to Prague or elsewhere."
The galleries themselves will offer a sampling of what the auction houses do. Sotheby's began its activities last fall with a showing of modern masters like Matisse, Kandinsky and Modigliani at the brilliant Charlottenburg Palace. Christie's gallery currently offers a sampling, in poster form, of the types of German art the house has auctioned in recent years, items ranging from medieval crossbows to a magnificent wooden sculpture by the Expressionist artist Ernst Barlach, with prices appended.
 
More Junk Than Art
 "Time was you discovered Ming vases being used as umbrella stands in England," said Mr. Konig of Sotheby's. "Well, you're going to have that occasionally in Berlin, in Dresden, and other places as well."
But for the time being, he concedes, it is more junk than the genuine article. "Every day people come with old books, piles of them," he said, "ceramic pieces, oil prints, 19th-century copies turned out by the hundreds that hung over Grandma's couch, usually totally worthless."
But with time and education, he believes, the jewels will emerge. "People in East Germany have to be brought back to art markets," Mr. Konig said. "For more than 40 years there was no art market there. People don't know what an art market is, how it works."
Mr. Bertz of Christie's agreed, saying: "It's fascinating what people have in their apartments, expensive items. We just have to wait."
Indeed, in the fall Sotheby's acquired a portrait by the Expressionist Emil Nolde from a retired worker in Dresden who had squirreled it away in 1945 and bided his time.
"Expressionism has a tradition in this part of the world," Mr. Konig said. "Ernst Ludwig Kirchner lived in Berlin, the Brucke people lived here. There must be a number of works from this period to be discovered here."
There is no way of knowing how much high-quality art will turn up, but Christie's has hired Peter Bet thausen, the director of the National Gallery in the eastern part of the city and an authority on 19th- and 20th-century art, to try to find out. Christie's is also making space for specialists who will assess other objects, like silver and jewelry.
 
Art's Long Winter
 All of this is not without significance in Berlin, which was a major center of the art trade before 1933. With the rise of Hitler, all forms of art but those realistically glorifying Nazi ideals were discouraged, and Jewish artists and art dealers were forced to abandon their businesses.
After the war, Communist governments throughout the East prevented the sale of art except through officially sanctioned channels or in shady deals arranged by party functionaries for personal enrichment. Loopholes existed in places like Berlin, where Russian emigres did business in icons and silver, though often illegally. Lingering restrictions in the formerly Communist countries still hamper the art business.
After a brief attempt in the early 1970's, Christie's abandoned the idea of holding auctions in Germany, preferring to focus on London and New York. But Sotheby's will begin twice-annual auctions in May, commencing with a sale of 20th-century works that will include a still life by Max Beckmann, a watercolor by Oskar Schlemmer and a gouache by Paul Klee.
Mr. Bertz said that although the talk in the United States and England was of bank closures and recession and both houses had cut personnel and had had reduced sales, the art market in Germany is booming along with the economy.
"The economy is going through a fantastic period," he said. "It used to take 10 minutes to get here from the airport. Now it's a half-hour. You cannot get lamps or telephones, because everyone wants to be here in Berlin, so there are material shortages that are extraordinary for the economy."
"We're not thinking of cutting personnel at all," he said.

HEADLINE: Pennsylvania Ballet Calls a Halt

BYLINE: By JACK ANDERSON

 BODY:
The trustees of the Pennsylvania Ballet announced yesterday that the troupe would have to suspend operations immediately because of insufficient funds.
After that announcement, at a news conference at the company's headquarters in downtown Philadelphia, Christopher d'Amboise, the artistic director, said the group's dancers, musicians, technicians and staff members would donate their time and services for an engagement by the troupe to open as scheduled on Thursday night at the Shubert Theater in Philadelphia. 
 Edwin E. Tuttle, the chairman of the company, said it needed to raise $2.5 million. He attributed the organization's financial crisis to reductions in government financing and to recession-related cuts in private and corporate donations.
Mr. d'Amboise said yesterday that if the company could raise $1 million it would be able to continue. Commenting on the willingness of the dancers and staff to waive payment, he said: "I was astonished and delighted by their decision. I'm so happy this is happening." All donations to the company, he said, are to go directly to a Save the Ballet escrow fund.
 
'We Believe in Ourselves'
 "We can't and won't allow ballet to die in Philadelphia," Mr. d'Amboise said. "The dancers are taking to the stage while staff members are taking to the streets. We believe in ourselves, each other and the excellence of this company."
On the program for its performances at the Shubert, which are to continue through March 24, is a triple bill of Antony Tudor's "Jardin aux Lilas" and George Balanchine's "Four Temperaments" and "Who Cares?" Program inserts and speeches are expected to encourage audiences to make contributions, Mr. d'Amboise said. "If we're not successful, everyone who contributed donations will be entitled to a refund," he said.
The Pennsylvania Ballet was founded by Barbara Weisberger, with the support of Balanchine and the aid of a Ford Foundation grant made in 1963 to ballet companies across the United States. It began offering regular seasons in 1964 and frequently appeared in New York City during the 1960's and 70's. Mrs. Weisberger shared the company's directorial duties with Benjamin Harkarvy from 1972 to 1982.
 
Ties and Unity
 The company has always maintained ties with the New York City Ballet. Mrs. Weisberger was a student at the School of American Ballet, now the City Ballet's affiliated school, when it was founded in 1934. In 1982, Robert Weiss, a former principal dancer of the New York City Ballet, was named the director of the Pennsylvania Ballet.
Under Mr. Weiss's direction, the Pennsylvania Ballet became involved in an elaborate arrangement to join forces with the Milwaukee Ballet and to create a company with two homes. This began in 1987, but proved unwieldy, and the groups separated in 1989.
Mr. d'Amboise, who succeeded Mr. Weiss as the director last year, is a former member of the New York City Ballet and the son of Jacques d'Amboise, a dancer, choreographer and teacher who was a principal dancer of the City Ballet for many years.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Members of the Pennsylvania Ballet listening yesterday as the company's board announced that operations would be suspended. (Associated Press)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (96%); 

STATE: PENNSYLVANIA, USA (96%); NEW YORK, USA (93%); 

CITY: PHILADELPHIA, PA, USA (94%); NEW YORK, NY, USA (93%);

HEADLINE: SCIENCE WATCH;
Suicide in Alaska

 BODY:
The suicide rate for young male Alaska natives is more than twice the rate for young white men in the nation as a whole, two Pennsylvania scientists have reported.
While white men over the age of 55 have the highest suicide rate in the United States as a whole, however, suicide after 55 is virtually nonexistent among Alaska natives, the scientists said. They studied suicides from 1979 to 1984 and reported their findings in the February issue of the journal Psychiatry. 
 Dr. Paul Kettl, a Pennsylvania State University psychiatrist, one of the suicide researchers, said the patterns appeared to reflect dramatic social change in Alaska native society.
Oil discoveries in Alaska in the mid-1960's, followed by economic growth and an influx of television in the 1970's, forced a cascade of change on Alaska natives, he said. They had to make choices between traditional values and new values.
Young men were particularly affected because economic growth and a cultural assault corroded their traditional roles, he said. Hunting, fishing and whaling became more difficult to pursue. The ensuing dislocation, along with high rates of alcoholism and a high frequency of gun ownership in rural Alaska, appear to have contributed to the suicide rates, Dr. Kettl said.
From 1979 to 1984, Alaska native men aged 15 to 24 committed suicide at a rate of 84.3 per 100,000, four times the rate of 21.2 per 100,000 for white men of the same age in the United States in 1982. Alaska native men aged 25 to 34 committed suicide at a rate almost double that for white men of the same age.
At the same time, native Alaskan elders lost little of their status in their communities as repositories of culture, Dr. Kettle said, and there were no reported suicides for Alaska native men over the age of 55 from 1979 to 1984.
Suicide rates for Alaska native women were slightly higher than rates for women in the nation as a whole. But the differences in the rates were not as dramatic, Dr. Kettl said, in part because women were able to retain traditional roles of childbearing and homemaking.

HEADLINE: ON MY MIND;
How to Lose the Peace

BYLINE: By A. M. Rosenthal

 BODY:
Only yesterday, the United States showed how swiftly it could win a war in the Middle East. Now the United States is showing how swiftly it might lose a peace in the Middle East.
Our defeated enemy remains in power, still slaughtering his countrymen. Our Arab allies refuse to take the one simple essential step toward Mideast peace. 
 How did we manage to get to this point? There's an answer, but first consider three cases.
 l. Saddam Hussein. The United States, surely to his astonishment, allows him to use his remaining weapons to destroy his enemies in Iraq. He is permitted to move helicopters and tanks around the country to shell down the rebellion.
 While there's time, Washington should issue standstill orders for all Saddam Hussein's helicopters and tanks, under pain of aerial destruction. That would at least give the fragmented opposition a chance to survive.
 As long as the man who brought about war is still in power, the peace will not be secure. President Bush knows this. But officially the White House sticks to the nonsense that Iraq's internal affairs are not our business. It was precisely Iraq's most intimate internal affair -- the character of its Government -- that forced us into war.
After Saddam may come a government as bad. Maybe not, if we help the non-fanatics among the opposition. But, in decency, he must not be allowed to linger in power, distributing death. Would the world have permitted Hitler to carry on in Berlin because of the chance of a period of German chaos without him?
 2. Syria. While hoping one Mideast dictator disappears, the U.S. abets the buildup of another.
Find the difference between Hafez al-Assad of Syria and Saddam Hussein of Iraq, try. In the torture, murder and gassing of their own citizens, in aggression against smaller neighbors, the stockpiling of chemical and bacteriological weapons, in dreams of empire, and terrorism against the West -- just try.
For lending his mouth and a few thousand troops to the war against his own Arab enemy, the Syrian receives billions from other Arabs, Europe and Japan. He spends it as fast as he can on more weapons.
 One day an American President, maybe Mr. Bush himself, will stare at this man and ask himself, in a sudden flash of clarifying horror, What have I wrought?
3. Allies. News story: Arab rulers agree to part of the Bush-Baker "peace plan." Turns out that it is the part that permits the U.S. to keep enough force in the Persian Gulf to save their necks, again.
Thanks. But peace-producing parts of the plan, an end by the Arabs of their 43-year state of war with Israel and direct Arab-Israeli talks, these get the same old three-word answer: No, no, no.
 How could all this happen? Answer: For decades the U.S. and other Western powers have misunderstood or ignored the nature of the Arab governments -- deliberately.
In almost every way -- in foreign aggression, domestic terrorism, persecution of minorities and women, control of the economy, the spread of religious bigotry, elimination of personal, political or intellectual freedom -- Arab governments rule under a self-perpetuating system of tyranny that can best be described as Arab fascism.
If such governments reigned in Europe, they would be exposed and detested. But in the Mideast, the West accepted and strengthened these governments, first out of lust for their land, then for their oil. Out of this grew the self-justifying Western accepted wisdom that freedom, democracy, political choice are outside Arab comprehension or ability.
Western Arabist diplomats prattle about Arab traditions of clan and sheik. But this simply prettifies their belief that alone among people, Arabs cannot achieve democracy, a belief essentially contemptuous and contemptible.
 So the U.S. finds itself with allies it strengthened, but which by their essence hate what it should stand for -- political and economic freedom.
The refusal to understand or openly discuss the reality of the Arab governments led the West to appeasement of Saddam Hussein and then to war, appeasement's child. It now leads the West to support his brothers in tyranny, and call them brother.
 Perhaps one day the President strong enough to finally see the truth about Saddam Hussein will be brave enough to see the truth about the rest of the Middle East and speak it. That would be his great gift to the chances of peace, and to the Arab people.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Poison Gas: Only Part of the Problem

 BODY:
Reflecting his Persian Gulf war experience, President Bush last week issued a highly welcome pronouncement: The U.S. is tightening controls over exports of chemicals and equipment for arms-making. That's a hopeful, if small, sign that Mr. Bush intends to try stopping the spread of sophisticated arms at the source. But why stop at that?
The President can do much more, like getting others to curb sales of materials and equipment essential to make chemical, biological and nuclear arms. He can also reduce buying pressure by spurring talks on a new treaty to ban the manufacture, possession and use of chemical weapons. He can support legislation to punish countries that produce, acquire or use such weapons. 
 And there is no reason to confine arms control efforts to these weapons and exclude sophisticated new conventional arms. After all, what made Iraq so menacing to its neighbors were the modern tanks and aircraft it had already acquired from abroad.
 Until now, U.S. companies have needed no license to export most chemicals to countries suspected of wanting them for weapons manufacture. The regulations issued last week extend controls to 50 chemicals and, for the first time, to equipment used to make arms. But these restraints will work only if America's gulf war allies follow. Germany, shamed by its indiscriminate sales, has begun to do so. Others across Europe need to as well.
A bill passed by the Senate and now before the House could induce them to do just that. It would not only impose sanctions on states that develop or use chemical or biological arms. It would also bar any foreign companies that sell materials or equipment to make such arms from selling in the U.S. -- unless their governments punish them. Mr. Bush vetoed similar legislation last year but has pledged not to do so again.
He has committed himself to ridding the world of chemical weapons. But he has insisted on retaining 2 percent of U.S. chemical stocks until all countries capable of making chemical weapons accept a ban. That insistence is holding up a treaty to ban these weapons in 40-nation talks in Geneva. So is U.S. backtracking on on-site verification. Mr. Bush could give new impetus to the talks by shifting his stance on both issues.
The President has been strangely silent on the need to curb conventional arms sales to the Mideast. Instead, his Administration proposes to sell some $33 billion in new weapons this year, two-thirds in this volatile region and much of that to Saudi Arabia and Israel. It has just notified Congress it intends to sell $1.6 billion in new weapons to Egypt, including 46 F-16 fighter planes. Just how much reassurance do the Saudis, Israelis and Egyptians need now that the U.S. is planning a larger permanent presence and more exercises?
The U.S. would be better off restraining arms sales to the Middle East and getting other states to do the same. As Iraq's aggression shows, the world can ill afford business as usual on arms of all sorts.

HEADLINE: Louisiana's Governor Shifts To G.O.P. in Career Gamble

BYLINE: By ROBERTO SURO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BATON ROUGE, La., March 11

 BODY:
In a gamble to save his career and stave off a challenge from a former Ku Klux Klan leader, Gov. Buddy Roemer announced today that he had abandoned the Democratic Party to become a Republican.
The Governor asked his new party to give him unified support in his re-election campaign this fall, when he faces a tough challenge from a popular former Democratic Governor, Edwin W. Edwards, who has already announced his candidacy. Although Mr. Roemer acknowledged that he had received no formal assurance of Republican backing, he said he had thoroughly discussed his plans with top state and national Republican Party officials, including President Bush. 
 Mr. Roemer now emerges as the Republicans' best hope to stifle the gubernatorial candidacy of State Representative David Duke, the former Klan leader who has amassed a following for his white supremacist views and whose past candidacies have embarrassed party leaders. Mr. Duke, who campaigns as a Republican even though local party leaders have disavowed him, has said that he will enter the race for governor later this week.
Ending months of speculation about his future, Mr. Roemer stood on the steps of the Governor's Mansion, which had been decorated with red-white-and-blue bunting for the occasion, and asserted: "Independence, though admirable, is not enough. My choice is Republican."
For the Governor, who has frequently antagonized the Democratic Party with his independent ways, winning Republican support appears to be his best chance to avoid political disaster in the fall election.
Speaking of his switch in parties, he said: "Will this affect the governor's race? Probably, but no one in this audience knows exactly how. I don't either. Therefore, I thought: Tell it like it is. Be what you are. Fight for it. Explain it, and let's see what happens."
In an interview today, Mr. Edwards, who lost to Mr. Roemer four years ago, said: "This is nothing but a crass political deal in which the Republicans get a sitting Governor and in exchange no Republican will run against him. The people of Louisiana regurgitate on such political deal-making."
But Mr. Roemer, repeatedly playing down the importance of his decision, cited the widely accepted notion that Louisiana politics were dominated by personalities rather than party organizations.
"To most Louisianians, party is unimportant and gets in the way," he said.
 
'We Never Had Him'
 Kathleen Vick, vice chairman of the state Democratic committee, said: "We can't lose him because we never had him. Buddy Roemer has never been a party player in any way shape or form. He may be proud of his independence, but the fact is he only hs one political party and that is Buddy Roemer."
Mr. Roemer did not directly criticize his former Democratic colleagues, and he admitted there is a "short but important list" of issues on which he differs with most Republicans, including his support for some affirmative action programs. He called for Republicans to be more open to women and minorities.
"Not perfect this party," he said, "but in prime position to open up from a strong base of shared beliefs of family values, of economic opportunity and of unshakeable national security and of law-and-order commitment."
While in Congress from 1980 to 1987, Mr. Roemer was one of the Boll Weevil Democrats who rebelled at their party's liberal agenda and supported much of the Reagan Administration's legislative platform. Several members of that group previously switched parties with a mixed record of political success.
 
Others Who Have Switched
 Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, for example, has become one of the most powerful politicians in Washington since his switch to the Republican Party. But last year two former Democratic Congressmen who changed parties, Kent Hance of Texas and Tommy Robinson of Arkansas, were defeated in Republican gubernatorial primaries.
As Governor, Mr. Roemer has consistently portrayed himself as an outsider trying to reform the Democratic establishment that dominates state politics. As a result, he has few friends among Democratic leaders and he faced an extremely hazardous re-election battle as a Democrat.
Mr. Roemer's switch was welcomed almost unanimously by Republican officials here. Billy Nungesser, the state chairman, said, "Throughout his career, Buddy has been closer to us than to the Democrats, and so this was a natural step for both sides."
And in a statement issued by the White House today, President Bush welcomed Mr. Roemer's announcement.
But some of Mr. Roemer's newfound Republican supporters still have doubts about his chances.
"We are real happy to have him," said Earl Wilson, a Republican district chairman in the New Orleans suburbs, "and I think now he can be assured 45 percent of the vote, but it is that other 5 percent that is pretty hard to figure."
Under Louisiana's open primary system all candidates will be on the same ballot for a first round vote on Oct. 19, and if no one wins a majority, the top two candidates face each other in a runoff.
Several prominent Republicans had indicated their intention to run against Mr. Roemer, but it appears that his party switch has pre-empted further challenge from that quarter, especially considering the apparent blessing Mr. Roemer has received from President Bush.
Mr. Roemer acknowledged today that he might fail to make a runoff if he split the votes of white moderates with one or more other mainstream Republicans, allowing Mr. Duke to gain a spot in a runoff with his strong conservative following.
Describing the President as "an old friend" Mr. Roemer said he had discussed his political plans with him as recently as Friday.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gov. Buddy Roemer of Louisiana after announcing his plan to abandon the Democratic Party and seek re-election as a Republican. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: U.S. and Albania to Restore Full Links

BYLINE: By DAVID BINDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 12

 BODY:
The United States will resume full diplomatic relations with Albania on Friday, ending 52 years of nonrecognition, American and Albanian officials announced today.
Administration officials said Foreign Minister Muhamet I. Kapllani was flying to Washington to take part in the formal act of diplomatic recognition with Assistant Secretary of State Raymond G. H. Seitz. 
 Months will pass before a United States ambassador to Tirana is named and still more time before an American embassy begins functioning in the Albanian capital, an Administration official said.
But the Bush Administration has concluded that it is desirable to act now because "we want to get engaged in the democratic process in Albania," the official said and because the Communist Government of President Ramiz Alia "is at least attempting reform."
 
'Greater Engagement' Urged
 On March 31, Albania is to hold its first multiparty elections since the Communists seized power in late 1944.
The Administration official said the State Department would send a small group of American diplomats to Tirana to become acquainted with the situation before the elections. Since early December, Albania, a country of 3.5 million, has been swept by waves of unrest marked by popular demonstrations againt the Communist system.
Richard A. Boucher, a State Department spokesman, said the turmoil called for "greater engagement, not less" by the United States. He also cited humanitarian concerns. There is currently a food shortage in Albania.
The United States and Albania had close ties before World War II. Americans of Albanian origin returned to the Balkans in 1912 to help establish the first Albanian Government. President Wilson was credited with having been the most powerful defender of Albania's territorial integrity in international councils immediately after World War I, when Italy, Yugoslavia and Greece vied to seize chunks of the country. There was also an American teachers college in Albania.
 
U.S. Reviled as Evil
 Diplomatic ties between Washington and Tirana were severed in June 1939 after Italy's invasion of Albania. An informal American observer mission was sent to Tirana in 1945 to explore resumption of relations. The Communist Government refused to honor prewar treaties and harassed the members of the mission so much that they were withdrawn in November 1946.
 The Albanian Government resumed diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union last year, after a break of 29 years. Albania and China have also agreed to increase trade and economic cooperation as part of Albania's effort to improve its international ties, and Albania has obtained observer status at the Helsinki talks in Europe, which emphasize human rights.
Until a little more than a year ago, the Communist Government regularly reviled the United States as an evil superpower bent on subjugating small countries like Albania. In fact, in the early 1950's, the United States was actively engaged in a plot to overthrow the Albanian Communists with paramilitary forces.
Talks on renewing ties were begun last summer and were virtually concluded in September. But senior State Department officials objected to moving ahead on the ground that human-rights abuses were continuing in Albania, causing the project to be delayed.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Political Prisoners Pardoned
 VIENNA, March 12 (Reuters) -- The Albanian Government said today that it had pardoned all the country's remaining political prisoners.
"Following this pardon, there are no more political prisoners in re-education centers and prisons in Albania," the said Albanian radio, monitored by the BBC.
The report did not say how many people were affected by the pardon. The International Helsinki Federation, a human rights monitoring group, estimated that there were 200 political prisoners in Albania's jails.

HEADLINE: Administration to Address Fears Raised by Mexico Pact

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 12

 BODY:
Worried that it may lose authority to negotiate new trade agreements, the Bush Administration told Congress today that it would offer a plan by May 1 on ways to alleviate the impact of a Mexican free trade pact on health, environmental and labor standards.
Many lawmakers fear a trade agreement with Mexico will reduce health standards, lead to environmental damage, depress employment and open up the United States to more smuggled cocaine. 
 Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the Democrat from Illinois who is chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, and Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Democrat from Texas who is chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, warned in a letter to President Bush last Thursday that a Congressional extension of negotiating authority was in danger if these concerns were not met.
 
Disparity Between Countries
 They called for an Administration plan to address "the disparity between the two countries in the adequacy and enforcement of environmental standards, health and safety standards and worker rights."
The negotiating authority -- so-called fast track authority to negotiate non-amendable agreements subject only to a final yes or no vote on the entire package -- would cover both the contemplated accord with Mexico and a broader 107-nation trade-opening arrangement under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
In an appearance before the House Ways and Means Committee today, the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, asserted that the Administration shared the concerns and would address them.
She said the plan would be designed in consultation with Congressional leaders and probably be forthcoming before May 1. The existing fast-track authority expires May 31. The Administration is requesting a two-year extension, which can be denied by a majority vote in either house.
 
Addressing Social Issues
 The Rostenkowski-Bentsen letter said the social issues needed to be addressed "either within the agreement itself or through some appropriate alternative context within the same time frame as the negotiations."
There has been talk of concluding an environmental treaty with Mexico later this year, while the trade negotiations are in progress.
The opposition is led by organized labor. During a time of rising unemployment in this country, labor groups fear further plant and job losses to Mexico and a diminution of wages and union strength.
Mrs. Hills pointed to Government studies showing that freer trade with Mexico would actually increase jobs.
"We don't think there will be a tumbling of jobs south," she said. "There has been no impediment to date to having jobs go south. Where jobs have gone south is where they are under rather considerable global pressure, and we would rather have jobs go to Mexico than just move offshore altogether, for example to East Asia."

HEADLINE: Support for Restoration of Full I.R.A. Deduction

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 12

 BODY:
More than 70 percent of the Senate lined up today behind a bill to restore fully deductible Individual Retirement Accounts for all workers, but the Bush Administration immediately rebuffed the proposal.
"It makes good sense for our economic future," the Senate Finance Committee chairman, Lloyd Bentsen, Democrat of Texas, said in announcing that he and 71 other senators from both parties -- enough to override a veto -- were introducing the bill. 
 It would allow all workers, regardless of income and whether they have a company pension plan, to make a tax-deductible I.R.A. contribution of up to $2,000 a year. Or, they could choose a new type of I.R.A. that, instead of an immediate deduction, would generate tax-exempt interest if held for five years or longer, or a third option that would split $2,000 between these types of accounts.
In addition, the bill would permit penalty-free withdrawals from an I.R.A. to make the down payment on a first home, pay catastrophic medical expenses or finance a college education.
Asked if the Administration would support the bill, the White House press secretary, Marlin Fitzwater, said, "We are not in favor of that at this point."
Representative Dan Rostenkowski, Democrat of Illinois, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, is also opposed. "He doesn't think we should be spending money on tax breaks, least of all not for tax breaks for affluent people," an aide said.
Deductible I.R.A.'s were made available to all workers in 1981. Four years later, 16.2 million taxpayers claimed I.R.A. deductions totaling $38.2 billion. About 36 percent of the tax saving went to people with incomes over $50,000.
The Tax Reform Act of 1986 restricted fully deductible I.R.A.'s to people not covered by an employer-sponsored pension plan or, for those who are covered, to people whose incomes did not exceed certain limits -- $25,000 for single people and $40,000 for married couples. Deductions are phased out on the next $10,000 of income. On tax returns filed in 1989, the deduction was claimed by 6.4 million taxpayers, for a total of $12 billion.
Under present law, a person who is not allowed a tax-deductible I.R.A. may still deposit up to $2,000 a year in such an account and the interest will be tax-deferred until withdrawn. There is a 10 percent penalty on money withdrawn from an I.R.A. before the owner reaches the age of 59 1/2.

HEADLINE: U.S. Inquiry Sought in Police Beating

BYLINE: By DAVID JOHNSTON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 12

 BODY:
Outraged over the videotaped beating of a suspect by the Los Angeles police last week, members of the Congressional Black Caucus asked the Justice Department today to conduct a wide-ranging inquiry into police brutality in the city.
Representative John Conyers Jr. of Michigan, a senior member of the caucus, said after a meeting with William S. Sessions, Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, that Mr. Sessions was noncommittal about widening the bureau's inquiry into the incident. A spokesman for Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said the Attorney General would also meet with caucus members to discuss the case. 
 There were these other developments today that grew out of the beating:
*Representative Don Edwards, a California Democrat who heads Judiciary Subcommittee on Civil Rights announced hearings next week on police brutality nationwide.
*The Chief of Police in Los Angeles, Daryl F. Gates, was urged to resign in a full-page advertisement placed by the American Civil Liberties Union in The Los Angeles Times. The ad included a photograph of an officer wielding a nightstick, with the headline, "Who do you call when the gang wears blue uniforms?" The Chief has said he will not resign.
*In Federal District Court in Los Angeles, a man charged that he was hogtied and beaten by Los Angeles officers when he was arrested on April 30, 1989. He is suing the city under Federal civil rights statutes, charging false arrest and excessive force.
In promising hearings by his panel on police brutality, Representative Edwards, called brutality "an epidemic."
Representative John Lewis, a Democrat of Georgia, said the behavior of the police in Los Angeles was "symbolic of what is happening around the country." Although neither Mr. Lewis nor Mr. Edwards provided details, police departments in cities like Miami and Dallas and smaller cities have faced charges of brutality.
 
'Absolutely Horrified'
 Mr. Sessions declined to be interviewed about the meeting with the black caucus or the F.B.I. investigation. The bureau is seeking to learn whether the Los Angeles police officers involved in the beating on March 3 violated the suspect's civil rights, thus warranting Federal charges.
Mr. Conyers, a Democrat, said he was "absolutely horrified" by the episode, which he said differed from other incidents of police misconduct in Los Angeles and elsewhere only in that it happened to be videotaped by an amateur photographer who lived nearby. The videotape was seen on national television over the Cable News Network and other networks.
The lawmaker said Mr. Sessions told the group that the F.B.I. was investigating the beating as an isolated incident. But, Mr. Conyers said, "We want a systematic investigation of the history of violence by the Los Angeles Police Department."
The videotape shows more than a dozen uniformed officers crowding over a prone man, later identified as Rodney Glen King, an unemployed construction worker, who the police said had led them on a car chase. The tape showed some officers repeatedly hitting him with their nightsticks and kicking him in the head while others stood by. Mr. King suffered a broken leg and facial injuries.
 
Inquiries in Department and Out
 Chief Gates said after the incident that he would seek felony charges against the officers involved and that all 15 officers who took part will face departmental disciplinary charges. The grand jury convened in the case is looking at the conduct of all 15, and it held a second day of closed hearings today.
The Chief can be removed from office only for cause by the five-member commission that appointed him.
 
'Not an Aberration'
 After the beating, Chief Gates called it an "aberration" in an otherwise well-disciplined department. But today everal members of Congress from the Los Angeles area disputed that.
"It certainly is not an aberration," said Representative Maxine Waters, a Democrat. "This is the order of the day in Los Angeles."
Mr. King is black, but Chief Gates has insisted that race was not a factor in the beating. Mr. King's lawyers have said they do not intend to make race an issue.
But several lawmakers said today that the incident had crystallized the perception that the Police Department of 8,300 officers often uses excessive force against blacks. They said a broad Federal investigation was necessary because the local authorities had been unable to halt what they referrred to as a "pattern of abuse" by the police.

HEADLINE: Deal Set on OPEC Cut, But Not All Are Happy

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GENEVA, March 12

 BODY:
OPEC decided today to cut oil production by 5 percent, or about a million barrels a day, which several officials of the group said should push prices higher.
But underscoring the tension in two days of talks here, Algeria and Iran expressed reservations about the plan in the final communique, and officials from those countries complained that the output cuts were too small to lift oil prices to OPEC's target of $21 a barrel. OPEC oil has fallen to $17.74 a barrel on average, in part because of the allies' quick success in the war against Iraq. 
 OPEC's Secretary General, Subroto, announced the group's decision at 7 P.M. here, and afterward crude oil for delivery in April rose 69 cents a barrel to settle at $19.68 on the New York Mercantile Exchange. When OPEC oil is trading at $21 a barrel, higher-quality West Texas oil costs $23. [Page D17].
 
More Power for Saudis
 OPEC officials and oil analysts here said today's decision reflected the Saudis' increased power within the group after the defeat of Iraq by Riyadh and its allies. How the agreement will affect oil prices was unclear, with oil experts and even OPEC ministers disagreeing among themselves about whether the cuts were large enough to raise prices.
After today's meeting, production of the 13-member group, currently estimated at 23.4 million barrels a day, would fall to 22.3 million barrels if members adhered to the agreement.
Saudi Arabia, by far the largest producer in the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, stubbornly resisted some other members' pleas for the group to cut production by 2 million barrels a day, with the Saudis absorbing 1.3 million barrels in cuts. Those members contended that the larger cuts were needed to bring prices back to $21 for a "basket" of seven OPEC crudes.
Under today's agreement, Saudi Arabia is expected to produce 8 million barrels a day, down from the 8.45 million barrels that Riyadh says it has produced in recent days, but far more than the 5.4 million barrels it produced under the old OPEC quota, before Iraq invaded Kuwait in August.
Oil experts said the reservations that Iran and Algeria expressed about the plan reflected their belief that OPEC, including Saudi Arabia, should accept far greater production cuts. It also reflected their unhappiness with the way the Saudis were exercising their muscle.
 
'A Price-Increasing Effect'
 "All ministers agree that one million barrels per day less than present production will have a price-increasing effect," Dr. Subroto said at a news conference. He said he did not know whether the price would increase "directly to $21," but said, "I'm sure it will go in that direction."
One Iranian official, speaking privately, expressed skepticism that the 5 percent cut in production would firm up oil prices. "It's not a serious number like the market is expecting," he said.
This morning, before the agreement was announced, Iran's oil minister, Gholam Rezah Aghazadeh, predicted that cutting production to a range of 21 million to 21.5 million barrels a day would raise prices to a range of $18 to $21 a barrel. But he said reducing output to 22 million barrels a day would keep prices between $15 and $18.
Dr. Subroto said today's agreement called for OPEC members to make "voluntary" proportional production cuts of 5 percent. But Algeria's oil minister, Sadek Boussena, who is also OPEC's president, said Algeria would ignore the agreement and would not cut production.
Some oil experts said the soft nature of today's agreement might lead to overproduction, because OPEC members might not adhere to the 5 percent cuts.
 
'Prices Will Drop'
 "I think in the coming weeks prices will drop because people will start to see a glut in the market," said Pierre Terzian, editor of Petrostrategies, a Paris-based oil journal.
OPEC officials said they could not specify the exact levels of new production because of the voluntary nature of the agreement and because OPEC had asked members to report within seven days their exact production levels. Oil experts estimated that under the new agreement Saudi Arabia would pump 8 million barrels a day, followed by Iran with 3.2 million barrels, the United Arab Emirates, with 2.3 million, and Venezuela with 2.2 million.
Oil analysts said one reason it was not hard to persuade members to agree to 5 percent cuts was that even with the reductions many members would be producing well above the quotas set last July. Those quotas were suspended after Iraq invaded Kuwait and the United Nations ordered an embargo on oil from those two countries, which had been producing 4 million barrels a day. OPEC members were encouraged to produce as much as they could to make up for that loss.
Today's agreement excludes Iraq and Kuwait because OPEC officials expect neither nation to export oil in the second quarter. OPEC will meet again in June to set production levels for the third quarter.
When the current meeting began on Monday, OPEC's secretariat said demand for OPEC oil would be 21.4 million barrels a day in the second quarter, some 2 million barrels below current production levels. But Saudi officials forecast that demand for OPEC oil would be 22.4 million barrels a day in the second quarter. They said increases in oil companies' stocks, a decline in Soviet oil exports and a rebound in the American economy would raise demand for OPEC oil.
 
Saudi Demand Is Met
 Oil officials here said one index of Saudi Arabia's new power was the closeness of the new production level to the estimate for demand by the Saudi oil minister, Hisham M. Nazer.. Showing new assertiveness, Saudi officials said they would refuse to produce fewer than 8 million barrels a day, and they persuaded other ministers to agree to that.
The Saudis also got their way in insisting that this week's gathering, a meeting of OPEC's market monitoring committee, not be turned into an emergency full-scale ministers meeting. Saudi officials worried that such a meeting might erupt into a political fight in which a heated debate would develop over future quotas for Iraq and Kuwait. There was also concern that OPEC members would attack one another over their stands in the gulf war.
One factor that helped Saudi Arabia dominate the meeting was the humbling of Iraq and the absence of Iraqi officials, who had been the intimidating price hawks at previous meetings.
Saudi officials rejected criticism that they were doing Washington's bidding by pushing for higher production levels and thus lower prices than some members wanted. Saudi officials noted that they had long opposed steep price increases because of their desire for steady growth in worldwide oil demand.
