HEADLINE: Exxon to Pay $100 Million Fine And Plead Guilty in Valdez Spill

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 12

 BODY:
The Exxon Corporation has agreed to plead guilty to a criminal charge arising from the 1989 Exxon Valdez oil spill and pay a $100 million fine, officials of the Environmental Protection Agency said tonight.
The $100 million would be part of payments by Exxon that could total as much as $1.1 billion over the next 10 years to settle civil and criminal cases arising from North America's largest oil spill. Alaskan and Federal authorities said today that all obstacles to the settlement appeared to have been cleared. 
 Final arrangements for the guilty plea, including a review of the agreement by the E.P.A. Administrator, William K. Reilly, are being worked out tonight, the E.P.A. officials said.
 
Protecting the Villagers
 It was not clear this evening what charge Exxon would plead to. The company had faced two felony charges and several misdemeanor counts stemming from the March 24, 1989, accident and could have been fined up to $600 million if convicted on all counts, Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said after the company was indicted just over a year ago.
As for the overall $1.1 billion settlement, Federal and state officials have agreed to the arrangement. Although a Federal District Court judge at first seemed to raise another hurdle today when he said he would review it to insure that the rights of 5,000 Alaskan villagers were protected, a state official said early this evening that the final barriers appeared to have been overcome.
Economists said Exxon would be able to claim tax deductions for every payment except for the $100 million criminal penalty, to be paid immediately.The $100 million would be one of the largest, if not the largest, criminal fine ever paid for pollution. A trial on the charges had been scheduled for April 10 in District Court in Alaska.
 
Effects Would be Studied
 The villagers had filed suit last week, asserting that they had been locked out of negotiations between Exxon, the State of Alaska and the Federal Government. The villagers said they feared that a settlement would prevent them from recovering financial damages caused by the March 24, 1989, spill.
The settlement, which has been under negotiations for months, would not end Exxon's legal troubles in Alaska. At last count, 330 separate suits by fishermen, environmentalists and others are pending against the company. But the settlement would end the major suits, brought by the State of Alaska and the United States.
In addition, the company would pay $90 million this year into a fund administered by three Federal agencies and three state agencies. The money would be used for scientific studies of the Prince William Sound region, which suffered great damage, and for projects to continue scrubbing the shoreline of oil left when nearly 11 million gallons of crude oil spilled from the hull of the Exxon Valdez after the tanker ran aground in the sound.
The skipper, Capt. Joseph J. Hazelwood, was convicted on March 22, 1990, of the relatively minor charge of negligently discharging oil but acquitted of piloting the vessel while drunk and other serious charges. He was sentenced to spend 1,000 hours in the cleanup operation and was ordered to make $50,000 restitution.
Exxon said in April 1990 that it had spent $2 billion on the cleanup and had paid an additional $200 million to settle claims.
The agreement made final today called for payments into the fund of $150 million in September 1992, $100 million in September 1993, and $70 million annually from 1994 until 2001. The settlement calls for Exxon to contribute $100 million more to the fund, bringing the total payments to $1.1 billion, if additional damage from the oil spill is discovered.
The proposed settlement was applauded by Gov. Walter J. Hickel of Alaska but strongly criticized by environmental groups and some state officials who said, essentially, that Exxon would be paying too cheap a price.
 
Bottom of the Pockets?
 "It seems like a good deal for Exxon," said Eric Jorgenson, a lawyer for the Sierra Club Legal Defense Fund in Juneau, which has sued the company.
But Governor Hickel said: "I am very happy with the settlement. It allows us to get to the bottom of Exxon's pockets."
Lance Lamberton, a spokesman for Exxon in Irving, Tex., declined today to say whether Exxon would sign the agreement and said the company would make no comment about the situation for the time being.
"If and when things break and we have come together for a proposal to be signed, there will be extensive notification," said Mr. Lamberton.
The settlement contains provisions to make public the scientific studies conducted after the spill by the Department of the Interior, the Environmental Protection Agency and other Federal agencies. But studies sponsored by the State of Alaska and the United States Coast Guard are to remain private pending the outcome of court cases brought against the state and the Coast Guard.
"Keeping the data secret is a major problem," said Mr. Jorgenson. "All of the data available from the spill should be released. The public paid for it."
 
Public Comment Allowed
 Although the terms would make the settlement the most expensive ever for damages caused by an environmental disaster, the pact is certain to raise a stir in Alaska and in Washington. The negotiators will open the pact to public comment for 30 days after it is signed.
Economists who have studied the spill for the state and Federal governments said today that the $1.1 billion settlement represents only a portion of the actual value of the damage to fisheries, water, wildlife and land. The economists said the Exxon Valdez disaster will have caused $2.5 billion to $5 billion in damages from the time of the spill before midnight on March 24, 1989, through 1994.
On April 9, 1990, Exxon and its subsidiary, the Exxon Shipping Company, pleaded not guilty in Federal District Court in Anchorage to two felony violations and several misdemeanor violations of five Federal statutes. The agreement resolves those charges.
The most serious violations were under Federal maritime law and accused Exxon Shipping of operating the Exxon Valdez with a "physically and mentally" incapable crew. The company also faced a misdemeanor count for violations of the Federal Migratory Bird Treaty Act for killing thousands of birds, and two misdemeanors for spilling oil under the Clean Water Act and the Refuse Act. Other charges were pending under the Ports and Waterways Act and the Dangerous Cargo Act.
The Government and Exxon had tried to settle the case through plea bargaining but Alaska's former Attorney General, Doug Baily, resisted the settlement and accused the Justice Department of selling out to the oil company.
Several state officials who asked not to be identified today said they had hoped that Exxon would be required to pay $1 billion in a one-time payment that could generate permanent income through annual interest payments. These officials said the payments spread out over 10 years would be much less valuable.
Senator Frank Murkowski, a Republican from Alaska, said today that Alaska was fortunate to have gained a settlement. The alternative was years of litigation that would have cost Alaska millions of dollars in legal fees without any assurances of success.
 
'A Bird in the Hand'
 "I think this agreement, if it is resolved, is going to have to stand the light of day by the Legislature, the Governor and Exxon shareholders," said Senator Murkowski. "The alternative is litigation. I certainly am inclined to think a bird in the hand is worth two in the bush. The cost of litigation would be very substantial."
The settlement also calls for an advisory group made up of members of the public to help oversee how money from the settlement is spent. The Department of Justice scheduled a news conference for Wednesday to explain provisions in the settlement.
The last obstacles were crossed this afternoon when Federal Judge Stanley Sporkin lifted an order here that prevented the pact from being signed, and a District Judge from Alaska, H. Russel Holland, approved the agreement. Judge Holland was to have presided over the criminal trial.
Last week, Judge Sporkin blocked the settlement from being signed until the state and Federal Government assured more than 5,000 Alaskan native villagers that their right to gain financial damages from Exxon would not be harmed by the pact. Today, Judge Sporkin said he was satisfied and lifted his injunction. But in an order he signed this afternoon, Judge Sporkin said he would review the settlement after it is signed.
"The court shall retain jurisdiction over this matter to insure that the defendants' representations are carried out so the plaintiffs' rights are protected," Judge Sporkin wrote in the order.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR: TURKEY;
Turks Claim Benefits of Allied Victory

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ANKARA, Turkey, March 9

 BODY:
All in all, Turks say, it turned out to be not a bad little war for them.
Totaling the pluses and minuses, Government officials are convinced that Turkey has emerged from the Persian Gulf crisis diplomatically sturdier, militarily richer and economically hopeful of making up the billions of dollars that were lost after Iraq invaded Kuwait. 
 And it was all accomplished, they add happily, while the country managed not to fire a single shot or suffer a scratch, despite early fears that Iraq might lob in Scud missiles at any moment. The main concern now is that civil unrest in Iraq could fragment that country and leave the Turks with an unstable neighbor.
Turkey's claim to some of the victors' spoils lies in its early and steady support for the United States-led alliance, a decision engineered and followed through almost single-handedly by President Turgut Ozal. If public opinion, the political opposition and the military and foreign-policy establishments all had their way, Turkey would have ridden out the entire crisis pretty much on the sidelines.
 
Unpopular One-Man Show
 "For the first time in 200 years, Turkey has allied itself with the winners of a war," the President said the other day. "Siding with the winners is always advantageous."
Mr. Ozal saw to it that Turkey quickly shut an important pipeline carrying Iraqi oil, that Turkish troops were massed at the southeastern border to tie down Iraqi troops there and that American pilots were allowed to use Incirlik Air Base for bombing runs against Iraq.
Although the Turks' military role was not central to the allied victory -- only five percent of the United States air sorties are said to have originated from Incirlik -- diplomats assert that the Turkish involvement was enough to force President Saddam Hussein to "look both ways," north as well as south, for possible attacks.
For all his success, the Turkish leader's tendency to be a one-man show makes him unpopular at home. But in Washington and Europe, his stock could not be much higher, and officials here argue that that translates into a victory for Turkey by reminding the West of the country's importance as NATO's point man in the Middle East.
 
'The Turkish Formula'
 The Turks are not fooling themselves on that score. Being on the winning side does not solve their many problems, they acknowledge. Turkey is no closer to its goal of membership in the European Community, and the West is not likely to stop protesting human-rights violations here or the continued Turkish occupation of northern Cyprus.
Nevertheless, Government officials emphasize the "stabilizing role" they can play in the region, and Mr. Ozal insists that no Middle East peace conference can be successful without Turkish participation. If nothing else, some here say, Turkey has underscored its importance as an Islamic model.
"The West," said Kamran Inan, a Cabinet minister, "has discovered that the best formula for a Muslim nation is the Turkish formula -- Muslim, yes, but secular and democratically ruled."
How Turkey can be a stabilizing force, in practical terms, is less than clear. Turkish participation in new long-term security networks in the region is unlikely. NATO, officials here say, may not approve of one of its members joining such an arrangement and, perhaps more to the point, Arab states say that regional security must be an Arabs-only proposition.
[In an attempt to address the question of civil unrest in Iraq, Turkey announced on Monday that Turkish officials had met with leaders of Iraqi Kurdish organizations. In the past, Turkey had sought to block Iraqi Kurds' separatist drives, fearing that they would lend strength to similar moves by Turkey's Kurds.]
 
Stronger Turkish Military
 On balance, Turkey has ended up with a stronger military thanks to wartime Western assistance.
Several NATO countries moved in troops and equipment to serve as a trip-wire force against a possible Iraqi attack, and when the European soldiers return home they will leave behind up-to-date tanks and artillery to replace museum pieces from the 1950's that the Turkish Army still uses.
As for help from the United States, the Turks hope to double the size of their fleet of F-16 fighters, to 320, and to break free from an American formula that gives rival Greece $7 for every $10 in military aid that goes here. Washington has already given the Turks an emergency package of $82 million and the Bush Administration wants to increase Ankara's regular military assistance, from $515 million last year to $700 million in 1992.
But the main concern for Turkey is to bounce back from the economic blows inflicted by the gulf crisis. Estimates vary, but the country puts its losses at up to $9 billion in forfeited trade, tourism, construction projects and oil-pipeline fees. Less than a third of that has been offset by foreign aid.
But Mr. Ozal, ever optimistic, said Turkey's prospects were bright -- especially because despite the crisis, the Turkish economy grew by nearly 13 percent in 1990. There is also hopeful talk here of winning contracts in the rebuilding of Kuwait.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "For the first time in 200 years, Turkey has allied itself with the winners of a war," President Turgut Ozal said recently. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Agreement Reached to Save Daily News

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER

 BODY:
Robert Maxwell, the British publisher, and the unions of The Daily News reached tentative agreements yesterday on new labor contracts, clearing a major obstacle to the purchase of what was once the largest daily newspaper in the country.
Mr. Maxwell will now try to complete the purchase of The News from its owner, the Tribune Company of Chicago. He indicated yesterday that he might ask the Tribune Company for more money in negotiations today and tomorrow than the $60 million the company had already promised. But he also suggested in countless ways that he expected to be the owner and publisher of The News within a few days. 
 Mr. Maxwell said he thought the sale could be completed by tomorrow, the deadline set by the Tribune Company. If the sale is not completed, The News, which has been crippled by a strike that began on Oct. 25, will cease publication on Friday, the paper's executives have said.
 
Threatened to Leave U.S.
 The settlement with the unions was achieved after deadlines set by Mr. Maxwell came and went over two days. Negotiations went on practically around the clock, as exhausted labor officials, anxious union members and thousands of interested New Yorkers wondered whether a 71-year-old landmark of the city's public life would survive the week. At 2 P.M. yesterday, Mr. Maxwell set a final deadline of 3 P.M., after which, he said, he would leave the country. The final union, the drivers', settled more than an hour after that deadline.
The labor settlements, which must be acted on by the rank and file, were reached after six days of talks that Mr. Maxwell described as "extraordinarily intensive." To save the paper, the unions had to agree to the elimination of 800 jobs, or almost one-third of the unionized work force of nearly 2,600 -- concessions worth more than $70 million a year.
 
Circulation Is Slashed
 News of the agreement, announced shortly before 4:30 P.M., circulated quickly among members of the nine unions that have been on strike for 139 days. The bitter strike has caused The News's circulation of more than 1.1 million to be slashed in half and has virtually eliminated its advertising base.
Many union members said they were thrilled at the paper's apparent survival and felt vindicated against the Tribune Company, which many have accused of trying to break the unions. But many also said they felt extremely sad about the jobs to be lost.
Eddie Borges, a reporter, said: "For a second there, I was on the verge of crying. We broke the company that tried to break the union."
But Mr. Borges, 27 years old, who began working at The News in February 1990, said he did not know whether he had enough seniority to avoid being laid off.
At two news conferences yesterday afternoon in the jammed lobby of the Macmillan building, at Third Avenue and 53d Street, which Mr. Maxwell owns and where the talks had been held since Thursday, he exulted in the labor agreements, which had represented perhaps the most difficult hurdle in his effort to buy The News.
"Common sense prevailed and we have a deal," Mr. Maxwell said.
He said he and the labor leaders had succeeded "in saving the vast majority of the jobs, preventing The News from being closed by the Tribune Company and giving the newspaper back to the people of New York."
 
'We Will Make a Profit'
 "It means, regrettably, the loss of jobs," he added, "but I am willing to go on record here that we will make a profit, barring any unforeseen circumstances, in the first year of operation. That is an indication to you of the kind of reality and realism of this bargaining."
Mr. Maxwell reached a tentative agreement with the Tribune Company last week to buy The News, contingent on his working out new labor contracts.
The Tribune Company has agreed to pay Mr. Maxwell $60 million to take over the paper and to assume most of its long-term liabilities, including severance pay in the event of a shutdown and lifetime job guarantees to more than 200 union members.
Mr. Maxwell was asked if he would seek to renegotiate the terms of the agreement, perhaps by requesting more than $60 million. "I may indeed well ask," he responded. "Whether I get it is another matter."
 
'Try to Write Editorials'
 He also offered some details about his plans for the tabloid, which was the nation's third-largest metropolitan daily before the strike. The Los Angeles Times and The New York Times are the two largest metropolitan dailies.
Mr. Maxwell said he would serve as publisher for the first 6 to 12 months. He said he would "try to write editorials," and he said helping to restore the city's economic stability would be a major concern of the paper.
"It would be one of my major jobs to support and sustain the public officials and private industries in making New York a viable town," he said.
Mr. Maxwell said he had no intention of importing editors from Britain. When asked who would be editor of The News, Mr. Maxwell said, "There is a very good editor at present at The News." He was referring to James P. Willse.
In an interview late yesterday afternoon, Mr. Maxwell said he wanted his Daily News to be "first and foremost, a paper that will be the voice of New York for the ordinary man."
He also said he hoped that the paper could become a voice of America for Europeans. "I would hope that The News could become an important voice internationally, in terms of telling the world how America feels," he said.
He also said he would try to lure back Jimmy Breslin, the celebrated columnist who moved from The News to New York Newsday several years ago.
 
$10 Million Investment
 Mr. Maxwell also said that a great many management positions would have to be eliminated, but he did not specify how many.
He said he expected to invest at least $10 million in the first six to eight weeks, in an attempt to rebuild the paper's circulation and advertising. The Tribune Company estimated that it would cost about $50 million to resurrect the paper.
He also said he expected to start using color within two or three years.
Mr. Maxwell had sought huge concessions from the unions to make the paper profitable, and that is precisely what he got.
He wanted to reduce labor costs by more than $70 million a year, primarily by eliminating about 800 jobs. The contracts that were completed Monday night and yesterday will do that, said Theodore W. Kheel, a labor lawyer who is the unions' chief adviser.
The largest unions at The News were among the hardest hit. The Newspaper Guild, which represents 759 newsroom, advertising and circulation employees, agreed to the elimination of 238 jobs, said Barry F. Lipton, president of the union. About 300 of the 700 drivers' positions will be cut, union officials said.
John P. Kennedy, head of the pressmen's union, declined to say how many jobs his union had agreed to drop. Mr. Maxwell was believed to be seeking to cut half of the 400 pressmen's jobs.
 
Buyouts First, Then Layoffs
 Cash inducements of $40,000 will be offered to employees willing to leave the paper or retire early. If the inducements, called buyouts, do not produce enough volunteers willing to leave the paper, there will then be layoffs, union leaders said.
Inducements to the printers, who have guaranteed lifetime contracts, will be $50,000. These are considerably smaller than similar buyouts that have been offered to other union members at New York's newspapers.
If Mr. Maxwell succeeds in restoring the paper's circulation and advertising, some of those laid off may be called back to work, union officials said. But the contracts do not contain precise formulas for such rehiring, Mr. Lipton said.
Mr. Maxwell achieved his goals for several reasons. Unlike the Tribune Company, he was willing to negotiate the staff reductions through collective bargaining. The current owner of The News had sought to make such decisions unilaterally. The Tribune Company wanted to regain total control of workplace issues like staffing levels and guaranteed overtime, issues that traditionally had been negotiated with the unions.
 
Partners, Not Enemies
 "What we're doing," Mr. Maxwell said yesterday, "is working with a work force in partnership rather than treating them as though they were the enemy within and without."
The unions also knew that Mr. Maxwell represented the last hope of keeping The News alive, which no doubt made it easier to accept the loss of 800 jobs in order to save 1,800 others.
Mr. Kheel said Mr. Maxwell's personality and salesmanship had also counted heavily. "It was a performance to end all performances," Mr. Kheel said.
"He was in everything," Mr. Kheel said. "He dominated. He cajoled. He met with the full committees and he met with the small committees. He got involved in the minutia."
Mr. Maxwell picked up all the costs of the negotiations, from the use of two floors in his building to takeout food and carfare. He provided food prepared by his corporate chefs to the union officials, and he offered them secretaries for typing and other tasks, Mr. Kheel said. Labor and management usually share the cost of negotiations.
 
The Only Hope
 Mr. Maxwell, whose many holdings include The Daily Mirror, Britain's second-largest daily paper, and the Macmillan publishing house, was invited by The News on Feb. 27 to begin talks about a possible sale.
The following day, negotiations between The News and the nine striking unions were abandoned. The unions and management had met for eight long days over a span of more than two weeks under the guidance of a private mediator, Bill Usery Jr. But the talks never progressed, and they were halted by Mr. Usery, who said he wanted to allow enough time for a possible sale of the paper. By that point, a sale was the only hope for keeping The News alive.
Mr. Maxwell and the Tribune Company reached a tentative sale agreement in five days, contingent on a resolution of the labor dispute.
The British publisher said yesterday that he was confident The News could be resurrected. "The News is rightly positioned in the marketplace," he said. "All we want to do is to get back to business as quickly as we can. I hope that we will have the enthusiastic support of every single member of the 10 trade unions involved in what has been a rather long and terrible dispute."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Barry Lipton, right, president of the Newspaper Guild, and George E. McDonald, head of the coalition of unions at The Daily News, announcing a settlement. All the labor organizations reached agreements. (Ruby Washington/The New York Times); Striking workers celebrating on picket line outside the Daily News building after hearing that unions had reached tentative agreements. (William E. Sauro/The New York Times) (pg. B4)

LENGTH: 1529 words

HEADLINE: They're Wearing the Green Amid the Great Reds

BYLINE: By FRANK J. PRIAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BORDEAUX, France, March 12

 BODY:
It is often said that Ireland's most important export has been its youth. In the 19th century, famine and despair drove well over a million of the Irish to the United States alone.
The enormity of that sad exodus, still vivid to many, tends to blur the memory of earlier waves of Irish emigrants, including the famous Wild Geese, who came to France in the late 17th and early 18th centuries. 
 Many of the Irish immigrant families went into the wine business, where their descendants are often still to be found. Almost forgotten is the fact that Ireland in the 18th and early 19th centuries imported more fine Bordeaux wine than did England.
"Someone came up with the name 'Wine Geese,' " said Anthony Barton, the urbane doyen of Chateau Langoa-Barton and Leoville-Barton in St. Julien. "Of course, it's just a pun. There's no society or club or any such thing," he added, plainly appalled at the idea.
This weekend, French descendants of those immigrants, joined by Ireland's Ambassador to France, Tadgh O'Sullivan, will pay homage to their forebears at a round of St. Patrick's Day celebrations here and in the nearby wine country.
According to legend, the first Irish immigrants to France were soldiers defeated in battle, unbowed Catholic warriors fleeing English tyranny at home to follow the Stuarts into exile and carry on the fight with their old foe. And some were just that.
But not all left to join the French Army's independent Irish Brigades. Many were merchants, some even Protestants, who came to prosperous France to seek their fortunes.
Mr. Barton, is a descendant of one of those men, Thomas (French Tom) Barton, who left Fermanagh in 1722. First at Marseille and then Montpellier, he established himself as a trader. He arrived in Bordeaux in 1725 and amassed a fortune trading French brandy and Cognac for Irish wool. Although the Bartons always kept close ties with Ireland -- Anthony Barton was born there -- since French Tom's arrival, there have been nine generations of Bartons here, an unbroken line. The Bartons were one of the first of the prominent Irish merchant clans of Bordeaux, but by no means the only one. Indeed, the Irish presence here in the 18th century was formidable. Renagh Holohan, in her book "The Irish Chateaux" (Lilliput Press, Dublin, 1989), says there were some 60 Irish names among the city's merchants in the mid-1800's.
Most of the old Irish families have disappeared. Some moved away, some simply died out. Others had daughters who married into the French aristocracy. Even so, many of their names live on in the great wine chateaus they once owned: Langoa-Barton, Leoville-Barton, Lynch-Bages, Lynch-Moussas, Kirwan, Phelan Segur, Dillon, Clarke and MacCarthy, among them.
Some Irish families bought chateaus and kept the ancient names. The Johnstons, for example, owned the Chateaux Dauzac and Lascombes in Margaux, Ducru-Beaucaillou in St.-Julien and had shares, with the Bartons, in Latour, in Pauillac. Chateau La Houringue, whose vineyards are part of Chateau Giscours's vineyard now, was owned by John O'Byrne, a merchant and shipper who was known as the Chevalier O'Byrne.
Hugh Barton, who headed the Barton family business at the time of the Terror, in 1793, was imprisoned in a Carmelite Convent, along with clerical students from Bordeaux's Irish College. He was released and fled to Ireland, leaving his business in the hands of his partner, Daniel Guestier. Barton & Guestier, their firm, survived independently until 1956 when it was absorbed into the Seagram wine and spirits empire.
In 1940 another Barton, Ronald, escaped to England ahead of the advancing Germans, again leaving the business to a Daniel Guestier. He persuaded the Germans that Langoa-Barton was owned by an Irish neutral; the Germans did not harm it.
Almost as venerable an Irish clan here are the Lawtons. Abraham Lawton came to Bordeaux in 1836 from Cork, where he had been Mayor. The shipping company he founded here, Tastet & Lawton, survives. Hugues Lawton is a negociant, or wholesaler and shipper, and his brother Daniel is a broker, or middleman, between the chateaus and the negociants.
In spite of their prominence in the Bordeaux wine trade, neither brother owns a chateau. Their grandfather, Edouard, owned Leoville-Poyferre and Edouard's cousin, Jean, owned Chateau Cantenac-Brown for many years. Their mother, Simone deLuze Lawton, is an example of how the Irish families became integrated here. The deLuzes are an old and distinguished negociant family.
The Phelans -- the accent didn't come until later -- arrived in Bordeaux around 1796 from Tipperary. Bernard Phelan bought Chateau de Segur, in St.-Estephe in 1810. His son, Frank, took over after his father's death in 1841. Frank was Mayor of St.-Estephe for a time and his portrait now graces Phelan Segur's second wine, which is called Frank Phelan. He also married a Guestier.
The chateau passed out of the Phelan family in 1918 and is now owned by Xavier Gardinier, from the Champagne region, who made much of his fortune mining phosphates in Florida.
Chateau Clarke, in Listrac, is a magnificent building but it has little relation to the Clarkes. Tobie Clarke was a gun merchant from County Down who came to Nantes after the Battle of the Boyne in 1690, then settled in Bordeaux. His son Luc-Tobie, a criminal court judge, gave the estate its name. The house was demolished in 1955. Baron Edmond de Rothschild bought it in 1979 and erected the present structure.
One of the best-known Irish names in Bordeaux is Lynch. In the hands of Jean-Michel Cazes and his father, Andre, who bought the property in 1934, Chateau Lynch-Bages, in Pauillac, has become one of the most sought-after of all Bordeaux wines.
The first Lynch in France was Col. John Lynch, an authentic member of les Oies Sauvages, the Wild Geese. He came to France after the Irish lost the battle of Aughrim to the British in 1691, turned to commerce and did well.
The best-known Lynch was Jean-Baptiste, who was born at Chateau Dauzac in the Medoc, in 1749. He was variously a staunch parliamentarian, a royalist, and then, when it seemed propitious, a Bonapartist. When Napoleon fell, he quickly became a royalist again. When Napoleon returned from Elba, Jean-Baptiste, who had been Mayor of Bordeaux for a time, fled to England. He returned after Waterloo and died at Dauzac in 1835.
Another descendant of Jean-Baptiste Lynch, Alain Miailhe, owned Chateau Dauzac for a time in the 1970's. He decided to rename it Lynch-Dauzac, but was sued by the Cazes and the owners of Lynch-Moussas, the Casteja family. They won and he had to drop Lynch from the property's name. He sold it soon thereafter.
Mr. Miailhe (pronounced mee-EYE), the owner of Chateau Siran in Margaux, and his sister May de Lencquesaing, who owns Chateau Pichon Lalande in Pauillac, are also decended from the Burkes, a Galway family that made a fortune in the Philippines and one of whose daughters married a Frenchman who brought her to Bordeaux.
Asked to name a few Bordeaux chateaus with Irish connections, many people automatically mention Chateau Haut-Brion, in Pessac, one of the five first growths of Bordeaux. They believe Haut-Brion to be a French derivative of O'Brien. It is not. The name comes from language spoken in the region hundreds of years ago and refers to the slight rise in the ground on which the property, once far larger, is situated.
Nor are the American owners, the Dillons, of Irish descent. Clarence Dillon, one of the founders of the Wall Street firm Dillon-Read, who bought Haut-Brion in the mid-1930's, was of Polish origin and had changed his name as a young man. After his death, the chateau passed to his son, Douglas, who was the United States Ambassador to France and Secretary of the Treasury in the 1960's. His daughter, Joan, the Duchesse de Mouchy, directs its operation.
Thus, the Dillons of Haut-Brion have no connection with the Dillons who were, with the MacCarthys, among the most prominent of all the Irish families in France in the 17th and 18th centuries. The Irish Dillons' fame came originally from their connection with the Irish Brigades. The Brigades were first organized in the mid-17th century when Charles II, exiled from Cromwell's England, formed an army in exile in France. One of these was headed by James Dillon of Roscommon.
Generations of Dillons served in these private armies. Some returned to Ireland but most of those not killed in battle eventually moved into French society. One history of the family lists seven separate Dillon families with French connections.
The MacCarthys, once said to be the richest of all Bordeaux wine merchants, on a par economically with the Hennessys in Cognac, are now known only by Chateau MacCarthy, a minor property in the Medoc, and by the Hotel MacCarthy, a magnificent town house in the center of Bordeaux.
One wine that will not be drunk this weekend is Chateau St. Patrick. Maurice Healey, the 19th-century Irish wine writer, claims to have found such a wine in Boston during his travels. Anthony Barton said he had never heard of it, but added, "It is a lovely thought, though."

(Photographs by Jean-Marc Charles/Rapho for The New York Times) (pg. C1); The Phelan family arrived in Bordeaux from Tipperary around 1796. Frank Phelan, inset, was Mayor of St.-Estephe. HEADLINE: Latest Tokyo Craze: Tiramisu in a Bottle

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 10

 BODY:
For trendier Japanese, European flair is in these days, while Americana has lost in luster. But few of the recent Euro-fads have swept Tokyo as thoroughly as tiramisu, which has been transformed from a chic dessert to a marketing phenomenon packaged as candy and even dispensed from vending machines.
This is a society closed to many things, as trade negotiators often assert, but open to trends more than most outsiders realize. In the last few years, as the traditionally penurious Japanese have been urged by their Government to spend some of the vast wealth that trade surpluses and a booming economy are depositing here, luxury goods with a foreign air have been snapped up with ferocious energy. 
 Now, tiramisu, the dessert of espresso-soaked cake slathered with mascarpone cheese, with a dusting of cocoa powder and Italian cachet, is demonstrating anew how a foreign product can breach Japan's forbidding cultural ramparts and take the country by storm -- once tastemakers and marketers decide to put their promotion machines into action.
Last week Asahi Breweries, which has a line of non-alcoholic beverages, unveiled its Tira soft drink. It is a canned concoction of coffee, chocolate, cream, sugar and, of course, mascarpone cheese. The development follows the widely advertised introduction of a tiramisu chocolate bar by a Japanese confectioner.
Last month Kentucky Fried Chicken rushed to unveil a frozen tiramisu dessert at its 415 outlets in the Tokyo region. (It tastes suspiciously like ice cream with chocolate powder on top.) Wendy's, the American fast-food chain, and two Japanese chains, Mos Burger and First Kitchen, have brought out their own versions.
Jun Orihara, an executive at the Nosawa Company, one of the major importers of mascarpone cheese from Italy, said his sales of the commodity have gone from less than 3 tons in 1989, before the fad took hold, to about 140 tons last year.
"Tiramisu is the only reason for this tremendous growth," he said.
Silvano Borroni, the Italian proprietor of Il Boccalone, a popular trattoria in Tokyo, explained the popularity this way: "They really like booms here. I tell them there are other very beautiful Italian desserts. But they feel whatever is a boom is good."
Trend, fad, craze -- none of those familiar words quite grasp the sometimes peculiar enthusiasm with which Japanese embrace "in" things, ranging in recent years from Louis Vuitton and then Chanel handbags to fresh French bread, pasta, pizza and foreign travel.
It can, however, seem a bit mechanical. Japan's corporate establishment seizes on these sales opportunities and pushes them with the vigor of a research team chasing the latest breakthrough in computer chip technology.
In fact, these spasms of buying are a sign of the times. A few years ago the Government decided to reduce the economy's reliance on exports, a sore point with trading partners, particularly the United States, and place more emphasis on domestic consumption as an engine of growth. One result: the mass passions that fill magazines and television talk shows and, ultimately, cash registers.
The current phenomenon was captured best by a description in a popular magazine, which labeled it the "tiramisu syndrome."
The craze began with an editorial meeting a year ago at the offices of Hanako, an influential two-year-old magazine whose 350,000 readers are largely women in their 20's seeking help in navigating the treacherous waters of trendiness. The subject of the meeting was desserts for affluent, fashion-minded, urban women.
Cheesecake (lighter here than the classic New York version) dominated the dessert scene for several years. But it seemed out of touch with the recent popularity of things European. That's when it happened.
"I'd been feeling we were ready for another big cake hit," said Yamato Shiine, Hanako's editor in chief. "But I didn't know what. While we were talking, someone mentioned tiramisu, and it just clicked. It sounded like a pop to me. I knew that was it."
Not least, it coincided with another boom, Italian food. There are now more than 100 Italian restaurants in Tokyo, compared to a handful a few years ago. And it did not hurt that tiramisu had already swept New York several years earlier, giving Manhattan's respected imprimatur to the dessert.
Last April Hanako touted tiramisu in its cover article and included eight pages listing restaurants and cafes that carried the dessert. The main headline read: "Emergency Information on Tiramisu, the New Queen of Italian Desserts."
"Delicious tiramisu is proof," the magazine said, "of a classy restaurant." Eating tiramisu, Hanako enthused, "will make you feel like an Italian all day."
The article hit Tokyo like the starting gun at a track meet.
Mr. Borroni of Il Boccalone said he had to eject a few customers who came in merely to have tiramisu and cappuccino.
Tetsuro Yanai, head of planning at Fuji Oil, a vegetable oil processor that had been trying without much success to market a synthetic mascarpone, said his company was soon overwhelmed with orders.
"After that article, the boom spread like a fire," Mr. Yanai said, adding that he felt Fuji Oil had helped create the groundwork for the fad by selling the virtues of cheesy desserts to bakers for several years. "Demand was much larger than what we could supply."
Sales of the mascarpone substitute, which is about half the price of the imported cheese and lasts longer without spoiling, more than doubled in each succeeding month.
"Tiramisu might be a little past peak now, but I think it is here to stay," Mr. Yanai said.
Ichiro Takatsuki, a spokesman for Kentucky Fried Chicken Japan Ltd., said that as the trend fades in Tokyo, his company plans to introduce tiramisu in other cities, like Osaka and Nagoya, where it takes about a year for Tokyo fashions to grab hold.
Some trendsetters feel the tiramisu fad is stale, but say they have not hit on a fitting replacement yet. Hanako tried in a recent issue to push creme brulee, the custardy French dessert with a burnt sugar crust, but failed to incite much enthusiasm.
"The problem," he said, "is that it's too hard for a Japanese to pronounce. We have to find something with a better name. We're still looking."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Tiramisu, the Italian dessert, is the latest Euro-fad to hit Japan.; Kentucky Fried Chicken and other chains serve frozen tiramisu. (Photographs by Ellen Rudolph for The New York Times) (pg. C7)

HEADLINE: Chip Index Up Sharply

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, March 12

 BODY:
The semiconductor industry's key indicator of business prospects jumped in February, a sign that the industry slump might be drawing to an end.
Propelled by orders for computer chips, the book-to-bill ratio rose to 1.09 for the three months that ended with February from 0.96 for the three months that ended with January, according to the Semiconductor Industry Association, the trade group that compiles the statistics. The jump was the largest monthly increase in the index since March 1983. 
 A ratio of 1.09 means that for every $100 in products shipped, or billings, semiconductor companies received $109 in new orders, or bookings, from customers in the United States, a sign that business is getting stronger.
Orders rose 14.9 percent for the three months through February over the three months that ended in January. Shipments, or billings, rose only 1.1 percent comparing three-month periods, but shipments in February alone were 9 percent higher than in Janaury.
Michael Stark, an analyst with Robertson Stephens & Company in San Francisco, said the ratio was higher than expected and was "definitely a good sign." He said, however, that the 1.1 percent increase in shipments for the three-month period indicates that the upturn in business might not be especially strong.
With some exceptions, semiconductor companies have been experiencing soft business, the result of the recession and a slowdown in the growth of the personal computer industry. In November, the ratio had been at 0.93, one of the lowest levels in years.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Pushed Down Again By Central Banks' Sales

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
A second day of central bank interventions pushed the dollar lower yesterday, but analysts said unflagging confidence in the postwar economy helped stem the currency's decline.
Gold was mixed. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery rose 10 cents an ounce to settle at $364.80. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $364.60, off 40 cents from Monday's late bid. 
 The dollar opened lower after some limited selling by overseas central banks. But it began to recover as belief in the economy's ability to rebound replaced nervousness caused by interventions.
"Traders are still cautiously friendly to the dollar," said Pete Grant, managing currency analyst for MMS International in Chicago.
Yesterday's central bank intervention was smaller in scope than Monday's selloff, in which European central banks and the Federal Reserve joined in an effort to deflate the currency's surging postwar momentum.
The only central banks involved in yesterday's intervention were the German Bundesbank and the Bank of Japan, traders said.
"Yesterday they did it for the initial shock and today it is just to show a presence," said Bob Morrissey, a senior trader at Bank of Boston. "They don't want to overkill the market and overly hurt people."
In Tokyo, the dollar settled at 136.05 Japanese yen, down from 138.07 at Monday's close. Later in London, it fell to 136.25 yen. In New York, the dollar fell to 135.84 yen from late Monday's 138.20 yen.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.8585, from $1.8505 late Monday. In New York sterling also rose, fetching $1.8625 by the end of the day, more than late Monday's $1.8515.
Against the German currency, the dollar fell to 1.5703 marks from 1.5815.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday's prices, included: 1.3605 Swiss francs, down from 1.3705; 5.3495 French francs, down from 5.3845; 1,172.00 Italian lire, down from 1,180.00, and 1.1538 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1558.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Oil Makes Strong Advance After Agreement by OPEC

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Oil prices rallied yesterday after OPEC agreed to cut crude oil production by a million barrels a day.
The surge erased losses that had come as traders speculated that the meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries in Geneva would produce no cuts or only token cuts. 
 Crude oil for delivery in April settled at $19.68 a barrel, up 69 cents, on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
In early trading, oil had fallen on perceptions that OPEC would fail to reach an agreement on pumping less crude oil. OPEC had lifted its previous production quotas after the United Nations boycotted crude oil from Iraq and Kuwait after the Iraqi invasion.
 
A Strong Finish
 "We started falling off rather dramatically as people started expecting OPEC to only cut about 300,000 barrels a day," said Peter Beutel, an oil analyst with the Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J. "That was the rumor when they were in session."
After the oil ministers announced the reductions, which will cut production to an estimated 22.3 million barrels a day, oil fell for a while but then reversed for a strong finish.
"While it is not a particularly strong agreement, the fact that they did get something together was enough to be supportive," said Ann-Louise Hittle, a senior oil analyst with Shearson Lehman Brothers.
Mr. Beutel said OPEC would still be pumping too much crude, but the cuts would bring the market "closer to alignment."
Some analysts say OPEC must cut about two million barrels a day to push prices much higher.
Refined petroleum products also finished higher yesterday.
Unleaded gasoline for delivery in April settled at 71.67 cents a gallon, up 0.26 cent. Home heating oil for delivery in April settled at 55.80 cents a gallon, up 1.37 cents.
In London, North Sea Brent blend crude oil for delivery in April settled at $19.03 a barrel, up 66 cents, at the International Petroleum Exchange.
 
Stockpiles Are Down
 After the oil markets closed, the American Petroleum Institute reported that the United States supply of crude oil, home heating oil and gasoline had fallen last week, as had refinery utilization.
Crude oil stocks were at 330.2 million barrels for the week ended March 8, down from 336.1 million a week earlier and 350.8 million a year earlier, the institute said.
Stocks of distillates, which include home heating oil, were at 101.5 million barrels, down from 103.3 million a week earlier and 110.1 million a year earlier. Gasoline stocks were at 220.1 million barrels, compared with 222.6 million a week earlier and 243.7 million a year earlier.
American refineries were running at 84.3 percent of capacity, compared with 85.3 percent a week earlier and 83.7 percent a year earlier.

HEADLINE: Credit Card Delinquency

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 12

 BODY:
The number of Americans behind in paying credit card bills rose sharply in the fourth quarter but the combined delinquency rate for seven other kinds of consumer loans was stable, a trade group said today.
The percentage of credit card holders 30 or more days late on their payments was a seasonally adjusted 2.86 at the end of the year compared with 2.56 at the end of September and 2.24 a year earlier, the American Bankers Association said. 
 Despite the deepening recession, however, the seasonally adjusted average for seven types of closed-end installment loans was 2.57 percent at the end of the year compared with 2.56 percent at the end of September and 2.64 percent at the end of 1989.
"Consumers are reorienting their finances," said Robert H. Dugger, an economist for the banker's group. "They're reducing savings, paying up their mortgage obligations, holding their own with ordinary consumer debt and falling behind in credit-card debt."
The delinquency rate for home equity lines of credit, as measured by the American Bankers Association, edged up to 0.85 percent at the end of 1990 from 0.80 percent.
Delinquency rates often do not rise significantly until well into a recession.
The banking group surveyed 800 commercial banks, tracking loans in all 50 states, Puerto Rico and the District of Columbia.
The seven loan types surveyed for the closed-end installment rate include personal, two types of auto loans, mobile home, recreational vehicle, property improvement and second mortgages.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
Using Bacteria to Control Pollution

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
Bacteria may be better than chemicals or absorbent materials at controlling emissions of volatile solvents that contribute to low-level smog and at eliminating the odors of sewage treatment plants and composting operations, experts in the field say.
Although the use of bacteria to clean up pollution on land and in water is still in the experimental stage, at least two dozen biological filters are in use in this country, scrubbing out odors and breaking foul organic compounds into more benign carbon dioxide and water. 
 Biofilters or soil bioreactors, as they are called, take advantage of bacteria's ability to adapt themselves to feed on whatever material is available, from tree leaves to propane.
The filters are decidedly low tech and appear from the outside to be little more than a mound of dirt. But they can control air emission problems without consuming the chemicals used in scrubber systems or without the regeneration systems needed with activated carbon treatment.
S. C. Johnson & Son Inc. uses a biofilter to treat emissions of pentane and butane that escape from its aerosol can filling operations in Racine, Wis. "We lose from 30 to 100 tons from the aerosol filling line a year," said Timothy Lafond, the environmental manager at Johnson's Waxdale manufacturing plant. "On average we get 90 percent-plus control efficiency" from the biofilter, he said. The bacteria present in the soil break the relatively simple hydrocarbons into carbon dioxide and water, which are vented into the atmosphere.
Since volatile organic compounds like pentane and butane contribute to low-altitude smog, emissions are being progressively restricted by Federal and state regulations. The Johnson filter has been in continuous operation since December 1988 with little maintenance other than watering in dry periods.
 
Key Ingredient Is Dirt
 Like most biofilters, the principal ingredient is dirt. Air from around the aerosol filling is collected and blown into a grid of perforated pipes laid in a bed of gravel. The gravel diffuses the air-solvent mix, which rises into the three-foot-deep dirt filter.
In it, the hydrocarbon molecules are adsorbed on droplets of water and then broken down by microbes that obtain energy and elements necessary for their survival and growth in the process. The oxygen-rich atmosphere insures that the offensive compounds will be converted chemically to oxides before leaving the filter.
The Johnson filter occupies an acre between two factory buildings. It is covered with grass and looks like an open field. The performance of the filter fluctuates with the seasons because it is based on living organisms. Mr. Lafond says that 99 percent of the hydrocarbons are destroyed in warm weather, but that the breakdown rate drops to 65 percent in severe cold as the bacteria become less active.
Mr. Lafond said it was not necessary to develop special strains of bacteria to make a soil filter work. "The bugs are already there," he added. But he said there was a "learning curve" when it was first used, as the bacteria adapted to feed on the hydrocarbons. "We started at 30 to 40 percent efficiency and gradually took that up to over 90 percent," Mr. Lafond said, as the solvent-eating bacteria increased in number.
 
Looking for Green Grass
 Since moisture in an important part of the treatment process, the water content of the filter is monitored. "If the grass is green, then we assume the water is O.K.," Mr. Lafond said. "If it starts to turn brown, then we get concerned." Lawn sprinklers are used until the grass is green and lush again.
Since the bacteria feed on the wastes they are treating, the filters can be operated for years with little attention. Maintenance is sometimes limited to cutting the grass. The one exception is in cases where the chemical products of the breakdown process tend to acidify. Many of the bacteria that best remove odor-causing compounds are sensitive to acidity of the soil. Once again, though, the solution is simple.
For example, in Gainesville, Fla., a soil filter is used to remove hydrogen sulfide -- a toxic gas with a rotten-egg smell -- from a sewage treatment plant. Although the filter removes more than 99 percent of the offensive gas, according to Eric R. Allen, a professor of environmental engineering at the University of Florida, the sulfur oxides produced by the breakup of hydrogen sulfide tend to combine with the moisture in the earth to form sulfuric acid.
"We have to add lime to offset the acidity," Professor Allen said.
 
'Very, Very Cheap'
 He said the low-tech nature of biofilters had made it difficult to convince engineers accustomed to chemical treatment systems of their value. But he said economics might increase their attractiveness. "They are very, very cheap to operate," he said.
A report produced by Geoffrey A. Kuter of International Process Systems, which uses biofilters to control odors from composting operations, indicated that the annual operating cost would be 44 percent less than a chemical scrubbing system and 75 percent less than activated carbon -- which is highly adsorbent because of its large surface area.
One drawback is the amount of land required for a biofilter. Not every industrial site has an acre or more to set aside to treat emissions. "If you have a lot of area, then you can use a biofilter," said Sam Cha, a chemist with TRC Environmental Engineering in East Hartford, Conn. "But if you do not, they you would probably want a carbon system, because they are very compact."
There are a variety of formulas for the composition of biofilters, depending on the compounds to be treated. Ordinary soil, compost and peat provide the microorganisms, and other materials, like volcanic ash, sand and bark, are used to make the pile porous. Mr. Kuter said the ideal filter had 40 to 60 percent empty space to allow air to circulate.
He said biofilters were merely an engineered version of a technique practiced for centuries: covering foul-smelling materials with soil to control odor. Some examples are the soil covers typically found over septic systems and garbage landfills.
But he said the effectiveness of this approach had been limited by the amount of oxygen present in the soil. By controlling the amount of air being mixed with the substance to be treated, biofilter operators can insure an abundant supply of oxygen.
Biofilters have been widely used in Europe and Japan, and are gradually attracting more interest in this country. "We did our project before it became popular," Mr. Lafond said. "Now a lot of people are very interested in biological systems."


GRAPHIC: Biofilters consist of microbes which break down foul-smelling waste gases. The microbes are nurtured in a soil filter bed that can also include such materials as compost, volcanic ash and sand. The gas is under the mound of soil.
Diagrams: "Clearing the Air Over Treatment Plants"
 The microbes live off the odorous compounds in the molecules of waste gas, producing largely carbon dioxide and water.
 Biofilters regenerate themselves and require very little maintenance to continue operating for years.
 
(Source: International Process Systems)

HEADLINE: Diamond Sales Hurt by War

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: JOHANNESBURG, March 12

 BODY:
De Beers Consolidated Mines Ltd., the world's largest diamond producer, said today that the Persian Gulf crisis had hurt diamond sales last year, but that the recent jump in world stock markets should lead to an improvement.
Sales fell slightly last year in North America and Japan but rose slightly in Europe.
But diamond activity in Israel, a leading cutting center, fell 30 percent to 40 percent during the crisis. Buyers of polished diamonds were unwilling to travel during the crisis. Economic uncertainty and consumer caution in the United States, the biggest retail jewelry market, also had an effect.
But the company's chairman, Julian Ogilvie Thompson, said he was encouraged by the gains in recent weeks on stock exchanges around the world. "That is often a pointer to how our business may go, down the road," he said.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Pink Slips, Budget Blues

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
FORECASTERS who have been counting on the recession to melt away with the sunny news from the Persian Gulf got a rude surprise from the Labor Department on Friday. Unemployment reached 6.5 percent in February, the highest rate in four years and a sobering three-tenths of a percentage point higher than a month earlier.
The prospect of a slow recovery is likely to focus attention on a subject that almost everyone in Washington would like to ignore: unemployment benefits. For while there is wide agreement that the safety net for jobless workers has been weakened in the last decade, a fix would cost money. 
 States bear the primary responsibility for unemployment insurance, setting eligibility rules and compensation levels and then taxing employers to finance the first six months of each worker's jobless pay. Last year the states spent $17 billion on some eight million claimants, with the average beneficiary taking home $154 a week for 13 weeks.
Once workers run through 26 weeks of ordinary benefits they become eligible for 13 weeks of extended benefits partly paid for by Washington, provided the insured jobless rate in their state exceeds 5 percent. In truly hard times, Congress usually stretches eligibility for many more months. From 1982 through 1985, workers in the hardest-hit states received benefits for 55 weeks at a cumulative cost to Uncle Sam of $12 billion.
Six months of benefits . . . three months of extended benefits in high-unemployment states . . . an extra three or four months beyond that if job prospects turn extra grim. . . . Where's the problem?
Wayne Vroman, an economist at the Urban Institute in Washington, points out that the proportion of unemployed workers who collect benefits has fallen sharply since the 1970's. In part this reflects tougher state eligibility requirements, in part a shift in unemployment patterns toward states that discourage claims. But whatever the cause, the fact that roughly three unemployed workers in five slip through the net is disquieting.
Then there is the issue of the extended benefits. With a majority of unemployed workers ineligible for ordinary benefits or unwilling to claim them, it takes very high unemployment among those who do make claims to get Federal financing to kick in. Last year only two states, Alaska and Rhode Island, along with Puerto Rico reached the threshold. Mr. Vroman estimates that unemployment would have to exceed 15 percent in some states before extended benefits kicked in.
Broadening basic coverage for workers who have lost their jobs in this recession would require state action. And with most states facing severe budget problems, the prospect of expensive reforms requiring higher taxes on employers seems remote. But the Congressional Budget Office does offer a menu of choices for stretching the jobless pay of the long-term unemployed.
Congress might lower the threshold for extended benefits, or use the more relevant total unemployment rate rather than the insured employment rate to determine eligibility. It might extend coverage for everyone who exhausts state-financed benefits as long as the national unemployment rate remains high. Alternatively, it might stretch jobless benefits for those who are poor -- a fundamental departure for a program that has never had a means test. Or it might extend benefits solely for those who had held the same job for many years.
The catch, of course, is the cost. The simplest reform, 13 weeks of extended benefits for everyone receiving regular benefits, would add $5 billion to the Federal budget next year. Changing state eligibility thresholds to 8 percent total unemployment from 5 percent insured unemployment would cost just $500 million a year -- but would help only an extra 300,000 unemployed people.
Washington is deeply reluctant to make an end run around the budget accord by declaring a temporary economic emergency. And it is hard to imagine Congress financing jobless pay at the expense of entrenched interests.
Perhaps the least painful alternative is the one suggested by Isaac Shapiro and Robert Greenstein, analysts at the liberal Center on Budget and Policy Priorities in Washington. They point out that the Federal unemployment insurance tax on employers now applies only to a worker's first $7,000 in income, a small fraction of the $53,400 Social Security tax base. If the unemployment insurance base were simply made equal to the Social Security base, the current tax rate (a not insignificant eight-tenths of 1 percent) could be cut sharply, even as billions in revenue were raised to finance extended benefits.
None of this seems likely in the current political climate. But for every jobless worker there must be five who worry about pink slips and foreclosed mortgages. And it is a fair guess that the political climate will change if the recession lingers.

HEADLINE: Bush Digs In on Arctic Drilling Plan

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 12

 BODY:
President Bush will veto any national energy strategy that does not include his proposal allowing drilling in part of the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge in Alaska, the Secretary of Energy told a Senate hearing today.
Both the White House energy plan and a Senate version propose opening a 1.5-million-acre coastal plain in the wildlife refuge to oil and gas drilling, a provision that environmentalists and some lawmakers oppose. 
 Testifying today before the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee, the Energy Secretary, James D. Watkins, said that any strategy that does not include drilling in part of the wildlife refuge "is a veto-able issue with the President."
Mr. Watkins also told the panel that if no new large oilfields were developed on Alaska's North Slope, where the refuge is situated, declining production would probably force the Trans-Alaska Pipeline to shut down within 18 years.
The two largest oilfields in North America are on the North Slope. One is the Prudhoe Bay field, the most prolific in the nation, and the other is the Kuparuck River field. These two fields and five smaller ones nearby produce from 1.8 million to 2 million barrels of crude oil a day, about 25 percent of American domestic production.
 
Decline in Oil Output Seen
 But Mr. Watkins said today that there was already evidence of a decline in the oil flow from the North Slope. And an Energy Department study whose results were issued today predicted that by the year 2009, the use of the Trans-Alaska Pipeline, which carries oil from the North Slope down the 800-mile length of the state to ports on Alaska's southern coast, might no longer be technically or economically feasible if North Slope production drops, as expected, to less than 300,000 barrels a day.
Estimates of the amount of oil to be found on the Arctic coastal plain range from zero to between 500,000 and 2 million barrels a day. "It could be a small Middle East," Gov. Walter J. Hickel of Alaska, an enthusiastic advocate of the drilling provision, said at the hearing today.
Among the critics of the proposal is Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, who is an Energy Committee member and favors a national energy strategy that places greater emphasis on conservation and less on production.
Mr. Bradley has proposed raising the price that Americans pay for their oil through higher taxes. Today he said the United States could either raise taxes or adopt a policy of "In Fahd We Trust" in which the nation would continue to be dependent on the Saudi king and the leaders of other major oil-producing nations.
Environmentalists today also reiterated their opposition to the Arctic refuge drilling. Brooks Yeager, vice president of the National Audubon Society, said the drilling would "destroy one of the earth's last great dynamic ecosystems."
But Mr. Hickel disagreed.
"We are tired of those who distort the arguments about A.N.W.R.'s coastal plain," he said. "It is a barren, marshy wilderness in the summer, infested with uncountable mosquitoes, and locked in temperatures of 60 and 70 degrees below zero for up to nine months of the year."

HEADLINE: In Rare Move, Governor Intervenes in Denver School Contract

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3d

 BODY:
In a highly unusual effort to improve schools, Gov. Roy Romer of Colorado has seized control of bitter contract talks in the Denver school system to prevent a strike and is personally writing a contract intended to overhaul the school system.
Several education analysts and a spokeswoman for the National Governors' Association says it is the first time a governor intent on bringing about change in his state's public schools has taken such a direct role in local teacher contract talks. The Governor is trying to use collective bargaining talks to force change on resistant school administrators and teachers in the state's second-largest school district with 59,000 students. 
 "I did it for two reasons," said Governor Romer, who invoked an obscure state law allowing him to intercede after Denver's 4,000 teachers voted to strike in January. "I saw a strike about to occur and the wounds would be too severe for too long. And I saw the negotiations were not leading to the kind of reform that ought to occur."
Education analysts praised the Governor, saying his effort shows that change can occur despite hurdles like resistance from the educational bureaucracy. Although no other state is believed to allow intervention by a governor in local labor talks, the analysts said Governor Romer's attempt to meld a labor contract with school reform measures could give the approach greater stature. As a result, they said the tactic might become more commonplace.
 
Posssible Trend Seen
 "Governor Romer is a pretty unusual fellow," said David Hornbeck, a school-reform consultant who helped Kentucky overhaul its public school system. "What he is doing in phenomenal. One is not going to see that kind of leadership and commitment to education from everyone. But I think you're going to begin to see collective bargaining agreements used more often as a vehicle to sustain widespread change."
School board officials and the teacher's union in Denver initially opposed the Governor's intervention. But after months of unsuccessful negotiations, in which Mayor Federico Pena unsuccessfully tried to bring the two sides together, school officials and teachers alike said they welcomed the Governor's involvement.
"If nothing else, it gave people a chance to cool down," said Evie Dennis, the Superintendent of Schools in Denver.
To date, collective bargaining has been used as a tool for systemic school reform in just a handful of school systems, with mixed success. Los Angeles teachers, for example, went on strike for nine days in 1988 over some proposed changes, including giving the schools management powers, before finally approving a contract. Teachers in Rochester, N.Y., have yet to approve a new contract, in large part because of ts performance-for-pay clause instead of a seniority-based pay scale.
"Everybody is going to be running into this when they begin collective bargaining," said Rexford G. Brown, a senior policy analyst at the Education Commission of the States, a Denver research group that studies education policy. Indeed, about 5,000 of the 11,000 local teacher unions represented by the National Education Association, the largest teachers union in the country, are up for contract talks this year and next. Many experts, including Mr. Brown, expect the Denver experience to be repeated.
 
Major Issues in Talks
 At issue in Denver are proposals that would greatly alter the way schools are managed. One would create school committees made up of school officials, teachers, parents and business leaders to manage individual schools. Teachers want such committees to have final veto power, but the school board wants the principal to retain that authority.
In another disagreement, the school board wants salaries to be based on merit, but teachers want salaries based on seniority, as is the current custom. Also in dispute are school transfers: The board wants school committees to decide on teacher transfers, but teachers want those decisions based on seniority.
Teachers also want criteria for performance reviews written into the contract, a point opposed by the school board, which wants greater flexibility in managing teachers.
"It has been a real chore and not a very pleasant one," said Ms. Dennis, the superintendent. So quarrelsome have the negotiations been that they have overshadowed the arguments over a salary package. Rae Garrett, president of the Denver Classroom Teachers Union, added, "We're ready to be through with this."
In personally tackling the Denver impasse, the Governor has chosen a tougher route, bypassing the usual path of addressing public school improvements through state legislation, as Arkansas, Mississippi and Kentucky have done in recent years.
"This is not the easiest way," he said. "It may not even be the most desirable way, but I did it because I saw a school district in crisis."
The Governor, who has held nine days of public hearings and who is getting help from state labor officials in writing the new contract, has not indicated which way he is leaning on the major issues. Whatever he produces will have to be approved by the school board and the union.
"To be frank, they're both going to be irritated at me when I'm done," said Governor Romer.
 
Bid to Recall School Board
 Whatever the outcome, Denver residents are already irritated at the state of the school system. Some parents began a petition drive last November to recall the board, but succeeded in collecting only 11,000 of the 15,000 signatures needed for a recall election.
Other residents have dispatched angry letters to the city's two daily newspapers, taking school administrators, teachers and the Governor to task for the messy state of Denver school affairs.
Undaunted, Governor Romer is expected to present his contract to both sides and the public by month's end, with analysts already giving it a good chance of succeeding -- not because administrators or teachers will be happy, but because it will be unpopular for either side to reject it, given their months of negotiations with no progress.
"We're both going to get a lot of pressure from influential people in town to accept it," Ms. Garrett, the union president, said of the teachers and the school board.

HEADLINE: Mother of Ill Child Wins Jobless Pay

BYLINE: By TAMAR LEWIN

 BODY:
The Minnesota Court of Appeals ruled yesterday that a woman who lost her job last year because she had frequently stayed home to care for her sick baby was entitled to unemployment benefits.
The 32-year-old woman, Diane McCourtney, was dismissed from her job as an account clerk at Seagate Technology, a computer company in Minnetonka, Minn., because she missed work almost half the time from January to May 1990 as her infant son had a series of illnesses, including pneumonia, influenza and pinkeye. 
 Ms. McCourtney did not question the dismissal but went to court to challenge the state's denial of unemployment benefits, contending that she had been unable to find alternative child care for her son when he was ill and should not be penalized for a situation that had been beyond her control.
She said that her husand had been unable to care for the boy and that all their nearby relatives worked. In addition, she said, most local day care providers did not accept sick infants, and the cost of a nurse or a baby sitter who would have come to theMcCourtneys' home on an emergency basis far exceeded their means.
Seagate and the State Commissioner of Jobs and Training said she was not eligible for unemployment benefits because she had chosen to stay home with her son and had voluntarily put family interests ahead of her employer's interest. That amounted to misconduct, they said, and made Ms. McCourtney ineligible for unemployment benfitis, which are available only to those who lose their jobs through no fault of their own.
But yesterday, in overturning the denial of benefits, the appeals court ruled in a 2-to-1 decision that Ms. McCourtney's absenteeism did not amount to misconduct under the law.
"Each of McCourtney's absences was excused and was due to circumstances beyond her control," the court said. "McCourtney made substantial efforts to find care for her child so she could work."
In light of those efforts, the court said, her inability to find care for her child was not misconduct. "McCourtney's actions were motivated by a willful regard for her child's interests and not a wanton disregard of her employer's interest or lack of concern for her job," the court said.
The court noted that Ms. McCourtney had been an excellent employee for more than 10 years and had had no attendance problem until she returned to work 10 weeks after her son was born in September 1989.
The majority opinion was written by Judge Thomas Kalitowski, who was joined by Judge Marianne Short. The dissenter was Peter Popovich, a retired Chief Justice of the State Supreme Court, who said, "Under the majority's analysis, an employer becomes the victim of an employee's personal problems with obtaining child care."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Note and Bond Selloff Lifts Rates

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Pessimism returned to the credit markets yesterday, as a rise in the price of oil and other commodities and worries about coming economic indicators prompted traders to sell Treasury notes and bonds, pushing up interest rates.
After falling on Monday, the Commodity Research Bureau's index of spot prices for 21 leading commodities rose by nearly a point yesterday. 
 Included in that increase was a rise in oil prices, which moved higher after the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries announced it had agreed to cut output in the second quarter by about a million barrels from current levels, to 22.3 million barrels a day. Oil on the New York Mercantile Exchange rose 69 cents, to $19.68 a barrel.
In the past, OPEC agreements have often proven easier to arrive at than to enforce. Some analysts suggested yesterday that the most recent agreement might fall into that category.
"We find the OPEC agreement highly suspect, and suggest the market reaction to it has been overdone," analysts at MMS International, an economic information service company, said in their daily market commentary.
 
Sellers Act on Rumors
 In addition, sellers acted on rumors that a report expected today on vehicle sales during the first 10 days of March would show surprising strength.
"Car sales are seen by the market as the first piece of information in the postwar period about whether the economy will improve," said Ward McCarthy, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, a Princeton, N.J., firm that provides research and commentary on developments in the foreign exchange and fixed-income markets.
Mr. McCarthy said vehicle sales of 7 million or more at an annual rate "would not be viewed in a favorable light" by credit market participants. Lately vehicle sales have been running at an annual rate of around 6 million units.
In addition, traders said the weekly money supply numbers, expected from the Federal Reserve Board tomorrow, are also expected to be fairly strong.
"The numbers have the potential to be disappointing," one government bond trader said. "But basically the story is that the market has run out of things to look forward to, and will find reasons to move lower. A lot of customers have placed their bets, and we aren't seeing any new buyers."
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the bulk of the selling was in longer-term maturities.
By late in the day, the Treasury's 7 7/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 95 23/32, down 1/2 point, to yield 8.26 percent. Late Monday, the issue was offered at a price to yield 8.21 percent.
Among note issues, the 7 3/4 percent 10-year notes were offered at 97 23/ 32, down 9/32, to yield 8.08 percent. And the 6 3/4 percent two-year notes were offered at 99 15/32, down 1/32, to yield 7.04 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates were unchanged.
 
Three- and Six-Month Bills
 Three-month bills were offered late yesterday at a discount rate of 5.84 percent, unchanged from Monday. Six-month bill rates were also unchanged at a late offered rate of 5.88 percent.
Attention in the investment-grade corporate bond market was mostly focused on a total of $1.3 billion worth of asset-backed securities offered by units of the Chase Manhattan Corporation and the Chrysler Corporation. But a number of other issues were also priced.
Among them was a $200 million offering of 30-year debentures by Borden Inc.
The 9.20 percent securities, which mature March 15, 2021, were priced at $99.694, to yield 9.23 percent, 97 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 7/8 percent bonds of 2021 at the time of pricing.
The issue, which is noncallable for life, is rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service and A-plus by the Standard & Poor's Corporation. The First Bostoni Corporation acted as lead manager for the transaction.
In the tax-exempt municipal bond market, the State of Connecticut held a negotiated offering of $200 million worth of general obligation bonds.
The issue consists of serial bonds with maturities from 1992 to 2011. Yields range from 4.10 percent in 1992 to a maximum of 6.90 percent in 2011.
Dillon, Read & Company acted as lead manager for the transaction. The securities are rated AA by both Moody's and Standard & Poor's.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt securities, traders said prices of most widely quoted issues fell by about 1/8 point.
