HEADLINE: IN THE NATION;
Friendlier Skies?

BYLINE: By Tom Wicker

 BODY:
Airline passengers have not had much good news lately, so they have reason to welcome -- for now, at least -- a British-American agreement that will keep Pan American and Trans World Airlines in business a while longer.
The trend has been the other way, exemplified by the recent demise of Eastern Airlines, a pioneer in air travel. Since deregulation began, and partly for that reason, the number of carriers and the number of cities served -- except by smaller commuter planes -- both have decreased. 
You don't have to be an economist or a genius to know what a trend like that ultimately will mean to travelers. Fewer airlines, less competition, curtailed service, higher fares -- that's the American Way.
The complicated British-American arrangement means, however, that Pan Am and T.W.A. will get immediate cash infusions. Both have been suffering big losses; Pan Am was on the verge of shutting down and T.W.A. was in little better shape.
Now they will be allowed to sell their valuable trans-Atlantic routes into London to United Airlines and American Airlines, two of the strongest American carriers. That became possible when the British, in return for various U.S. concessions, granted United and American landing rights at Heathrow, the primary London airport.
Pan Am will get $290 million from United, a substantial part of which will go immediately in lease payments on its aircraft, which were in danger of being grounded by creditors. T.W.A. is to receive $440 million from American, which will help make up for substantial recent operating losses.
These transactions, of course, do not guarantee the survival of either carrier. The sale of assets -- particularly assets as valuable as the right to fly the Atlantic and land at Heathrow -- is not necessarily the best way for a company to save itself. That these weathered veterans of years of airline competition finally were forced to such expedients -- they seem to have had no attractive alternative -- is not encouraging. Pan Am, in fact, was founded and flourished for decades as an international airline, which makes its withdrawal from Atlantic service particularly ironic.
Nevertheless, the reprieve is welcome, particularly since the British-American agreement does not mean that fewer American carriers will be flying to London. United and American will simply replace Pan Am and T.W.A. -- a substitution that angered British Airways officials, since it means two stronger carriers competing on their primary routes.
For trans-Atlantic passengers, in fact, more competition -- that is, more flights -- lies ahead. The deal allows Virgin Atlantic, another British carrier, to begin flights out of Heathrow to the United States. British Airways, moreover, won the eventual rights to schedule more flights from the U.S. to Britain and continental destinations, to receive better representation on U.S. carriers' computerized reservation systems, and to continue London-U.S. flights on to Latin America, Canada and Asia. After this year, United and American, too, will be allowed to schedule more flights into Heathrow.
Most U.S. travelers, however, never fly to London or elsewhere in Europe. Their major concerns are frequency of flights within the U.S., fares for those flights, and communities served. Apart from the immediate rescue of Pan Am and the needed aid to T.W.A., in the long term the British-American agreement may not be all that good for these concerns. It probably means the strengthening of United and American, which already are relatively strong, but not necessarily the survival of Pan Am or T.W.A.Thus, the deal has not removed but may someday add to pressures resulting in less domestic competition.
As a regular airline passenger, I already have felt the effects of the curtailed availability of flights (presumably caused by Eastern's going out of business) from Raleigh-Durham and Florida to New York. And I recently had to fly a commuter airline into and out of Springfield, the capital of Illinois, a city that once had jet service and still deserves it.
Two or three giant carriers dividing the U.S. market may make for healthy airline profit sheets. But if such a quasi-monopoly comes about, which seems more likely all the time, there's no reason to believe that most air travelers will be able to fly to more places at lower fares in greater comfort or safety. Quite the opposite.

HEADLINE: U.S. Trade Benefits From War

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
As a result of the war in the Persian Gulf and its aftermath, the United States is likely to borrow far less from abroad this year than last. Many forecasters expect the deficit in the current account -- the broadest gauge of the nation's imports and exports of goods and services -- to shrink sharply in 1991.
"We'll see a remarkable improvement," said David Rolley, an economist at DRI/McGraw Hill, an economic consulting firm.
According to a report released by the Department of Commerce yesterday, the United States' current account deficit amounted to $99.3 billion in 1990, down from $110 billion in 1989. The $99.3 billion figure is the smallest gap since 1984. 
 Here is how the gulf war could narrow the gap even more: For starters, the invasion of Kuwait helped touch off the recession, cooling the nation's appetite for imports. Then, the allied victory caused crude prices to plunge, slashing the bill for imported oil.
 
$51 Billion for the War Kitty
 In addition, America's allies are contributing about $51 billion to the United States' war kitty, money that otherwise would have had to have been borrowed from private investors overseas.
Finally, postwar rebuilding in the Middle East will increase business for American construction companies and equipment producers. United States arms makers are also expected to benefit as countries restock their arsenals.
In fact, if the allies anted up the bulk of their share of war costs right away, analysts said, the United States could become a net foreign lender, at least for a month or two, for the first time in a decade.
Borrowing less abroad, even temporarily, helps the United States because a smaller current account deficit relieves downward pressure on the dollar and upward pressure on interest rates. That could be important at a time when United States assets are losing some of their allure because investors can now harvest higher returns in, say, Europe.
"Any reduction in the current account deficit is positive in a financial context," says Robert Giordano, director of economic research at Goldman, Sachs & Company. "It will help to limit the buildup of U.S. assets in foreign hands and therefore helps stabilize the dollar and interest rates."
The dollar's recent recovery, for example, has handed the Federal Reserve Board more leeway to fight the recession by reducing the threat of inflation. "The current account collapse gives the Federal Reserve a lot more wiggle room," said Robert Gay, an economist at Morgan Stanley.
The effects of the war on the nation's foreign borrowing are certainly not permanent, and DRI and other forecasters expect the current account to swell again in a year or two.
The nation's current account gap has been narrowing since 1987 when it peaked at $162 billion or 2.6 percent of the gross national product -- the nation's total output of goods and services. The report released yesterday by the Department of Commerce shows a steady pattern of improvement through 1990, in large part, because United States exports of goods and services have been rising while imports continue to slow. And, even before Saddam Hussein's tanks rolled into Kuwait, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development in Paris was predicting major gains that are supposed to bring the current account gap below 1 percent of G.N.P. by the end of 1992.
Mr. Giordano of Goldman, Sachs said even a temporary reduction in United States borrowing would buy time for more permanent trends to have an impact. For example, the dollar's slide last year should give United States exports a lift in 1993.
By the same token, the dent made by last fall's budget-cutting deal on the Federal deficit will show through a few years from now. "With fewer demands on resources by the U.S. Government, the United States wouldn't have to import as many resources from abroad," said William Cline, senior fellow at the Institute for International Economics.
 
Compelling Arithmetic
 While long-term trends are highly uncertain, the arithmetic for this year seems compelling. Total allied pledges amount to more than $51 billion, just $4.3 billion of which had arrived by the end of the year. Federal officials seem reasonably confident, at this point, that the payments will in fact be made.
According to yesterday's Commerce Department report, last fall's allied contributions were more than offset by $7.1 billion in American asssistance to Egypt and Israel.
"What matters is that six or seven months ago, everyone thought the war was purely a U.S. burden," said Maria Ramirez, president of Maria Ramirez Capital Consultants. "U.S. rates went up, the dollar was sliding and the stock market fell apart. Now it's the other way around."
Lower prices and smaller volumes could trim the 1991 oil import bill. In the last two years, by contrast, more expensive oil increased the current account deficit by $10 billion a year. "The moderation in oil prices is likely to last," said Robert D. Hormats, vice chairman of Goldman, Sachs. "The U.S. is in effect the 14th member of OPEC now."

HEADLINE: The Battles to Come;
A Revival of The News Will Prompt Fierce Fighting for Readers and Ads

BYLINE: By ALEX S. JONES

 BODY:
The likely salvation of The Daily News by Robert Maxwell will raise the curtain on a fierce newspaper war as the paper tries to win back its lost circulation and advertising.
"It's how much comes back how soon," said John S. Reidy, a newspaper investment analyst for Smith Barney, who estimated that it would be clear in about four months whether The News can make a successful comeback. 
 Newspaper analysts and executives at New York City's papers generally agree that the survival of The News will be damaging to The New York Post and New York Newsday and good news for The New York Times.
Neither The Times, Newsday nor The Post would discuss specific plans for waging a fight for circulation and advertising in the coming months. But a number of news executives gave their analysis of the situation on the condition of anonymity.
A regenerated, leaner News could threaten the very existence of The Post, whose owner almost closed the paper last fall because of its chronic losses. During the News strike, which began on Oct. 25, The Post enjoyed new profitability because of increased circulation and advertising.
The news executives and analysts say survival of The News is also a blow to New York Newsday and its larger sister paper, Newsday on Long Island, which have been particularly successful in capturing the advertising that had appeared in the Sunday edition of The News. The Post has no Sunday paper.
Had The Daily News been closed, Newsday was poised to scoop up much of its remaining circulation, which would have made it even more attractive to advertisers.
And with The News gone, the logical target for New York Newsday would have been the largely affluent readership and upscale advertisers of The New York Times. But now, instead of attacking The New York Times, New York Newsday will be forced to fight a defensive battle with The News.
 
Newsday's Emergence
 John Morton, a newspaper analyst at Lynch, Jones & Ryan in Washington, said the survival of The News would delay New York Newsday's emergence as the city's second most powerful newspaper, next to The New York Times. "But I don't think it will stop it," Mr. Morton said.
Indeed, business executives at The Times who spoke on condition of anonymity agreed that the main reason The News's survival would help The Times was that it would give The Times breathing room to prepare for a probable battle with Newsday.
For The News, the key to long-term survival will be to win back readers, who in turn would make The News attractive once again to advertisers.
A month before the strike, The News reported to the Audit Bureau of Circulations, which tracks readership, that its average weekday circulation in the New York area during the six months ending Sept. 30 was 1,047,000.
For the same period, in the New York area, The Post reported circulation of 460,000 and The Times reported 719,000. Total circulation for The Times was considerably higher because of its distribution beyond New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
A spokesman for Newsday said Long Island Newsday's pre-strike circulation was 492,000 and New York Newsday's was 222,000.
During the strike, The News's circulation dropped sharply. The paper claims to be selling 600,000 copies a day, but analysts say the actual number may be considerably lower.
A spokesman at Newsday said that Long Island Newsday's weekday circulation grew by 33,000 and that New York Newsday's weekday sales were up 118,000 since the strike began. Peter Kalikow, owner of The Post, said his paper's circulation was up about 190,000 in the city, and a spokesman at The New York Times said the paper's daily circulation in the city and suburbs was 56,000 more than the average reported in September.
 
Big Sunday Jump
 But the biggest swing in circulation -- and in advertising -- has been in the Sunday papers, which typically have the largest circulation of the week and may have almost as much advertising as the rest of the week combined.
A Newsday spokesman said that on Sunday, March 3, New York Newsday's circulation was 435,000, compared with 151,000 before the strike. Long Island Newsday was up by about 23,000, to 586,000. The total for the two Newdays was over one million.
A spokesman for The Times said Sunday sales in the New York area at the end of February were about 1.1 million, which meant that the two Newsdays were within striking distance of overtaking The Times had The News ceased publication.
At a time of economic doldrums in the city, when advertising is scarce, New York Newsday has used its Sunday surge to attract advertising that had been in The News. For the fourth quarter of 1990, Long Island Newsday and New York Newsday together increased advertising, measured in inches of space, by 86 percent compared with the same quarter in 1989, according to Media Records, an organization that measures advertising.
For the same period, The Post was up by 55 percent. But because The Post has no Sunday paper, the Newsdays had six times the total advertising of The Post in the fourth quarter.
 
Now Comes the Test
 The quantity of advertising in The New York Times increased by 20 percent in the fourth quarter, compared with a year earlier, but the total was still 16 percent short of the total amount of advertising in the two Newsdays.
The test now becomes whether New York Newsday and The Post can retain their gains, and especially how the reappearance of The News on city newsstands on Sunday will affect Newsday's Sunday behemoth. "That's the bread and butter, and that's going to be a big part of the battlefield," said Mr. Reidy, the newspaper analyst.
A spokesman for Newsday and New York Newsday said that their plan of slow, steady growth would not change, regardless of The News's fate.
Mr. Kalikow, the owner of The Post, said that if The News survived, he expected The Post's circulation to drop. But he said the paper could still make a profit as long as The News's circulation did not dwarf it, as it did before the strike.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 14, 1991, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article yesterday about the impact of The Daily News settlement on New York City's three other major daily newspapers misstated the change in advertising lineage from the fourth quarter of 1989 to the fourth quarter of 1990. Lineage in The New York Times declined 19 percent in that period, and it declined 8 percent in The New York Post. Lineage in Newsday rose 4 percent.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR: DIPLOMACY;
Baker Sees Israeli and Palestinians But Fails to Narrow Differences

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, March 12

 BODY:
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d concluded talks today with Israeli and Palestinian leaders without either side indicating fundamental change in long-held positions.
Mr. Baker appealed to Palestinian leaders from the Israeli-occupied West Bank and the Gaza Strip to discard the Palestine Liberation Organization and negotiate directly with the Israelis. 
 At the same time, Mr. Baker appealed to Israel's Prime Minister, Yitzhak Shamir, to consider taking steps to open the way for negotiations with the Arab countries and with the Palestinians.
This range of options, Israeli and American officials said, included a halt to Israeli settlement-building in the territories, stopping the deportation of Palestinian militants, ending arrests of Palestinians without trial and, most important, declaring that Israel would not rule out an exchange of land for peace with the Arabs someday.
 
Adamant on P.L.O. Status
 The Palestinian leaders told Mr. Baker that the P.L.O. was their sole representative and that they had no intention of replacing it. And while Mr. Shamir did not reject Mr. Baker's overture, other senior Israeli officials indicated privately and publicly that the idea that this Israeli Government would even suggest trading land for peace one day was out of the question.
[As Mr. Baker pressed his effort to resolve the Arab-Israeli conflict, King Hussein of Jordan said his nation would never agree to be a substitute for the P.L.O. in talks with Israel. But he said that if the Palestinian leadership asked Jordan to join such talks, he would be willing to under certain conditions. Page A12.]
The sense conveyed by the Israeli and Palestinian responses to Mr. Baker's remarks was that, at least for now, the gulf war had not brought much new thinking .
In fact, if anything, the war appears to have provided more of a timeout in the Palestinian-Israeli conflict than a catalyst for its solution. More Israeli civilians and soldiers have been stabbed to death by Palestinians in the two weeks since the gulf war ended and Israeli lifted its curfew in the West Bank and Gaza than were killed in six weeks of Iraqi Scud missile attacks.
Yet both sides seem more interested in being positive with Mr. Baker -- to avoid blame for what they regard as the inevitable failure of this new round of American diplomacy, rather than sincerely considering bold new steps.
American officials traveling with the Secretary of State insist, though, that it is early in the postwar diplomatic process. Further, they say, while no breakthroughs are near, both Israelis and Palestinians are encouraging Mr. Baker to keep working because they recognize that the status quo is becoming increasingly intolerable.
Mr. Baker began his second day in Israel by meeting alone with Mr. Shamir for an hour and 20 minutes. A senior Administration official said Mr. Baker laid out his plans for seeking peace, in which he would try to promote Palestinian-Israeli negotiation simultaneously with peacemaking between Israel and the Arab nations.
Mr. Baker asked Mr. Shamir to "consider a range of different steps" that Israel might take in order to get diplomacy started, and he outlined what he had heard from Arab nations last weekend.
The steps Mr. Baker mentioned, the the senior official said, included reiterating that Israel was committed to an interpretation of Security Council Resolutions 242 and 338 that would not rule out exchanging land for peace.
This last point is crucial for the Americans because only if Israel accepts this principle might Arab nations be willing to make positive gestures -- like ending their state of belligerency with Israel and abandoning an economic boycott. Also, only after such an Israeli commitment might Palestinians be prepared to accept self-rule in the West Bank, under continuing Israeli occupation, as a transitional phase before a final settlement.
Resolution 242 calls on Israel to return territories occupied in the 1967 war in exchange for recognition from the Arab nations and secure borders. Mr. Shamir has consistently argued that the resolution does not mention "all the territories" and that since Israel has already returned the Sinai to Egypt, it has fulfilled the land-for-peace requirements of the resolution.
Yossi Ben Aharon, director general of Mr. Shamir's office, told Israel radio today that the Government would not make such a commitment at the start of negotiations begin without conditions.
"To focus only the U.N. resolutions can lead only to failure," Mr. Ben Aharon said. "It is natural we all must be ready for negotiations without preconditions, and then we will confront the territorial issue."
American officials said Mr. Shamir promised to consider Mr. Baker's suggestions and to come back with some of his own. The Israeli Prime Minister did not rule anything in or out, and Mr. Baker did not ask for any definitive answers now, the American official said.
A few hours after meeting with Mr. Shamir, Mr. Baker went to the residence of the American Consul General in Jerusalem, Philip Wilcox, and held talks with 10 leading Palestinian figures from the West Bank and Gaza. He laid out his approach and asked them to consider what steps they could take to get some peace talks started.
One prominent point Mr. Baker made, said Hanan Ashrawi, a Palestinian professor, was to try "to convince the Palestinians that we should move on our own, without the P.L.O., but we told him that is not on."
Mr. Baker, the Palestinian said, tried to argue that they had a great deal at stake now and should not squander the opportunity by continuing to rely on the P.L.O. leadership, which supported President Saddam Hussein's invasion of Kuwait. Mr. Baker said that all eight Arab foreign ministers he spoke with in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, over the weekend told him that they were "sick" of Yasir Arafat, the P.L.O. chairman, an American official said.
The Palestinians asked Mr. Baker what Mr. Arafat would have to do to persuade Washington to resume its dialogue with the P.L.O., which was broken off in June 1990 when Mr. Arafat refused to condemn a terrorist attack by a P.L.O. faction. The official said Mr. Baker responded that in light of Mr. Arafat's support for Iraq in the gulf war, he was not quite sure now what, if anything, would be sufficient, but that he would think about it.
 It was understood before today's meeting by both sides that no official member of the P.L.O. could attend; otherwise, the Americans would have canceled. Both Palestinians and Americans described the talks today as an animated give-and-take, with the Americans offering to keep the channel open for future contacts.
Faisal al-Husseini, a prominent Palestinian, said after the talks that the Americans "are determined to do something, to go forward, to push."
Before leaving, Mr. Husseini presented Mr. Baker with an 11-point document, apparently cleared by the P.L.O., stating the Palestinians' bottom line. It called for a two-state solution, with a Palestinian state existing "next to the state of Israel," and at another point declared that any peace process must be "structured within a comprehensive, interconnected and coherent plan with a specified time frame for implementation and leading to Palestinian statehood."
In between diplomacy, Mr. Baker took time out for two important side trips. He went to the cemetery where the four Israeli women killed by a Palestinian on Sunday were buried.
In an earlier trip today, Mr. Baker took a helicopter tour to allow the Israelis to show him how narrow the country was within its pre-1967 boundaries -- 10 miles wide and five minutes by helicopter. He also got to see the Golan Heights from the air, as well as Israeli settlements in the West Bank.

HEADLINE: Rushing From Yacht to Jet, Maxwell Relishes New Role

BYLINE: By ALESSANDRA STANLEY

 BODY:
His first, jaunty words as he stepped off his yacht into a waiting Cadillac to complete negotiations with the unions at The Daily News were "I love New York," but the bold lettering on his white baseball cap spoke of another favorite cause: "Maxwell."
Yesterday, Robert Maxwell was able to serve both. His flamboyant last-minute effort to rescue New York City's largest tabloid newspaper did not merely provide the British publisher with yet another newspaper. Mr. Maxwell has also acquired a heady celebrity status in New York that had mostly eluded him in previous visits. And that pleased him. 
 "Somehow this has captured the imagination of the city," said the 67-year-old Mr. Maxwell as he sipped iced tea on his private jet on his way to Massachusetts after a crowded news conference announcing the conclusion of the negotiations. He confided gleefully that an associate had assured him that "even a president or prime minister wouldn't get that big an audience."
Until recently, Mr. Maxwell had remained virtually unknown to the man on the street in New York. But yesterday he began making the city his own in a swirl of activity that took him from his yacht to the news conference at the Macmillan building and then a helicopter to his private jet.
"I am notorious in many parts of the world," he said in his booming English baritone, "but in New York I could always go out for coffee and not be recognized."
 
Private Satisfaction
 Formally, but with a broad smile of private satisfaction, he added, "I recognize that luxury will be gone at the end of this week."
Mr. Maxwell, the self-made British press lord and a socialist leader of a far-flung corporate empire, clearly relished the prospect of owning The Daily News. If he had any last-minute doubts that the deal would collapse, he kept them well hidden. Instead he brought a dash of British pomp and even a twist of Broadway showmanship to the 11th-hour proceedings.
Striding shortly before 10 A.M. into the lobby of the Macmillan building, where the negotiations were held, Mr. Maxwell beamed at waiting reporters and instructed his butler to fetch a giant bouquet of pink roses that had been sent to him by an anonymous, and admiring, Daily News editor out on strike. He read aloud all 12 stanzas from the accompanying poem, including this:
 
We promise you ends,
Just cough up the means.
You've got Princess Di,
But we'll give you Queens.
Sounding very much the publisher, albeit prematurely, Mr Maxwell said of the author, "Clearly, we will make her poetry editor."
Earlier in the morning, refreshed and buoyant after only a few hours' sleep, Mr. Maxwell chuckled over some of the semantic problems that at times had stalled communication between the Englishman and his American interlocutors. "Holidays, vacations," he said with amusement. "I was surprised at how often we were misunderstood, but we sorted it all out."
Almost all of it. Mr. Maxwell, who grew up in Czechoslovakia and who fought with the Free French in World War II, is fluent in six languages, but he is still learning American lore, as evidenced by a fractured reference to Yogi Berra. At one tense juncture in the negotiations, he informed impatient reporters, "As Yogi Bear once said, a thing is not done until it is done."
Mr. Maxwell said he was "terribly sorry" for all the employees at The News who would lose their jobs as a condition of the sale, calling the prospect a "terrible tragedy."
 
'Tough as Boots'
 But he was full of good cheer about his complex dealings with officials of the nine striking unions, some of whom he described as "Runyonesque -- straight out of 'West Side Story.' " He added: "They have a great sense of humor -- I had not realized how the Irish dominate the crafts here. I hold them in high regard. They have good spirits and are as tough as boots."
Though Mr. Maxwell became a prominent figure in Manhattan media circles after he bought the New York-based Macmillan publishing company in 1988, his was not a household name.
Perhaps to correct that imbalance, his entry in Who's Who doubled in length the year after Mr. Maxwell acquired the company that publishes it, Marquis. (The accomplishments of Rupert Murdoch, a rival international press entrepreneur who once stormed the city and bought The New York Post, are mentioned in Who's Who at a far more economical length.)
Mr. Maxwell said he expected to live in New York for the first six months of the newspaper's revitalization.
Yesterday he did not immediately retreat to his yacht on the East River for a public party or a private celebratory moment. Instead he flew to Bedford, Mass., for a meeting to discuss giving money to Harvard for AIDS research.
He planned to end the night in the city where he started the day.
"I never celebrate," he said. "This is a sobering additional responsibility to take on 1,800 people's jobs and the survival of a monument."
Asked if he would add one staple of British tabloids, the seminude models known as Page 3 girls, he replied, "Certainly not."

HEADLINE: DE GUSTIBUS;
A Baker Who Builds And Rebuilds Bakeries

BYLINE: By MARIAN BURROS

 BODY:
WHEN Alou Niangadou left West Africa for Paris in 1979, clutching degrees in mathematics and physics, it was not to start a career in baking. He left, he said, "seeking a better life" than he had in Mali. An apprenticeship at a bakery was the first job he could find, and he loved it. He has never looked back.
 Eager to improve his lot once again, Mr. Niangadou made his way to the United States in 1982, bringing with him all the secrets of the Alsatian bakery in Paris where he worked. By 1986 he had met Eli Zabar and gone to work at E.A.T., the Upper East Side emporium of fancy foods. 
 In his three years there, he enlarged the shop's bread repertory of plain and onion ficelles, the loaves that look like broom handles, and he added raisin-nut bread (which became wildly popular) and health breads as well as a country white and country rye that he brought with him from France. The country bread, he said, is similar to the sourdough bread of the French baker Lionel Poilane that has been shipped to the United States from Paris for 10 years. Not a few Americans willingly paid at least $25 a loaf.
Imagine spending $25 for a loaf of two- or three-day-old bread! In those days it was thought that even New York, with all its wonderful bakeries, could not compete with Paris. New Yorkers know better now.
By the time Mr. Niangadou left E.A.T. in 1989, he had helped to increase its bread business more than tenfold. He is now plying his trade at Burke & Burke, a fancy-food deli owned by Joseph Burke, an Irish immigrant who came to New York with a high-school diploma and a knack for making money.
 Mr. Niangadou hitched his rising star (pun intended) to the company, which seems to be defying the recession.The first Burke & Burke opened in 1982; now there are 16 branches in Manhattan and another is to open on Rodeo Drive in Beverly Hills next month.
Mr. Burke, who had been buying bread from other suppliers, said he hired Mr. Niangadou because he wanted to "trade up." Mr. Niangadou now oversees a crew of seven people, speaking French to one, Spanish to another, his native Bambara to a third and English to an a Polish assistant and to the manager of the bakery on West 13th Street. Three of his assistant bakers came with him from E.A.T.
 Mr. Niangadou also brought his recipes. All the specialty breads he bakes begin with a sourdough starter. Some use no yeast; in winter, others require a small amount.
The 34-year-old baker gets excited when he talks about his two-year-old sourdough starter, or "mother," as bakers call the mixture of flour, water and yeast. One of the first things Mr. Niangadou did before opening the Burke & Burke bakery was to create his own starter. Like the best red wines, the older the starter, the better, which is why he says he is "dying to go to San Francisco," to sample a starter there. "There's no sourdough on earth that is older," he said. He may be right. One San Francisco bakery has a sourdough starter that is at least 75 years old.
 It is the starter that gives the distinctive taste to the best sourdough breads. It is not a taste universally admired. When E.A.T.'s raisin-nut bread was compared with the Burke & Burke raisin-nut bread, the tasters were divided: some preferred the former with wall-to-wall raisins and almost no sour taste; some chose the latter, with fewer raisins and the strong singular sourdough flavor.
Baking with sourdough is a long process that requires patience. Sourdough starters are notoriously temperamental, affected by the wind and rain and snow and sleet. "It's very hard work," Mr. Niangadou said. "You need more than your head to come up with very good bread."
He distinguishes between commercial breads, which turn from flour into loaves in two hours, and sourdoughs, which take eight. "Anyone can make commercial breads," he said. "The breads I'm making, you have to feel it. Without feeling, you can't make them."
 Mr. Niangadou's favorite part of the baking process is the end: the atonal crackling of two dozen loaves of bread just out of the oven. "It's the sound I like best," he said.
 In an informal tasting, the breads Mr. Niangadou is baking at Burke & Burke did as well as or better than the breads he left behind at E.A.T., with more character and more interesting textures and flavors. They are also handsome, particularly the country breads, whose decoratively cut crusts evoke African motifs.
 "The quality of my breads will continue to get better because the older the mother grows, the better the bread," he said. "I'm not afraid of great volume. It's easy compared to developing the sourdough."
 Watching him rest his huge heat-proof fingers on the heated stone of an oven, precisely dividing and shaping the dough, making the slashes on the tops of the baguettes with a razor -- it seems as though he has been baking all his life.
That doesn't mean he is fond of bread. He can barely stand the stuff.
"I've been in the business 10 or 11 years now," he said. "I've seen too much bread, working with it every day, every day. But it makes me feel proud that everyone likes my bread, even if I don't eat it. "
He does take it home to his wife, Rakia, and daughter, Fanta, who will be 3 in June. "Both of them like the bread better than I do."
A few years in America and Mr. Niangadou has latched on to the local dream: a place of his own. When? "As soon as possible," he said. "Somewhere in the U.S." Certainly within five years. "In five years," he said, "my breads will be much much better than they are now, because the mother will be better."

GRAPHIC: Photos: The best part of the baking process, says Alou Niangadou, is the end. (Chester Higgins Jr./The New York Times) (pg. C1); All of the specialty breads baked by Alou Niangadou begin with a sourdough starter. (Chester Higgins Jr./The New York Times) (pg. C7)

HEADLINE: Ex-Gov. LeRoy Collins Dies at 82; Floridian Led Way in 'New South'

BYLINE: By GLENN FOWLER

 BODY:
LeRoy Collins, who was Governor of Florida from 1955 to 1961 and an early "New South" politician who sought to promote racial justice in the region, died in his sleep at his home in Tallahassee yesterday, two days after his 82d birthday.
Mr. Collins had surgery for colon cancer in 1986 and three years later was found to be suffering from lung cancer. He had been undergoing chemotherapy since then. 
 A lawyer and member of the Florida Legislature for two decades, beginning in 1934, Mr. Collins emerged from a conservative "Old South" background at a critical time to play a part in helping to transform the region politically, economically and socially.
 
Took Unpopular Stances
 At the height of the civil rights movement, Mr. Collins took widely unpopular positions, urging Floridians to accept integration of the state's public institutions and promoting equal treatment of blacks by commercial and other interests. "I realized that we had to change," he said later.
In 1965, he represented President Lyndon B. Johnson during the civil rights march by followers of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. from Selma, Ala., to the state capital.
During the years when Mr. Collins held public office and continuing through the 1960's, he was derided by opponents as "Liberal LeRoy" and he was defeated in a 1968 campaign for a seat in the United States Senate by a Republican, Ed Gurney. After the campaign, Mr. Collins decided he would not seek elective office again.
Aside from his activities in promoting racial harmony, he was known for the changes he helped bring about in education and health care in Florida and for his efforts to bring high-technology industries to the state.
Mr. Collins was born in Tallahassee, the son of the owner of a small general store. He later studied at the Eastman Business School in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., and received a degree from the Cumberland Law School in Lebanon, Tenn.
In 1934, at the age of 25, he won his first election for political office, to represent Leon County in the Florida House. After three terms, he won election to the Florida Senate in 1940. He resigned during his second term in the Senate to serve in the Navy in World War II. After the war he was re-elected to the Senate, in 1946 and 1950.
 
Pushed Education Measures
 While in the Senate, he pushed educational measures, including a law that equalized financing among poor rural counties and wealthy urban ones.
In 1954 he ran for the unexpired two-year term of Gov. Dan McCarthy, who died while in office. Mr. Collins won a runoff, defeating Charley E. Johns, the Senate President and acting Governor.
Two years after he became Governor, Florida's public schools and higher education was racially segregated, and a Gallup Poll indicated that four of five white Floridians opposed the United States Supreme Court's 1954 school-desegregation ruling.
Although he had endorsed segregation in his 1954 and 1956 campaigns for Governor, Mr. Collins said his objectives were "to preserve order, obey the courts and keep the schools open."
 
Denounced Store Owners
 As the civil rights movement spread, with sit-ins at lunch-counters in several Florida cities, Mr. Collins went on radio and television in March 1960 to denounce white owners of stores who encouraged blacks to patronize parts of their establishments but denied service to them in others.
He later explained his views on race relations, saying that he had accepted segregation "because I considered that this was the way it was supposed to be," but that he later realized segregation had to end "because it denied fairness and equal opportunity and equal advantage for a large part of our population."
He is a former chairman of the Southern Governors' Conference and the National Governors' Conference, and he was chairman of the 1960 Democratic National Convention that nominated John F. Kennedy for President.
In early 1961, after leaving the Florida Statehouse, Mr. Collins moved to Washington, where he served as president of the National Association of Broadcasters until 1964.
He served as director of the Federal Community Relations Service in 1964 and 1965, after organizing the agency to try to keep the peace at the request of President Johnson after passage of the 1964 Civil Rights Act. It was in that capacity that he represented the Johnson Administration in Alabama, helping to mediate between Dr. King's followers and the police.
Mr. Collins was Under Secretary of Commerce in 1965 and 1966. In 1970, he joined the Tallahassee law firm Evans, Varn, Jacobs & Odom.
He is survived by his wife, the former Mary Call Darby; a son, Thomas Jr. of Tampa; three daughters, Jane Aurell and Mary Proctor of Tallahassee and Darby Begeman of Miami, and several grandchildren.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 15, 1991, Friday

 CORRECTION:
An obituary on Wednesday about LeRoy Collins, a former Governor of Florida, misidentified the Tallahassee law firm that he joined in 1970. It was Ervin, Varn, Jacobs & Odom.

HEADLINE: India Disbands Parliament; Vote in May Seen

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, March 13

 BODY:
The President of India dissolved Parliament today, a week after the resignation of Prime Minister Chandra Shekhar, paving the way for the country's 10th national election. It is expected to be held in May, on a date to be set by the Election Commission.
The vote will be a critical one for India's besieged democracy, and even more so for the Congress Party of former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, which has tried to avoid an election by a variety of ploys since the fall of the V. P. Singh Government in November. Mr. Gandhi's political stock has never been lower. 
 On Tuesday, L. K. Advani, leader of the conservative Bharatiya Janata Party and the opposition to the Shekhar Government, called the Congress Party a threat to democracy.
For four months, the Congress Party supported an administration with no electoral mandate and barely a 10th of the seats in the lower house of Parliament. But it soon became clear that Mr. Shekhar, a professed socialist, intended to act in an independent and pragmatic manner, accepting help from the International Monetary Fund -- unacceptable to many Indian nationalists -- and agreeing to allow American military transport planes to refuel in India during the Persian Gulf war. The refueling was an issue on which Mr. Gandhi, taking a line sympathetic to Iraq, had confronted Mr. Shekhar.
When Congress legislators made a major issue of the stationing of two state policemen from neighboring Haryana outside Mr. Gandhi's house in addition to the usual huge complement of national security officials, Mr. Shekhar quit in annoyance, calling Mr. Gandhi "childish."
Since its defeat in 1989 the Congress Party has suffered in-fighting and charges from state branches and leaders that too much power was in the hands of Mr. Gandhi and a few advisers without political experience.
Before adjourning this week, both houses of Parliament passed continuing resolutions allowing for the federal budget to operate for three months after the end of the fiscal year on March 31. Under electoral law, a new Parliament must assemble by June 5.
International investment ratings for India are plummeting, as the country's budget deficit and balance of payments widen and debt ratios increase.
Economists warn that the perception that the country is without a government -- and is not likely to elect another with any degree of stability whenever voting takes place -- will be very damaging to India among international lending organizations and companies in industrialized nations.

HEADLINE: Manhasset Journal;
Trafficking in Parking For a Fast-Track Crowd

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANHASSET, L.I., March 13

 BODY:
Every morning, like piranhas converging on a tasty ankle, thousands of out-of-town commuters descend on this little hamlet on the North Shore of Long Island, hunting for a place to park.
And every morning the illegal underground economy in this outwardly law-abiding community helps the commuters out. In Manhasset, $125 to $200 can get you a monthly parking place at a gas station, behind a hardware store or even in a driveway. 
 "That's how this place makes its money," said Murray Rousso, who was striding cheerily to the train station on a recent morning, having come from the next-door village of Rosyln to park his car several blocks away behind someone's house.
Manhasset's cottage industry began about 10 years ago, when local officials, annoyed that so many non-residents were taking the train to Manhattan from Manhasset, began to limit parking near the station.
The nonresidents, some from as far as Suffolk County, could go to their own stations on their own lines if they chose. But the trains on Manhasset's line, the Port Washington branch, are prized because they are electric instead of diesel and therefore faster and newer, and because they are almost the only trains on the Long Island Rail Road that do not have to stop at Jamaica.
This convenience of avoiding having to change trains at the Queens junction comes at a considerable price. To get the shorter train ride from Manhasset, many of these commuters must drive much farther, pay much more and walk quite a distance through whatever kind of weather is out there that day.
"Manhasset is quite a desirable place to commute from; it only takes about 28 minutes at rush hour," said Mary Jane Davies, zoning chairman of the Manhasset Council of Civic Associations. "We call these people the out-of-town parkers, and they will go to any limit to get a space."
Because their train line is so coveted, all the communities along the Port Washington branch have problems. In Port Washington itself there is commerce in stolen and counterfeit resident stickers, which permit parking at the station.
In Plandome, parking is so scarce that people have been known to join the Plandome Country Club, right next to the station, just so they can get a parking spot. That means paying a club initiation fee of $2,500 to $15,000 and annual dues of $2,500 to $5,000. Around the station, parking is so bad that village officials recently dusted off an old law against waiting there in a car.
"You're allowed to pick up and discharge there, but not stand and wait," said J. Tim Rice, the village clerk. "If the train that these people are waiting for is not the train that comes, the people in the parking lot can't get out of their spots."
But nowhere is the situation more miserable than in Manhasset, the train stop most convenient to Northern Boulevard, a busy east-west thoroughfare. More than 2,100 commuters, many from out of town, get on the train here each day, turning a sleepy village by night into a busy parking lot by day.
About 10 years ago, when the Manhasset Park District, which regulates parking for the 4,500 families within its borders, began to restrict parking on most nearby streets to 90 minutes, the laws of supply and demand kicked in. Residents began advertising parking space in driveways and even in backyards; commuters began going door to door.
"They call all the time," said a resident of a nearby street who rents four places in his driveway and who asked not to be identified because his little business is illegal. "I don't know how they get my number, but they find it somehow."
Steve Adamides, who owns a gas station several blocks from the station, said he takes in more than $1,000 a month renting parking spaces. "People are always looking for parking," he said. "They always come up and ask. But I only have room for 10 people."
Though renting out space for parking is against the law ("It would mean you were using residential property for business purposes, and you can't do that," Mrs. Davies said), village officials say they can't do much about it.
"If this was one or two cases, it wouldn't be a problem," Mrs. Davies said. "But we'll win a court case in a gas station and knock it out as a parking lot, and within six months it's back to being a parking lot." She has heard that churches rent out spots, too.
Even if the authorities could do something about the illegal parking trade, they're not sure they would want to.
"If we were to close all these lots down tomorrow, where would these people go?" asked Michael C. Adams, chairman of the Manhasset Park District. "They won't go away."
Though some Manhasset residents complain that they have lost their hamlet to the out-of-town parkers, Mr. Adams takes a more sanguine view. "We have no problems with outsiders," he said. "I only hope a few of them would stop and buy something at the local stores on the way out."

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR: United Nations;
Destruction of Iraqi Chemical Arms Urged in U.N.

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, March 13

 BODY:
Britain is pressing the Security Council to demand that President Saddam Hussein destroy all his chemical and biological weapon stocks under international inspection and publicly renounce terrorism before a formal cease-fire in the Persian Gulf war is put into place, diplomats said today.
The British argument is that the council is now in a position to impose such further conditions on President Hussein as part of an obligation under previous resolutions to restore "international peace and security in the area." 
 The British and other diplomats said Britain believed that Iraq was likely to go along with such a demand because it had already shown itself eager to see the Council's economic sanctions lifted by agreeing in principle to other conditions for a cease-fire. Baghdad has agreed in principle, for example, to pay damages to Kuwait and return abducted people and property, even if though it might be slow to carry these out in practice.
So far, the United States and the other countries with forces in the gulf say they have not captured any Iraqi chemical or biological weapons, suggesting that the Iraqi Government has somehow managed to preserve its known stocks intact.
 
Weapons Believed to Be Hidden
 In the war, American military officials reported that Iraq's ability to produce such weapons had been destroyed in allied bombing. But they cautioned that munitions alreadly produced were probably not all destroyed, since the Iraqi Army was believed to have hidden them in many undetermined locations.
The Bush Administration has apparently come to the conclusion that Iraq still has ample stocks of chemical or biological weapons, since Washington has threatened to resume air strikes against Iraq if such weapons are used against rebel groups now trying to overthrow President Hussein.
Other members of the Security Council, however, want to refrain from imposing further conditions on Baghdad, moving instead to enact a formal end to hostilities and lift economic sanctions so Iraq can start earning some of the money it will need to compensate Kuwait for losses suffered during its occupation.
The Bush Administration is not expected to decide where it stands on the British proposal until Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d. returns from the Middle East over the weekend.
 
Comment From Kuwaiti
 Today the Kuwaiti United Nations representative, Mohammad A. Abulhassan, who has just returned from Kuwait, told a news conference that Iraq was still showing no readiness to comply with the Security Council's existing terms for a cease-fire in practical ways, even though it claims it has accepted them in principle.
He said Iraq's National Assembly has still not specifically rescinded the law it passed formally annexing Kuwait and officially published that decision, although the Revolutionary Command Council, the country's supreme decision making body, invalidated all laws concerning Kuwait.
Iraq has also only promised to return unspecified " quantities " of gold and currency stolen from Kuwaiti banks and has said nothing about some $2 billion to $3 billion worth of stolen military equipment as well as art treasures and books looted from museums and libraries, he said.
Mr. Abulhassan stressed the point that Iraq had freed only about 1,200 of the estimated 33,000 Kuwaiti civilians he claims were abducted and has failed even to provide the names of the prisoners of war it is holding, while refusing to take back any of its own P.O.W.'s when the Red Cross tried to send them home.
 
Iraq's Liability Described
 "They don't want them back to tell the story of their defeat and join the rebels," he said.
Finally, Mr. Abulhassan said Iraq should show its readiness to pay compensation for damage caused in Kuwait by agreeing to accept the adjudication of the World Court or some other international tribunal and by creating a fund it would pay money into when sanctions are lifted and it can start selling oil again.
He said Iraq's total liability for such damage could reach $100 billion.
Meanwhile, the United Nations Security Council authorized the largest emergency food shipment to war-torn Iraq today-20,000 tons of wheat flour sent by Yemen, which sided with Baghdad in the gulf crisis.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Ends Mostly Higher On Report of Big Japan Deal

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar finished mostly higher against leading foreign currencies yesterday as traders reacted to a large overseas purchase, the possibility of further interventions by central banks and uneven economic news.
Gold was higher. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery rose $2.10 an ounce, to $366.90. The Republic National Bank of New York later quoted a bid of $366.60, up $2 from late Tuesday's bid. 
 The dollar drifted higher in New York after reports that a large Japanese foreign exchange house bought several billion dollars, driving up the value of the dollar in Tokyo.
But the currency's upward move was stemmed when the Bank of Japan stepped in to counteract the purchase by selling dollars, said Mike Casey, international economist for Maria Ramirez Capital Consultants Inc. in New York.
Economic news later in the day helped push the dollar back down.
In testimony before Congress, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, said the central bank would be willing to ease interest rates again if necessary to promote an economic recovery.
Lower interest rates tend to make dollar-denominated investments less attractive and thus decrease the value of the dollar.
The Fed, in its first national survey since the end of the Persian Gulf war, said it had found the economy still weak but with hints of a pickup in sectors like housing and car sales.
Traders also viewed with skepticism a report from the Commerce Department that retail sales rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in February, their first gain in four months.
"In absolute terms, while retail sales might have been up a little, they are still abysmal," said Lenny Dendunnen, the assistant vice president of foreign exchange at Union Bank of Switzlerand's New York office.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose by 0.50 yen, to a closing 136.55 yen. In London, it fell to 136.35 yen. In New York, the dollar slipped to 135.66 yen, from 135.84 yen late on Tuesday.
In London, the pound fell to $1.8570, from $1.8585 late on Tuesday. In New York, sterling fetched $1.8615 by the end of the day, less than $1.8625 late on Tuesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with those of late on Tuesday, included: 1.5730 German marks, up from 1.5703; 1.3645 Swiss francs, up from 1.3605; 5.3605 French francs, up from 5.3495; 1,173.75 Italian lire, up from 1,172.00, and 1.1538 Canadian dollars, unchanged.
In London, gold rose to a late bid of $366.75 an ounce, up from $364.75 late on Tuesday. In Zurich, the metal's closing bid was $366.30 an ounce, up from $364.75 late Tuesday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose 52 cents an ounce, closing at $366.09.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Money Market Funds Show Only Slight Change in Yields

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report showed mixed changes for the week ended yesterday for the second consecutive week.
Analysts at IBC/Donoghue's noted that the Fed's apparent lowering of the Federal funds rate late last week might be a harbinger of another round of interest rate cuts. Weaker-than-expected employment figures and yesterday's slightly stronger retail sales report for February sent mixed signals for lowering interest rates. 
 In response, the markets are now holding, with yields changing only slightly.
 
Starting Lower
 Walter S. Frank, Donoghue's chief economist, said there was a sense that the recession was bottoming but was not over yet. The only difference between the last week and the previous week, he said, is that rates are starting lower as a result of the easing by the Fed.
In tax-exempt money funds, the average number of days that securities were held in portfolios was up 3 days, to 51. Assets declined a modest $277 million, to a total of $91.5 billion.
The average seven-day compounded yield for the week was unchanged, at 4.14 percent, while the 30-day compounded average yield fell 8 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, to 4.15 percent.
The taxable equivalent of the current seven-day tax-exempt yield is 5.75 percent in the 28 percent tax bracket and 6.17 percent in the 33 percent bracket.
Of the tax-exempt funds with assets of more than $100 million that are monitored by IBC/Donoghue's, the Strong Municipal Money Market fund produced the best return on investment with a yield of 5.22 percent. The fund is managed by Strong/Corneliuson Capital Management of Milwaukee.
Assets on taxable funds rose by $1.7 billion, for a record total of $458.3 billion. Almost the entire cash inflow was in consumer funds, as assets rose by $1.7 billion, to a total of $347.3 billion; institutional fund assets rose by $67 million, to a total of $111 billion. Of the cash flow that went to consumer funds, $418 million went toward Treasuries and $740 million toward Government agency securities.
The average seven-day compounded taxable yield fell by 4 basis points, to 6.34 percent, and the 30-day yield fell 8 basis points, to 6.46 percent. The fund with the best return on investment this week was Dreyfus Worldwide Dollar Money Market, with a yield of 7.21 percent.
By comparison, bank money market accounts, which compete with the money funds and are included in The Bank Rate Monitor's national index, showed an average rate of return that was down 3 basis points, to 5.59 percent.

HEADLINE: Greenspan Hints at Cut In Rates

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 13

 BODY:
As the Federal Reserve reported the first tentative signs that the recession might be easing, Alan Greenspan hinted that the reduced threat of inflation might make it possible for the central bank to give the economy an additional boost by cutting interest rates further.
But Mr. Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board and the Government's most influential economic policy maker, urged Congress not to try to stimulate the economy with lower taxes or increased spending. 
 Asked during testimony before the Joint Economic Committee whether room existed for the Federal Reserve to drive down interest rates more, Mr. Greenspan said, "I think there's certainly more now than there was a few months ago."
He went on to say, however, that he remained cautious about reducing short-term rates at a time when long-term bond rates have been rising slightly.
 
Markets Strengthen
 Some traders said Mr. Greenspan's comments encouraged the financial markets. The prices of Treasury securities rose, and the Dow Jones industrial average, representing blue-chip stocks, was up 32.68 points. [Pages D10 and D20.]
When a questioner asked at the hearing what Congress should do to try to shorten the recession, the Fed chairman replied, "I would be inclined at this stage essentially to stand pat."
Since last fall, the Fed has reduced the Federal funds rate, the interest rate banks pay each other for overnight loans, by two percentage points, to 6 percent from 8 percent. The most recent quarter-point reduction came last Friday, shortly after the Government released employment statistics showing that the nation was still feeling the full force of recession in February.
In theory, lower interest rates should lead to increased borrowing and spending and thus stimulate economic growth, but they tend to take six months or longer to work their way through the economy. If the economy is strong when the effects of the lower rates take hold, the result could be worse inflation.
The prevailing view on Wall Street is that the Fed will soon cut the discount rate, the rate the central bank charges for direct loans to banks. The discount rate is now at 6 percent, the same as the Federal funds rate. Mr. Greenspan prefers the discount rate to be lower than the Federal funds rate because that gives the central bank somewhat more control over the economy.
 
An Added Sentence
 The statement Mr. Greenspan read to the committee today was almost identical to one he presented to the House Ways and Means Committee last week. But he added this sentence to the second paragraph: "The economic data of the past few weeks also included further indications of reduced cost pressures on prices and provided scope for a further easing of monetary policy last Friday."
In financial circles, Mr. Greenspan's words are scrutinized with the kind of intensity that Talmudic scholars apply to the ancient Jewish laws. The additional sentence in the written testimony was interpreted by some analysts today to serve two purposes: to assure the markets, where some confusion existed about the Fed's intentions, that monetary policy had actually been relaxed last Friday and to suggest that the lessened risk of inflation could lead to further easing of interest rate policy.
But no one on the committee asked Mr. Greenspan about that sentence, so his reason for adding it could not be known for sure.
 
'Decline May Be Slowing'
 While the chairman was on Capitol Hill, the Fed released its periodic survey of economic conditions in the various regions of the country. "Economic activity remained soft in much of the nation, but there were indications that the decline may be slowing," the survey concluded.
The survey, called the "beige book," was taken to help the Fed prepare for its March 26 meeting, where monetary policy will be set for the spring. The evidence that the recession might be tapering off was anecdotal rather than statistical.
Among the positive signs were these: Retail inventories, except for automobile stocks, seemed to be at satisfactory levels. A slight improvement or an easing of the downward trend in manufacturing was noted in several regions. Realtors and home builders reported an increase in buyer interest and, in some areas, a rise in home purchases.
The information for the survey was collected before March 4 and was compiled by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
Retail sales in most regions were still sluggish, according to the survey. But the Commerce Department reported today that retail sales nationwide increased by eight-tenths of a percent in February, the first gain in four months. The sales level was still half a percentage point below what it was in February 1990. And auto makers reported today that their sales in early March were down 14.7 percent.
Mr. Greenspan said his advice to Congress not to lower taxes or increase spending to stimulate the economy was grounded in his belief that the recession would end and the economy begin to rebound soon. If that appraisal proved to be wrong in the next few months, the Fed chairman said, additional fiscal stimulus might be wise.
Senator Paul S. Sarbanes, the Maryland Democrat who heads the Joint Economic Committee, suggested that Congress might want to improve unemployment benefits or step up spending on public works projects to create jobs. Mr. Greenspan said such steps might be "counterproductive" because the economy could be "accelerating" by the time they went into effect.
Mr. Greenspan said he remained concerned about the reluctance of some banks to make loans to creditworthy customers and about the failure of the Fed's policies thus far to make much of a dent in the credit problem. "We're going to continue to push until we find the unraveling of the credit crunch evident," he said.

HEADLINE: American Airlines Begins Round Of Discounts to Encourage Travel

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

 BODY:
American Airlines, the nation's largest carrier and the airline that is considered a leader in determining fares, initiated a broad range of price cuts yesterday in the hope of attracting travelers put off by the gulf war and the recession. But it also raised some fares in an attempt to compensate for revenue lost through the many reductions.
American introduced a number of short-term promotions like a $318 round-trip fare between New York and Los Angeles or San Francisco, and the other four biggest airlines -- United, Delta, Northwest and Continental -- said they would match most of them. 
 But American went beyond these special offers, altering its pricing structure and hoping the industry will follow. The airline, which along with its competitors had spent two years trying to simplify the fare structure and eliminate many discount rates, is now seeking to reverse that trend. It has brought back the 30-day advanced-purchase fare, which until it was phased out two years ago had been the lowest fare available to travelers. It also added new discount fares aimed at the business traveler. And it is substantially cutting the price of some international tickets.
 
14-Day Fares to Rise
 But while American revived the 30-day discount fare, it will significantly raise its 14-day advance purchase fares, which have been particularly popular with leisure travelers. The carrier also announced that more of its lowest discount fares will now require travel between noon Monday and noon Thursday, the days when the most seats are available industrywide. The goal is to try to prevent discount passengers from taking away too many seats from higher-fare passengers. American also said it would limit the number of lowest-fare seats that it makes available.
To these changes, the other major carriers reacted cautiously, saying they needed to study them.
American will revive the 30-day advance-purchase fare on April 9, after its short-term promotions end. The 30-day fares will for the most part be somewhat lower than the best fares now available except for the short-term offers. For example, a round trip between New York and Los Angeles on weekdays will cost $468 if bought 30 days in advance and on weekends, $518.
The current 14-day rate on weekdays is $504 and on weekends, $554. But the 14-day fare between these cities will rise to $558 on weekdays, and to $608 on weekends.
Michael W. Gunn, senior vice president of marketing at American, said the 30-day advance-purchase fare would be the lowest discount fare in the market -- about 8 to 10 percent below the current 14-day fares and from $60 to $90 a round trip below the new, lower 14-day fares.
 
Low Prices Until April 8
 The savings on the short-term offer are more substantial. For example, the round-trip fare from New York to San Francisco, which was $504 on weekdays on a ticket bought at least 14 days before traveling, will fall to $318 for travel during the spring and to $398 for travel during the summer, as long as the ticket is bought by April 8. The new fare must be purchased seven days in advance, is not refundable and requires a Saturday-night stay.
American is also trying to respond to the growing resistance of business travelers to pay full coach fares, which have risen substantially in recent years.
For the short term, it matched Delta's offer of 20 percent off regular coach fare if the trip is booked three days in advance.
For tickets bought after April 9. American has proposed a seven-day advance purchase fare aimed at business travelers that would have a 25 percent cancellation penalty.
 
Discounts to Europe
 American is also offering lower fares to Europe, Japan, Hong Kong, Australia and New Zealand. Travel from New York to various European destinations, for example, would be $598 round trip during the peak travel period after June 1, which is 29 to 32 percent lower than the current Eurosaver fare, the main discount fare in the market.
Some analysts would not characterize American's moves as the beginning of a fare war, because they were not aimed at gaining share in a particular market or against another carrier. Instead, they said, the strategy was broadly aimed at stimulating weak traffic.
Mr. Gunn said the fare restructuring was intended to encourage people to make their summer reservations early.
 
Profits Are Expected
 Kevin Murphy, an airline analyst for Morgan Stanley, said the fares would not cut too deeply into the industry's revenues because fares have been driven upward by about 15 percent by a series of fuel surchages since last August. He added that there had also been significant fare increases before then.
Mr. Murphy said that because of the increases the industry had room to cut and still keep fares high enough to make a profit.
The industry has been helped recently by a drop in fuel prices to about 70 cents a gallon, from well over $1 last fall. Traffic has also showed signs of recovering now that the Persian Gulf crisis has been resolved although it is still far below normal.
On the other hand, the carriers have been taking delivery of a large number of new planes and need to bring in more passengers to fill up the new capacity.
American is preparing to take over the London routes of Trans World Airlines, pending approval from government agencies, and is trying to restore the confidence of travelers.

HEADLINE: $60 Million in Cash Backs New Credit-Card Securities

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
To allay investor concerns that rising consumer defaults on credit-card loans could cause losses for holders of securities backed by those loans, J. P. Morgan Securities and the MBNA America Bank announced a new variety of credit-card security yesterday.
The new $500 million issue is backed by $60 million held in a special cash collateral account, rather than by a letter of credit from a bank. The cash account will be available to investors if needed to avoid a default on the securities. 
 Like other credit-card securities, the primary backing for the new issue is the interest and principal payments from a pool of credit-card loans. Because the interest rate on those loans is 22.2 percent, analysts expect that in normal times the interest payments would be more than enough to cover loan losses. Last year, the default rate was 3.4 percent for the pool of credit cards backing the new securities.
 
Relying on Banks' Letters
 In the past, issuers of credit-card securities have relied heavily on letters issued by triple-A rated banks that promised to make payments if needed to avoid default on the securities. But if the banks' credit rating is cut, the rating on the credit-card securities would also decline, and that has raised concern among investors.
Analysts at Moody's Investors Service Inc. noted in a January report that "a future recession could result in significantly higher losses on credit-card debt" than the peak default rate in the previous recession of 2.7 percent set in 1980.
At MBNA, for example, recent rating cuts on Barclays Bank and the Industrial Bank of Japan resulted in lower ratings on some of its outstanding credit-card securities. Although a ratings decline does not result in any loss of interest or principal payments, investors are hurt because it reduces slightly the value of their investment.
Peter Atwater, an investment banker at J. P. Morgan, noted that MBNA sought new ideas because the loans backing the securities were from cards issued by the First American Bank of Tennessee and the Equitable Bank of Delaware, and would be the first offering by the company since it became independent earlier this year.
MBNA, which recently bought the credit-card businesses of the banks, had been owned by the MBNA Corporation in Baltimore, the holding company of the Maryland National Bank.
Although the default rate on the cards backing the securities differs little from the national rate, some investors were concerned because the cards' issuers were relatively small.
 
Role of Swiss Bank
 The source of the cash in the MBNA deal was not disclosed yesterday, but investment bankers said the Swiss Bank Corporation provided money in exchange for an annual fee and use of the interest earned by investing the funds in top-rated commercial paper. Swiss Bank declined to confirm or deny its participation.
The $500 million issue pays an interest rate of 8.25 percent and was offered at a price of about 99.86, to yield 8.325 percent over the estimated average life of 3.1 years.

HEADLINE: Growth Cited by Prudential

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The Prudential Insurance Company, North America's largest insurer, said yesterday that its total capital grew by $100 million, to $8 billion, last year, despite large losses in investments and its home real estate and securities divisions.
The privately held insurance giant said total capital, a key measurement it uses to report overall financial growth, expanded despite "the most difficult conditions that financial services companies have faced in a decade." 
 The company's individual insurance, group insurance and asset management businesses reported strong earnings in 1990, Prudential's chairman and chief executive, Robert C. Winters, said.
But those gains were trimmed by a $259 million annual net loss from Prudential Securities, the company's securities brokerage subsidiary.
Prudential Securities last year turned in one of the worst financial performances in Wall Street history and scrapped an ambitious plan to expand into the lucrative investment banking field.
Prudential's residential brokerage network, Prudential Real Estate Affiliates, suffered losses "somewhat greater than planned" because of a slowing economy and poor real estate market.
Prudential, a mutual insurance company owned by its policyholders, did not release net income figures for the last year.
