HEADLINE: To Sell Tax, Weicker Takes It on the Chin

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BLOOMFIELD, Conn., March 13

 BODY:
Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. rubbed his eyes, took another swallow of Perrier and prepared himself for one more anonymous assault from a listener of the Brad Davis Breakfast Club.
It was not yet 8 A.M., and already callers to the radio talk show had accused Mr. Weicker of misleading voters, padding state finances to fix up the Executive Residence and devising an income tax that a Bloomfield woman said could force her to lose her home. It was just another morning, in other words, in Mr. Weicker's one-man campaign as a lightning rod for his plan to overhaul Connecticut's tax system. 
 "I've put myself in the position where I can be shot at, because that's the way I'm going to sell the budget," Mr. Weicker said as he emerged after nearly 90 minutes of conciliatory salesmanship -- and occasional flashes of impatience -- in Mr. Davis's cramped sound booth at WDRC-AM. "I don't blame anybody for their frustration. It's the same frustration I had when I devised the damn plan."
One month after Mr. Weicker announced that the state's fiscal crisis and recession had rendered Connecticut's budget system unworkable and obsolete, and that a long-avoided personal income tax on wages was the necessary cure, frustration seems to reign on all sides. To a certain extent, Mr. Weicker says, that is a good thing. As long as everyone is angry, his budget will be perceived as fair, he argues, while letting anyone off the hook would doom any chance of passage.
 
'It's Hard but It's Fair'
 By that measure, to judge by the tone of most Breakfast Club callers today, Mr. Weicker's plan would seem to be in pretty good shape, with little danger of anyone being truly happy anytime soon.
The balance of pain was threatened for the first time this week, the Governor said, when union leaders representing 50,000 state workers said they would not accept $400 million in wage and benefit cuts without extending negotiations.
The Governor immediately ordered his commissioners to begin preparing for layoffs as early as April 1. "I think the message is very consistent -- very tough, it's hard but it's fair -- and that is the reason why I can't allow somebody to go ahead and stiff us," he said of the unions. "The minute someone escapes, in terms of the price to be paid, believe me, the whole matter will collapse."
 
Cuts and Layoffs
 Mr. Weicker, who took office as an independent less than three months ago, has proposed a 6 percent tax on all income earned in the state above $25,000 for a family and $12,500 for an individual. Other taxes would lowered to stimulate the economy: The 8 percent sales tax would be reduced to 4.25 percent, but broadened to include previously untaxed items like gasoline; the 13.8 percent corporate profits tax, by far the highest in the nation, would be lowered to 11.5 percent.
State education aid to wealthy towns would be sharply reduced. More than $700 million would be cut from the preliminary budget requests submitted by state agencies, resulting in at least 1,100 layoffs beginning on July 1. And he is counting on $400 million in contract givebacks by state employees.
In what has become almost a stump speech repeated on radio and television call-in shows and in speeches, Mr. Weicker makes the same points in favor of the plan, often in response to the same questions or the same insults.
When a caller says that he or she can't bear to pay a single dollar more in state taxes, the Governor asks how much they earn, then in most cases tells them they will pay less.
The state's poorest families, he says, now pay 5.5 percent of their income in taxes, primarily because of the relatively high sales tax, and would pay only 3.6 percent under his plan.
 
'Not Now or Ever'
 Families who earn $30,000 or less would pay less in taxes than they do now, while those earning $30,000 to $40,000 a year would pay about $150 more, he says. (He generally does not mention that people who do not itemize deductions on their Federal tax returns will pay more, since they will not be able to deduct the cost of their state income tax payments.)
Mr. Weicker, who has no members of his independent Connecticut Party in the General Assembly, also says he will veto any alternative that does not allow cuts in business taxes, or that includes "gimmicks" or excessive borrowing, though he would not require another plan to include an income tax.
On this morning's call-in show, Mr. Weicker faced more complaints than questions. "Connecticut voters will not now or ever allow a state income tax," vowed one of the many anti-tax callers.
Mr. Weicker began, "The fact is that you haven't paid your bills . . ." When the man interrupted, Mr. Weicker snapped, "Let me finish,' and explained how the tax system had depended on gimmicks that had worsened the region's recession.
The next caller was a supporter of Mr. Weicker's -- the only caller to so identify herself -- who said a friend was so infuriated with Mr. Weicker that the two no longer spoke. She hoped that his fiscal solutions would be no more severe than they had to be; Mr. Weicker used that softball to say he had hoped to minimize layoffs, but that the unions were making it difficult.
 
'Unsure What to Do'
 But the public at large is more clearly confused, pollsters say. "Weicker confronts a public unhappy about the fiscal situation but unsure of what to do about it," said G. Donald Ferree Jr., the associate director of the Institute for Social Inquiry, which conducts opinion polls for the University of Connecticut.
Mr. Ferree said that 500 people were questioned between Feb. 26 and March 5 in a poll with a margin of error of plus or minus 5 percent. Asked to choose between an income tax and raising existing taxes, 29 percent selected the income tax and 30 percent favored raising other taxes. But 40 percent said they disliked all the alternatives.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. responding to a caller as he defended his tax plan on a radio talk show in Bloomfield, Conn. "I've put myself in the position where I can be shot at, because that's the way I'm going to sell the budget," he said. (Steve Miller for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Economic Pulse: The Pacific Northwest - A special report.;
Northwest's Fortunes, Once Grim, Thrive Despite National Recession

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEATTLE, March 13

 BODY:
Ten years ago, during the nation's last recession, the Pacific Northwest was an economic disaster zone, with unemployment rates exceeding 15 percent in some areas and people leaving in droves. The 1980 eruption of Mount St. Helens and the destruction it wrought seemed an apt symbol of the region's fractured economy.
Now, as the nation struggles through another downturn, Washington, Oregon and Idaho are thriving, adding jobs and people while most areas are fighting just to hold on. And economists predict the Northwest's economy will continue to outperform the rest of the United States well into the 1990's. 
 Although the Northwest has only 10 million people, it exports more manufactured goods than much more populous regions of North America. It sells airplanes to the Japanese, computer software to the Europeans and sneakers to the world.
 
A Bountiful Economy
 From the region's forests and river valleys come apples, wood, wheat and wine, most of which are also sold overseas. Its abundant water is used to grow potatoes and peaches in the region's desert interior and to provide cheap hydropower to the big cities on the coast. It has been adding jobs at nearly three times the national rate.
"Economic growth in the Pacific Northwest has been unmatched by any part of the country," said Paul Sommers, research director at the University of Washington's Northwest Policy Center and co-author of a recent report on the regional economy. "At the same time that the manufacturing sector in the rest of the United States was falling apart, this region took off."
Yet, as with all booms, the ride up is fraught with risks. Washington, one of the fastest growing and most prosperous states in the nation, is still heavily dependent on one company -- Boeing -- and that company's fortunes depend on the health of the airline industry worldwide.
The explosive growth of recent years, fueled in large part by migration from California, has produced choked traffic in Seattle and Portland, driven real estate prices well beyond the reach of many and forced a number of new responsibilities on local governments used to a slower pace.
"If you've been here for awhile, you like the economic good times, but you hate what has happened to the area," said John Prumatico, who works at Microsoft, the world's leading software manufacturer, based in the Seattle suburb Redmond. "But people who just came here from Los Angeles laugh at all the headlines over traffic. It's nothing to them."
And as Governor Booth Gardner of Washington and Mayor Norm Rice of Seattle emphasize, the region, while doing well now, could still be hurt by recession and the social ills associated with rapid growth. In fact, Mayor Rice spends more time sounding notes of caution than working to attract new industry.
"Seattle is not immune to the recession," he said in a recent budget message.
 
Fortune, Nature and Planning
 What happened to turn things around is, in part, a result of luck -- the good fortune of having picked industries that grew beyond expectations in the 1980's. But nature, the abundance of raw materials with which the area is blessed, played a large role. And the rest of the impetus can be attributed to the deliberate attempts by the region's governments to expand the economy.
One of the big catalysts for change was the depression in the timber industry of the early 1980's, when the combination of high interest rates, low demand for lumber and automation put thousands of people out of work. The slump forced those areas most dependent on timber or any other single industry to change their economic focus, or die.
Washington, with less than 2 percent of its jobs tied to the wood-products industry, led the way, sprouting a high-technology community that added Microsoft to the resurgent Boeing, which makes more than half of the world's commercial airplanes.
Spokane, in eastern Washington, known primarily as a logging, mining and farming hub, also began to rebuild its economy. Nearly one worker in eight was unemployed in the inland Northwest in the early 1980's. But then the city's leaders made a conscious effort to change its economy and eventually attracted two big new companies, Seafirst Bank and Boeing.
Washington, like the rest of the Northwestern states, has tied its economic fate to trade with Pacific nations. So, while the rest of the United States went into a slump last year, this state with the highest ratio of jobs tied to international trade, at one job in five, continued to expand. Even in the last quarter of 1990, when Boeing stopped hiring workers and severe floods knocked out bridges and inundated housing developments, Washington added 22,000 jobs, giving it a job growth rate that was nearly four times the national average.
 
Boom in Idaho
 Similarly, Idaho's economy rose out of a crushing slump, with silver and wood prices in the cellar, to a mini-boom as food-processing plants and high-tech companies doubled their overseas sales and their work forces at home. The northern part of the state has been utterly transformed from an area of bleak and polluted towns into an international tourist destination with small manufacturing companies and rich in natural resources.
One town, Kellogg, has replaced its smelter with a ski resort, while another, Coeur d'Alene, a mountain retreat and convention center, last year was named by the readers of Conde Nast's Traveler magazine as the best resort in the country. A company that makes bathing suits opened in Sandpoint, an old logging town.
Oregon, with 80,000 forest products workers in 1979, was the slowest to recover. But in the last decade, as the nation's No. 1 timber state has shed some of its dependence on cutting down trees, it has added 230,000 jobs, almost all of them in areas other than resource extraction, while it has lost nearly 15,000 timber jobs. The state boasts a glamor company in Nike, the athletic shoe manufacturer, a robust trade and financial center in Portland and a high-tech corridor in the fast-growing suburbs west of the city.
So, while the Northwest remains an area where most workers still make something tangible -- airplanes, computer programs, plywood, french fries, clothing -- what they make has changed considerably. For example, shipbuilding, once a mainstay of the region's economy, has virtually disappeared, fled to overseas shipbuilders who have lower manufacturing costs. Timber is still important, but the new emphasis is on selling finished products, like custom-cut wood instead of raw logs, and experts see more of that in the region's future.
 
The Recovery
Years of Pain With a Payoff
The transition to a new economy has not been without pain. Wet coastal timber hamlets -- places like Forks, Wash., or Sweet Home, Ore., -- are a step away from being ghost towns as lumber mill jobs have gone overseas or fallen victim to automation or to cutbacks in logging.
Last year, as the Government debated environmental restrictions to protect the forest home of the endangered spotted owl, state officials predicted that the proposed logging limits would kill thousands of jobs. Restrictions were imposed, but only a small number of jobs have been cut. Instead, an old nemesis -- a recession that hits new home construction particularly hard -- has caused lumber prices to tumble. As a result, 43 mills closed in the three-state area last year.
"It's bad and it's just going to get worse," said Lawrence Gaydeski, a former logger and now a Clallam County official, who lives in Forks, on the Washington coast. "They keep telling us to retrain, retrain, retrain," he said. "I keep saying, for what, for what, for what?"
 
One Worker's Solution
 But Jim Bolton, who lost his job last year when the sawmill that employed him near Eugene, Ore., closed, has found an answer for the dislocated worker. Like many other former forest workers, he has decided to stay in the Northwest and retrain himself for the new economy rather than pull up stakes and leave, as many people did ten years ago during the last downturn.
Mr. Bolton enrolled in a vocational program to learn how to repair recreational vehicles. "I wanted to get into something that isn't dependent on nature," he said.
But he says he expects that initially he will earn less than the $12 an hour he was paid at the mill.
Tourism is a huge growth industry in the Northwest. And while others have disparaged the idea that tourism can generate good jobs, Mr. Bolton sees a good future and better wages in the long run.
 
The Mainstays
Jet Airplanes And High-Tech
The Northwest economy has long been two-tiered, divided between boom-and-bust areas with natural resources like timber, fish and mining, and the fast-growing cities with large labor pools and the ability to provide various services to industries.
The Seattle metropolitan area, with more than two million people, is the region's powerhouse. In 1989, it led the nation in job growth. And a recent nationwide poll of 400 business leaders conducted by Cushman & Wakefield, the real estate company, listed Seattle as the top city in the country for business. Portland was ranked third.
The largest contributor to the boom, of course, is Boeing. Spurred by the decade-long expansion in air travel, Boeing added nearly 50,000 workers in the last six years at pay levels that are among the highest in American manufacturing. Before hiring leveled off at Boeing last fall, the company's work force reached about 105,000 people statewide. Economists at the University of Washington say that each additional Boeing worker brought 2.8 new jobs, usually in retail.
 
Profit's Ascent
 Last year, the company's annual profit reached $1 billion for the first time on sales of $27.6 billion of airplanes. The company's annual sales figure is a big contributor to the Federal Government's balance of trade with foreign countries. The only money-loser was its military business, which drained more than $400 million from the company's revenue last year, with its concentration on Cold War-era weapons that are playing a reduced role in the national military strategy.
Despite the severe slump among airline carriers -- the industry lost $2 billion last year -- Boeing remains confident it will not repeat its collapse of 20 years ago, in which the company was forced to lay off two-thirds of its work force. Company officials say they have a backlog of airplane orders to take it into the next century. Even if airlines continue to fold, Boeing officials argue, the surviving companies will still need to update their fleets with new equipment. If the orders materialize, as analysts predict, for Boeing's next generation of airplanes, the 777, the company might hire another 10,000 workers.
But the Boeing blessing is also a curse, some economists say. During the disastrous drop in business at Boeing two decades ago, Seattle led the nation in unemployment with a level of around 13 percent. At the time of the downturn, 18 percent of all jobs in the Puget Sound region were tied to Boeing. Now, 21 percent of jobs are tied to the company, and Seattle has virtually no unemployment.
"What happened was, the area diversified away from Boeing, and then the company came back like gangbusters, well beyond what anyone ever expected," said Mr. Sommers of the University of Washington, putting the area close to a level considered full employment.
But, experts point out, if the airline industry goes into a prolonged, worldwide recession -- and even before the Persian Gulf war cut air travel the industry was in trouble -- the future of the largest employer in the Northwest may not be so rosy.
 
A $4 Billion Milestone
 It is the jobs outside of Boeing that have been so encouraging to many economists. Microsoft, co-founded by William Gates 3d, who was reared in the area and later dropped out of Harvard to start the company, now has 4,000 people on its Seattle-area payroll. On paper, the personal wealth of Mr. Gates just passed $4 billion. And through a generous employee stock ownership plan, Microsoft has made many of its workers wealthy.
Like Boeing, much of Microsoft's market is overseas. The company is currently creating software programs in Arabic, Chinese and other languages.
Even entry-level jobs in the service industry have benefited from the overall boom. "There is hardly anyone working minimum wage in Seattle, because those jobs would go begging if they tried to pay that low," said Byron Angel, an economist with the State of Washington.
Growth has made construction the leading creator of new jobs in the Northwest. But the surge of new residents, who are entering the Northwest at a rate of more than 100,000 a year, has increased traffic and crime and has led to a shortage in affordable housing.
"Now, we're going to have to start paying the bills for all those newcomers," Mr. Angel said. The rapid job growth, however, is helping the region avoid the high unemployment rates of the last recession. The rate in the three states now closely tracks the national rate.
 
The Challenge
Nature Vs. Growth
The challenge for the Northwest, as its fattening urban areas swallow up much of the spectacular scenery, is to stay prosperous without ruining its garden setting.
"An attractive environment is money in the bank, and that's what the Northwest has in great abundance now," said Ed Whitelaw, a University of Oregon economics professor who is advising the state's new Governor, Barbara Roberts. "If you throw it away during a quick binge, as California did, you are in for a long, long hangover. We have not yet spent our inheritance."
But economists also warn that the Northwest must find a way to use the dividends paid by its new economy, in aerospace, high technology and world trade, to develop the old one, including the dying logging, mining and fishing industries.
 
Fish's Fortunes
 Perhaps no situation is more emblematic of the fight between an environment that draws people to the Northwest and a growing economy that threatens to harm it, than the looming problem over the loss of once-bountiful salmon runs in the Columbia River. This clash between resources and growth could dwarf the spotted owl and forest problem.
If, as expected, certain species of salmon are declared endangered this spring, more water will have to be released from the dams of the Columbia to assist the natural cycle of the fish. That water would normally go to people who farm more than 6 million acres of irrigated land and the utilities that run dozens of hydro-electric power dams.
The fight over the preservation of the salmon runs is an argument that is intricately linked to the concern among many in the Northwest about the quality of life, a phrase frequently mentioned by new businesses. While per capita income in Oregon and Idaho is still below the national average, residents speak of receiving a dividend that has nothing to do with money.
Mr. Bolton, the former sawmill worker who came to Oregon from Ohio 20 years ago, said one of the reasons he could not go back to the Midwest is that he could never give up steelhead fishing.
Mr. Whitelaw, the economist, coined a phrase for this phenomenon -- the "two-paycheck" theory -- now heard throughout the Northwest. "Every worker here gets two paychecks," he said. "One in dollars, the other in clean air, clear streams and scenic vistas."

HEADLINE: Chairman Calls Exxon Strong After Valdez Pact

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 13

 BODY:
Lawrence G. Rawl, the chairman of the Exxon Corporation, said today that the $1.1 billion settlement reached Tuesday night with Alaska and the Federal Government in the Exxon Valdez oil spill would not have any effect on Exxon's finances or its plans.
In a news conference at the company's headquarters in Irving, Tex., that was also shown on closed-circuit television at the National Press Club here, Mr. Rawl said he did not believe the settlement would affect the company's image, which he described as good. 
 Combative at times and not at all chastened, Mr. Rawl nevertheless said the spill, the bad publicity that followed, the expense of cleaning up Prince William Sound in Alaska after the nation's largest oil spill and the civil and criminal cases brought by the Government against Exxon had been an ordeal.
"I feel this a heck of a lot," said Mr. Rawl. "I've been disappointed and angry since March 24, 1989. It's been a burden to us."
 
58 Days of Negotiations
 He insisted, however, that the settlement would not have "a significant effect on our earnings." Indeed, investors saw it as good news: Exxon stock closed at 57 1/4, up $1, on the New York Stock Exchange today.
The settlement, reached late Tuesday after 58 days of negotiation in Juneau and Washington, resolved civil and criminal cases against the world's largest oil company.
As a part of the agreement, Exxon and its shipping subsidiary pleaded guilty to four misdemeanor violations under three Federal environmental laws and agreed to pay a penalty of $100 million, the largest ever for a criminal violation of environmental statutes.
As part of the agreement, two felony charges under the Federal Maritime Law were dropped.
More than 300 civil suits filed against Exxon by private parties are not affected by the accord.
At a news conference in Washington today, Attorney General Dick Thornburgh hailed the agreement as the "strongest message" ever sent by the Government that pollution violations would be thoroughly investigated and prosecuted.
 
Environmentalists Happy
 Several national environmental groups applauded the agreement and said it set new standards for penalizing polluters, among them the principle that full payment would be required to cover environmental damage.
But the chairman of Exxon, the nation's third-largest industrial corporation, today seemed exasperated at times and testy at other moments. It was clear that his intention was to assure shareholders that the settlement would not alter the company's day-to-day operations.
"The settlement encompasses issues we were prepared to contest," Mr. Rawl said. "However, we have agreed to the settlements because they are in the best interests of Exxon shareholders and all other parties involved."
He said Exxon had been preparing for more than a year for the criminal trial that had been scheduled for April 10 in Alaska. "We felt pretty good about our chances." Mr. Rawl said.
But he said he had agreed to fly to Washington, where he signed the settlement just before midnight Tuesday, because "looking forward to years of litigation, maybe decades, wasn't in anybody's interest."
Asked whether he or Exxon had learned anything from the accident and the cleanup, whose cost the company puts at more than $2 billion, Mr. Rawl said: "We learned a lot. Actually, all of us knew some of these things before. We learned a lot about cleanup."
Near the end of his remarks today, Mr. Rawl indicated that the Exxon Valdez disaster had heightened awareness within Exxon about the environment.
"You can't let your guard down," he said. "We all have to be more diligent, I guess. In the future, we have to be a lot more sensitive."
Moments later, he concluded with these remarks: "The day it happened, we said it was our oil, our ship, and we would clean it up. It has distracted us. When you spill oil like that, a disaster like that, you change your priorities pretty quick."
The settlement was reached after negotiation by Mr. Rawl, Gov. Walter J. Hickel, Charles Cole, the Alaska Attorney General, and lawyers from five Federal agencies. The talks started in Juneau on Jan. 15, when Mr. Rawl flew to the state capital to meet with Mr. Hickel and Mr. Cole.
 
A Tough Issue
 One of the toughest issues, participants said today, was gaining Exxon's agreement to plead guilty and pay a $100 million penalty for misdemeanor violations of the Clean Water Act, the Refuse Act and the Migratory Bird Treaty Act.
A year ago, Doug Baily, then Alaska's Attorney General, was unable to obtain the conviction of the captain of the Exxon Valdez, Joseph J. Hazelwood, on charges of piloting the tanker while under the influence of alcohol. Mr. Hazelwood was convicted of a relatively minor charge, negligently discharging oil, but he was acquitted of charges of criminal mischief, operating a vessel while intoxicated and reckless endangerment.
The Federal Government had already initiated talks with Exxon before the verdict in one of the most widely followed trials in state history. In the talks, the Government was seeking $150 million in criminal penalties and guilty pleas to felony violations of environmental laws. But the negotiations fell apart in 1990.
Along with the $100 million criminal penalty, Exxon will pay $90 million this year into a fund overseen by officials from three Federal and three state agencies. In September 1992, the company will pay $150 million more to the fund, followed by a $100 million payment in September 1993, and $70 million annual payments from 1994 through the year 2001.
The agreement could require Exxon to pay as much as $100 million more after 2001 if more environmental damage is found.
 
Only Penalty Isn't Deductible
 Except for the criminal penalty, all payments by Exxon will be tax-deductible. One economist who studied the effects of the spill estimated that Exxon's ability to write off most of the settlement could cost the taxpayers $300 million in lost revenues.
The agreement also calls for the state and the Federal Government to be reimbursed for many expenses incurred in determining the environmental damage from the spill.
Alaska spent more than $72 million and the Federal Government $62 million. These reimbursements are to be among the earliest payments from Exxon.
"The size of the settlement and the criminal pleas represent a clear and unmistakable signal that those involved in environmental crimes will not go unnoticed and unpenalized," Mr. Thornburgh said.
In Alaska, the settlement was greeted with widespread approval.
"I think it's great there is money to protect Prince William Sound," said Tom Masolini, a 34-year-old fisherman from Cordova, a prosperous fishing village near the mouth of the sound.
"You know, along with the oil, one of our concerns here is that there is too much clear-cutting of the forests around the sound. Maybe they can use some of this money to buy up timber rights and preserve forests here."
National environmental groups, including the Natural Resources Defense Council, the National Audubon Society and the National Wildlife Federation, also applauded the agreement.
 
 
 
Spill Was Bigger Than Thought
 GRAND RAPIDS, Minn., March 13 (AP) -- The crude oil that spilled from a ruptured pipeline outside this northern Minnesota city last week totaled 1.7 million gallons, nearly three times as much as the company that owns the pipeline initially estimated.
The new estimate, which was issued Tuesday by the company, Lakehead Pipe Line, makes the spill the largest from a pipeline ever recorded in the state and about one-sixth the size of the Exxon Valdez spill.
Lakehead had previously estimated the spill from the 34-inch pipeline, which carries crude oil from Canada into the United States, at 630,000 gallons.
Most of the spill was contained on land. The Minnesota Department of Natural Resources said harm to fish and wildlife had been minimal.
Officials said the cause of the rupture would probably take months to determine.

He and Gov. Walter Hickel of Alaska spoke yesterday at a news conference. (Agence France-Presse)

THE ECONOMY
Greenspan hinted of further rate cuts, saying the reduced rate of inflation might make it possible for the central bank to give the economy an additional boost. But he urged that Congress not try to stimulate the economy. [Page D1.]
A bill to provide $30 billion more for the bailout of savings and loans was approved by the House. [D1.] Bank profits fell 31 percent in the fourth quarter, to $1.39 billion, the F.D.I.C. said. [D5.]

Retail sales rose in February for the first time in four months. The gain was 0.8 percent. [D7.] Sales of American-made vehicles fell 14.7 percent in early March. [D7.]

COMPANIES
American Airlines initiated a broad range of fare cuts in the hope of attracting travelers put off by the war and the recession. But it also raised some fares. [A1.] The war is over, but the airport security measures imposed at its start may remain. [A18.]

HEADLINE: Breaking Up Is Becoming Harder to Do

BYLINE: By TRISH HALL

 BODY:
THESE days there is so much emphasis on the family that divorce seems to be going out of style. Therapists say many couples struggle harder and longer to stay together than they might have a few years ago. Poll takers find a greater value being placed on the idea of commitment and a happy marriage. And researchers churn out studies suggesting that both children and adults suffer physical and emotional harm from divorce. Indeed, with the advent of books like "Adult Children of Divorce Speak Out" (Simon & Schuster, 1991), the day may be coming when divorce will be considered a pathology.
"I think there is definitely a turning away from the acceptability of divorce and from minimizing the impact of divorce," said Bickley Townsend, a vice president for the Roper Organization in New York, which polls people on social attitudes. 
 When Roper asked 2,000 people last year to define the most important aspect of success, the top choice was "being a good wife and mother, or husband and father." Four years earlier, the top choice was "being true to yourself."
Today, there are 4.7 divorces annually per 1,000 people in the population, down from a peak of 5.3 in 1979. Although the aging of the population may be a major cause of this decline, divorce is also less attractive these days for reasons like the fear of AIDS and the cost of setting up two households in an uncertain economy.
Furthermore, the glorification of the traditional family is evident on television, in movies and especially in books. There has been a proliferation of titles like "Rebuilding the Nest," "The Case Against Divorce," "Family Matters" and "Back to the Family." In the 70's and early 80's, the climate was different. Movies like "Alice Doesn't Live Here Anymore" were popular then and popular fiction celebrated divorce as a means of gaining liberation and a new life.
A woman who divorced in the 70's said so many of her friends were also breaking up that it seemed like an easy thing to go through. Like others who were interviewed, she did not want her name used. Another woman, who is divorcing for the second time, agreed that social realities are different this time around. There is a feeling, she said, that people should try harder. Before breaking up she and her husband spent several years seeing therapists individually, going to joint counseling and even attending marriage workshops and seminars. With her first husband, she said, she sought counseling only briefly before deciding to divorce.
Increasingly, marriage is supposed to be worked on, like a car or a roof, often with expert help. In the last 10 years membership in the American Association for Marriage and Family Therapy has doubled, to 17,500. Although the therapist has been supposed to be neutral as to outcomes, a growing number believe their colleagues ought to try harder to keep marriages together.
Prominently arguing that point of view is Michele Weiner-Davis, a therapist in Woodstock, Ill., whose speech, "Divorce Busters," attracted intense interest at the association's meeting last fall. In her practice, she said in a telephone interview, she has seen many people discover that divorce does not solve their problems.
"In the 60's and 70's," she said, "people really thought that the cause of their unhappiness was their spouse, and if they could get rid of that person, they'd be happy." Instead, said Ms. Weiner-Davis, whose parents were divorced, "divorce creates wounds that never go away."
That message is painful for those who have decided to end their marriages. Painful messages or not, divorce has been made easier by its prevalence and many couples are still willing to divorce. The rate has not fallen as far as some demographers expected it to as the population moved past the teens and twenties, when divorce is most common.
"Just based on the population structure, fewer people are in high-risk groups," said Sally Cuningham, a statistician with the National Center for Health Statistics. The divorce rate has fallen by 11 percent from its peak in 1979, but little of that change has come in the last four years.
"In lots of ways, we have a gap between yearning and behavior," said Barbara Caplan, a vice president at Yankelovich Clancy Shulman in Westport, Conn., which does research in social trends. "There is a recognition that the family is a very workable unit of emotional and economic support. But to bring that about is not the easiest thing in the world."
The long-term consequences of divorce are a topic of great debate among researchers and therapists. Just as some therapists worry about the effects of divorce, others are concerned that bad marriages also create wounds that never go away. "High-conflict or icy-cold marriages often stay together for life, and these are very detrimental to children," said Constance Ahrons, a professor of sociology at the University of Southern California and the author of "Divorced Families" (Norton, 1989).
Adolescent girls are just as distressed by conflicts between their parents at home as they are by the eventual divorce, said William J. Doherty, director of the marriage and family therapy program at the University of Minnesota in St. Paul and a psychotherapist in private practice. He is the author of a study on the effects of divorce to be published next month in The Journal of Child Development.
Researchers' conclusions on the consequences of divorce affect the way people feel. Particularly influential was a study several years ago by Judith Wallerstein suggesting that 50 percent of children in divorced households suffered long-term negative effects, like depression and anger.
Dr. Doherty said his clients took to heart the message of her book, "Second Chances," written with Sandra Blakeslee (Ticknor & Fields, 1989). "I see people who are in distressed marriages and have kids and read Wallerstein's book, and they are scared for their kids," he said. "They may try harder to try to make it work."
Although most researchers agree that divorce causes problems for children, they disagree as to how long those problems last. Many of them discount the Wallerstein findings because there was no control group.
Research by E. Mavis Hetherington at the University of Virginia, which did have a control group, suggests that children can be "survivors, losers or winners" in divorce, depending on such variables as their character, age and resources.
Dr. Ahrons questions society's willingness to blame divorce for an array of problems, and believes the concept of failure should be removed. Given the increase in longevity and the greater economic independence of women, divorce will always be a reasonable choice, she maintains, and couples should be helped to achieve successful marital dissolutions.
 To some extent the feeling that divorce is an unpleasant alternative is a result of 20 years of experience as divorce became more common. In addition, a population that is growing older tends to have a different perspective on relationships.
Judith Langer, a market researcher in New York who interviews about 2,000 people a year in focus groups, said the single life has lost so much of its allure that some people seem to be sticking with marriages despite significant dissatisfaction. "What I'm seeing now, with AIDS, is a lot of fear," she said.
A woman who lives in the Washington area and has been married for 13 years, said she now understands that problems would exist in any relationship. Her marriage may not be what she dreamed of when she was young, she said, but she finds the cost of dismantling it to be too high.
Susan Dangerfield, 39, who lives in Crystal Lake, Ill., was in counseling briefly with her husband and considered divorce at one point, but backed off. "I started looking around at other men I knew, both married and single, and I saw a lot of jerks out there," she said. "It made me realize what a wonderful guy I had."

HEADLINE: The Joke's On Whittle For Losing Best Seller

BYLINE: By RANDALL ROTHENBERG

 BODY:
Whittle Communications roiled book publishing more than a year ago when it introduced a line of advertiser-sponsored books. Now, the book industry's worries have turned to derision. Whittle let a best seller slip from its grasp.
"The Next Century," a look at the future of the world's economy by David Halberstam that now sits on several best-seller lists, was originally solicited by and written for Whittle. But Mr. Halberstam, a Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist and the author of several previous best sellers, said he withdrew the book when Whittle executives objected to the book's tone, content and length. 
 Mr. Halberstam took the book to William Morrow & Company, which published the book with what he and editors there described as minor revisions, three weeks ago. "The Next Century," which has 140,000 copies in print, is No. 4 on The New York Times Book Review best-seller list for March 17.
"David Halberstam is one of the most distinguished figures in American journalism, and it is amazing to me that Whittle Communications or the editor of this book would say that in some way his work doesn't meet their standards," said Peter Osnos, an associate publisher of Random House. "But these things happen."
 
Brings Advertising to Schools
 Whittle, which is based in Knoxville, Tenn., specializes in the development of media that bring advertising into unconventional venues like schools, doctors' offices and health clubs. Several of its projects, notably "Channel One," a sponsored television news program for high school classrooms, have become controversial among educators and communications professionals who believe that such forums should be free from advertising.
In late 1989, Whittle upset many in the publishing industry by announcing the creation of a book division and the publication of a series of short nonfiction works by well-known authors that would carry advertising from the Federal Express Corporation . Many in publishing worried that advertiser sponsorship opened the way for marketers to manipulate the content of books.
Among the writers signed by Whittle in addition to Mr. Halberstam were William Greider, the political editor of Rolling Stone, George Gilder, a conservative economic theorist, and Michael Lewis, the author of "Liar's Poker," a best-selling chronicle of Wall Street in the 1980's.
At the time the project, called the Larger Agenda Series, was announced, Whittle said the authors would be paid about $60,000 each for books of about 20,000 words. One author, who spoke only on condition of anonymity, said that some writers received more than $100,000. The books are distributed free by Federal Express to a list of about 150,000 people prominent in business and Government, but have also been available for purchase in a few Waldenbooks stores around the country.
One Whittle author, James Atlas, an editor at The New York Times Magazine, praised the Tennessee company's handling of his book. "I got the kind of great, professional editing and meticulous line editing you rarely get with trade editors these days," said Mr. Atlas, whose work "The Book Wars," explored the current academic debate over what books should be taught in university curriculums. He said his only disappointment was in the lack of bookstore distribution and the paucity of reviews.
 
No Influence From Sponsor
 Both Mr. Halberstam and Whittle officials said that Federal Express did not influence the media company's desire for changes in "The Next Century" or Mr. Halberstam's decision to withdraw the book.
"My sense is that they didn't know what they wanted," said Mr. Halberstam, whose earlier best sellers have included "The Best and the Brightest," a history of the Vietnam War, and more recently, "The Reckoning," a book about the development of the Japanese and American automobile industries. "I had a sense of almost amorphous objections." He said his Whittle editors told him that the book needed more reporting, and that it was about 5,000 words too long. Mr. Halberstam said he was paid "a small kill fee" for his efforts, but declined to specify the amount.
Tony Kiser, the executive editor of Whittle Books, said: "You shouldn't think of this as an outright rejection. It wasn't. The book had tremendous potential. We felt some revisions were in order and he did not want to do them. It was just not ready for publication by our standards."
Mr. Kiser said he could not recall the exact objections to Mr. Halberstam's manuscript, but said the book did not contain enough reporting to satisfy Whittle. Another Whittle executive, who spoke only on condition that he not be identified, said the company also did not like the work's "preachiness."
After withdrawing the book from Whittle, Mr. Halberstam said he hesitated to take it to Morrow, his regular publisher, fearing that there was no commercial market for such a short essay. But Douglas A. Stumpf, his editor at Morrow, said he considered the book exciting and marketable, requiring only some expansion. "I thought there should be more personal anecdotes based on his experience as a reporter," he said. The final version is about 35,000 words.
 
Expanded Publishing Division
 The revelation that Whittle passed on a work of such popularity comes at an embarrasing time for the company. It recently announced an expansion of its publishing division, and named Hamilton Jordan, the White House chief of staff in the Carter Administration, as its president and chief operating officer. Today, the company is expected to announce the introduction of a new series of sponsored books in the field of health.
But several publishing professionals said that Whittle may have performed a service to their industry, by showing, however inadvertently, that there is a market for serious, non-fiction books substantially shorter than the 60,000-to-100,000-word trade hard cover.
"This could prove that there is a market for what we used to call broadsides," said Thomas McCormack, the chairman of St. Martin's Press, who said he was considering publishing a line of short paperbacks on current issues. "When I first heard the Whittle notion two years ago, I was too slow-witted to infer from it this lesson."
Despite their differences, Mr. Halberstam also praised Whittle. "The idea is a very good one," he said. "I feel badly that there must be something between a 5,000-word magazine article and a book of 60,000 words or more."

HEADLINE: ESSAY;
Europe in 1996

BYLINE: By William Safire

DATELINE: LONDON

 BODY:
Fate's croupier, long accustomed to a loser at my position at his table, has murmured amazement at my recent war and market luck and shoved two piles of winnings my way.
But Saddam Hussein has made a compulsive gambler out of me. I'll risk all on a bet about the future of Europe -- and try to be the first to break the bank at Pundit's Roulette. 
 The 1996 Euro-Union Monetary and Defense Summit will take place in Brussels (only a 12-hour drive through the new Chunnel traffic jam from London) in June, just after the British elections.
The Brits will have just tossed out Neil Kinnock and Paddy Ashdown, the Labor-Liberal coalition that upset Conservative damps behind John Major in the fall of 1991. The new right-wing Prime Minister, Chris Patten, who swept to victory with the slogan "Maggie Thatcher Was Too Soft," has promised to end the disastrous monetary experiment with the Deutschpound that put British workers in thrall to German bankers.
From Berlin comes Volker Ruhe, the Christian Democrat who brought Kohl to Newcastle -- that is, who wrested party leadership from Helmut Kohl in 1993, after it became apparent that Mikhail Gorbachev, in giving up East Germany, had handed West Germany a ravenous pig in a poke. Mr. Kohl's lust for unification shifted a capital-gulping burden from the Soviets to the Germans, generating Hirschflation, stagnancy accompanied by rising prices.
The only Socialist at the '96 summit talks is France's Laurent Fabius, who slipped past Michel Rocard to succeed President Mitterrand. (Jacques Chirac would not step aside for the popular Lyons Mayor, Michel Noir, to carry the right's banner.) "Socialist" now means protectionist; its regional police is the Delors Corps, an all-European deployment lentement regiment replacing NATO.
Most Europeans did not intend the Delors Corps to replace NATO. But the Germans insisted that U.S. troops replace their nukes with nightsticks on German soil, the French demanded a French NATO commander, the Italians preferred a C.S.C.E. framework. The Americans said here's CNN's number, call it if your Sarajevo Process leads to war.
Yes, Topic A at the Euro-Union Mon-Def-Sum will be trouble in the Balkans. The blank Czechs will have split into the Bohemian and Slovak republics, squabbling with the handful of states that used to be Yugoslavia, while overlapping Romanians and Hungarians will be exhorted to cut out the border clashes annoying Western Ukraine.
And what to do about the former Soviet republics, with their newly productive market systems? From Yeltsin in Russia to Shevardnadze in Georgia, a curtain of grain will fall from the separated parts of the old Kremlin empire. Although capitalist Poland is reviving nicely, fresh competition from the former Soviet republics is now causing Central European unemployment.
The French blame the insular Germans for letting that happen; both France and Germany blame Britain for letting Japan produce automobiles in the U.K. that outsell Mercedes and Peugeot on the Continent. Italy says if the Delors Corps, dominated by French and German officers, doesn't station its Italian platoon on Capri, Rome will form a "third defense pillar" with the Turks.
At this point, the assembled world press will declare the Euro-Union Mon-Def-Sum to be in disarray. Patten of Britain will delightedly concur, but Chancellor Ruhe and President Fabius will plead with the American Observer at the '96 Summit to say something to reunify Europe.
Vice President Quayle, sent by retiring President Bush to assume a statesmanlike role rather than take on Republican Elder Statesman Jack Kemp in the '96 California primary, will finesse the Democratic candidates Norm Schwarzkopf and Al Gore by calling for burden-sharing in gulf-style war on global warming.
Such arrant American triumphalism will infuriate the summiteers and reunify Europe against Anglo American domination, at least enough for a Joint Communique and a decent group picture.
My pile of chips is on the table. I could lose all: if disparate nationalities amalgamate into Europeans, with a common currency and no farm subsidies and with a projectable defense; and if this united Europe persuades America to keep over 100,000 troops in NATO -- then Fate's croupier will rake in my whole bundle.
If not, I break the bank.

HEADLINE: Fighting Crime With Ceremonies

 BODY:
"America is a can-do nation, and today, at home, we must seize the day. The kind of moral force and national will that freed Kuwait City from abuse can free America's cities from crime."
That was a big applause line for President Bush when he addressed a convention of law enforcement officials recently. But the crime bill he has just sent to Congress -- a centerpiece of his "hundred days" challenge to the lawmakers -- consists of little more than misguided measures that are unlikely to improve public safety. 
 Nearly the only innovative thing about the bill was its perverse presentation. Mr. Bush made a ceremony out of signing the order transmitting the bill to Congress. Usually, ceremonies occur after bills are enacted. Perhaps the President suspects this is his crime proposal's high-water mark.
 A main element of the package is a weaker "exclusionary rule" barring use of improperly seized evidence to prosecute criminals. Mr. Bush says he considers the exclusionary rule an inappropriate burden on police. But the millions who last week saw the videotape of Los Angeles police savagely beating a helpless suspect have new reason to understand the need for protection against police abuse.
The bill also would authorize greater use of the death penalty for certain dramatic Federal crimes and limit habeas corpus petitions that delay executions. Such measures stir the blood of law and order zealots. But most street crimes that outrage the public are subject to state, not Federal, law and aren't punishable by death.
Meanwhile, the President ignores steps that would truly make a more effective Federal anti-crime program. One is gun control designed to disarm drug gangsters and street thugs. Federal laws are essential to curb gun trafficking between states with lax laws and those with strict ones. Specifically, there is urgent need for a national waiting period between purchase and delivery of guns, and a ban on selling domestic military assault weapons to civilians. Yet the Administration, bowing to the gun lobby, resists such measures.
Another obvious task for Washington is to provide more money for innovations in local law enforcement. City police and state courts and prisons handle the vast majority of crime, and that is properly their responsibility. But big states now are overwhelmed by crime problems linked to demographic and economic factors beyond their control.
There is no lack of good ideas: community policing to secure neighborhoods and prevent crime; "boot camp" prisons for first offenders who now go free; closer monitoring of convicts released under court supervision; drug treatment mandated by the court.
Senator Joseph Biden released his version of a crime bill yesterday and while it contains many of the Bush bill's provisions, it would provide $1 billion in criminal justice aid to the states. The bill also includes the laudable plan for a police corps -- college scholarship grants for students willing to serve four years with a police department after graduation. President Bush's budget, by contrast, would reduce law enforcement aid to localities by $100 million.
Mr. Bush rightly cites crime as an urgent domestic problem. But it won't be solved with ceremonial grandstanding in the White House.

HEADLINE: Early March Vehicle Sales Down 14.7%

BYLINE: By PAUL C. JUDGE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 13

 BODY:
Sales of American-made cars and light trucks fell 14.7 percent in early March, deflating auto makers' hopes that euphoria over the quick allied success in the Persian Gulf war would lift vehicle sales out of the current slump.
"These numbers are truly a disappointment, because dealer expectations for the period were so high," said Tom Webb, chief economist of the National Automobile Dealers Association in McLean, Va. 
 Automotive analysts cited fundamental weakness in the economy, despite recent reductions in interest rates and gasoline prices. Prospective car buyers apparently have been stalled by slowing income growth and increasing unemployment, analysts and automotive executives said, causing many to postpone new vehicle purchases.
The 10 manufacturers with American plants sold 130,640 cars during the March 1-10 period, down 11.9 percent from the comparable period last year. Seasonally adjusted, cars sold at an annual rate of 5.9 million, consistent with the sluggish pace of industry sales since the beginning of January, but well below the pace of 6.5 million cars set during the 1990 period.
 
Light-Truck Sales Slide
 Sales of United States-made light trucks slid 19.1 percent, to 74,021 pickups, mini-vans and four-wheel-drive vehicles.
There were eight selling days in the period this year, and nine selling days last year.
The Big Three domestic auto makers posted a collective decline of 14.1 percent in car sales, compared with a 4.4 percent rise in overall sales by the seven Japanese companies with car assembly plants in this country.
The General Motors Corporation reported a 15.2 percent decline in car sales, to 57,768 cars. G.M.'s light-truck sales fell 19.9 percent, to 30,953 vehicles. G.M.'s Chevrolet division was hit especially hard, with sales down 34.3 percent from a year earlier. Among the big losers were several Chevy models that are popular with daily rental fleets, including the Lumina, Corsica and Caprice models.
Ford Motor's car sales fell 12.6 percent, to 38,630 cars. Sales of Ford's compact Escort remained weak, and the company has reduced first-quarter production of Escort by about 25 percent. Ford's light-truck sales dropped 26.4 percent, to 23,202 vehicles. While the four-wheel-drive Explorer continued to sell well, sales of Ford's F-series pickup truck were nearly halved during early March.
According to estimates provided by Ward's Automotive Reports, a trade publication, the Chrysler Corporation sold approximately 15,500 cars in early March, down about 14 percent from a year earlier. Chrysler's light-truck sales were off about 6 percent, to 17,200 vehicles. In January, Chrysler stopped reporting its sales every 10 days, saying the practice gave rise to unfavorable comparisons with Japanese auto makers.
The Honda Motor Company reported an increase of 17.9 percent in car sales, to 9,344 cars during the period, reversing three months of sales declines for the Japanese auto maker. In February, Honda began offering $300 in dealer incentives on the Accord, the best-selling car in the United States for the last two years, and the incentive was increased to $500 on March 5.
Even so, sales of imported Hondas fell 6.5 percent in early March. Honda manufactures Accords in both the United States and Japan.
The Toyota Motor Corporation's sales of American-made cars dropped 21 percent, to 4,774 cars. The Nissan Motor Company fared better, with sales of its domestically produced cars down 2.7 percent, to 1,699. The Mazda Motor Corporation posted an increase of 1.2 percent in car sales, to 1,197.
One bright spot for auto makers was a general reduction in their stocks of unsold cars, accomplished through widespread plant shutdowns and layoffs. Ford dealers had a 60-day supply of unsold cars at the end of February, according to Ward's Automotive Reports. G.M. dealers' supply dropped to 77 days, and Chrysler dealers had an 84-day supply of cars.
Honda continued to have abnormally high stocks of unsold cars, with Honda dealers showing an 85-day supply of American-built cars at the end of February, virtually unchanged from 88 days a month before. At the end of February last year, Honda dealers had 39 days' supply.
A 60-to-70-day supply is considered normal for this time of year.

CORRECTION-DATE: March 20, 1991, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Thursday about auto sales in early March misstated the size of the Ford Motor Company's Escort automobile and the extent of a cut in its first- quarter production. The Escort is a subcompact, not a compact; production of the car at Ford's two North American plants was reduced by 15 percent, not 25. The article also referred incorrectly to the Escort's recent sales. They fell 21 percent in early March, but were up in February after having declined in January.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
A Defeated Republican Will Be S.B.A. Director

BYLINE: By Daniel F. Cuff

 BODY:
Patricia Saiki, a Republican who lost a close race to Senator Daniel K. Akaka of Hawaii in the fall, has been nominated as the director of the Small Business Administration.
The position was left vacant by the resignation of Susan S. Engeleiter, a Republican who got the post after losing a close race to Senator Herbert H. Kohl of Wisconsin in 1988. 
 Ms. Saiki, 60, served in Congress for 4 years and spent 14 years in the Hawaii Legislature. She had been mentioned as a candidate for Secretary of Education when Lauro F. Cavazos resigned in December, but that post went to Lamar Alexander, former Tennessee Governor.
Also mentioned for the education post was former Representative Lynn Martin of Illinois, another Bush loyalist who lost an election. The 50-year-old Ms. Martin, who lost to Senator Paul Simon, went on to become Labor Secretary.
The S.B.A. has often been in hot water and the subject of complaints by minorities. In 1988, Congress revised some of the agency's rules to curb abuses by "front" companies, like the Wedtech Corporation, that resorted to illegalities to keep their status as minority companies eligible for no-bid contracts.
Ms. Saiki, whose nomination is subject to Senate approval, said in a statement that her selection was an honor. "Small business is the backbone of the American economy," she said, "creating two out of every three new jobs and producing 40 percent of the gross national product.
She added that "in my home state of Hawaii over 90 percent of the businesses are small businesses."
Ms. Saiki has also had experience in Hawaiian big business. She served on the board of Hawaiian Airlines for 13 years and on the board of Amfac Inc., Hawaii's largest private landowner, for 14 years.
During her Congressional terms, from 1986 to 1990, Ms. Saiki was a member of the Banking, Finance and Urban Affairs Committee. She was listed as the committee member who received the most money from finance-related political action committees during the months before the 1990 elecions. From January 1989 through November 1990, she received $194,692 from finance-related political action committees, or 20 percent of the total she received from such committees in that period.
Ms. Saiki, a Hilo native, taught in junior and senior high schools for 12 years before entering politics. She now lives in Alexandria, Va. She is married and has five children.

HEADLINE: As Collor Completes First Year, Brazilians Write Off Their Highest Hopes

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRASILIA, March 7

 BODY:
One year ago, Brazilians watched with expectation as Fernando Collor de Mello donned the presidential sash here and vowed to bring Latin America's largest nation into the first world, following a road of low inflation and free-market economics.
As the anniversary of the inauguration passes on March 15, the 41-year-old President's first-year report card in the Brazilian press speaks of a year of disappointment. 
 "Lost Illusions," Veja, the nation's largest selling newsweekly, headlined its one-year review.
"A Lot of Noise and Little Action," Jornal do Brasil, an independent Rio de Janeiro daily, said in a headline, referring to a year of watching the President drive a tank, fly a jet, camp out in the Amazon and give a speech in Antarctica.
 
Inflation Persists
 Public opinion polls have tracked a growing disenchantment with the Government's performance. In a survey of 2,581 households completed early in March for Veja, 58 percent of respondents gave a "negative" evaluation to the Collor Government and 35 percent gave a "positive" evaluation.
Critics say the Government has plunged the nation into the sharpest recession in memory and has little to show for it.
In 1990, Brazil's economy shrank by 4.6 percent, the largest drop since the Brazilian Institute of Geography and Statistics started measuring the economy in 1947.
While at least one million people lost their jobs, the recession cooled, but did not kill, inflation. In Mr. Collor's first year in office, prices rose by about 400 percent. In February alone, prices rose by 21 percent, despite a monthlong wage and price freeze.
Mr. Collor had singled out inflation as his No. 1 enemy. Today, he is condemned for failing to meet the targets he set.
"Collor put the military in its place, he made progress on the environment, he opened the economy, he broke up monopolies -- but all this is obscured by the image of the man who couldn't beat inflation," Fernando Henrique Cardoso, a centrist opposition Senator from Sao Paulo, said in an interview here.
 
Modernizing the Economy
 Indeed, often overshadowed by the economic crisis, Brazil's President did move decisively to modernize the nation's economy and to clear away several points of friction with the United States.
In the Amazon, the elimination of tax credits to ranchers helped reduce burning of the rain forest. Responding to international concern over the Amazon's Indians, the President dedicated scarce resources to destroying dozens of illegal landing strips used by gold miners to enter lands of the Yanomami Indians.
Confronting Brazil's industries, among the most protected and inefficient in the world, the President announced a four-year schedule of gradually opening the economy to imports. Also to further free trade and international competitiveness, he cut in half -- to four years -- a timetable for the creation of a regional common market with Argentina, Paraguay and Uruguay.
Mr. Collor also disclosed, and repudiated, a project by Brazil's military to build an atom bomb. He opened the military's secret nuclear sites to inspection and started negotiations with neighboring Argentina toward internationally acceptable nuclear safeguards program.
 
Visit to Washington Planned
 In June, Mr. Collor is to visit Washington, where President Bush will undoubtedly express appreciation for progress in these areas.
Less pleasing to the United States has been slow progress on renegotiating payment terms for Brazil's $60 billion foreign commercial debt. Foreign private investors and the International Monetary Fund have largely postponed committing new money to Brazil until progress is made.
Also unsettling to some American officials, Brazil declined to take part in the allied campaign in the Persian Gulf war. But next week a Brazilian trade and construction mission is to arrive in Kuwait, seeking contracts.
"In the short term, Brazil's sitting on the fence during the war will be very negative to some people here," Riordan Roett, an expert on Brazil at Johns Hopkins University, said in a telephone interview from Washington. "But more important in the long term is the impression here that there is no social pact, that the political community is up in arms, and that privatizations haven't even started yet."
 
An Autocratic Style
 Critics here say Mr. Collor's first year revealed an autocratic style of governing. Without a firm majority in the 19-party congress, Mr. Collor ruled largely through "provisional measures," or decrees. Although the use of decrees was intended only for emergencies, he issued an average of 12 a month in his first year.
While Congress now struggles to strip the President of this power, political analysts say their widespread use reflects a President uncomfortable with consulting and seeking a consensus with other political groups.
In 1989, Mr. Collor, the Governor of a small state, Alagoas, won 35 million votes to become the first President popularly elected in Brazil without the support of any major party.
"Collor managed to antagonize a lot of people in a very short time," Alexandre de Barros, a political risk consultant, said here. "Unions, the middle class, civil servants, the military -- he treated businessmen like bandits."
Most traumatic for the middle class was the freezing of virtually all bank accounts over $1,500. The money is to be released in monthly installments, starting next September.
"In 24 hours, the Collor Government destroyed confidence in savings accounts that took 20 years to build up," said David Fleischer, a political scientist here.
 
Privatization Plan Delayed
 The confiscation, essentially an 18-month moratorium on paying the internal debt, may well be for naught.
Although as many as 200,000 federal workers were dismissed or laid off, the country is far from living within its means. A long-delayed plan for the privatization of state-owned companies is to start next month, Marcos Coimbra, General Secretary of the Presidency, said in an interview here.
To meet the budget gap, and to cover unchecked spending by state governors, the Central Bank increased the nation's money supply by 2,035 percent lastt year, according to a study by Eduardo Giannetti da Fonseca, a University of Sao Paulo economist. Inflation has continued at such a steady whirl that people in Rio de Janeiro used two denominations of cruzeiro bills for two months without realizing that they were no longer valid.
"It is like an old hose where water sprays out of the holes," Ozires Silva, Minister of Infrastructure, said here of the Government's continuing attempts to control the money supply.
When the Government recently imposed wage and price controls, for the fifth time in five years, many Brazilian economists openly wondered what happened to Mr. Collor's free-market nostrums of one year ago.
 
New Plan Prepared
 "Each shock attacks the institutional tripod of a free-market economy -- inviolability of property rights, respect for legal contracts, and stability of the rules of the game," Mario Henrique Simonsen, a former Planning Minister, wrote last month in an essay widely quoted here. "With these successive attacks, Brazil operates neither like a market economy, nor like a socialist economy. It works as a laboratory for university economics departments."
Apprently taking some of his critics to heart, Mr. Collor has vowed to present a plan for national reconstruction to Congress for debate on March 15. The plan has been drawn up to win majority approval by Congress, presidential aides say.
"We need to mobilize the nation, not through decrees, but through an agreement among the political forces," Senator Cardoso said. "We don't need any more magic solutions."

HEADLINE: Fate of Police Chief in Los Angeles Is Vigorously Debated After Beating

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, March 13

 BODY:
From the Mayor's office to breakfast tables in Watts and the San Fernando Valley, the main question in Los Angeles today is: Should Daryl F. Gates leave his job as Chief of Police?
The Police Commission, which appoints the Chief, is scheduled to hold a public meeting with him on Thursday to discuss the March 3 beating of an unarmed, unresisting black motorist by white officers. The beating was videotaped by a witness and has been broadcast over and over, shaking television audiences nationwide. 
 The meeting will come two days after the Congressional Black Caucus asked the Federal Bureau of Investigation to investigate allegations of police brutality here and elsewhere and after Mayor Tom Bradley proposed amending the City Charter to allow him to dismiss police chiefs and other department heads who are now protected by civil service.
To all this, the stern, dapper and often cocky Chief has responded as he has to numerous other storms in his nearly 13 years as department head: with charm, defiance, blaming of others, tempered apologies and mustering of his political support.
Having developed a national stature as an implacable foe of crime and defender of the police, Chief Gates will not be easily moved by cries for his resignation. "He has succeeded in developing a constituency of his own, unique among department heads, like an elected official in his own right," said Councilman Michael Woo, who represents Hollywood.
 
Adapting to a Changed City
 The 64-year-old Chief began his career with the Los Angeles Police Department 42 years ago. In those "Dragnet" days, Los Angeles was a much smaller place and the line between good and evil seemed clear. It has since become the nation's second-largest city, an international polyglot where police work is as much sociology as criminology.
Critics say Chief Gates has adapted to the changes only slowly and grudgingly. They concede that he was as appalled as they at the recent beating, but say that his longtime attitudes have fostered an insensitivity to minority members throughout the 8,300-member force, which is 61 percent white. Over the years, the Chief's outspoken comments have disparaged black and Hispanic residents as well as women, homosexuals and others.
"The tone of leadership that has created the climate for this has to be altered," said Melanie Lomax, a civil rights lawyer who was recently appointed to the Police Commission by Mayor Bradley. "The intemperate and inflammatory statements regularly made by our chief of police tend to inflame Gestapo-type tactics by officers who are marginal. I do not believe that he condones it, but he has blinders on."
The view is entirely different in the police stations. "We and the officers view him as one who understands their job, supports them, speaks them," said Lieut. George Aliano, president of the police union, the Los Angeles Protective League.
Bill Rathburn, the former commander of Los Angeles's South Bureau who became chief of police in Dallas eight days ago, called Chief Gates a "very sensitive, very compassionate, very private man" who takes any failure by his people or insult to the department very personally.
He said the Chief had been maligned in the press and was a "strict disciplinarian with no tolerance for police misconduct of any type."
 
A Stubborn, Proud Man
 Few people seem to know the Chief well. Acquaintances call him something of a loner, a stubborn and proud man dedicated to law and order. He maintains a stern personal regimen, running regularly and eschewing alcohol. Chief Gates, who is said to be an excellent cook, and his wife, Sima, live in a condominium near downtown, and have a beach place in San Clemente.
In 1982, Chief Gates said he had disowned his only son, Lowell, because of drug use. In 1985 Lowell Gates was arrested on charges of robbing a Huntington Beach drugstore of $5,000 worth of narcotics and was sentenced to a year in jail. "He will get no assistance from me," the Chief said at the time of the arrest.
He runs the department with the same discipline, meting out harsh punishment for theft or dishonesty. But critics say he has been less vigilant about the use of excessive force and possible racism in the ranks, allowing a cowboy attitude to flourish. They point, for example, to a case in 1985 in which the Chief overruled a department tribunal that had ordered the dismissal of an officer who lied about an incident in which his partner killed a Cuban immigrant with a shot in the back; the Chief reduced the penalty to six months' suspension.
A politically conservative Republican, the Chief has sometimes been mentioned as a possible candidate for Mayor or Governor, and he has not discouraged such speculation.
 
Warning to Officers
 Chief Gates's press office did not respond to repeated requests for an interview with him. At press conferences and television appearances since the beating of Rodney G. King, the Chief has called the incident an "aberration" in an otherwise "model department" and has rejected suggestions that he resign.
He was in typical form today when he addressed the Los Angeles County Peace Officers Association. "We have brought shame and dishonor upon the police profession," he said, but later he lashed out at critics like the American Civil Liberties Union of Southern California, which has been running newspaper advertisements calling for his resignation.
Indeed, many political leaders say Chief Gates just might win out. Los Angeles is perhaps unique among major American cities in placing the chief of police and all other department heads under civil service protection to insulate them from political corruption. Chief Gates cannot be removed by the Mayor or the commission, which is appointed by the Mayor, without "cause," generally meaning malfeasance or moral terpitude.
Even then, his ouster could be delayed for years by appeals. No Chief has been ousted since the revised City Charter was approved in the 1930's.
 
'A Praetorian Guard' of Whites
 Such insulation has had its negative aspects, critics say, making the police unaccountable. "Sun Belt cities have prided themselves insulating police from political pressure," said Henry W. McGee Jr., who teaches criminal justice and urban planning at the University of California at Los Angeles School of Law. "But it has insulated them from any minority influence.
"So the L.A. police turn out to be a praetorian guard of blue-collar whites who are blatantly and openly hostile to non-white minorities. While they are incorruptible, they also turn out to be deeply racist in ways more affluent Americans do not indulge themselves."
Politicians here say Chief Gates would be difficult to oust. He has a substantial following among the largely white residents of the San Fernando Valley and other areas, including some minority ones, that are increasingly fearful of crime.
"The Chief is not removable without a tremendous knock-down, drag-out fight," said a former Police Commission member who spoke only on the condition of anonymity. "It would polarize the community in a very undesirable way."
Three times in the past 10 years voters have rejected Mayor Bradley's request for power to dismiss police chiefs and other department heads.
 
Nibbling at Authority
 While the Mayor, a former police officer who has long been at odds with Chief Gates, has currently refrained from calling for his ouster, close associates say Mr. Bradley would be pleased to see the Chief go.
For months the Mayor has been trying to gain more control over the Police Department indirectly through appointments to the commission. He recently appointed two political allies, Dan Garcia and Ms. Lomax, and, after two recent vacancies are filled, his allies will hold four of the commission's five seats.
While the commission cannot dismiss Chief Gates, it can make life uncomfortable for him by changing policies on training, use of force and weapons. Mr. Garcia said the panel would be asking tough questions and would urge quick work on an detailed study of instances of brutality in recent years.
Over the years Chief Gates has made accommodations with minority members and women, but slowly. He fought black and Hispanic leaders when they complained that a police deployment formula based in part on the value of stolen property tended to favor rich areas, but in the end he agreed to increase patrols in poorer parts of the city and to expand the police force.
For nearly a decade, the department has been under a Federal court order to hire more minority members and women, and it has made considerable progress. As of Jan. 27, according to figures supplied by the department, 22 percent of the 8,423 sworn officers were Hispanic, 14 percent black and 13 percent female.
Recent Census Bureau figures show non-Hispanic whites make up 37 percent of the Los Angeles population, non-Hispanic blacks 13 percent, Hispanics of all races 40 percent and all other races 10 percent.
The California Department of Fair Employment and Housing recently filed suits against the department, charging that it has systematically denied promotions to Hispanic and black officers. Only 10 percent of detectives in the highest grade are Hispanic and 7 percent black. Chief Gates has disputed the charges.
 
'He Is Not Stupid'
 Even critics say that the Chief has mellowed in recent years and become more sensitive to the concerns of minorities, and that he has come to recognize that the problems of the police in poor communities are rooted in social and economic conditions.
But, Ms. Lomax said, "He is too involved in technology and trying to bring law-enforcement techniques to a new state of art," Ms. Lomax continued. "Anybody can blow things up. The question is whether we've got the people orientation not to let things get out of hand."
