HEADLINE: Housing in the Catskills;
A New Project at Windham Ski Resort

BYLINE: By DIANA SHAMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WINDHAM, N.Y.

 BODY:
The shift is away from town houses and toward semiattached houses for one developer of residential lots in this ski resort town who is seeking to find the best market for the 90's.
The builder is Bernard J. Brabazon, one of the most active developers in what has become a large resort center in the northern Catskills. The housing development was set off by the opening of Ski Windham, a family-oriented resort, in 1981. The resort is on the north side of the 3,035-foot-high Cave Mountain, 140 miles northwest of New York City. 
 Mr. Brabazon is a one-time Queens real estate broker who moved to Windham in 1974. He found a sleepy hamlet at the foot of a mountain where "there was no place to play tennis and you swam in the creek." He built Windham's first town-house complex, the 30-unit Elm Ridge Bath and Tennis Club, which has a swimming pool and tennis courts, completing it in 1982.
Now he is involved in the third phase of Windham Ridge Club, on a 320-acre former dairy farm off Mill Street across the valley from Cave Mountain. The property was purchased in 1982 for $2 million and has been approved for the construction of 329 housing units. A third of the units have been built. The contemporary styles are the design of Frost & McConnell of Saratoga Springs, N.Y., and, more recently, of Minor L. Bishop of Manhattan.
The third phase consists of fourteen 1,800-square-foot, two-bedroom houses that are semiattached with one-car garages. They are priced at $250,000. The switch to semiattached houses was made because of the slow market for smaller town houses.
In the first two phases, the development offered attached one-, two- and three-bedroom town houses. A total of 109 such units were built and 107 have been sold.
Last year it was necessary to turn to an auction to sell 23 of the one-bedroom units, which failed to sell partly because of their small size -- 700 square feet -- and partly because of the downturn in the vacation market that started in 1989, Mr. Brabazon said. The November auction brought prices of $65,000 to $70,000 a unit, well below the $125,000 original asking prices.
In general, town-house development has accounted for most of the new construction in the 44.9-square-mile Windham in recent years. Since 1981, 367 units in five projects have been completed, and another 190 units in four projects are before the planning board, said the town building inspector, Robert M. Bosworth.
Since the softening of the vacation-house market in 1989, three proposals were canceled and the construction of 42 approved units was put on hold, he said. An auction is scheduled on Sunday for the 20 unsold units in a 103-unit project called Windham Mountain Village.
Land prices, on the other hand, are holding up. A price of $200,000 for a half-acre lot adjoining the ski slopes is not unusual, said Judith A. Higgins, a Windham broker. "The buyer who has to be on the ocean in the Hamptons has to be on the trail of a ski slope," she said. "It's the same thing, only a different season."
The town supervisor, Thomas Meehan, estimated that the town's year-round population of 1,600 swells to 6,000 on a winter weekend and that 40 percent of the local economy is related to the resort business.
At Mr. Brabazon's development, lots are already on sale for a fourth section of single-family houses. The land parcels range in size from one-fifth of an acre to three-quarters of an acre and are priced from $75,000 to $125,000. All four sections are part of a homeowners association, which maintains roads and common areas.
Work has begun on an 18-hole golf course. Future construction plans include an additional 44 units of semiattached houses and a 120-room inn with condominium units that could earn rental income when not used by their owners. The inn still needs site plan approvals from the town.
Recreational amenities at Windham Ridge Club are available to homeowners on a membership basis. The initial fee is $3,500 and annual dues are $800. The amenities include an indoor pool, seven outdoor and three indoor tennis courts and a health club. Golf membership will cost $7,500 initially and $1,200 a year.
The future of development in Windham may depend less on a slowdown of demand and more on hearings being conducted by the New York City Department of Environmental Protection. The agency is proposing stringent new regulations for city watershed areas, which include Greene County, in which Windham is situated. Watershed areas contain the reservoirs for the New York City water supply. Passage of the proposals would kill development in the town, Mr. Meehan said.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Israeli Blessings And Burdens

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
THE effort to achieve peace in the Middle East, which President Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d are now trying to push, is complicated by the huge influx of Soviet Jews to Israel, the scarcity of land and other resources and the uncertain ability of the Israeli economy to absorb the number of immigrants expected to arrive.
Last year 200,000 Soviet Jews entered Israel -- five times as many as the Israeli Government was expecting. The collapsing Soviet economy and the outbreak of ethnic conflict and anti-Semitism created the new exodus. 
 This year 300,000 to 400,000 more Soviet Jews are expected. By 1993 or 1994, according to a study by four Israeli economists at Tel Aviv University, the influx of Soviet Jews will reach 1 million, and by the year 2000, 2 million. The study estimates that as a result of total immigration from all countries and natural increase the Jewish population of Israel could climb to 7 million in this decade, double the 3.5 million of 1990.
The Arab population of Israel is 650,000, according to official Israeli sources, and 800,000, according to Palestinian sources. In addition, 1.7 million Palestinians live in the occupied territories in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip.
All told, 300 million people live in 20 countries of the Middle East. Assuming present growth rates, the population of the region will double in 24 years; specific growth rates from natural increase range from 1.6 percent in Israel to 3.9 percent in Iraq.
About 40 percent of the Arab world is under 15; as the Population Research Center in Washington notes, longstanding political instability in the Persian Gulf region has made population a politicized and sensitive issue. With its heavy losses in the Iran-Iraq war, Iraq sought to spur even faster population growth. For Palestinians and Israelis, population size is taken to spell political power and security.
That is why Israel sees the influx of Soviet Jews as a blessing. But it is a burden, too, as the sluggish Israeli economy struggles to create housing and jobs. If the influx continues to grow as rapidly as anticipated, it will strain other resources as well, with fresh water in particularly short supply.
Israel will need huge infusions of capital to take care of its new immigrants. At a conference in New York this week on the Soviet influx into Israel, Haim Ben-Shahar, an economist and former president of Tel Aviv University, stressed the difficulty of finding the needed capital abroad. Global capital markets, he said, are "extremely cautious, and no doubt will prefer to focus on other regions, such as Eastern Europe."
The Arab boycott of Israel and of foreign companies that deal with Israel further reduces the inflow of capital to Israel. Asked whether he saw any reasons for hope that the Arab states would drop their boycott of Israel, Dr. Ben-Shahar said, "No -- unless it is part of an overall peace process."
Asked whether the United States, with its influence enhanced by the victory over Iraq, had enough leverage to get the Arab states to drop the boycott, Dr. Ben-Shahar said he couldn't judge, but added that he would still prefer an overall deal through which, in a carefully staged peace process, "the boycott will be lifted and Israel will receive financial support to absorb the Soviet Jews." He added, "In return, Israel will be ready to compromise on territories, provided that military and security arrangements are installed." The Israeli Government, however, has been resistant to the idea of trading land for peace.
At the New York conference, several economists argued that Israel now needed to overhaul its economy, shifting resources from military to civilian production and reducing the heavy hand of Government. Howard Pack, director of the program in international development at the University of Pennsylvania, said Israel was in danger of re-enacting the Argentine "miracle" of underdevelopment, transforming its "enormous economic potential into continuing slow growth that increases its relative military burden, encourages emigration, depresses Western immigration and weakens it politically."
A high-level team of American economists -- Richard T. McCormack, Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs; Herbert Stein, former chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers, and Stanley Fischer, former chief economist of the World Bank -- has been working in Israel , under official auspices, on a study of the structure of the Israeli economy.
This could provide the basis for cooperation between the Israeli and American Governments -- and between private businesses and educators in both countries -- for the revival of Israeli economic growth, which could, at the same time, facilitate the peace process.
As Professor Pack put it: "The growth in living standards would reduce many of the current frictions that beset Israeli society and might even lead neighboring states to calculate the potential benefits of closer economic relations. There are many more routes to normalization of relations than were envisioned by the Camp David accords."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up Sharply in U.S. After Mixed Day Overseas

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose sharply in domestic dealings yesterday after putting in a mixed performance abroad.
Gold prices were mostly lower. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $365.30 an ounce, off $1.60. The Republic National Bank said gold fell $1.95, settling at a late bid of $364.65. 
 The dollar's advance came despite continued negative economic news. The Commerce Department reported that business sales slackened 1.2 percent in January, helping to swell inventories by four-tenths of 1 percent.
 
'Testing the Upside'
 But the dollar advanced as investors continued to "suspect the economy will turn around shortly, and nobody wants to miss the boat," said Marc Chandler, an analyst with IDEA, a New York consulting firm.
The absence of central bank intervention also gave traders reason to test the dollar's upper limits. "The dollar bulls have a reason to continue to buy because they don't think the Federal Reserve is serious about stopping the dollar's climb," he added.
The dollar also rose despite rumors that the Fed was about to cut the discount rate, the interest member banks are charged on loans from the central bank.
"Despite all the rumors and without intervention," said Stephen Flanagan, a vice president at Mitsubishi Bank, the market "was coaxed back into testing the upside."
The dollar appeared strongest against the European currencies, while its gains were spotty against the Japanese yen.
In Tokyo, the dollar fell 0.9 yen, closing at 135.65 yen. Later in London, it fell to 135.95 yen. In New York, the dollar settled at 135.87 yen, up from 135.66 yen on Wednesday.
In London, the pound fell to $1.8560, from $1.8570 late Wednesday. In New York, it cost $1.8520 to buy a pound, less expensive than Wednesday's $1.8615.
Against the German currency, the dollar rose to 1.5825 marks, from 1.5730 on Wednesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's rates, included: 1.3715 Swiss francs, up from 1.3645; 5.3910 French francs, up from 5.3605; 1,181.00 Italian lire, up from 1,173.75, and 1.1538 Canadian dollars, unchanged.

HEADLINE: Inventories Rose 0.4% In January

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 14

 BODY:
Business sales slackened 1.2 percent in January, helping to increase inventories by four-tenths of a percent, the Government said today. That resulted in an inventory-to-sales ratio of 1.56, the widest in six and a half years, but analysts said the figure was still not dangerously high.
The Commerce Department said sales in January fell to $523.6 billion after declining by a revised 2.4 percent in December and 1.5 percent in November. It was the first time that sales dropped for three consecutive months since July, August and September 1984. 
 The revised December drop was slightly worse than the 2.3 percent fall first reported last month. It was the steepest decline since sales plunged 3.1 percent in January 1987.
Inventories advanced to $814.4 billion after dropping six-tenths of a percent in December. They had edged up two-tenths of a percent in November.
The new data produced the 1.56 inventory-to-sales ratio, meaning it would take 1.56 months for businesses to clear their shelves and backlots at the January sales pace.
In past recessions, large backlogs have caused serious production cutbacks and job layoffs as businesses tried to sell off their inventories. The ratio had risen as high as 1.75 during the severe recession of 1974-75 and to 1.74 during the 1981-82 downturn. The ratio averaged 1.49 last year.
"It's still under control," Kris Bledowski of Cahners Economics in Newton, Mass., said of the ratio. "With sales weak across the board, we have to expect inventories to rise as well, but the ratio is manageable."
Many economists expect sales to pick up this spring, fueling a mild turnaround in the economy.
Thomas Runiewicz, an economist with the WEFA Group in Bala-Cynwyd, Pa., said sales would remain sluggish in February but pick up in subsequent months.
"January and February may well be the low point of these numbers," he said. "We'll see a little more optimism in March and going into the spring."
In fact, the Commerce Department reported Wednesday that reail sales started to pick up in February, posting an eight-tenths of a percent gain for their first advance in four months. Analysts viewed that report as evidence the recession might have bottomed out.
But in January, retail sales slumped 1.4 percent following a 1.8 percent decline the previous month. Sales on the wholesale level dropped 2.8 percent after sliding seven-tenths of a percent in December. Manufacturing sales were unchanged after a 3.9 percent drop a month earlier.
Inventories on the retail level rose seven-tenths of a percent, nearly wiping out an eight-tenths of a percent decline in December. Wholesale backlogs, which were unchanged in December, gained nine-tenths of a percent. Factory inventories held steady after dropping eight-tenths of a percent a month earlier.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Inventory-Sales Ratio" shows total month-end business inventories divided by total monthly business sales, seasonally adjusted. (Source: Commerce Department)

HEADLINE: Loan Troubles Grow for Banks and S.& L.'s

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 14

 BODY:
Real estate problems for banks and savings institutions worsened sharply in 1990 and shifted from the Southwest to Northeast and Middle Atlantic States, the Government said today.
The Office of Thrift Supervision said the 2,342 savings institutions still outside Government control lost $965 million in the final three months of 1990 and $2.41 billion for the entire year. 
 A 25 percent increase in losses from the third to fourth quarters occurred despite the transfer of 39 insolvent savings institutions in the period to the the Resolution Trust Corporation, the Government agency overseeing the bailout.
Also, the institutions' bad loans as a percentage of all loans have risen steadily throughout the year, again despite the removal of the worst savings associations. The percentage was 2.34 at the end of the year compared with 2.03 at the end of the first quarter.
 
Unwilling to Predict
 The director of the thrift office, T. Timothy Ryan Jr., said lower interest rates should help the savings industry this year, but he was unwilling to predict improvement.
"We are uncertain at this time what to expect in the first quarter of 1991, especially in view of the economic slowdown and weak real estate market," he said.
Meanwhile, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said Wednesday that profits at the nation's 12,338 commercial banks rose 6.5 percent, to $16.6 billion in 1990 from $15.6 billion in 1989.
But that masked rising problems caused by the recession and plummeting real estate prices.
Delinquent real estate loans jumped to $36 billion at the end of 1990 from $22.5 billion a year earlier. Repossessed real estate rose to $19.8 billion, from $12.5 billion in 1989.
For the fourth quarter, commercial bank profits fell 31 percent, to $1.39 billion.
 
Trouble in the East
 Although the number of weak banks actually declined from 1,109 at the end of 1989 to 1,046, the fact that larger Eastern institutions are now in trouble means a much higher proportion of the industry's assets are owned by ailing institutions.
Assets held by problem banks soared by 74 percent from $235 billion in 1989, or 7 percent of the industry, to $409 billion, or 11 percent.
"In effect, what has happened is the problem has moved," said Bert Ely, a financial institutions analyst in Alexandria, Va. "Texas has been through it and now it's in New England. But in all candor, things are worse than they were in 1987. We're in a national recession and we have broader concerns about the rest of the country."
 
Top Money-Losing States
 The banking industry in nine states and the District of Columbia lost money, with the worst red ink, $1 billion, coming in Massachusetts. The other money-losing states were Arizona, Colorado, Connecticut, Maine, Maryland, New Hampshire, New Jersey and Rhode Island.
A year ago, the five states with the highest percentage of bad real estate loans in commercial banks were, in order, Texas, Arizona, Oklahoma, Louisiana and Massachusetts.
The F.D.I.C. issued a separate report for the country's 473 savings banks, which are primarily in the Northeast and invest more heavily in real estate than do commercial banks. They lost $2.4 billion in 1990, more than three times the $773 million loss in 1989. The fourth-quarter loss was $1.2 billion, with 48 percent of the institutions losing money.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Ford Tightens Terms On Rental Fleet Sales

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 14

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company today revised the terms under which it sells cars to car-rental companies, reflecting a growing concern that new-car sales are being damaged by growing inventories of slightly used cars.
Ford stipulated that rental fleets must keep cars in service for at least six months or 15,000 miles before they can be sold to Ford dealers, who then sell them to the public. Rental fleets must now keep cars for only four months, and many of them land on dealer lots with only a few thousand miles on them. 
The policy change was announced to rental car companies today and will affect cars and trucks built after April 30.
For consumers, slightly used cars often have proved to be a bargain. Some slightly used late models may sell for thousands of dollars less than new models. For example, Potamkin Chevrolet in Miami now sells a new 1991 Chevrolet Cavalier for $9,680, which includes a $400 customer rebate. For about $1,600 less, a consumer can buy the same model with 8,000 miles on it and the remainder of the warranty.
The General Motors Corporation said it planned to extend the four-month minimum period rental fleets keep their cars in service beginning in the 1992 model year. The Chrysler Corporation said it would watch what Ford has done, but the company now had no plan to change its four-month minimum holding period.
Since the mid-1980's, Big Three auto makers have been providing financial incentives for rental companies to buy cars and resell them more frequently. While sales to rental fleets provide auto makers with less profit than sales to dealers, they represent additional production.
Automotive analysts say about a million cars annually come out of American rental fleets and compete with new cars.
As the number of slightly used cars has increased, however, concern has grown among dealers and manufacturers that too many potential customers are buying cars coming out of the rental fleets rather than new cars. Last year, Ford agreed to sell its slightly used cars through Ford dealers exclusively.
Ford's biggest rental customers are Hertz and Budget Rent-A-Car, but Robert L. Rewey, Ford vice president for sales operations, declined to say how many cars Ford sells annually to the fleets. Ford owns 49 percent of the Hertz Corporation.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR: DIPLOMACY;
Baker and Syrian Chief Call Time Ripe for Peace Effort

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DAMASCUS, Syria, March 14

 BODY:
After seven hours of talks with President Hafez al-Assad of Syria, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said today that he and Mr. Assad agreed that they must take advantage of the "window of opportunity" that exists after the Persian Gulf war to produce a comprehensive Arab-Israeli settlement.
But when Mr. Baker was pressed as to whether he heard any "new thinking" about Israel from Mr. Assad -- as he said he had heard from Arab leaders in Saudi Arabia -- he could not point to anything other than a Syrian commitment to be active now in the pursuit of peace. 
 Before leaving Damascus, Mr. Baker also said at a news conference with the Syrian Foreign Minister, Farouk al-Sharaa, that the Syrians recently received a shipment of advanced Scud missiles. Israeli officials had previously reported the shipment, saying the missiles, sent here by North Korea, were about two dozen Scud-C's. More accurate versions of the missiles Iraq used against Israel, the Scud-C's can hit targets up to 300 miles away.
 
'State of War With Israel'
 "Syria is still in a state of war with Israel," Mr. Sharaa when reporters asked him for his reaction. "Israel has so many missiles and so many different types of mass destruction weapons. A just and comprehensive peace would solve all of these problems."
The thrust of Mr. Baker's remarks, as well as those of a senior American official in his party, was that they were pleased with their talks because the Syrians were agreeing that now was the time for a major push to resolve the Arab-Israel conflict and because they were generally supportive of Mr. Baker's approach. His plan involves trying to get the Arab nations and Israel to make gestures to begin reconciling their differences, while promoting the same process between Israelis and Palestinians.
It was difficult to tell, though, if Mr. Baker was truly pleased by these Syrian commitments, which appear rather predictable and routine, or whether he was simply highlighting them because he had nothing else and wanted to maintain at least an appearance of momentum.
 
Baker Sees Opportunity
 "With respect to the Arab-Israeli conflict," Mr. Baker said, "I think that the minister would agree with me that we find ourselves agreeing that we share a commitment to seek a comprehensive settlement based on U.N. Security Council resolutions 242 and 338.
"We find ourselves in agreement with respect to the fact that there is, we think, an opportunity now in the aftermath of the gulf crisis that should be seized -- a window of opportunity that could make it possible for us to make significant progress in the Arab-Israeli conflict."
He added: "I sensed a very serious intent on the part of the Syrian Government to pursue an active peace process and to continue to work toward that end with the coalition countries that worked together to reverse Saddam Hussein's aggression."
When a Baker aide was asked later what Mr. Assad or Mr. Sharaa said to Mr. Baker to make this seeming repetition of long-standing Syrian positions significant, the aide said one of the Syrian leaders -- apparently Mr. Sharaa -- told Mr. Baker that this time the Syrians were ready not simply to end the state of war with Israel but to construct a genuine peace based on real reconciliation.
 
An 'Intractable Problem'
 The official said the Syrians indicated that "there had been a change of their position" and that now "they are committed to a genuine peace."
Asked if the Syrians defined "genuine peace," the official said no, but added: "In the past, the Syrian position was that peace is the absence of war. When they start talking about genuine peace they are talking about something other than the absence of war."
Having met with leaders from nine different Arab nations and Israel, Mr. Baker went out of his way today before leaving the Middle East for Moscow to lower expectations for an immediate breakthrough.
"We are dealing with the most intractable problem I think there is, and we ought not to let expectations get out of control," Mr. Baker said. "This is very early in the process of trying to address this problem in the aftermath of the war.
"You have to crawl before you walk, and you have to walk before you run, and we've been at it maybe five or six days. It is a little bit premature to be suggesting that somehow there is no opportunity here because we have not had instant peace. Maybe the wheels will come off tomorrow, but let's give it a chance."
 
On Trading Land for Security
 Mr. Sharaa made no reference to real reconciliation with Israel. He simply said at the news confrence that his Government and the Bush Administration were in full agreement that peace should be based on United Nations Resolutions 242 and 338, which call on Israel to trade land for security and recognition from its Arab neighbors.
Syria also believes that negotiations should be conducted through some type of international conference, in which Mr. Assad would present Syria's demands for a return of the Israeli-occupied Golan Heights and for a Palestinian state.
The entire basis of legitimacy of Mr. Assad's Government -- and the reason it gets economic support from wealthy Arab oil states -- rests on its claim to be the vangaurd not only of Syrian interests but of Palestinian and Arab rights as well. That is something it would be unlikely to squander for the sake of a separate peace with Israel over just the Golan.
The talks with Mr. Baker, Mr. Sharaa said, "will help all of us to work actively for a just and comprehensive settlement of the Arab-Israeli conflict and the Palestinian question."
"We are optimistic that this opportunity will be utilized in the proper manner," he said. "That's why we will keep contacts and there was agreement on keeping in touch and keeping these contacts in order to give a momentum to the peace process for the months to come."

Baker Arrives in Moscow
 MOSCOW, March 14 (Special to The New York Times) -- Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d arrived here today intent on Middle Eastern affairs but no less wary of the minefield of domestic Soviet politics.
Beyond Mr. Baker's meeting Friday with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, politicians are watching to see if he meets in any prominent fashion with the Soviet leader's domestic rival, Boris N. Yeltsin, the President of the Russian republic, who has called for Mr. Gorbachev's resignation.
More explicit is Mr. Baker's decision to meet separately Saturday with representatives of the three Baltic republics, Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia. He will also meet with the former Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, who resigned from the Government last year.
"We are going to concentrate on the gulf," Foregn Minister Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh said of Mr. Baker's two days of talks here. Disarmament and Soviet economic needs also are expected to be discussed.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices on U.S. Securities Mixed

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were narrowly mixed in light trading yesterday.
An urge to take profits and a drop in weekly unemployment claims helped to push bond prices down somewhat. But shorter-term notes were stable to up slightly because of the lingering effect of comments on Wednesday by the Federal Reserve Board chairman, Alan Greenspan, that the central bank might decide to move short-term interest rates lower. 
"People are trying to assess how panicked the Fed really is," one government securities trader said.
Participants said trading was light because some potential accounts were reluctant to establish positions before the release this morning of February producer price data.
 
Fixed-Income Markets
Most Wall Street economists are expecting the figures to be favorable for the fixed-income markets. Largely because of a big drop in energy prices, the consensus forecast is that the producer price index fell by three-tenths of a percentage point last month. The index fell by one-tenth of a percentage point in January.
"One of the things that is supposed to help the marke is the notion that inflation is coming down even if the economy regains some momentum," said James R. Capra, a principal at Moore Capital Management, a money management firm. "If the data reinforce that sense, the market will be fine. If they don't, that will create problems, especially for bonds."
A report from the Labor Department yesterday showing that initial unemployment claims fell by 34,000 in the week ended March 2, to 474,000, helped to push bond prices down early in the session. As the day progressed, they never really recovered.
 
Treasury's 30-Year Bonds
 Late yesterday, the Treasury's 7 7/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 96 14/32, down 6/32, to yield 8.19 percent, compared with 8.18 percent late Wednesday.
In the secondary market for Treasury notes, the 7 3/4 percent 10-year notes were offered at 98 6/32, down 1/8 of a point, to yield 8.01 percent. But the 6 3/4 percent two-year notes rose by 1/32, to a late price of 99 22/32, to yield 6.92 percent.
Meanwhile, rates on short-term Treasury bills eased slightly.
In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 5.76 percent, down two basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by three basis points, to a late offered rate of 5.77 percent.
Among the new debt issues priced in the investment-grade corporate bond market was a $100 million offering of four-year senior notes by Salomon Inc.
The 9 percent notes, which mature July 1, 1995, were priced at 100, or par, 1.55 percentage points over the prevailing yield on Treaury securities of comparable maturity. The securities are non-callable for life.
Salomon Brothers acted as lead manager for the underwriting. The issue is rated A-2 by Moody's Investors Service and A-plus by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Participants in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds said that prices of most issues dipped by 1/4 of a point to3/8 of a point.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bond market, traders said that prices of most widely quoted issues fell by about 1/8 of a point in quiet trading.
In other developments, the Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday that all three measures of the nation's money supply rose in the week ended March 4.
The report had little impact on prices in the credit markets, largely because the $5.8 billion increase in M-2, the monetary aggregate most closely followed by the Fed, was smaller than most analysts had anticipated.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
U S. Ruling A Setback For T.W.A.

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
In a move that could plunge another airline into financial crisis, the Transportation Department gave tentative approval yesterday for the sale of only three of Trans World Airlines' London routes to American Airlines. It turned down the sale of three others.
Carl C. Icahn, T.W.A.'s chairman, promptly denounced the decision, which the Transportation Department said was intended to promote competition in service to London. American Airlines said it was puzzled by the ruling, but declined to comment on what effect it might have on the $515 million price tag American had agreed to pay for routes from six cities in the United States to London. 
 "I believe that the order could well become a disaster for T.W.A.," Mr. Icahn said in a statement. "It is unclear whether the sale to American will be able to be completed, and if the sale is not completed, our financial condition, which is already precarious, will worsen substantially."
T.W.A. had previously said it might seek protection under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy code if the route sale did not go through.
The Transportation Department approved the sale of T.W.A.'s routes to London from New York, Los Angeles and Boston, which it said accounted for a very large percentage of the value of the sale.
The department disapproved the sale of three others, however, saying that it needed to hold new proceedings to select new United States carriers for the London routes from Philadelphia and Baltimore. That move would prevent T.W.A. from realizing any gain from the transfer of those routes.
 
Decision on Sixth Route
 On the sixth route, from St. Louis, the department tentatively concluded that T.W.A. should retain its right to serve the route and be able to sell it to a carrier other than American.
Samuel K. Skinner, the Transportation Secretary, and the staff of the Transportation and State Departments reached an agreement with the British Government on Monday under which United Airlines will take over Pan American World Airways' right to serve London from Heathrow Airport and American will take over T.W.A.'s rights, also operating out of Heathrow. Pan Am is already in Chapter 11, as is Continenal Airlines, another major United States carrier.
Donald J. Carty, an executive vice president of American, said he was pleased that the department had approved the three routes but expressed concern that the department had blocked some of American's planned routes while allowing United to proceed with its purchase of Pan Am's. He emphasized that the Transportation order was preliminary.
 
United's Heathrow Debut Set
 Separately, United announced that it would begin service to Heathrow on April 3 from Kennedy International Airport in New York, Dulles International Airport near Washington and San Francisco International Airport. It said it would fly daily from New York and Washington and five times a week from San Francisco.
United, which paid $290 million for Pan Am's routes, said it would start service to Heathrow from Seattle and several European cities on April 21, from Los Angeles on May 7 and from Newark on May 18.
The share price of the AMR Corporation, the parent of American Airlines, fell $1.375 yesterday, to $55.875, in New York Stock Exchange trading, while that of the UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines, rose 25 cents, to $146. After the close of trading, underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company priced an offering of 1.5 million UAL shares at $146 each. Pan Am's share price fell 12.5 cents, to $1.125. T.W.A. is privately owned by Mr. Icahn and an employee stock plan.
 
Carrier's Incentive a Concern
 The Transportation Department said that since American would have East Coast gateways from New York, Boston and Miami, it would have little incentive to develop gateways in Philadelphia and Baltimore. The department also said that since American already had service to London from Chicago and Dallas, service from St. Louis "could put it in the position of competing against its Midwest gateway cities."
Mark A. Buckstein, the general counsel of T.W.A., protested that "the disparate treatment to T.W.A., when compared to the favorable treatment afforded to Pan Am, is, to say the least, arbitrary and capricious."
Mr. Buckstein said he was surprised that the department did not intend to allow T.W.A. to keep the Philadelphia and Baltimore routes. Both he and Mr. Carty of American noted that the Philadelphia route now serves Heathrow, but it would presumably be transferred to London's second airport, Gatwick, if a carrier other than American or United were to operate it. British rules allow only two United States carriers to serve Heathrow.

HEADLINE: Critics of New Denver Airport Say Bad Times Demand Halt to Project

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DENVER, March 14

 BODY:
Even as workers are preparing to pour the foundations for a new airport here, the first big airfield in the nation in nearly 20 years, bad times have emboldened critics seeking to halt the project.
New projections of reduced air travel around the country, the coming change in the mayor's office and the bankruptcy of Continental Airlines, one of the leading carriers in Denver, all make the financing of the airport much riskier, a bond-rating company said on Wendesday. 
 The company, Standard & Poor's, lowered its rating on the bonds to BBB-, which is the lowest investment-grade rating, just above the high-risk "junk" category. Denver has already sold about $900 million in bonds. In the past month the price of Denver airport bonds has been falling. That means the city will have to pay higher interest rates to investors buying the bonds.
Worried about the added expense, at least one mayoral candidate has called for a two-year moratorium on construction, saying that economic conditions would improve and enable the project to regain a higher bond rating.
 
$470 Million in Contracts
 "Let's step back and take a look at this thing," said the candidate, Don Bain, a Republican seeking to succeed Mayor Federico Pena, who is not seeking re-election.
But city and state officials have already scaled back plans for the airport in an attempt to reassure investors that the project is financially feasible. The officials said they were pleased that the rating had not dipped below an investment level and said that the $2 billion project would not be detered. Contracts totaling more than $470 million have already been awarded at the airport and the figure is expected to reach about $900 million this summer.
"I think the bond rating is good news," said Gov. Roy Romer. "These are investment grades. It could have gone below BBB-."
He said shelving the project now would be a bit like stopping to look at traffic while crossing the street. "You've got to keep going," he said, "or something's going to hit you."
But the Governor added that he would not oppose a short delay in construction, "certainly less than six months," if a savings could be demonstrated.
 
Changing Conditions
 Mayor Pena said the problems that led to the lower rating, like recession and war, would soon change.
"You don't stop an airport project because of events which are short-lived," said Mr. Pena. "You build a new airport because it's important to the future of the city and the state."
Proponents of a new airport note that the city's current airport, Stapleton International, which is the nation's seventh busiest, does not have adequate space to accommodate all its carriers in bad weather.
"Delays at Stapleton cause delays all over," said Carol Luther, manager of marketing for the new airport. "We're gunking up the works for everybody else."
 
Many Suits at Stapleton
 The new airport site, about 10 miles northeast of Stapleton, is on 34,000 acres of wheat fields. Stapleton, which is flanked by residential neighborhoods and the Rocky Mountain Arsenal, sits on about 4,700 acres. It has been the target of numerous lawsuits over noise and pollution.
Norm Early, a Democrat who is considered to be the front-runner in the campaign for mayor, has been a steadfest supporter of a new airport.
"Stapleton has become an embarrassment," he said. "Moreover, the new airport site would be away from residential neighborhoods."
Workers have already dug the tunnel for rail service between the terminal and three concourses at the airport. And concrete for the foundation is scheduled to be poured soon.
Airline industry analysts, who noted that the Denver project has suffered from the war, recession and reduced air travel, nonetheless said they did not expect the project to be delayed.
"The new Denver airport was planned and designed when Stapleton was a very constrained airport," said Hans Plickert, an investment banker with the Transportation Group Limited in New York. "Both United and Continental have reduced the number of flights in and out of Denver. So the situation is not quite as tight as it was. That does not change the fact that Denver probably needs a new airport."
 
Closings for Weather
 Bad weather has forced the closing of Stapleton only three times in 60 years. But the airport routinely experiences delays in bad weather because of its limited space. Federal regulations require that planes be spaced more widely in bad weather.
More space for runways at the new airport would mean far fewer delays caused by poor weather, airport officials say.
But supporters of the new airport concede that there have been setbacks.
"We need to be dead honest" said Governor Romer. "Some things have changed that we didn't anticipate," he said, referring to the Continental bankruptcy and the Persian Gulf war. "But you don't back off from what you're doing, you're just more wise about how you proceed."

The $2 billion project is to open in 1993 as the nation's largest new airport in almost 20 years. (Eric Bakke for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Administration Yields on Speeding Jobless Benefits

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 14

 BODY:
Under pressure from Congress, the Bush Administration has increased the amount of money that it is willing to spend to shore up the management of the nation's unemployment benefit system and has agreed to exclude that money from caps that Federal budget law imposes on discretionary Government spending.
The effect of the Administration's move, which was made public today in a letter from the White House budget director to Congressional leaders, should be to speed passage of legislation intended to shorten delays in the states' processing of benefits to unemployed workers.
 
House Voted $200 Million
 Those delays have steadily increased in recent months as the unemployment rate climbed to its current level of 6.5 percent. State unemployment offices have beeen overwhelmed by a lack of adequate staff, with the result that some laid-off workers have waited as long as six weeks for their first benefit checks. 
 Although the benefits paid to the unemployed come from state funds, the administrative costs of the nation's unemployment system, including staff salaries, are a Federal responsibility. Last week the House of Representatives voted to supplement by $200 million the $1.98 billion that was initially budgeted to cover that responsibility in the current fiscal year.
The new amount, which would pay for additional staff members and other benefit-processing improvements, equaled what the Senate was expected to approve before adjourning for an Easter recess at the end of the month. But it was twice the amount that the Administration had proposed, and the difference was one factor that threatened to stall the legislation.
But in his letter today, Richard G. Darman, director of the White House Office of Management and Budget, moved closer to Congress's figure, saying the Administration now supported spending $150 million instead of the $100 million it had earlier proposed.
He also said the Administration was prepared to designate these funds as "emergency" money, thus removing another disagreement with Congress and another stumbling block to passage.
Under the Federal budget law passed last fall, any increase in discretionary Government spending must be offset by an equal amount in spending cuts or in tax increases unless the President certifies that the new spending is necessary to meet an emergency. Congressional leaders have refused to raise taxes or cut other spending to pay for the unemployment benefits bill, and until today the Administration had refused to designate the shortage of staff at unemployment offices as an emergency.

HEADLINE: In Coal Country, a Home-Grown Clinic

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: GRETHEL, Ky.

 BODY:
Near the Appalachian village of Harold, Mud Creek divides into Little Mud and Big Mud. From there, Big Mud runs along Route 979, a twisting, shoulderless two-lane road that carries 22-wheel Mack trucks with tarpaulins stretched over immense cargoes of coal. Every square foot of Big Mud's damp banks seems cluttered with trash, like the lungs of many patients at Eula Hall's Mud Creek Clinic, about seven miles along Big Mud.
Mrs. Hall is the founder and de facto boss of the Mud Creek Clinic in the dingy hamlet of Grethel, although her title is simply "social director." A slow-talking, soft-talking woman, she is an example of how a person with modest credentials, modest means and a home-grown vision keeps a distressed community afloat. 
 This is black lung country. And in this remote coal-mining community of junked terrain, junked jobs and junked bodies, Mrs. Hall is a local legend who cuts red tape and badgers bureaucrats. She is social worker, jobs counselor and benefits coordinator for men in their 40's and 50's, many illiterate, who sleep with breathing machines and have heart ailments from straining to breathe and who bring their privation and ailing bodies to the single-story brick command post of one woman's lifelong war on poverty and disease.
Mrs. Hall, 63 years old, is of this soil. She stopped school after completing the eighth grade. Her first husband. whom she divorced and who has since died, was a miner, and her second husband has retired from mining with various ailments. Three of her four sons cannot work because of illnesses and accidents incurred in the mines. She earns $22,000 a year and lives in a cabin that a now-defunct coal company built for miners.
"I was raised poor," Mrs. Hall said, "and I've never gotten above my raisin'."
With the help of charitable contributions and an $800,000 subsidy from the United States Public Health Service, the clinic treats the physical and emotional complaints of about 8,000 patients, handling 50 to 75 a day. The clinic charges patients in line with their incomes. The 53 percent who do not qualify for Medicare or who have incomes below the poverty level but still do not meet Kentucky's standards for Medicaid pay just $5 for a doctor's visit and $4 for a prescription.
The Federal health service supports about 1,500 such clinics for the poor, 60 percent of them in rural areas.
From one room of a trailer behind the clinic, Mrs. Hall also runs the Mud Creek Water District, which she helped organize two decades ago. It pipes potable water to 800 homes, 90 percent of which had contaminated wells when the district was organized in the 1960's. From another room she distributes free food at the end of the month, when people's food stamps run down. From a third room she gives away clothes collected by churches.
Mrs. Hall works from 8 in the morning until 7 or 8 at night, takes no vacations and pays for the gas she uses on her rounds in her four-wheel-drive Chevrolet Suburban, a gift of the Kentucky Department of Human Resources. She ferries medicine, food, clothing and counsel to the housebound and brings them to the clinic, to the hospital and to government offices to apply for health and welfare benefits.
If people reproach her, it is for selflessness in the extreme. "She's a heroic figure," said Dr. Ellen Joyce, who came to Grethel from Watertown, Mass., to spend a decade as the clinic's principal doctor, leaving three years ago when her husband entered law school in Louisville.
 
'Works Till She's Sick'
 "But it's hard to work with a saint sometimes," Dr. Joyce said. "She works till she's sick, which she is, with heart disease and arthritis."
Jim Stewart, executive director of the Big Sandy Health Care Corporation, a nonprofit organization that processes grants for the clinic and manages its accounts and pays its workers, said the staff, however dedicated, drew a line at working Mrs. Hall's hours. "But because of that drive," he said, "people have that clinic. The clinic would not be there if not for her."
Mrs. Hall got the clinic off the ground in 1973 with a private donation of $1,400 and a commitment from two doctors from a nearby hospital to work two days a week. The clinic now has two doctors on the staff of about 10.
Like similar outposts in rural communities and urban ghettos, the Mud Creek clinic lends credence to pressures in Congress to check soaring health care costs and overhaul a national health care system that leaves 30 million to 40 million people uninsured. Mr. Stewart said the clinic's cost has been climbing about 8 percent annually while the Federal subsidy this year is up just 1.5 percent. "Right now our pharmacy is running out of medicine," he said.
Helping men with black lung disease inflates the clinic's costs, both in treating them and in helping them qualify for disability pay. Many tests and procedures are required to prove the presence of this progressive condition in which an accumulation of coal dust ravages the lungs and breathing passages. Miners who can prove that they have the debilitating, sometimes fatal disease, as well as that it incapacitates them and that they contracted it mining coal can tap their former employers, if they can be found, or, if not, the Department of Labor's Black Lung Disability Trust Fund. Either way, monthly benefits range from $387.10 for a miner with no dependents to $774.10 for a miner with three or more.
But nationwide, only 4 percent of the applicants last year qualified, compared with a peak of 48 percent in 1979, when standards were looser. And some have to spend years appealing for the benefits after rejections while the disease keeps wearing them down.
"You have to be near dead to get it," Mrs. Hall said.
Among the patients in Mrs. Hall's clinic one day in February was Omery Compton, 59. He worked for several mining companies for about 12 years, then worked for the state as a heavy equipment operator before being laid off. He was back in the mines in 1980 and 1981, despite evidence of black lung, because other jobs were scarce. His lungs forced him to quit.
 
Rejection Despite Findings
 Mr. Compton was first denied black lung benefits in 1973 and said he had been rejected repeatedly at various levels of the Governmet since, despite the positive findings of eight doctors. "I got a breathing machine now," he said. "I take oxygen on it. They want me to sleep with that oxygen, but you can't."
Roy Lawson came in the same day for painkillers. "I started work at 18 in the coal mines, worked in them 21 years," he said. At 51, he has black lung disease, ulcers, has suffered two heart attacks and lost the fourth and fifth fingers of his left hand in a mine accident.
"Your lungs work on your walking and at night," Mr. Lawson said. "I couldn't walk 500 foot without resting. I sleep on three pillows. I got a breathing machine."
Thanks to Mrs. Hall, Mr. Lawson said he now gets black lung benefits -- $528 a month -- after a 10-year struggle, plus about $224 in workers' compensation insurance benefits. "Eula's my lawyer," he said.
The clinic also has two mental health workers. One, Don Laferty, explains that after retiring from the mines and being freed of the fear of accidents, men here routinely suffer the same post-traumatic stress disorder that afflicted Vietnam veterans. The clinic provides other services as well, like refuges for physically abused wives, which Mrs. Hall once was.
 
She Learned From Congressman
 People here say Mrs. Hall's forte is cutting red tape and badgering bureaucrats. She learned bureaucracy through her Congressman, Carl D. Perkins, a Democrat, who died in 1984 and was succeeded by his son, Carl C. A legend around here, the elder Mr. Perkins was the father of the first black lung legislation in 1969, and he would go to bat for Mrs. Hall in wresting assistance from Federal agencies.
John Rosenberg, head of the Appalachian Research and Defense Fund in the Floyd County seat of Prestonsburg, about 20 minutes north of Grethel, said many Floyd County people are illiterate and intimidated by officialdom, so Mrs. Hall helps them file and negotiate claims for workers' compensation, black lung disability benefits, food stamps and other forms of aid.
Jim Kelly, the Social Security Administration's director for a five-county district of easternmost Kentucky, said she is at least as competent as the lawyers who come to his office representing clients who are seeking Federal benefits. He said she is able to establish the fact that disabled miners are unemployable and have limited education and skills, which is essential to qualifying for disability aid.
 
Idea Formed in Her Youth
 Mrs. Hall said her efforts to help the poor began in her youth. She was the second child and first daughter of the seven surviving children of L.D. and Nanny Elizabeth Riley. The Rileys lived in Pike County, the turf of the Hatfields and McCoys, without electricity, running water or an automoble. She walked to the nearby grade school but did not go to high school because it was several miles away.
"My daddy was a saw logger and a farmer," she said, cutting trees for timber as well as to make furniture. The family's circumstances made Mrs. Hall realize early the importance of health care.
"I saw mommy almost bleed to death when she had a baby because there was no doctor," she said. "I got typhoid fever as a child. I was 11. All of my hair come out from the high temperature. I had a little brother and sister. I always worried because there was no doctor to take them to. My dream from the time I was a child was a health facility where nobody would be turned away."
 
Married at the Age of 17
 At 17, she married a miner. "He brutalized her," Dr. Joyce said. Mrs. Hall divorced him after 33 years and married Oliver Hall, a retired miner who has heart and lung ailments.
Mrs. Hall's small house became her clinic after the first year when it outgrew the original site. She and her husband and her five children moved into a trailer. An arsonist looking for drugs burned the clinic in 1982.
Mrs. Hall's response has become Floyd County folklore. Patients and a doctor, unaware of the fire, arrived the next morning. Mrs. Hall and a doctor set up shop on a picnic table, under a willow tree. They needed a telephone to order prescriptions, so Mrs. Hall called the telephone company and asked for a phone on the tree. Dr. Joyce told the rest of the story this way:
" 'We don't put phones on trees,' they told Mrs. Hall. 'You put them on poles at coal mines,' Mrs. Hall told them. 'You can put a phone on a tree. I got to stay in contact with these people.' She got the phone."
They worked that way for three days. Since school was out for the summer, the school board let her move the clinic into the elementary school. Then the State Department of Health and Human Services bought a second-hand trailer for her, the one that is now the water district office.
 
$400,000 for a New Clinic
 To build a new clinic, she needed $400,000. The Appalachian Regional Commission, a Federal development agency, agreed to put up $320,000 if she raised $80,000. With quilt raffles, radiothons and reaching for donors far beyond Kentucky, she raised $120,000. The new clinic opened in late 1984.
Now that clinic, too, is overtaxed, and so is Mrs. Hall, who has clients parked in her tiny office, with books for children on one wall, waiting to see her for help with their foods stamps, Medicaid, or other government benefits.
Their waits can stretch for hours, particularly when Mrs. Hall gets a call from someone sick or an abused woman, and she darts off to her car. "But they'll wait on me," Mrs. Hall said. Except for emergencies, she said, "They know I don't want to put anybody in front of anybody."

HEADLINE: West Plans 50% Write-Off of Polish Debt

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, March 14

 BODY:
Polish and French officials said today that Western governments would announce on Friday the write-off of a large portion of Poland's $33 billion in official debt in a move aimed at helping Poland's transition to a market economy.
Western officials said around 50 percent of Poland's debt would be forgiven. That is less than the 80 percent write-off Poland had requested, but would still represent one of the largest write-offs that creditor nations have ever allowed a debtor country. 
 Officials from the United States, Canada, Japan and numerous European creditor nations, in a group known as the Paris Club, were meeting today in Paris with Polish officials to make final the details on a debt-reduction package. In recent days, Western officials have said the Paris Club should give Poland more favorable treatment than many other debtor nations because it has been much more courageous in taking painful steps to reform its economy.
The United States has been pressing other nations to forgive almost the whole 80 percent Poland has requested, but Japan, France and Germany have argued for a lower percentage of forgiveness.
Officials said the Paris Club agreement would allow creditor nations several options in reducing Poland's debt burden.
Poland also owes $10.9 billion to commercial banks, and its commercial creditors, led by Barclays Bank, were also in Paris today to discuss whether and to what extent they should lighten Poland's debt load.
Polish officials said the nation's oppressive debt burden was hurting living standards by making it hard to import needed goods at a time when the nation's dismal living standards were being further traumatized by the move to a market economy.
Reuters reported today that Poland had approved a proposed three-year agreement with the International Monetary Fund that is needed to clear the way for the Paris Club write-off. Under the accord, which the IMF will now review for final approval, Poland may receive more than $2 billion over the next three years.
